body_text.text: Continuous progress is being made in the development of 3 T-scanners for clinical application, especially for neuro, cardiac and extremities and MR angiography. Nevertheless, 1.5 T remains the workhorse for clinical MR. A key development is the design of smaller and more open magnets with movement of the patient bed under scanner control, such that the scanning volume can be defined to cover the area of interest up to and including examinations from head to toe. This development is facilitated by progress in RF coil design. Coil arrays with 20-100 and smaller elements allow unprecedented flexibility in optimizing spatial and temporal resolution and volume coverage for any given indication. More robust scanning is facilitated by further developments in computer aided procedures (CAP). Autoalignment of the head and spine allows operator-independent definition of the scanning volume with particular advantages in follow-up examinations. Although the number of clinically used generic measurement sequences (spin echoes, gradient echoes, TSE, EPI, etc.) is modest, there is an ongoing rapidly proliferating zoo of acronyms for sequence modifications, adaptations and optimizations for specific applications. In order to ensure robust and reproducible scanning quality, much effort is placed toward the development of an automated workflow of examination protocols for any specific task. Standardized scanning with well-tested protocols is required to ensure robust diagnostic examinations. On the other hand, ongoing innovation is continuously improving scanning quality. Finding strategies to establish the right balance between these poles is a key challenge for defining the optimized use of MR in clinical diagnosis. CT is presently the most rapidly developing technology in radiology: for the past decade, scanner performance has been doubling every 2 years. The choice of scanner therefore becomes a strategically important decision. This course discusses the differences between the various multidetector CT scanner generations and how these influence their clinical performance. The physical limits of CT scanning will be explored with respect to where we can expect future improvements and where not. Spatial resolution remains a limiting factor for CT: Improvements in resolution require massive increases in patient dose. Patient dose can now be adapted individually but differences between programs can be substantial. Scan duration was a limiting factor for 4-row scanners but has now been reduced to less than 5s for 64-row scanners. Temporal resolution is the main limiting factor for cardiac imaging. Techniques like adaptive multisector reconstruction and dual source scanning will be discussed. The technical requirements for being able to comfortably perform various types of clinical indications will be discussed. Special emphasis will be put on cardiac and perfusion CT applications, for which the choice of scanner becomes most important.
Learning Objectives:

1. To understand the basic differences between the various scanner generations and how these influence their clinical performance. The capability of using short scan times (i.e. within a single breath hold) has contributed fundamentally to the success of CT and CT angiography (CTA). With the introduction of even faster 64-channel CT scanners it became apparent, however, that short scan times also have significant disadvantages: Short contrast medium (CM) injections generally result in lower arterial enhancement and in scan timing becomes less forgiving; one may also tend to outrun the bolus in situations of altered vascular flow dynamics such as in large aneurysms or in patients with peripheral arterial occlusive disease. The ‚key-rules' of early arterial CM dynamics explain the relationship between intravenous CM injection and arterial enhancement: (1) arterial enhancement is proportional to the iodine flux: hence, increasing the injection flow rate and/or increasing the iodine concentration of the CM translates into a proportionally greater arterial opacification; (2) arterial enhancement also increases with increasing the injection duration: hence, arterial opacification can also be improved by prolonging the injecting duration relative to scan time, and by increasing the scanning delay accordingly. Modern CM injection strategies for 64channel CTA take advantage of both the above rules. For example, in abdominal CTA we use the same, fixed scan time (10 s) and the same fixed injection duration (18 s) for all patients. The scanning delay is set to 8 s after CM arrival in the aorta, as determined by automated bolus triggering. Injection flow rates are individualized to a patient's body weight and range from 3.5 to 6 mL/s using high-concentration ( 350 mgI/mL) CM. Learning Objectives:

1. To become familiar with the basic principles of early arterial contrast medium dynamics for CTA. 2. To understand the physiologic constraints of arterial enhancement which become apparent with fast CT scanners. 3. To learn strategies for achieving reliable arterial enhancement and image quality with 64-channel CT.
Diffusion weighted imaging in the assessment of lymph node metastases A. Herneth; Vienna/AT (andreas.herneth@meduniwien.ac.at)

The assessment of possible lymph node metastases is mandatory for accurate tumour staging. Criteria used to differentiate malignant from benign nodes are size and morphology. These macroscopic criteria are unspecific, because inflammatory processes may cause similar transformations and in early metastases size and morphology may still be unchanged. Diffusion weighted imaging (DWI) evaluates microstructural changes of a tissue on a molecular basis. Lymph node metastases present with increased cell density and an increased amounts of intracellular obstacles due to the high energy turnover. These microstructural changes result in a restricted diffusion capacity of water protons, which in turn produce a specific contrast on DWI. T2 shine through and perfusion effects may also contribute to the signals on DWI, which can mimic restricted diffusion and malignancy. These confounding signals can be eliminated by utilizing appropriate diffusion parameters and by quantification of diffusion effects, which can be achieved by calculating the apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC). At our institution, a lymph node with an ADC of less than 1,100 mm²/s is considered to be malignant. In patients with head and neck cancer or lymphoma, DWI yielded similar accuracy in the assessment of lymph node metastases compared to PET. Current results indicate that microstructural tissue changes following chemotherapy can be quantified with the ADC, which may therefore be used for therapy monitoring. Limitations of DWI are the size of the lesion and artefacts. Lesions smaller than 1 cm in diameter cannot be accurately quantified, and susceptibility and motion artefacts restrict the use of DWI to certain anatomical regions. Learning Objectives: 1. To introduce the principle of measuring DTI outside the brain. 2. To explain how changes in perfusion may change the DTI data. 3 . To learn how to differentiate between malignant and benign LN using DTI data.
Perfusion imaging in the assessment of response to anticancer therapy F. Berger; Munich/DE (Frank.Berger@med.uni-muenchen.de)

At initiation, tumors in a pre-vascular phase are supplied by oxygen and nutrients that diffuse from pre-existing normal vessels. When the tumor reaches a critical size of approximately 1-4 mm diameter, the resultant ischemia leads to the secretion of angiogenic factors. These factors, such as vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), recruit and maintain tumor vessels. Both in vitro and in vivo, 'new' vessels (neovasculature) exhibit increased blood volume and permeability compared with normal vessels. Of newer magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) modalities, perfusion MRI has emerged as a unique marker of tumor-induced blood vessels and their function. MRI-based perfusion measures the vascularity within a tumor, as well as its component heterogeneous parts. Of the parameters, which can be measured to date, blood volume and permeability are commonly applied in patient studies. Blood volume measures the aggregate size of the vascular space within designated areas, while the permeability function informs about the integrity of vessels and their 'leakiness' to contrast agents. Various new specific therapies in oncology target tumor vasculature or tumor neoangiogenesis. We will describe the use of MR perfusion to monitor such new therapies. Alternative strategies for treatment

The ankle is the most commonly injured joint. Radiographs of the ankle account for more than 10% of all emergency room radiography and approximately 20% demonstrate a fracture. Plain film imaging should be performed in the initial assessment of ankle disorders to rule out a fracture or calcified loose bodies. In adults, the majority of common ankle sprains are inversion injuries of the lateral ligaments; approximately 10% are syndesmotic injuries. The anterior talofibular ligament (ATF) is most commonly affected. Approximately 20% of ATF ligamentous injuries are associated with a tear of the calcaneofibular ligament. Comparative stress views (inversion and anterior drawer) using a biomechanical device could help to confirm ligamentous injuries when the clinical diagnosis is uncertain. CT (with two-and three-dimensional reconstructions) is needed for preoperative assessment of complex and dislocated ankle fractures. CT (or MR) arthrography is a valuable option for cartilage assessment in the tibiotalar and subtalar joints. MR imaging is not indicated in acute ankle trauma. It is helpful in patients with persistent pain following trauma. It allows direct visualization of the stretched or torn ligaments and offers the advantage of detecting injuries associated with or mimicking ankle instability such as (osteo)chondral lesions, tenosynovitis or tendon injuries. It helps to rule out other painful conditions, such as sinus tarsi syndrome, and posttraumatic complications, such as ankle impingement syndromes or early osteoarthrosis. Learning Objectives: 1. To review the role of imaging in management and surgical planning of traumatic lesions of the ankle. 2. To describe MR imaging findings associated with specific ligamentous injuries. 3. To provide an overview of posttraumatic complications, including impingement syndromes.

Over the last 10 years, much has been written about the technical aspects, safety and efficacy of UAE for symptomatic fibroids. Health-care providers have previously been bemused by the plethora of small and sometimes not so small case series, which often have conflicting results and messages. The publication in 2006 and 2007 of good scientific studies, driven by interventional radiologists, such as REST, EMMY and HOPEFUL, along with the publication of earlier registry data from the USA, has provided realistic evidence-based data on UAE, allowing HCPs to make informed decisions about cost effectiveness. Gynaecologists and interventional radiologists have evidence-based data to inform their patients. Patients can now make informed decisions about their treatment when conservative treatment or medical therapy had failed This should be what this debate is about, not personal views or prejudices, just the evidence and how patients can take advantage of it.
Clinical aspects and treatment options in uterine fibroids W.M. Ankum; Amsterdam/NL (w.m.ankum@amc.uva.nl)

The majority of women with uterine fibroids are asymptomatic and need no treatment at all. The driving force in women seeking medical help for uterine fibroids are predominantly menstrual disorders, mechanical symptoms or both. Gynaecologists use a stepwise approach when managing these women. First of all, uterine and ovarian malignancies should be ruled out, especially when irregular vaginal bleeding or a pelvic mass is present. Secondly, the presence of intra-cavitary fibroids amenable to hysteroscopic surgery should be assessed by transvaginal sonography. If present, hysteroscopic resection provides instant cure at low morbidity and costs. Thirdly, when malignancies and submucous fibroid amenable to hysteroscopic resection have been ruled out, symptomatic relief may be reached by a variety of medical treatment options.Lastly, when conservative measures have failed or are denied by the patient, more rigorous options are available. In women desiring pregnancy, myomectomy is the obvious choice. In those women not desiring future pregnancy, hysterectomy provides a definite solution for fibroid-related menorrhagia or bulkrelated symptoms. Uterine artery embolisation (UAE) may be offered as a less invasive alternative to surgery, but may fail in up to 20-25% of patients. UAE should be restricted to women without a desire for pregnancy, since UAE will compromise both uterine and ovarian vasculature. In these women, further studies are needed before UAE can be offered without concern. Learning Objectives: 1. To recognise how and when to use medical therapy for fibroids. 2. To understand the indications and contraindications of surgery for fibroids. 3 . To appreciate which patients require treatment and which don't. 4. To review how all these options compare, medically and economically.
Technique and results J.-P. Pelage; Boulogne/FR (jean-pierre.pelage@apr.ap-hop-paris.fr)

Radiologists performing uterine fibroid embolisation should also be familiar with the different techniques available. Recent technical improvements may influence the outcome from therapy and reduce complication rates. The method of uterine fibroid embolisation has been extensively described in the literature. In essence it involves the placement of a catheter into the uterine arteries and injection of embolisation particles into the uterine arteries to obtain fibroid infarction. Non spherical Polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) particles were the first embolization agents used for uterine fibroid embolisation. Spherical embolisation particles, such as tris-acryl microspheres and PVA spheres have been developed to address some of the disadvantages of non-spherical particles such as the unpredictable level of arterial occlusion and clumping. In most of the recent studies, a limited uterine artery embolization technique has been used. Calibrated microspheres larger than 500 or 700 μm in diameter injected using microcatheters are currently recommended. With an appropriate patient selection and optimized technique, good clinical outcomes can be achieved. The clinical success rate ranges between 80 and 95% for both control of menorrhagia and bulk-related symptoms at 3-6 months. In the long-term, the clinical recurrence rate seems higher than initially expected with up to 20% of patients becoming symptomatic after 2-5 years. Recurrence seems to be related to either insufficient fibroid infarction after embolization or to growth of new fibroids. MRI with contrast administration may play a role in evaluating the subgroup of patients with recurrent symptoms. It is really surprising that some women want to preserve their genital organs in the face of benign disease. Even the German Highest Social Court has ruled "preservation of the uterus is an understandable concern". However, overuse of hysterectomy is an undeniable fact. The German Federal Office for Quality published that 130,000 hysterectomies were performed for benign disease in 2005, conditions for which there are other treatments such as UFE. Further motivations for wanting UFE are bad experiences with gynaecological surgery, a fear of general anaesthetic, ease in the transition of being childless ("I still have my uterus, I could if I really wanted "), desire to resume activities quickly without restrictions on lifting! How can a mother of a 3-year old avoid heavy lifting? Prior to UFE, however, women need to understand that the goal is to relieve symptoms and not the degree of fibroid shrinkage. Women also need to realise that it may take a few months for the treatment to become effective. They will need understanding and support during this time. UFE is successful in 80-90% of cases. However, it may fail to relieve symptoms that have unrecognised causes such as adenomyosis, endometriosis, adhesions, von Willebrand disease or hormone imbalances. Treatment failures often get little under-gray matter structures, hyperattenuating arteries, and mass effect. Loss of gray-white interface definition or insular ribbon sign reflects cytotoxic edema and relates to specificity of arterial anatomy. Disappearing basal ganglia sign is caused by MCA occlusion proximally to lenticulostriate arteries. Early mass effect includes narrowing of sylvian fissure or loss of cortical sulci. Hyperdense artery sign represents stasis of flow due to arterial thrombus; most frequently seen in MCA. Hyperattenuating artery sign correlates positively with angiographic finding of occlusion. CTA is essential for evaluating intra-and extracranial vessels, intravascular thrombi, and trombolytic therapy guiding. Visibility of infarcts can be improved by setting of variable window width and center levels to accent the gray-white matter contrast. CTA source images are more sensitive, compared with nonenhanced-CT, in early detection zones of ischemia and prediction of final infarct volume. Conventional MRI include T1 SE, T2 FSE, FLAIR, T2* GE, and contrast-enhanced T1 SE. Findings in acute stroke are hyperintense zones on T2 FSE and FLAIR; sulcal effacement, mass effect; loss of arterial flow voids on T2 FSE; intravascular hyperintensity on FLAIR, stasis of contrast media within vessels in affected territories; abnormal blooming and parenchymal black dots due to hemorrhage on T2* GE. DWI is the most sensitive tool for detection of hyperacute stroke in the first 6 hours. DWI signal alone cannot be used for a correct estimate of the infarct age; it is important to examine DWI in comparison with ADC maps. Learning Objectives: 1. To describe the early signs of cerebral infarction on CT. 2. To describe the early signs of brain infarction on conventional MRI. 3 . To learn the importance of diffusion-weighted imaging in the early detection of stroke.

Even though the spatial resolution of CTA has improved, its diagnostic capability is restricted by artifacts related to cone beam hardening, blooming from calcium and stents, and rotational derived distortions. There are also problems with dose reduction and optimization of scanning. MRA is contraindicated in patients with pacemakers. Blooming artifacts can distort the region surrounding a ferromagnetic metal, while non-ferromagnetic metals (nitinol) may create signal voids, which also affect the image quality. Catheter-based angiography remains the gold standard in several emergency cases, as it offers the advantage of concurrent endovascular treatment. Among those are acute severe limb ischemia with neuromotoric symptoms requiring rapid catheter-directed thrombolysis or thrombectomy to minimize the risk of limb loss, and visceral bleeding requiring urgent embolization. Carbon dioxide represents an alternative contrast medium in catheter-based angiography. Indications for CO 2 include iodinated contrast allergy, renal insufficiency, arterial bleeding, TIPS, central venous evaluation and procedures requiring a high volume of contrast. Precautions should be taken to avoid contamination, explosive delivery and gas trapping in vessels. Arterial injections above the diaphragm should be avoided and CO 2 should never been administered with the patient's head in an elevated position. Gadolinium chelates are also indicated in patients considered to be at increased risk of nephropathy. The major limitation of gadolinium-based angiography is poor radiographic density, which can be significantly improved by the addition of small quantities of iodinated contrast to gadolinium. The basic components of speech recognition systems (SRS) are the acoustic and the language model. The first provides statistical information on speaker-dependent variability of phoneme pronunciation, the latter contains empirically gathered probabilities of triplet word combinations. Requirements for sufficient performance of SRS within a multiuser PACS/RIS environment are a client-server architecture, a robust institution network and a high-end PACS/RIS hardware infrastructure. The client workstation is linked to the SR server and employs individual, continuously updated voice profiles and the radiological context vocabulary. Department-wide integration of the SR application is important for correct attribution and timely and continuous generation of reports. Two operation modes of SRS can be used in a clinical setting: 1. Offline (batch) SR with transfer of the dictation to the SR server for subsequent processing. The preliminary report is corrected by a transcriptionist and finally proofread and authorized by the radiologist. 2. Online SR with realtime processing of the dictation and instant report correction, proofreading and authorization by the radiologist in one step. Offline SR can only be implemented given a preexisting transcription service and is comparable to conventional tape dictation regarding the radiologist´s time effort. Online SR can decrease the report turnaround times significantly, but also reduces the radiologist's productivity due to the correction effort, and lead to clinically relevant homonym and non-sense errors. State-of-the-art continuous SRS are characterized by recognition rates between 90 and 97% and extensive context vocabularies. Depending on the product, frequent update of the individual or common context vocabulary is critical for maintaining recognition accuracy. Learning Objectives: 1. To be familiar with the principles of the computer basics behind the application. 2. To understand and be able to critically appraise the potential clinical applications.

Combined transabdominal and transvaginal US is the study of choice for the initial evaluation of the female pelvis. MRI typically follows US as a problem-solving modality. It helps differentiate benign processes that necessitate specific therapy from those that can be managed expectantly. MR is the imaging modality of choice for staging and treatment follow-up of uterine malignancies. CT has no role in the detection and characterization of pelvic tumours; however, it is the modality of choice for staging ovarian cancer. CT is also very useful in the detection of post-operative complications, and both CT and US are excellent for image-guided interventions. PET/CT is particularly useful in the detection of lymph node metastases and in assessing patient suitability for salvage therapy, as it can provide precise re-staging information. It is crucial to be familiar with normal anatomical and physiological imaging appearances of the uterus and ovaries in order to avoid potential pitfalls and maximize the accuracy. Endometrial thickness and appearances of the endometrium, myometrium and ovaries change with the phase of menstrual cycle, menopausal state and use of oral contraceptives (OC) or hormone replacement therapy. For example, in patients on OC, the endometrium may become atrophic and the myometrium may appear swollen and globular on both US and MRI. Uterine cervix appears of lower attenuation than uterine corpus on early contrastenhanced CT and should not be confused with cervical pathology. On PET/CT, premenopausal endometrial FDG uptake changes cyclically, increasing during ovulatory and menstrual phases. Similarly, premenopausal ovarian FDG uptake may be functional due to the presence of corpus luteum cysts. Infertility is defined as the inability to conceive after 1 year of intercourse without contraception. However, in women age 35 and older, the work-up for infertility can begin 6 months after an inability to conceive. Infertility may be secondary to male and/or female factors. This lecture will focus on those imaging examinations that assess the uterus and fallopian tube. The classic imaging test is hysterosalpingography (HSG), but ultrasound, sonohysterography, and MR may all play a role in the imaging assessment. HSG is used to assess uterine contour abnormalities, appearance of the fallopian tube and free spill. HSG should be performed during the period between the cessation of menses and ovulation. Tubal flushing during HSG increases the likelihood of pregnancy compared to no intervention. Abnormalities of the uterine contour associated with infertility include uterine leiomyomata, Müllerian anomalies (in particular septate uterus) and endometrial abnormalities such as polyps and synechiae. Sonohysterography can be used for diagnosis and hysteroscopic resection for treatment. Structural defects in the fallopian tubes that cause obstruction or disrupt motility are the cause of infertility in 25-40% of women. The major cause of tubal infertility is pelvic inflammatory disease. In women with proximal tubal obstruction on HSG, selective salpingography with tubal catheterization can be offered. Patients with distal tubal obstruction may develop hydrosalpinges, which decrease the success rate of in vitro fertilization (IVF). Removal of the hydrosalpinges increases the success of IVF. Distal tubal disease caused by pelvic adhesions is diagnosed by visualizing loculated spill on HSG and surgical treatment improves fertility. Learning Objectives:

1. To understand the roles of HSG, US, and MR imaging techniques in the evaluation of uterine anomalies and tubal pathology. Ultrasound is the imaging modality of choice for the initial evaluation of benign uterine disease. However, in patients whose sonographic findings are indeterminate or inconclusive, MR imaging can play an important role as a problem-solving modality.

Benign endometrial pathology such as polyps, hyperplasia and the pre-menstrual endometrium have a specific appearance on dynamic contrast-enhanced MR imaging sequences. MR imaging can help to differente the cause of abnormal uterine bleeding in patients where sonography cannot distinguish between leiomyomas and uterine adenomyosis. This is particulary important since leiomyomas can be treated medically or by a number of uterine sparing therapies, while deep adenomyosis is treated by hysterectomy. In addition, MR imaging helps in precise delineation of leiomyomas and their position with respect to the endometrial cavity, thus allowing optimal preoperative planning (open procedure myomectomy versus hysteroscopic removal). Dynamic MR imaging allows confident distinction between junctional zone thickening due to adenomyosis versus transient thickening caused by uterine peristaltism. MR imaging is useful in the pre-and post-procedural evaluations of patients undergoing uterine artery embolization (UAE) for symptomatic uterine leiomyomas. Relative contraindications to this procedure include pelvic malignancy, desired future fertility, adenomyosis and pedunculated leiomyomas. Although adenomyosis is considered a relative contraindication, most advocate treatment if adenomyosis and leiomyomas co-exist. Fibroids with hemorrhagic degeneration have loss of vascular supply and therefore show poor response to UAE. Molecular Imaging (MI) is a diversifying research discipline that focusses on establishing imaging tools to non-invasively visualize key targets in disease processes. While traditional imaging research is primarily driven by engineering and physics, MI is additionaly highly influenced by molecular biology and chemistry. Experimentally a wide variety of imaging tools have been developed over the past years. Some of these techniques are increasingly becoming standard research tools for basic scientists. Moreover, MI has become a mainstay for pre-clincal drug development. However, clincal translation of MI technologies is another important goal of the MI community and finally first imaging techniques are entering the clinical arena mainly driven by the recent advances in PET imaging. A major motivation of pushing MI tools into patient care is the prospect of an early, sensitive and specific diagnosis of disease and precise monitoring of treatment response. Molecular imaging is a relatively young field that is rapidly changing our approach towards understanding and solving problems in in vivo diagnoses with innovative solutions. The development of high sensitive, targeting and responsive agents is a major challenge to enhance the role of MRI in the field of Molecular Imaging applications. Understanding the relationships between structure/dynamics and paramagnetic relaxation processes has been fundamental for the development of high sensitive Gd (III) based agents. The need of targeting molecules that are present at very low concentration requires the development of novel classes of contrast agents characterized by higher contrasting ability and improved targeting capabilities. Efficient targeting procedures for cellular labeling and recognition of epitopes characterizing important pathologies have been set up. As far as the delivery of a large number of Gd-complexes at the targeting sites is concerned, several systems are currently under intense scrutiny, including dendrimers, liposomes and other form of lipophilic aggregates. Finally, much attention is currently devoted to CEST agents that represent an emerging class of MRI contrast media of huge potential. They act as negative agents by reducing the signal intensity of water protons through saturation transfer mediated by chemical exchange. The great potential of CEST agents lies on the possibility of switching on and off the contrast at will, making possible the detection of more agents, each uniquely characterized by the specific frequency of their mobile protons. Marked sensitivity improvements have been obtained by using as source of mobile protons the water molecules contained in the inner cavity of liposomes, properly shifted by the addition of a shift reagent. New stem cell based therapies require the assessment of cell homing and engraftment in the host organ. MR imaging is well suited to track transplanted stem cells in vivo, after the cells have been labeled with MR contrast agents. Basic principles, capabilities and limitations of various labeling techniques will be presented in this lecture. Virtually any cell type can be labeled with MR contrast agents. Labeling techniques comprise simple incubation, receptor-mediated uptake, transfection and electroporation. Cells can be labeled with positive or negative MR contrast agents and can be subsequently depicted with clinical MR scanners. Each labeling procedure has to be tailored to the investigated cell type, target organ and application. Adanvatages and disadvantages of MR-based cell tracking techniques will be compared with alternative optical or radiotracer-based techniques. More recent research concentrates on functional aspects of the transplanted cells, such as their viability, differentiation capacity and long-term residence in the target organ. These functional aspects are essential for a successful stem cell-based tissue regeneration. Capabilities and limitations of MR to depict these functional properties of the cells will be reviewed. In conclusion, MR contrast agents can be used for labeling and in vivo tracking of various cell types with clinical MR scanners. The ability to trace the in vivo cell distribution with non-invasive imaging techniques may improve our understanding of how stem cells mediate recovery of injured organs and may be ultimately applied clinically for safety assessments of transplantation procedures. The diagnosis of airway disease is challenging to the clinician as it has no specific clinical or functional features. Chest radiography shows highly variable radiographic abnormalities and considerable interobserver and intraobserver variability. HRCT has become the best imaging modality for the assessment of the airways and is nowadays the radiological method of choice for investigating a patient suspected of airway disease. Volumetric HRCT of the entire lung combining end inspiratory, end expiratory, and dynamic expiratory acquisitions demonstrates localized functional information. The addition of postprocessing techniques such as maximum intensity projection, minimum intensity projection, and multiplanar reformations enhances the diagnostic capabilities of CT in showing characteristic findings of airway diseases. Moreover, volumetric HRCT assesses the extent and severity of disease. It may be repeated for assessing the response to therapy and often avoid the need for histological evaluations. Learning Objectives:

1. To review the advantages of VHRCT for the diagnosis and characterisation of bronchial abnormalities. Although there are differences in the prevalence of specific histopathological patterns, the spectrum of lung pathology seen in the CVDs is relatively limited and, to a certain extent, mirrors that seen in the idiopathic interstitial pneumonias. Thus, the patterns of usual interstitial pneumonia (most commonly encountered in RhA), non-specific interstitial pneumonia (now known to be the most prevalent histopathological pattern of lung disease in SSc and PM/DM), organizing pneumonia (typically associated with PM/DM, but also RhA) and lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (a feature of lung disease in SS and RhA) all occur in CVDs. The histopathological evaluation of CTD-related lung disease can be difficult and is compounded by the different patterns of interstitial lung disease, which may coexist. To complicate matters further, airway disease (which has been reported in RhA and SS) is also reasonably common and might occur simultaneoulsy with fibrotic lung disease. Plain chest radiography, pulmonary function tests and high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) are the standard non-invasive tests used to evaluate these patients. In this presentation, the imaging features of the CVDs will be discussed. Where relevant, the relationships between the histopathological changes and imaging features will be emphasized. The liver provides excellent soil in which metastases can establish, thus it is the second most commonly involved organ of metastatic disease from virtually any primary malignant neoplasm. Hepatic involvement of metastatic tumor and the duration of survival are considered to be inversely related; nevertheless, the available therapeutic arsenal becomes more and more effective, and thus information regarding the presence, number and localization of liver metastases may greatly influence therapeutic decisions and outcome of the disease. However effective the clinical and laboratory tests may be, the final diagnosis of hepatic involvement is based on results of imaging procedures. The list of modalities available for this purpose includes transabdominal and intraoperative ultrasound (US), computed tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), angiography, image-guided biopsy and different methods of nuclear medicine. Detectability, appearance and characterization of liver metastases depend on the site of origin, tumor characteristics, and size and localization of lesions. The usual diagnostic algorithm is based on routine ultrasound and multiphase CT examination, but the clinical situation may require more accurate evaluation by contrast-enhanced US, CT arterio-portography or cell-specific contrast-enhanced MRI examination. Proper knowledge of the efficiency of these methods is indispensable for finding the most effective diagnostic algorithm for each individual patient. Learning Objectives: 1. To emphasise significance of liver metastasis detection in staging and therapy planning of malignancies. 2. To define examination technique, role and accuracy of different imaging modalities. 3 . To evaluate the place of different cell-specific MR contrast materials in the diagnostic process.

A-040 09:00 B. Primary malignancies in the non-cirrhotic liver T.K. Helmberger; Munich/DE (thomas.helmberger@kh-bogenhausen. de) In comparison to metastases and hepatocellular carcinomas in cirrhotic livers, primary malignant hepatic tumours without cirrhosis are less common. About 10-40 % of all HCC may occur in the non-cirrhotic liver, whereas the imaging features compare HCC in the cirrhotic liver (hypervascularization, necrosis/heterogeneity in large tumours, fibrous capsule, fatty metamorphosis, calcifications). Fibrolamellar HCC, a tumour in young adults, distinct from HCC regarding origin, differentiation and prognosis, is characterized by lamellar fibrous strands, a fibrous central scar, calcifications and heterogenous enhancement. Less common tumours arising from the cholangiocellular cell line are represented by the intrahepatic (peripheral) and the extrahepatic (ductal) cholangiocarcinoma (Klatskin tumour). Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinomas (CC), accounting for about 10% of all primary hepatic malignancies, arise from the biliary ductal epithelium in the hepatic periphery often mimicking metastases with respect to imaging findings. Unlike intrahepatic CC, extrahepatic CC often cause biliary obstruction, while the tumour itself is frequently not displayed. In contrast, biliary cystadenocarcinomas appear as uni-or multilocular cystic masses, whereas peripheral nodular and septal enhancement may represent malignant components of these tumours. Angiosarcoma, a rare tumour deriving from endothelial cells, has a strong association with the exposure to toxic agents. In these solitary or diffuse occurring tumours, imaging is unspecific with heterogenous appearance pre-and post-contrast on CT and MRI. Other rare tumours are epithelioid haemangioendothelioma and lymphoma of the liver, which present in most cases no specific features, whereas the differential is more triggered by the clinical context. Learning Objectives: 1. To present demographic and pathologic background of primary malignant lesions in the non-cirrhotic liver. 2. To describe typical imaging findings in radiological imaging modalities of this lesions. 3. To define clinically focused, diagnostic strategies or the assessment of these lesions.
C. Primary malignancies in the cirrhotic liver G. Brancatelli; Palermo/IT (gbranca@yahoo.com)

Hepatocarcinogenesis represents a progressive process in which regenerative hepatocytes give rise to hyperplastic hepatocyte nodules, and these progress to dysplastic nodules, which are thought to be the direct precursor of hepatocellular carcinoma. Distinction among regenerative nodules, dysplastic nodules, and hepatocellular carcinoma with varying degrees of differentiation requires an assessment of the hemodynamic nature of the mass. As with regenerative nodules, dysplastic nodules receive predominantly portal venous flow and do not usually demonstrate bright enhancement on arterial phase after rapid bolus injection of intravenous contrast at cross-sectional imaging. As the degree of (de-differentiation) malignancy increases, portal blood supply decreases, whereas nontriadal arteries (i.e., unaccompanied by portal venules and biliary ducts) and aberrant capillaries (a process known as "capillarization") develop to feed the nodules. When trying to characterise nodules developing in cirrhosis at cross-sectional imaging, marked arterial phase enhancement with rapid washout during the portal venous and delayed phase should be regarded as highly suspicious for the presence of hepatocellular carcinoma, but there is much overlap in imaging features among regenerative nodules, dysplastic nodules and well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma. Ophthalmologists accept ocular MRI if the radiologist is 1) aware of diagnostic problems and 2) knows about the advantages and limits of ocular ultrasound. The presentation will explain the use of surface coils to obtain high-resolution MR images of the eye. Techniques like DW-MRI are demonstrated. MR and clinical images will exemplify differential diagnosis and staging of ocular melanoma, retinoblastoma, metastasis, hemangioma and foreign bodies. Melanoma is the entity found most often; correlation between melanin content and signal on T1-WI is demonstrated, as well as enhancement and signs of retrobulbar extension. Leukokoria is the clinical sign of retinoblastoma. Retinoblastoma may be exophytic or endophytic. As both eyes and the brain have to be imaged, MR is usually performed with general anesthesia. Calcification is the defining feature seen on ocular CT. Coats disease is a differential diagnosis and may be differentiated by missing mass. Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous is characterized by micophthalmos, an enhancing mass and layered hemorrhage. Hemangioma is an important differential diagnosis of ocular metastases. It is characterized by high signal on T2-WI. Foreign bodies may lead to hard-to-control inflammation and every attempt to verify their location is usually deemed justified. A brief excurs treats ocular findings not to be missed on standard head CT. These include hemorrhage in trauma CT, ocular prostheses and foreign bodies. The extraocular orbit can be affected by pathological conditions derived not only from the globe. Orbital compartment anatomy and extraorbital anatomy should be considered to establish the origin of pathology and for a correct diagnosis. Imaging of the orbital structures is performed with CT and/or MRI, either with or without iv contrast material. CT should be used in cases of foreign bodies and MRI should not be performed. The orbital spaces contain the lacrimal glands, the extraconal, conal and intraconal region, the bulb and the retrobulbar area with the optic nerve. The bony walls of the orbit are those of the paranasal sinuses and the anterior skull base. The posterior part is in close proximity to the parasellar regions. The pathology affecting the orbit may originate from intraorbital regions or may use vascular or neural structures as a "road" to infiltrate the orbit. The pathologic entities may range from benign to malignant structures. Especially, inflammatory extraocular pathology can reach the orbit and its components by direct invasion through the walls or by the vessels and then yield to intraorbital inflammatory processes with potential thrombosis of the orbital vein and cavernous sinus. Malignant processes may originate from the intraorbital structures or infiltrate the orbit directly by destructing the bony walls or by nerval or vascular structures. In this course, the anatomic situation, the different benign and malignant pathologies, and the traumatic entities affecting the extraocular orbit will be demonstrated. Of the six external ocular muscles, the superior oblique muscle is supplied by the trochlear nerve (N IV), the lateral rectus by the abducent nerve (N VI), and all other external muscles by the oculomotor nerve (N III). All of these cranial nerves have their nuclei situated in the brainstem, have an interpeduncular or prepontine cisternal course, and run through the cavernous sinus and the superior orbital fissure. The abducent nerve has a long cisternal course making it extra vulnerable. In its cisternal course, the oculomotor nerve runs very close to the circle of Willis, making it vulnerable to aneurysmal disease. When a patient with diplopia undergoes an MRI examination, an extended study is recommended to visualize the brain, brainstem, and the central skull base. A wide variety of lesions can be seen at different locations, such as the brain (demyelinating disease, ischemia, etc.), the brainstem (ischemia, etc.), cisterns (meningioma, infectious disease, carcinomatous meningitis, neurogenic tumor, etc.), cavernous sinus and superior orbital fissure (neoplastic disease, neurogenic tumor, vascular disease, etc.). Besides specific sequences used in younger (FLAIR) and older patients (DWI), such an examination always consists of T2WI of the brain and brainstem, and T1WI covering the course of the III, IV, and VI cranial nerves. After gadolinium injection, the T1WI are repeated. In case of oculomotor nerve disease, performing an MRA of the circle of Willis is mandatory. Shunt stenosis is frequently detected in native fistulas, which should undergo balloon angioplatsy as first-line treatment in order to keep the shunt running. In implant shunts, stenosis frequently leads to complete thrombosis if not deteteced early by careful watching of either dialysis parameters, ultrasound or recirculation measurements. In-time intervention in grafts prevents deterioration into complte occlusion, which is more difficult to treat as also in upper arm fistulas. Shunt thrombosis is less common in native fistulas. Both may undergo mechanical recanalization without thrombolysis. While in native fistulas, simple balloon angioplasty is a very useful tool for short segment thrombosis, extensive thrombosis in native veins or grafts requires use of different mechanical devices or aspiration catheters. In venous access thrombosis, thrombolysis and fibrinous sheath stripping are the percutanous options. Congenital vascular malformations (CVM) are infrequently encountered in everyday practice and, to date, numerous misconceptions and a confusing nomenclature in relation to them remain. Vascular malformations, as opposed to hemangiomas, are not neoplastic, always present at birth and show neither endothelial proliferation nor growth on tissue cultures. Approximately, two-thirds of the malformations are of venous predominance, either isolated or sometimes associated with complex congenital syndromes. The pathogenesis of CVM remains incompletely understood. Most often, isolated anomalies exist and they are rarely genetically transmitted. Venous malformations usually manifest in childhood or early adulthood, growing commensurately with the individual and, unlike hemangiomas, do not regress. They can expand in response to trauma or altered hormonal states, or following incomplete surgical resection, thrombosis or sepsis. Their clinical presentation is variable depending on their size, location and secondary complications, such as haemorrhage and ulceration. Most of the venous malformations are asymptomatic and should be managed conservatively. Surgical resection is often contraindicated as complete excision is difficult or impossible, particularly when the malformation is diffuse, shows deep involvement or is located in the head, neck and extremities. Laser therapy has a minimal role for very small superficial lesions. The mainstay of treatment is sclerotherapy, which does not suffer from any of these limitations and has become particularly safe and effective with the use of foam sclerosants. New approaches to therapy will develop as more knowledge in connection with the pathogenesis and angiogenesis drugs is gathered. Colorectal cancer is an important health problem. Nearly one million new cases of colorectal cancer have been diagnosed worldwide each year and there have been half-a-million deaths. Metallic stent placement is a reasonable alternative that can provide an effective, non-surgical decompression of the obstructed left-sided colon to avoid an emergency colostomy. Main indications for endoluminal metallic stent placement in the colon and rectum are: 1. for temporary colonic decompression in patients with acute malignancy obstruction as a "bridge to elective surgery"; 2. for long-term colonic decompression in patients with large-bowel obstruction due an unresectable colonic carcinoma; 3. for long-term colonic decompression in patients with large-bowel benign strictures due a fibrosis post surgery or post radiotherapy; 4. as palliative treatment for close coloenteric or colovesical fistulae. Stent deployment in colon can be achieved under fluoroscopy guidance alone, under colonoscopy guidance alone and combined (fluoroscopy and colonoscopy). Lesser complications of stent placement are common to many reports. More severe, life-threatening complications are described, however, including death. The technical success in deploying stents with fluoroscopic, endoscopic or combined guidance has ranged from 88 to 100%. Clinical or medical success, improvement of obstructive symptoms, has been reported in 80-92%. Radiation exposure is a very important problem for the patient and for the operator when the procedure its carried out with fluoroscopic guidance. Saving of up to 20% for presurgery stent placement versus surgical management has been reported. The decreases in the cost were attributed mainly to the shorter hospital stay. Endoscopy is the first-line invasive treatment for GI tract bleeding, but interventional radiology is indicated in 5-10% of patients whenever endoscopy fails. Embolization has always been the preferred interventional radiological treatment for upper gastrointestinal (UGI) tract bleeding, while vasopressin infusion was in the past indicated for lower gastrointestinal (LGI) tract bleeding. However, since the early 90s, embolization has been favored for LGI tract hemorrhage also. Findings of angiography include contrast extravasation, pseudoaneurysm, arteriovenous malformation, angiodysplasias or hyperemia. Embolization should be performed as selectively as possible, especially for LGI bleeding, with microcatheter technique; the materials include microcoils, polyvinyl alcohol particles and glue. Control of hemorrhage is achieved in 90-100% of LGI bleeding, and in 70-92% of UGI bleeding (richer collateral supply in the UGI tract). Rebleeding occurs in 20-30%. Intestinal ischemia is reported in 0-70% of patients for LGI embolization, although it is usually asymptomatic. Ischemic complications after UGI embolization are less frequent. CT is currently the most important emerging non-invasive modality for the assessment of the heart and coronary arteries. Most of the requirements for a proper Cardiac CT examination concern the adequate design of the protocol and a good knowledge of normal and abnormal cardiac and coronary anatomy. The implementation of newer technologies every year requires constant update and optimization of Cardiac CT protocols. Also, the differences between different vendors' equipments require some adjustments in protocols. Parameters such as slice thickness, pitch, mAs, kV, reconstruction increment, temporal window of reconstruction play complementary roles in achieving adequate image quality. Contrast material administration is a key part of the Cardiac CT scan. In this phase of the examination, patients' preparation is a very important issue. The use of negative cronotropic drugs is delicate but very important and effective in improving image quality and in reducing evaluation and post-processing time. Cardiac anatomy is also very important since normal, variants, and anomalies are extremely frequent in different configurations. Many cardiac conditions are associated with typical anatomical landmarks. These features should be part of the basic knowledge of cardiac radiologists. The advent of multi-detector row CT scanners with subsecond gantry rotation time and high isotropic spatial resolution, together with acquisition of data synchronized to the ECG has allowed the visualization of coronary arteries with a high diagnostic quality. The same date set, however, also contains huge amounts of information regarding the myocardium, atrial and ventricular size and function, as well as cardiac valves. In the past years, evidence has accumulated to indicate that CT allows the assessment of ventricular size and function with a similar accuracy as compared to the current standard of reference magnetic resonance imaging. Moreover, a number of recent studies have indicated that multi-detector row CT allows not only the morphological but also the functional evaluation of cardiac valves with comparable results as compared to the current clinical reference modality echocardiography. Finally, recent evidence has accumulated to indicate that viability assessment of myocardium with CT has become feasible with a similar accuracy as compared to MRI. When ECG-gated imaging protocols are modified to cover the whole thoracic cavity and aim at a simultaneous opacification of coronary arteries, thoracic aorta, and pulmonary arteries, CT enables in evaluating patients with acute chest pain by diagnosing or excluding aortic dissection or rupture, significant coronary stenoses, and pulmonary embolism. Particularly, most recently introduced dual-source CT scanners with a high and heart rate-independent temporal resolution have opened the field for routine application of such CT protocols to the emergency patient, because heart rate control prior to cardiac CT is no longer necessary. It is known for years that radiotherapy is useful in the treatment of hepatic neoplasms. The problem, however, is that if therapeutic doses were applied, there would be major damage of the non-tumoral liver tissue. Research with new materials has produced spherical embolic particles, of any size, that may provoke a wide variety of interactions (even none) with the embolized vessel wall and the surrounding tissue. They can be safely loaded with many substances. The anatomical basis for performing endovascular treatments to liver tumors is the well-known fact that they are, almost exclusively, fed by arterial vessels. With the new developments in microcatheters and guidewires, a superselective placement of particles in the afferent arteries can be technically done in most cases. Taking advantage of the three points mentioned above (radiotherapy, particles and catheters), it has been possible to perform a novel method to treat liver tumors, which consists of intra-arterial, selective application of therapeutic dossages of radiation. This procedure, defined as "liver radioembolization (RE)", is based on the deployment of small (30 μ), inert particles loaded with Yttrium 90. Y90 is a pure -emisor with a half-life of 64 h and a maximun tissue penetration of 11 mm (mean 2.5 mm). Clinical implantation of RE requires a multidisciplinary approach among different specialties, and radiologists are in a relevant position, not only for the diagnosis, staging and follow-up of the tumors, but also because interventionalists play a major role in the therapeutic planning and deployment of the treatment. With the widespread acceptance of uterine fibroid embolization offered in most European countries, new issues and questions have been recently raised. The published experience demonstrates that embolization is very effective in treating menorrhagia (success rate 80-95%), bulk-related symptoms (success rate 85-90%) and pelvic pain. Uterine volume reduction and fibroid shrinkage range between 30-50% and 40-60%, respectively. The patient's satisfaction is high and the hospital stay very short compared to surgery. Recent randomized studies comparing mainly embolization to hysterectomy have demonstrated that embolization compares favourably to abdominal hysterectomy in terms of quality of life, length of recovery and cost. Conversely, minor complications and rates of re-interventions are higher in women treated with embolization. Training of interventional radiologists and optimized patient selection with both gynecologists and radiologists involved may help reduce these side-effects of embolization. In the long-term, the clinical recurrence rate after embolization (i.e. need for additional procedures such as repeat embolization, myomectomy or hysterectomy) seems higher than initially expected with up to 20% of patients becoming symptomatic after 2-5 years. Recurrence seems to be related to either insufficient fibroid infarction after embolization or to growth of new fibroids. MRI with contrast administration may play a role in evaluating the subgroup of patients with recurrent symptoms. Similarly, little data regarding fertility after embolization or embolization in infertile patients is available to date. Large multicenter studies should therefore be conducted to confirm that embolization is a valuable alternative to myomectomy. Learning Objectives: 1. To describe the main anatomical and technical considerations relevant to uterine fibroid embolisation. 2. To be familiar with indications and contraindications of uterine fibroid embolisation with special emphasis on fertility. 3. To recognise complications associated with uterine fibroid embolisation and apply prevention and management options. 4. To understand respective indications for medical treatment, hysterectomy, myomectomy and uterine fibroid embolisation in women with symptomatic uterine fibroids.

In this interactive lecture, several neuro-radiological imaging signs, illustrated with cases, will be discussed not only with respect to their classic appearance, but also with respect to their reliability and significance in modern cross-sectional imaging, inherent pitfalls and differential diagnoses. The signs presented will be relevant, easy to recognize and reasonably frequent. The face and neck offer some of the most complicated anatomies with which the radiologist has to deal, and also a particularly wide range of pathology, making cervicofacial imaging one of the most complex areas of clinical practice. Further, imaging signs in the face and neck can frequently be difficult to elicit. Many general radiologists therefore prefer to avoid practising in this area if possible, but a basic knowledge of the face and neck is fundamental to general radiology practice. A simple approach to the complexity of this area may be made on the basis of anatomical compartments. These are also the key to differential cervicofacial diagnosis and provide the radiologist with a useful guide to establish the pathological basis of imaging signs. In this area, it is also important to correlate imaging with clinical examination, as lesions may have identical imaging signs but radically different pathophysiologies. In radiology generally, knowledge of the clinical treatment options is fundamental to providing a meaningful radiological report. This is particularly true of cervicofacial disease where therapeutic options are generally not well understood by radiologists, and clinicoradiological liaison becomes paramount. Excellent image quality at an acceptable dose is a basic requirement for digital mammography. In many European countries, evaluations are guided by the European Guidelines for Quality Assurance in breast imaging. This document includes limiting values of contrast thresholds for objects of various diameters. In practice, the CDMAM phantom is used. The purpose of this lecture is to explain and illustrate the contrast detail analysis, to compare this approach to other measures of image quality assessment and to provide the reader with reference values of both DR and CR modalities The lecture will be based on literature data and personal measurements using the European protocol. We have extended the contrast detail evaluation using the computer read-out by the CDCOM software (www.euref.org). For each condition, 16 input images were used. All 16 matrices obtained with CDCOM were averaged, Gaussian smoothing or a smoothing procedure based on the statistical decision theory was used and all rows were then curve fited with a psychometric curve to retrieve contrast thresholds. The CDMAM approach is compared to other methods such as MTF and noise power spectra and lesion detection experiments using data sets with well-known (simulated) lesions. A critical evaluation and a good understanding of the European guidelines is needed. Human readings of the contrast detail phantom will soon be replaced by a computerized analysis from which predicted human threshold values will be estimated. Physicists and radiologists have to cooperate to ensure optimal quality of clinical mammograms. Computer-aided detection (CAD) has been proposed as an adjunct to single reading with the aim of increasing cancer detection rates. CAD systems have three stages. The initial stage is digitising films, which has associated time and cost implications, or direct application to digital mammograms. Secondly, the digital information is analysed. There are regular improvements in the analytical features, particularly to reduce the number of false prompts. Finally, calcium and mass markers are displayed on a screen. When the information is displayed, there is user ability to set a threshold level for marker display, thus choosing sensitivity and true-to-false prompt ratio, as well as to manipulate the CAD images. The initial clinical studies were retrospective reviews of selected batches of films. CAD was found to be very sensitive for malignancy and it was postulated that cancer detection rates would increase, if all CAD prompts on cancers were actioned. Prospective studies in the screening setting have had widely variable outcomes with some demonstrating improvements in cancer detection rate. Some, however, have shown either no change or reduced accuracy of interpretation. The impact of other factors, such as radiologist experience and breast or lesion characteristics, is also discussed. In the future, increasing use of digital mammography will facilitate CAD use. Several other applications include merging CAD information from prior views and clinical data correlation. Full field digital mammography is superior to analogue in image quality and is fast becoming the system of choice for new purchases where finances allow. Studies in the US (ACRIN/DMIST) and Europe (Oslo, London, etc.) show that at worst it is equivalent to analogue in terms of cancer detection screening, and at best outperforms analogue substantially, particularly in pre-and peri-menopausal women, and in those with dense breasts. Personal service screening experiences of 9 FFDM units having carried out approximately 75,000 mammographic studies are described. Training for experienced mammographers should be minimal once manufacturer's induction has taken place and a short learning curve overcome. Acclimatisation to high-contrast levels is a common early requirement. Soft-copy reading requires more meticulous attention to incident light than hard copy due to lower light output from monitors.This applies to the radiographic monitoring of current examinations as well as image reporting. Incorporation of FFDM into a department requires attention to PACS and connectivity issues, environmental issues such as air-conditioning, and also reading and prior image display protocols, particularly in a screening setting. The technical details and the performance characteristics of the dual-source CT (DSCT) concept and apparatus, and the possibilities for very fast acquisition at 83 ms effective scan time and dual-energy acquisition will be explained. Dual-energy CT (DECT) will be the focus of this presentation; clinical applications are the topic of the following two. DECT relies on the principle that the attenuation data necessary for the reconstruction of an image are acquired at two different energies. To do so, several technical realizations have been used and are still available today:
(1) Successive scans of a given slice or volume at two different voltage settings;

(2) acquisition with rapid kV switching; (3) acquisition at one voltage level but with a split "sandwich-like" detector which absorbs predominantly lower energy photons in the front and higher energy photons in the back portion; (4) dual-source CT (DSCT) with the two sources being operated at different energies. Although the acquisition schemes may differ, the processing and interpretation of DECT data are always based on the same principle: The energy-dependent differences in attenuation for a given region or a given tissue of interest allow conclusions on the effective atomic number. The physics behind it will be explained in detail by illustrations and examples. DECT is not material specific like spectroscopy. DECT nevertheless allows separating materials of sufficiently different atomic numbers such as soft tissue, calcium and iodine and has already proved specific advantages for clinical applications. Dual-source CT was developed to achieve a higher temporal resolution for cardiac imaging. The clinical indications of dual-source CT with both X-ray sources operating at the same potential are ECG-gated examinations. The high temporal resolution is not only beneficial to ensure a robust diagnostic image quality for coronary CT angiography but also to obtain diagnostic examinations at high heart rates. Also, dynamic images can be reconstructed to assess non-coronary structures including heart valves and myocardial wall motion. A specific protocol for the evaluation of acute chest pain offers the possibility to switch the second tube only on for the area of the heart. For dual-energy CT, the two X-ray sources run at different tube potentials (i.e., 140 and 80 kVp), and the tube currents are adjusted to obtain a similar photon output. The patient dose roughly equals that of a normal CT scan. Average images are immediately available for diagnostic evaluation. Additionally, a variety of postprocessing algorithms can be applied to exploit the spectral information. One algorithm removes the bones from angiography data sets. Another option is to color-code iodine uptake in parenchymatous organs or to subtract the iodinerelated density to obtain virtually unenhanced images. In pulmonary angiography data sets, perfusion of the lung parenchyma can be mapped by its iodine content. Different types of renal calculi can also be differentiated by their spectral properties and tendons and ligaments can be differentiated from other structures with a specific algorithm. Initial studies elucidate the clinical value of these applications. The advent of dual-source CT has re-invigorated the evaluation and development of dual-energy CT (DECT) that for technical reasons was largely abandoned in the early days of CT. Although this technique's renaissance has already resulted in currently available clinical applications, these are highly likely to merely be a starting point in the evolution of this modality. This presentation will focus on the potential future applications of DECT and its potential to shape the future of CT imaging. The future impact of DECT can broadly be categorized into three different areas: the dual availability of simultaneously acquired low and high kVp images, the potential for dual-energy calculated images to differentiate elements and finally the performance of advanced post-processing reconstructions, a composite group of images resulting from subtraction/fusion of images generated from other dualenergy data sets. Thus, DECT has the capacity to transform CT into a series of "sequences" simultaneously generated from the same volume to enhance visualization of anatomy and pathology. This presentation will concentrate on the most promising of these future applications and attempt to demonstrate how these may impact patient clinical evaluation. DECT utilization may result in significant modification of CT practice with the potential to reduce radiation exposure and alter current contrast media administration protocols. However, the advent of DECT may also introduce some confusion to some of the established quantitative CT techniques such as pulmonary nodule enhancement. The presentation will highlight these potential issues and address areas where future investigation is warranted. Stroke is one of the leading causes of death in industrialized countries. Although there are many causes of anterior circulation stroke, emboli from carotid occlusive disease account for a significant percentage. The primary endpoint is the determination of the degree of stenosis, although there is an increasing interest in plaque morphology. The US criteria used for diagnosis are variable among laboratories and each laboratory needs to establish its own criteria. The noninvasive nature of ultrasound makes this testing modality more attractive than the angiography "gold

technique with morbidity about 4% and risk of stroke 1.2% (ACAS). In addition, angiography provides little information on plaque structure. The development and continuing technological evolution of vascular US, the ability to post-process images accessing almost all imaging parameters enabled us to study the presence, rate of progression (or regression) and most importantly the consistency of plaques. The identification of a high-risk group of patients based on, other than stenosis, ultrasonographic features should lead to a better selection of patients for carotid endarterectomy or stenting. The user's subjectivity and the artifacts are the major limitations of ultrasound. Improvements of the ulstrasonographic image quality and our ability to normalize images may provide more detailed information on plaque morphology. B-flow, 3D, 4D and SRI imaging promise big changes in the way we evaluate the stenosis and structure of the plaque. Novel applications like new algorithms and software identifying patients at high risk of stroke are expected to become available on ultrasound devices in the near future. In the last 15 years, both MRA and CTA have contributed to the progressive reduction in the number of DSA examinations performed in vascular patients. Even though Doppler ultrasound has played a major role in the screening of carotid stenosis, the number of MRA and CTA exams to rule out or better define the grade of stenosis has grown considerably. MRA has the advantage of being performed without injection of contrast, even though data from comparison studies reported a slightly better sensitivity to CEMRA in comparison to TOF MRA in stenosis grading. Recently, the possible implication of Gd chelates in NSF in severe renal failure, has led to considering again unenhanced techniques in these patients. Nevertheless, the possibility of reducing contrast dosage when using high relaxivity GD compounds contributes to reduced risk. MRA and CTA have reported similar sensitivity and specificity in comparison to DSA in grading carotid stenosis, and their choice really depends on the experience of the center. MRA still remains, in general, easier and faster to be reconstructed, but on the other side, CTA, though more challenging, due to the necessary bone extraction and sometimes superimposition of jugular veins, has the great advantage of axial view of vessel wall and evidence of calcifications. Different considerations can be made for other pathological conditions, i.e. carotid dissections, where MRA with unenhanced techniques allows depiction of mural hematoma also within the petrous bone. Technical and clinical considerations for the two different modalities will be addressed in the lecture. Endometrial carcinoma is the most common uterine malignancy, occurring in a primarily postmenopausal population. Uterine sarcomas, lymphoma, small cell carcinoma and metastatic disease involving the uterus are rare. Treatment and prognosis of uterine cancer is influenced by tumor morphologic factors including depth of myometrial invasion, cervical extension and lymph node metastasis. Ultrasound (US) remains the study of choice for initial evaluation. However, it is less accurate than magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for delineating the extent of disease within the uterus. MRI is the gold standard in the assessment and staging of uterine cancer providing excellent soft tissue contrast, allowing for direct tumor visualization and assessment of tumor volume, depth of myometrial invasion and extension to adjacent tissues. Assessment of these parameters is crucial in deciding on the choice of therapy, whether surgery, radiation, chemotherapy or their combination. MRI is also an essential tool in monitoring treatment response and in assessing disease recurrence in these patients. CT can provide useful information about the extent of disease, lymph node involvement, metastatic disease and in patient follow-up. PET/CT is an accurate method for detecting recurrence early, evaluating therapeutic response, assessing lymph node status and prognosis. Lymph node involvement in uterine cancer is mainly assessed with CT. However with the use of USPIO as specific lymph node contrast media, MRI might play a major role in the future. A multidisciplinary approach is mandatory for the final management plan based on a combination of clinical assessment, imaging and histology. MR imaging is the method of choice for primary staging of cervical cancer. The backbone of staging cervical cancer is T2-weighted imaging with a high spatial resolution performed in two imaging planes. Invasion of the parametrium can thus be assessed with a high degree of accuracy. Especially in staging cervical cancer, MR imaging can replace numerous other diagnostic tests and thus improves pretherapeutic staging while at the same time reducing costs. Imaging is not routinely used for follow-up after surgery and/or radiotherapy. In patients with suspected tumor recurrence, MRI provides the best information. However, MRI should not be performed within the first 6 months after the end of radiotherapy in order not to mistake tumor necrosis or inflammatory processes for recurrent tumor. In patients with suspected recurrence of cervical cancer after surgery, the MR protocol should include a dynamic contrast-enhanced study to distinguish recurrence from scars. In patients with ovarian neoplasms, imaging plays a crucial role in tumor detection and characterization, preoperative staging and treatment planning, monitoring of treatment response, and detection of recurrence. Ultrasound is the primary modality for detecting and characterizing adnexal masses. MRI is a problem-solving modality for indeterminate masses and the best modality to assess pelvic sidewall invasion.

Abdominal and pelvic multi-detector contrast-enhanced CT is the modality of choice for preoperative staging and prediction of tumor resectability, extension into the upper abdomen and related complications (e.g., hydronephrosis, bowel obstruction). It is also the primary modality for treatment follow-up. PET-CT is valuable for imaging recurrent disease, especially in detecting tumor deposits of normal-sized nodes, mesentery and bowel serosa, and distant sites. In tumor detection and characterization, the most important role of imaging is the identification of cancer and, thus, patient referral to oncologists. Imaging is gaining acceptance in patient triage between surgery and neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgery. The value of imaging in surgical planning has been underestimated. In a recent prospective study, intraoperative reporting of optimal primary cytoreduction (residual disease 1 cm) correlated with postoperative CT findings in only 52% of patients. Presurgical planning using CT may improve these results. Furthermore, imaging detection of the size and site of recurrence may obviate a second-look laparotomy, since secondary cytoreduction is only justified if complete resection is possible. Thus, while progress in early detection and survival of ovarian cancer has been relatively slow, a clear role for imaging in improving patient outcome is emerging. Although spread beyond the linings of cervical lymph nodes or salivary glands, these may be detected; but ultrasound does not allow assessment of the deep extent of inflammatory processes towards the skull base, the spine, and the mediastinum. Contrast-enhanced MDCT, being not hindered by bone or air, is the technique of choice to detect spread along the neck with potential extent towards the skull base or mediastinum. Early inflammatory changes in the membranous labyrinth in the meninges and brain may be detected by MR, which is also sensitive in demonstrating bone marrow edema. In acute inflammatory conditions of the nasosinusal tract, the clinical findings may require contrast-enhanced CT to rule out or grade the extent of orbital and/or intracranial complications. Moreover, CT is indicated to detect and to assess fluid collections and abscesses arising from the salivary glands or the pharyngeal walls and spreading into the deep compartments of the neck. Involvement of the upper airways walls, the retro-pharyngeal, or the pre-vertebral space implies changes in the risk profile of the process. The purpose of this lecture is to familiarize the radiologist with the most common types of traumatic injuries seen in the head and neck. First, relevant practical aspects of CT and MR imaging in the emergency situation will be discussed, followed by a brief discussion of priorities when dealing with fractures and soft tissue injuries. A systematic review will include key radiologic features of : a) facial trauma and their effects on the skull base, maxilla, mandible and orbit; b) characteristic radiologic features of temporal bone trauma and its effects on the middle ear, inner ear, facial nerve and posterior base of the skull; c) laryngeal injuries involving both the laryngeal skeleton and soft tissues; d) vascular injuries and e) various other soft tissue injuries including the brachial plexus, major salivary glands and neck muscles. Major emphasis will be placed on what the clinician needs to know and how to report the findings in a comprehensive way. Learning Objectives:

1. To become familiar with common types of craniocervical trauma and their effects on skull base and maxillofacial skeleton. 2. To be able to adapt the examination protocol depending on the type of injuries suspected. 3. To learn to describe the pertinent findings in fractures, and to identify the related soft tissue injuries. 4. To learn to report the pertinent findings to the clinician.
