The most common head and neck neoplasm, seen by radiologists, is squamous cell cancer (SCC), but numerous other tumour types may be encountered. SCC of the head and neck is a very heterogeneous disease. The symptoms, treatment and prognosis are influenced by the site of origin. This site determines, by its particular anatomy, the local extension pattern, the risk of lymphatic dissemination, as well as the localisation of metastatic adenopathies. The diagnosis of cancer is often made clinically. However, SCC shows the tendency to extend submucosally, following the paths of least resistance. These paths are along submucosal fatty planes, along nerves and vessels. Tumour extension is diverted by bone and cartilage, and to some extent also by fascial layers. Invasion of these structures usually occurs at a later stage. This deep tissue spread may be difficult to detect by clinical examination alone. The radiologist should describe as accurately as possible the structures that are involved and where the tumour borders are situated. Furthermore, subclinical neck adenopathies may be detected by imaging, and should be looked for in the positive neck signs of extranodal extension. This imaging-derived information affects staging and has prognostic importance. Tumour localisation and staging are important factors in treatment planning. Several imaging techniques are available to visualise head and neck cancer, each having particular advantages and disadvantages. CT is the workhorse of the head and neck radiologist, but in some tumour localisations, such as the sinonasal cavity, nasopharynx and skull base, MRI provides better overall results. This presentation will detail general principles related to the frontal and lateral view of the conventional chest radiograph. In a first part, technical aspects of conventional and digital acquisition methods, together with their drawbacks and advantages, will be presented. Special emphasis will be put on details related to display, storage, and transfer of data via PACS facilities. The second part of the presentation will include issues related to projection radiography as related to the anatomy of the thorax, and propose potential solutions to these issues. The final third part of the presentation will then present perceptual challenges occurring in the analysis of chest radiographs, and present tips and tricks aimed to improve the visual assessment of chest radiographic images. The chest radiograph can accurately detect diseases, which are frequently associated with significant morbidity such as infectious diseases, heart failure, chronic airway diseases and pulmonary neoplasms. Important diagnoses may be missed when the amount of time spent reading the chest film is limited. A systematic approach is essential to avoid overlooking a lesion or misinterpreting a normal variant. We have focused on creating a convenient, user-friendly teaching method, adapted to everyone interested in thoracic radiology. To improve the radiologist's perception and performance, a concentric step-by-step approach is presented, using computerized animations. Key areas of the chest radiogaph, including the apices, the hila and the lower lobes are reviewed with relevant pathologic and CT correlations. Memotechnical methods covering the crucial areas of the chest radiograph will be provided. Participants should learn to answer the following question with confidence: Does this radiograph provide information relevant to the patient's health? Case studies will demonstrate how a small improvement with a systematic approach can provide many benefits in terms of time, cost and health. A thorough understanding of the anatomy of peritoneal ligaments and spaces enables the correct interpretation of abdominal imaging studies and enhances the diagnostic workup. In this course, the attendee will learn how the ligaments and mesentries in the upper abdomen interconnect the upper abdominal viscera and serve as important pathways of disease. In addition, the peritoneal ligaments and mesentries define the peritoneal spaces, which they bind. By recognizing the location of an interperitoneal process, one may better predict its origin and likely route of spread. This would influence the therapeutical approach, especially in surgical cases. Detection of peritoneal carcinomatosis is a major challenge in onco-imaging, because of emerging and promising treatments for this condition. Reported sensitivity of imaging is low, inferior to 50%, even though it may be overestimated due to the lack of a gold standard, like surgery, in many series. Detection relies on peritoneal fluid and peritoneal nodules, especially the localization to the liver surface and to the greater omentum known as the "omental cake". These signs lack sensitivity and/or specificity. Nevertheless, modern imaging provides the tools to improve dramatically the detection rate, using a combination of technical improvements, anatomical knowledge and multimodality comparison: Technical tips are thin slices, multiplanar reconstruction and appropriate use of contrast media. Anatomical knowledge consists in the identification of peritoneal spaces and structures, as well as the most common, but overlooked, seeding sites. Radiologists should be trained to detect small peritoneal nodules confidently, because it is mandatory in the era of laparoscopic surgery. It also helps in tumor follow-up. Multiplanar imaging is especially useful. Multimodality approach combines the advantages of US (high-resolution images of superficial structures), MRI, MDCT (unique anatomical display) and PET-CT (detection of small active enhancing nodules) to improve both detection and characterization of detected lesions, avoiding the drawbacks of each single method. Finally, some benign conditions may mimic peritoneal carcinomatosis in oncologic patients and should be ruled out like radiation therapy scarring, postsurgical changes and infection. The major features of primary peritoneal tumors, which are rare conditions, will also be presented. The peritoneal cavity and its reflections are frequently involved by infectious and inflammatory processes. Before the introduction of cross-sectional imaging, the peritoneum and its reflections could only be imaged with difficulty, often requiring invasive techniques. Multidetector computed tomography and, to a lesser extent ultrasound and magnetic resonance imaging, allow the accurate examination of the complex anatomy of the peritoneal cavity, which is the key to understanding the pathological processes affecting it. Differential diagnosis among different conditions however, is often difficult because of non-specific and overlapping clinical and imaging features. Peritoneal cavity infection may be localized (peritoneal abscess formation) or generalized (peritonitis). Peritoneal abscess formation most frequently follows surgery despite modern surgical techniques and antimicrobial therapy. It may also complicate appendicitis or Crohn's disease in younger patients, and diverticulitis in older patients. Inflammation can become more generalized within the peritoneum which is often the case with tuberculous peritonitis. Tuberculous peritonitis develops after rupture of a caseous abdominal lymph node or due to secondary spread to the intestinal tract. Sclerosing peritonitis can occur as a longterm complication of chronic ambulatory peritoneal dialysis. Inflammatory change in the mesentery can occur in any gut-associated pathology, particularly Crohn's disease and less common diseases affecting the mesentery including mesenteric panniculitis and epiploic appendicitis. It is important for an interventional radiologist to be able to recognise the signs and symptoms of aorto-iliac disease. At the interventional radiology clinic, a focussed history needs to be obtained with specific reference to claudication distance, the part of the leg that is affected by pain, presence of impotence, past surgical history, and symptoms of rest pain and ulcers. Examination should include peripheral pulses including brachial, ankle brachial pressure indices (ABPIs), any scarring in groins, degree of obesity, and stigmata of arterial insuffiency. Preoperative imaging should include a method of noninvasive imaging, at least colour Doppler ultrasound or either CT angiography or MR angiography. At the time of writing, the jury is out as to which is less potentially injurious (contrast nephrotoxicity, CTA versus nephrogenic systemic fibrosis, MRA). Neither is a substitute for a good history and examination. Ideally, one should have at least a Plan A and B in terms of initial puncture. Lesion traversal will be discussed with appropriate examples. Primary stent placement is generally the preferred option and the various types of stents will be discussed. Procedure endpoints, potential complications, and possible bailouts will also be discussed. The importance of further clinical follow-up and outpatient review cannot be overstressed. Stroke is a clinical diagnosis with a high prevalence. The underlying pathology is either cerebral ischemia or a hemorrhagic lesion, and for each category of stroke a host of pathological conditions can be responsible. The radiologist plays a crucial role in the diagnostic work-up of stroke patients. Apart from assessing whether the stroke is of an ischemic or hemorrhagic nature, radiological techniques can help assess the underlying pathology. In order to be effective for stroke patients, radiologists need to have a thorough understanding of the pathophysiological responses of the brain to the initial events and be familiar with the manifestations of these responses on radiological examinations. The current WHO classification divides brain neoplasms into primary and metastatic. This classification is mixed based on histogenesis as well as on anatomic location and includes a wide heterogeneous group of neoplasms with different phenotype, genotype, age prevalence, biology, response to therapy and clinical outcome. Gliomas, meningiomas and metastatic brain lesions make up more than 90% of all brain tumors. The prognosis is poor for most gliomas and metastatic lesions. Imaging plays a fundamental role in the initial diagnosis and surgical planning, but a minor role in planning specific therapy and predicting the clinical outcome. Current imaging modalities are: 1. Anatomic: MR is the modality of choice for localization and characterization of brain tumors and biopsy guiding. FLAIR T2W and post-contrast T1W sequences should be included in the protocol. Susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) allow easier detection of hemorragic foci. CT scan is complementary owing to its superior visualization of intratumoral calcifications and bony involvement. 2. Functional: a) Diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI): ADC (apparent diffusion coefficient) parameters are helpful for correlation with architecture and grading of gliomas. b) Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI): DTI colour maps and tractography can delineate integrity of white matter tracts, i.e. dislocation vs infiltration in the vicinity of tumors, and they are useful for surgical planning. c) Proton MR spectroscopy: Increased Ch/Cr ratio is found in gliomas and correlates with tumor grade. Lipid peak is a predictor of poor outcome. d) Dynamic susceptibility-weighted (DSC) perfusion imaging: rCBV is utilized for tumor grading and differentiation of recurrent tumor vs radiation effects. Spiral computed tomography (CT) has surpassed ultrasound (US) in imaging of bowel emergencies in many situations. The combination of high spatial resolution, large field of view, vascular information and multiplanar reconstruction in a single breath hold have made CT an important part of the work-up of patients with bowel emergencies. The CT protocol includes the use of intravenous contrast medium, while oral contrast medium will not be routine in many institutions. A dedicated CT scanner in the emergency department facilitates the use of the technique. Important imaging findings include abnormal air and fluid configurations, fat infiltration and vas-A 33 B C D E F G cular abnormalities (e.g. thrombosis). CT has acceptable to excellent sensitivity and specificity for many diseases (e.g. appendicitis, diverticulitis, abscesses). However, the majority of studies concern appendicitis and the evidence for other conditions and bowel emergencies in general is limited. Apart from good test accuracy, the examination is fast, and communication with clinicians and comparison of repeat examinations are facilitated as compared with US. Reproducibility is considered favourable to US, although this is not a thoroughly studied topic. The role of CT in management will depend on several factors, such as disease presentation, disease spectrum, age groups and local situation. Modern cross-sectional imaging techniques allow accurate visualisation of a variety of abnormalities enabling their precise targeting with minimally invasive methods of treatment. This session will discuss very different techniques, which share imaging guidance as a key component. MR-guided focussed ultrasound therapy uses high doses of focussed ultrasound waves to destroy uterine fibroids and other soft tissue tumours without affecting any of the surrounding tissues. The procedure is conducted in a magnetic resonance imaging scanner, which enables the operator to pinpoint, guide and continuously monitor the treatment. Stereotactic radiosurgery utilises accurately targeted, large doses of radiation to destroy tissues. This minimally invasive treatment is an effective alternative to surgery or conventional radiation for treating many small tumours and some other selected medical disorders. The Cyberknife uses an advanced, lightweight linear accelerator, a robot which can point the accelerator from a wide variety of angles and several imaging devices that can track patient position. Cyberknife technology makes it possible to perform radiosurgery at almost any location within the body. Sophisticated methods of drug delivery, such as heat activation, enable the precise deposition of active agents within tumours to enable ablation or gene therapy. The above techniques illustrate the magnitude and speed of advances in imaging-guided therapy, which are set to revolutionise modern medicine, and emphasise the need for multidisciplinary collaboration in this field. MR-guided focussed ultraound (MRgFUS) therapy combines very high-power ultrasound with MR targeting and thermal manometry to create a destructive modality that can ablate discreet areas of tissues in a highly controllable manner. This ablation modality is entirely non-invasive and as long as there is a reasonable acoustic window into the target, then the whole process can be carried out completely safely. Currently, the process has been used in the treatment of uterine fibroids, very successfully, with more than 3,000 patients being treated worldwide.

Other evolving applications are the palliation of painful bone secondaries, the treatment of breast malignancies and the destruction of areas of malignant soft tissue. Other emerging areas, which are still in the early stages of technology development include a method of treating any part of the liver, overcoming the obscuration of the rib cage, and respiratory problems, with this type of technology being also applied potentially to the kidney as well. In summary, therefore, this new modality offers completely non-invasive approaches to the controlled destruction of areas of soft tissue, with exquisite feedback control using MR thermal imaging and very precise targeting using MR for this aspect. Cyberknife technology, combining integrated image-guided and robotic technology, has led to a paradigm shift in radiosurgery. With Cyberknife technology, an invasive stereotactic head frame is no longer required to obtain the highest possible accuracy for brain treatments. This offers the patient a real non-invasive and pain-free radiosurgical treatment. Apart from standard neurosurgical indications (i.e. acoustic neurinomas, meningeomas, brain metastases), radiosurgical applications are currently evolving to extracranial indications. The newest development in Cyberknife radiosurgery is a breath-triggered real-time movement correction, which makes it possible to apply radiosurgical doses to body lesions. It is nowadays possible to treat tumors of the spine, pancreas, lung and the liver safely and effectively with radiosurgical techniques in cases where they are well delineated from the surrounding healthy tissue. In selected cases, this could replace a surgical procedure and enhance interdisciplinary oncological treatment concepts. Cyberknife treatment is designed for outpatient treatment and can mostly be applied in one treatment session. Well-selected and high-quality imaging is of utmost importance for successful radiosurgical applications. High field MRI studies, fast CT scanners, PET and PET-CT information are integrated in the planning phase for optimal target definition. The interaction with experienced academic radiologists for optimal selection of the desired imaging studies enhances the quality of the radiosurgical application significantly, making this non-invasive treatment a true interdisciplinary achievement for optimal clinical results. The Munich center reports about the first 1,000 patients treated in close cooperation with a variety of clinical and imaging experts. Learning Objectives:

1. To learn about the principles and clinical applications of image guided robotic radiosurgery. 2. To understand the importance and requirements of multimodal imaging for dedicated 3D computerised planning for radiosurgical applications. Soft tissue lesions account for approximately 80% of invasive cancers and 5% of non-invasive cancers detected in mammography screening. Challenges in detection and diagnosis are overcome by a systematic approach to viewing, a knowledge of the range of normal appearances, thorough analysis of abnormal features and application of the Triple Approach at assessment. Systematic viewing of high-quality mammograms is essential for perception of subtle signs. Although the most common sign of a cancer is a spiculate mass, small tumours detected by screening may appear as non-specific asymmetric soft tissue densities without classical signs of malignancy. Careful observation of the mammographic review areas will help in the detection of such lesions. At assessment, further mammographic views, including spot compression and fine focus magnification techniques are important in demonstrating the mammographic features of soft tissue lesions, which are then classified according to the predominant abnormal feature: spiculate mass, circumscribed mass, parenchymal distortion or asymmetric soft tissue density. The radiologist should understand the differential diagnosis and the risk of malignancy for each mammographic abnormality. High-frequency ultrasound is essential in the assessment of soft tissue abnormalities, features providing further important diagnostic information. The radiologist should not however be reassured by a normal ultrasound examination when abnormal mammographic features persist. The histological diagnosis for soft tissue lesions found on mammography is confirmed by image-guided needle biopsy. US-guided 14G core biopsy is most commonly used. A non-operative diagnosis can be achieved in more than 95% cases. Breast calcifications are very frequent findings, especially in elderly women. Not all calcifications represent malignancy, but a lot of attention has to be paid to them, because of their varying appearance. Artefacts may be present because of technical reasons, at analogue and digital mammography as well, and radiologists should be familiar with them. Macrocalcifications mostly represent benign lesions, while microcalcifications may indicate malignancy. Characterisation is mainly performed by targeted mammography examination, sometimes completed by ultrasound and MRI. Recognition of typically benign microcalcifications is quite easy and secure, but distinction among the rest of the microcalcifications is based on the reader's experience and statistical probability. These methods rarely fail to reveal malignant tumours of the breast. Very early cancers may be considered as benign lesions because of their small extension and atypical, benign-looking morphology. Following the BI-RADS lexicon, it is mandatory to categorize these lesions in order to standardize therapy planning, but biopsy is always recommended when the probability of cancer is over 2%. Stereotaxy is recommended as the targeting method while identification of calcifications by ultrasound is not secure. Vacuum core biopsy or traditional core biopsy are the sampling methods of choice. If multiple clusters are present, the two most distant groups are the subjects of biopsy. Percutaneous treatments of primary (HCC) and metastatic liver malignancies have progressively gained importance in recent years either as valid alternatives to surgical resection or as main therapeutic tools for unresectable tumors. In the Consensus Conferences on HCC held in Barcelona in 2000 and 2005, percutaneous treatments have been definitely inserted in the therapeutic flow-chart for "very early" HCC (within 2 cm in diameter) and their role is getting increasing importance, as only treatment or in combination with intra-arterial therapies, and also for "early" and "intermediate stage" HCC. The first prospective randomized clinical trials comparing radiofrequency ablation (RFA) and surgery for HCC smaller than 3 or 5 cm have been published too. The 3-and 5-year survival rates did not show significant differences between the two treatments, but had clear advantages with RFA in terms of lower rate of complications and markedly lower costs of treatment and hospital stay. As far as liver metastases are concerned, several clinical studies have reported the excellent results of RFA, which achieved local control and long-term survival rates almost comparable to those reported in literature for surgical resection of metastases from colorectal, breast and endocrine malignancies, but with lower complication rates and costs. However, essential requirement to achieve good results is the size of metastases, with a clear cut-off value of approximately 3 cm. The constant and progressive improvement of results achieved by percutaneous treatments is also due to the continuous technological improvement of imaging modalities, which allow to guide interventional procedures, such as contrast-enhanced sonography, contrast-enhanced and diffusion-weighted MRI and real-time image-fusion systems. All hepatic lesions, primary as well as metastatic, are mainly fed by arterial circulation and this is the rationale for every kind of intra-arterial treatment. There are two main groups of intra-arterial hepatic treatment, with different indications: liver embolization (which includes TACE, TAE and radioembolization) and hepatic arterial chemotherapy (HAC). If targeting is the main concern for embolization, to selectively deliver embolic material into the vessels feeding the lesion, the basis for HAC is totally opposed, the drug should be delivered as proximally as possible, with the aim of treating the whole liver parenchyma. A wide variation in vascular anatomy, which varies from the classical scheme in more then 45% of cases, represents the main limitation to reaching this target. Pre-intervention arterial phase MDCT helps in assessing the main vascular anatomical variations for an easier and faster endovascular procedure. The catheter tip for drug delivery should be located in the proximal section of the main feeding artery (ideally the proper hepatic artery) after all the other vessels feeding the liver have been proximally occluded with coils. In this way, only the whole liver will be fed by intra-parenchymal anastomotic vessels and the drug could be homogenously infused; otherwise "misperfusion" may occur. Coil embolization of visceral vessels should be also performed in order to avoid drug infusion outside the liver, which may lead to complications such as gastritis, ulcers and even bowel perforations. It is mandatory to have a high level of confidence with hepatic vascular anatomy, including possible variations, in order that the treatment is effective and safe. In the early twenty-first century, prostate imaging incorporates sophisticated and highly accurate anatomical imaging and physiological and biological imaging yielding an expanding volume of data on tumour extent and activity. The choice of the technique used depends on the clinical presentation and the intent to treat actively or otherwise. The interpretation of MRI findings and clinical information determines the feasibility of radical treatments, either surgery or radiotherapy, or palliative therapy. This lecture will define the patients, who should be evaluated with MRI in the context of lesion localisation and staging, for response assessment and when relapse is suspected. The relative contributions and limitations of morphological assessments and the added value of new techniques such as dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI, MR spectroscopy and diffusion weighted MRI will be outlined. The contribution of MR lymphography in patient care pathways will also be outlined. Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (NSF) is generally connected with exposure to Gd-containing contrast media. Findings of Gd in the skin of patients with NSF support this association. However, the precise trigger for NSF remains obscure. NSF develops mainly in patients with advanced renal failure, since Gd-containing contrast media are almost exclusively eliminated renally. Thus, renal failure dramatically delays Gd-clearance. Moreover, high EPO-levels may contribute to NSF, as often encountered in patients with renal failure under EPO substitution. Also circulating fibrocytes play a crucial role in NSF. Fibrocytes are aberrantly stimulated and synthesize collagen, resulting in skin thickening. This process has been correlated with thrombotic events or hypercoagulable states. Remarkably, persistent inflammation and endothelial lesions have also been suggested to facilitate NSF. However, why mainly the skin is targeted remains unknown. Renal dysfunction and tissue injury may inflict a proinflammatory milieu with release of cytokines. These recruit circulating fibrocytes from the bone marrow, which deposit in the skin and joints causing more cytokine release, growth and neoangiogenic factors, resulting in fibrosis. Due to various physicochemical properties, some Gd-containing contrast media are more susceptible to affect the release of free Gd. Within a short period of time it was shown in several centers that the incidence after exposure to gadodiamide varies between 3 and 7%, whereas we do not know yet the incidence after exposure to the other agents except that it is closer to 0. Also with regard to clusters of patients ( 10) gadodiamide deviates. Only one cluster where the patients had gadopentetate has yet been identified whereas there are more than ten after gadodiamide. As all patients do not develop nephrogenic systemic fibrosis, it is assumed that here must be a co-factor involved. There are two definitive factors: (1) end-stage renal failure including dialysis (CSK 4 and 5), and (2) exposure to gadolinium contrast agents in particular the non-ionic linear agents. How to avoid NSF in the future S.K. Morcos; Sheffield/UK (sameh.morcos@sth.nhs.uk) There are differences in the incidence of nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (NSF) with the different Gd-CM, which appears to be related to differences in physico-chemical properties and stability. NSF has been reported so far only with the following Gd-CM: gadodiamide, gadoversetamide and gadopentetate dimeglumine. They are flexible, open chains linear chelates which have a weak binding to the gadolinium ion. No cases of NSF have been reported following the exclusive use of macrocyclic Gd-CM (gadoterate meglumine, gadobutrol and gadoteridol) which have high stability as they are preorganized rigid rings of almost optimal size to cage the gadolinium ion. Release of free gadolinium through transmetallation between Gd-CM and endogenous ions seems to be an important factor in the pathogenesis of NSF. Prevention of NSF starts by identifying patients with renal impairment, including those on dialysis. Measurement of serum creatinine before Gd-CM administration is not necessary in all patients but mandatory if considering the use of Gd-CM associated with NSF. In patients with renal impairment (eGFR 30 ml/min) or those on dialysis do not use gadodiamide, gadopentetate dimeglumine or gadoversetam. The most stable Gd-CM (macrocyclic agents) and the lowest dose possible should be used in these patients. At least 1 week should be allowed before giving more Gd-CM. During pregnancy, if the use of a Gd-CM is essential, whatever the maternal renal function, the most stable Gd-CM in the lowest possible dose should be used to protect the fetus. It is important not to deny at risk patients clinically important MR examinations. What counts as a high field now in the MRI world is 7 T and above. Tough commercial competition for the past 5 years at the 3 T level has established this field strength for clinical MRI, both for head and for body scanning. Doubled signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) at 3 T, as compared with 1.5 T, combined with parallel imaging radically shortens scanning time and dramatically improves image quality. Will increasing the field strength to 7 T and beyond result in comparable gains for clinical scanning? This lecture outlines the hardware requirements, potential benefits and pitfalls, and the consequences for imaging strategy and sequence design. The five major physical facts regarding high-field MRI are that (a) the spin magnetization increases linearly with field, (b) transverse relaxation times T2 and T2* decrease, with T2* decreasing rapidly, (c) the longitudinal relaxation time T1 increases, more slowly than linearly, (d) the rf wavelength approaches the size of the imaged object, and (e) radiofrequency power deposition increases as the square of field. The first four of these facts enable improved or novel imaging strategies. All five of them constrain magnet, gradient, and pulse sequence design. Use of rf transmit and receive arrays, head gradient coils, parallel acquisition, and sequence optimization will be described. Fields of 7 T plus can provide impressive images, already promising for neuroscience research. The combination of novel tissue contrasts, high contrast to noise and very high resolution is possibly to have major clinical application.

Learning Objectives: 1. To comprehend the importance of magnetic field strength in MR imaging of humans. 2. To understand the basic physical factors related to field strength that affect MR images. 3. To become familiar with the strategies that are currently employed to make the best use of these factors.
Pre-clinical studies with high field and very high field MRI: What is available, what is needed?

The main advantages of MRI at high field are: higher signal-to-noise ratio, higher contrast-to-noise ratio that result in the improvement of anatomical and/or temporal resolution. In general the shift to higher fields reduces scan time while preserving image quality. Image signal-to-noise ratio depends on B 0 7/4 in the intermediate field range but moves to a more linear dependence in the high field range. Any step towards higher fields implies relevant technological, physical and safety issues. In this lecture I'll tackle issues related to changes in relaxation kinetics, increased susceptibility effects and other changes in contrast mechanisms. The spin-lattice relaxation time, T 1 , increases with the magnetic field strength providing interesting new opportunities to enhance the contrast thanks to the relationships with the exchange rate of water across the biological membranes. T 2 shows some shortening going to higher fields. Very important is the shortening of T 2 *as the magnetic susceptibility gradients increase linearly with the field. Therefore T 2 *-susceptibility agents enhance their effect with the field. Also the newly reported class of contrast agents deemed CEST (Chemical Exchange Saturation Transfer) improves markedly their performance with the field. Finally, at high fields, Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy applications will obviously benefit (larger separation between absorptions of different species and increase in signal-to-noise).This will prompt new studies involving the detection of less sensitive nuclei of biological interest such as 31 P, 13 C, 23 Na and 19 F. There has been a rapid development of hybrid scanners combining both positron emission tomography (PET) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). An overview of the PET detector technology and the impact of MRI on this technology will be included.

Multi-detector row computed tomography (MDCT) has emerged as a new diagnostic tool for global assessment not only of the heart but also of the entire cardiovascular system. 64DCT and in particular the recent development of dual source CT allow the evaluation of cardiac morphology as well as coronary and by-pass graft anatomy. MDCT is also very promising for valve assessment. Cardiac MRI is seen as especially effective for the evaluation of complex anatomy, cardiac function, myocardial viability, valvular disease, myocardial perfusion and congenital heart disease. It is replacing echocardiography as gold standard for cardiac motility and volumetry. MRI as a "one-stop shop" procedure, however, has never been realized because of the difficulty in visualizing the coronary arteries. Session Objectives: 1. To show that cardiac imaging is recognised as an increasingly important area of radiology. 2. To become familiar with the essentials of cardiac pathophysiology and pathoanatomy when evaluating the heart with CT and/or MRI. 3. To present recent advances in cardiac CT and MR imaging.
What does MDCT offer?

The advent of multi-detector row CT scanners with subsecond gantry rotation time and high isotropic spatial resolution, together with acquisition of data synchronized to the ECG has allowed the visualization of coronary arteries with a high diagnostic quality. The same data set, however, also contains huge amounts of information regarding the myocardium, atrial and ventricular size and function, as well as cardiac valves. In the past few years, evidence has accumulated to indicate that CT allows the assessment of ventricular size and function with a similar accuracy as compared to the current standard of reference magnetic resonance imaging. Moreover, a number of recent studies have indicated that multi-detector row CT allows not only the morphological evaluation but also the functional evaluation of cardiac valves with comparable results as compared to the current clinical reference modality echocardiography. Finally, recent evidence has accumulated to indicate that viability assessment of myocardium with CT has become feasible with a similar accuracy as compared to MRI. When ECG-gated imaging protocols are modified to cover the whole thoracic cavity and aim at a simultaneous opacifica-tion of coronary arteries, thoracic aorta, and pulmonary arteries, CT enables to evaluate patients with acute chest pain by diagnosing or excluding aortic dissection or rupture, significant coronary stenoses, and pulmonary embolism. Particularly, most recently introduced dual-source CT scanners with a high and heart rateindependent temporal resolution have opened the field for routine application of such CT protocols to the emergency patient because heart rate control prior to cardiac CT is no longer necessary. Learning Objectives:

1. To provide an overview of the current knowledge about CT imaging of the heart. 2. To describe the latest technical developments in multi-detector row CT which impact on the performance of cardiac imaging. 3. To understand the role of cardiac CT for a comprehensive cardiac evaluation including coronary arteries, myocardium, and cardiac valves.
What does MRI offer?

The latest MRI technology provides high spatial resolution to evaluate cardiac anatomy without any radiation exposure. Besides the visualization of often very complex cardiac morphology, especially in congenital heart disease, in which echocardiography often fails due to a lack of acoustic window, MRI offers the additional possibility of a comprehensive functional evaluation of the heart. This includes not only volumetric and flow measurements but also more complex evaluations such as cardiac strain analyses and spectroscopy. Cardiac MRI's potential of tissue characterization in a variety of non-ischemic or ischemic cardiomyopathies or even in acute myocarditis is another strength of this imaging technology. Independent from the clinical indication, each cardiac MRI examination should include not only a morphologic evaluation but also a dedicated functional evaluation of the heart. One of the major drawbacks of cardiac MRI compared with the competitor MDCT is the still insufficient visualization of the coronary arteries. With the combination of higher field strength, parallel imaging techniques and new contrast agents, this may be solved within the next few years.
Learning Objectives:

To learn what MRI can offer for functional assessment of the heart (e.g. CINE-MRI, myocardial tagging, flow quantification). 2. To learn what MRI can offer for tissue characterisation of the myocardium in different ischemic or non-ischemic heart diseases (e.g. differentiation between edema, fibrosis, scar and inflammation). 3. To learn how all these techniques can be improved according to acquisition time and spatial resolution to better compete with MDCT in the morphological assessment of the heart.
Integrating MDCT and MRI in the work-up of heart disease V.E. Sinitsyn; Moscow/RU (vsini@mail.ru)

Progress of technology and accumulation of clinical data have resulted in a wide recognition of MDCT and MRI as powerful tools to diagnose cardiac diseases. Greatest advantages of cardiac MDCT are speed, sub-millimeter spatial resolution and robustness. MRI has excellent capabilities for studies of myocardial function, perfusion and viability, blood flow quantification. MDCT has clear advantages over MRI in coronary imaging. In some areas (e.g. valve studies, quantification of chamber volumes and function, and myocardial viability), MDCT already competes with MRI. Nevertheless, MRI has better tissue contrast and functionality. MRI has progressed into leading modality for performing myocardial viability and perfusion studies. The combination of cardiac MDCT and MRI gives possibility of getting holistic picture of cardiac and coronary anatomy, valve and myocardial function, myocardial perfusion and viability (e.g., in patients with coronary artery disease, complex congenital and valve diseases). Guidelines for practical use of cardiac MDCT and MRI have been developed and suggested by some radiological and cardiological societies. In brief, major indications of MDCT are noninvasive coronary angiography, detection of intracardiac thrombi and tumors, constrictive pericarditis, imaging of thoracic aorta, pulmonary arteries and veins. Most useful indications of cardiac MRI are myocardial viability and perfusion studies, imaging of myocardial diseases and cardiac tumors, assessment of heart function, quantification of blood flow in valve and shunt lesions, monitoring of cardiac remodeling in clinical trials. Further progress of technology, accumulation of scientific data and cost-effectiveness analysis will allow us further clarify relative role of these two modalities in cardiac imaging. With increased spatial resolution, contrast flexibility and new contrast strategies, MRI is viewed as a promising technique for characterization of atherosclerotic plaque. Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory vascular disease. As an inflammation process, many cellular and molecular events are involved at each step of the progression of atherosclerosis from the early fatty streak lesion to the highly dangerous rupture-proned plaque. The first part will focus on high-resolution MRI and optimal sequence combination in clinical and experimental protocols for characterization of plaque components with contrast agents. The second part will evaluate the diagnostic impact of currently available MR contrast agents to detect inflammatory processes and evolutive atherosclerotic lesions. The third part will briefly introduce the main cellular and molecular actors involved in atherosclerotic lesions at different stages and present some recent and ongoing MRI works for cellular and molecular imaging of atherosclerosis. The concept of stem cell therapy has been receiving increasing interest as a potentially valuable therapeutic entity in various medical disciplines. In cardiovascular medicine this led to a brief furor. A number of clinical trials were performed after only a few initial, successful preclinical studies. While some evidence of the benefit of stem cell therapy was obtained from these trials, the response rates and response duration were far from the expectations raised by earlier preclinical studies. The rather disappointing clinical results indicate that a better understanding of the fate and function of transplanted cells and of how stem cells cause therapeutic benefits is mandatory to mold stem cell therapy into an effective clinical treatment option for myocardial infarction. Through novel imaging techniques, including molecular imaging, we can now study these issues better and more efficiently. These new techniques include tools for: in vivo tracking of stem cells, assessment of cardiac function and clinical response, and assessment of biochemical pathways involved in myocyte degeneration. To review the needs for imaging of angiogenesis and outline the potential imaging targets. To review the established and new emerging tools for molecular imaging of angiogenesis: Targeted contrast agents, imaging markers for gene expression and enzymatic activity, and tracking recruitment of vascular cells. Angiogenesis, the growth of new blood vessels, requires coordinated participation of numerous cell types and signaling pathways. MRI facilitates the study of the basic biological mechanisms that execute angiogenesis, in addition to its role in preclinical drug development and clinical imaging of response to pro and antiangiogenic therapy. A key regulator of angiogenesis is vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), which is also a popular target for antiangiogenic therapy. VEGFstimulated blood vessels show acute increase in permeability, and dissociation of perivascular pericytes and smooth muscle cells, resulting in reduced vasoreactivity. The plasticity of the vasculature during angiogenesis is accompanied by changes in cell surface markers. In addition, enzymes secreted into the interstitial space and plasma proteins extravasated from leaky blood vessels result in profound changes in the extracellular matrix. Functional imaging of blood volume, blood flow, perfusion and vasoreactivity depict the consequence of angiogenesis. Recent developments in molecular imaging of specific cell surface markers using targeted contrast agents, imaging markers for gene expression and enzymatic activity, and tracking recruitment of vascular cells further expanded the repertoire for MRI of angiogenesis. MRI provides a comprehensive multiparametric view of the entire angiogenic process. Since its introduction in 1992, CT angiography (CTA) of the pulmonary arteries has become the main diagnostic test for the evaluation of pulmonary embolism (PE). The introduction of multi-detector CT scanners a few years later has in many ways changed its diagnostic yield. With the advent of multi-detector scanning, CTA has gained substantially in image acquisition speed and spatial resolution. Shortening of image acquisition times not only reduces the breath hold and examination time for the patient, it also allows limitation of the required amount of contrast material dose to achieve high and consistent enhancement of the pulmonary arteries. Submillimeter image acquisition protocols increase the spatial resolution along the z-axis and generate nearly isotropic data sets that allow post-processing ranging from relatively simple multiplanar reconstructions to volume rendering techniques with the same high spatial resolutions as the original axial sections. However, with the development of these fast multi-detector scanning techniques, it is of outmost importance to pay close attention to radiation dose and optimizing the scanning technique and contrast injection in order to obtain studies of uniformly high quality. Furthermore, there are a few sources of misinterpretation that should be known. As compared to single-slice CTA, some of them are less frequent with multi-detector CTA whereas others are found more frequently. This lecture focuses on multi-detector CTA and discusses the imaging technique and interpretation.
A 39 B C D E F G Learning Objectives:

1. To understand the effect of CT equipment (4-to 64-row scanners) on the choice of the optimal image acquisition and contrast medium injection protocols. 2. To learn how dose can be minimised without compromising image quality. 3 . To learn about the sources of misinterpretation with multi-detector CTA and to avoid pitfalls. 4. To become familiar with the different 3D-processing techniques that can be used to improve the interpretation of CTA for PE.
A-122 09:00 B. The dyspnoeic patient: Which diagnostic strategy?

Dyspnoea is a common symptom that can result from a range of conditions with various clinical presentations (acute, subacute and chronic) and with many possible associated signs and symptoms. The most common causes of acute or subacute dyspnoea are cardiogenic, such as congestive heart failure, acute myocardial infarction and arrhytmias, or pulmonary, such as exacerbations of COPD and asthma, pulmonary embolism, pneumothorax, pulmonary infections and upper airway obstruction.An integrated diagnostic strategy is mandatory to achieve a correct diagnosis, reducing delays that can lead patients even to death. Some of the causes can be identified by clinical examination, but other causes can be insidious, requiring further diagnostic exams that comprehend evaluation of some biomarkers and radiological tests, such as chest X-ray and multidector computed tomography pulmonary angiography (MDCT PA). MDCT is able to provide detailed information on pulmonary arteries, aorta, coronary arteries, heart and lung parenchyma at the same time, giving a comprehensive assessment of cardiac and noncardiac causes of dyspnoea in stable emergency department patients, with a good overall sensitivity and specificity. In this context, pulmonary embolism remains a diagnostic challenge and dyspnoea is a common presentation symptom; an accurate assessment of pre-test probability that involves clinical evaluation, laboratory tests and, in some cases, even chest X-ray has a key role in the diagnostic algorithm. When pre-test probability is intermediate or high, MDCT is the method of choice to achieve the definite diagnosis with a high sensitivity and negative predictive value, and with an high percentage of alternative diagnosis identification. Multidetector-row computed tomographic (CT) angiography of the pulmonary arteries is the first-line imaging technique in patients suspected of having pulmonary embolism (PE). Patient risk stratification is important because optimal management, monitoring and therapeutic strategies depend on the patient's prognosis. Acute right-sided heart failure is known to be responsible for circulatory collapse and death in patients with severe PE, and can be assessed on CT pulmonary angiography by measuring the dimensions of the right-sided heart cavities or systemic veins. The magnitude of PE can be calculated on CT pulmonary angiography by applying dedicated CT scores or adapted angiographic scores. This information can be combined with clinical data such as the Wells score. However, small pulmonary emboli may go undetected in patients who do not present typical clinical signs or whose symptoms are not attributed to PE. To date, there is limited knowledge about such incidental undetected cases of acute PE in patients who undergo multidetector row CT of the chest, and how the severity of PE in combination with other morbidity factors influences the natural course of the disease in patients treated for PE in comparison with those receiving no treatment. This refresher course reviews CT-based scoring methods for assessment of patients with acute PE. The various CT-based methods for risk stratification and their potential value for a combination with clinical scoring system such as the Wells score are discussed. A comprehensive review of imaging strategies for patients with incidental and minor subsegmental PE is given.
Learning Objectives:

1. To learn about the frequency and prognostic significance of mild pulmonary embolism with one-year outcomes in high-risk patient cohorts. 2. To improve the diagnostic skills in detection and severity assessment of acute pulmonary embolism using CTA. 3. To stratify patients with acute PE according to high and low mortality risk using combined clinical and CT-based scoring techniques. Acute pancreatitis is a common disease with inflammatory and necrotic process of the pancreas and the peripancreatic field. This is one of the most complex and dramatic pathologies of the abdomen, which needs urgent therapy. The degree, stage and preferable therapy are based on the early evaluation of the first exacerbation. Diagnosis can be obtained from serum amylase and lipase levels. Chronic pancreatitis (CP) is characterized by inflammatory changes of the pancreas with fibrosis formation, resulting in irreversible morphological and functional damage of the gland. The predominant etiology is alcohol abuse, with drug-induced, hyperlipoproteinemic, hereditary and idiopathic forms being less common. Staging of chronic pancreatitis according to the Cambridge classification is based on imaging, which can demonstrate the ductal changes with strictures and duct stones. MRCP ist the modality of choice for noninvasive imaging of ductal changes to guide endosopic interventional therapy. The risk of developing pancreatic cancer is increased by the factor of 16 in patients with chronic pancreatitis. During imaging surveillance of patients with CP, early signs of pancreatic cancer should be noted. To make the differential diagnosis even more challenging, in approximately 20% patients with CP, a mass-forming type of pancreatitis is observed, which may be confused with cancer. Imaging features of CP without and with signs of cancer will be presented. The "duct penetrating sign" is most helpful in allowing a reliable diagnosis. Strategies to increase diagnostic confidence are shown. A rare segmental form of CP is groove pancreatitis, which is also known under the synonym of cystic dystrophy of the duodenum. It affects the "groove" between the pancreatic head and the duodenum, resulting in a mass with subsequent duodenal stenosis, often masquerading as pancreatic cancer. The CT and MRI features of groove pancreatitis will be presented. Awareness of this diagnosis may help to avoid unnecessary surgery. Learning Objectives:

1. To review the imaging findings of chronic pancreatitis. 2. To describe the role of imaging for differentiation between chronic pancreatitis and tumor. 3. To present the imaging features of unusual types of chronic pancreatitis (i.e., groove pancreatitis).

The diagnosis of acute pancreatitis is generally based on clinical and laboratory findings. However, CT is the imaging technique of choice for detecting complications. Patients with complicated pancreatitis require multiple follow-up examinations. Substitution of US or MRI for CT in certain cases would reduce the radiation dose considerably. Complicated pseudocyst and other pancreatic collections may contain solid debris, which is best depicted by MRI. Necrosis may be also better identified on MRI than CT. Abscesses are suggested when gas is present in a pancreatic or peripancreatic collection. MRI can reveal air-fluid levels or large pockets of gas, but CT is more sensitive for small gas collections. Hemorrhage can occur in patients with severe necrotizing pancreatitis or as a result of the rupture of a pseudoaneurysm. Hemorrhagic fluid collections are more evident and remain visible longer on MRI than on CT. Pseudoaneurysms most frequently involve the splenic, gastroduodenal and pancreaticoduodenal arteries. Contrast-enhanced US, CT or MRI confirm the diagnosis. Venous thrombosis of the splenic, portal or superior mesenteric veins is also well visualized on contrast-enhanced images. Short gastric and gastroepiploic collaterals constitute useful complementary findings in chronic thrombosis. US or CT-guided percutaneous drainage of pancreatic pseudocysts or abscesses is a useful therapeutic approach in acute cases, while its use is complementary to surgery in the treatment of complicated chronic pancreatitis. EUS-guided transgastric stent placement is recommended if pseudocysts are in close proximity to the stomach. CT-guided thrombin injection into a splenic pseudoaneurysm lumen may also result in complete occlusion. Pelvic floor dysfunction (PFD) corresponds to a wide variety of clinical conditions including stress urinary incontinence (SUI), pelvic organ prolapse (POP), fecal incontinence, defecatory dysfunction, sexual dysfunction and several chronic pain syndromes. The first three conditions are the most common clinical conditions. Although, multiple factors predispose for PFD, the precise pathological mechanism is poorly understood, and treatment is often started irrespective of the specific anatomic lesion involved. Subsequently, postoperative recurrence rates of 30% in population-based studies, and more than 50% in females presenting to tertiary referral centers have been reported after successful surgical procedures possibly due to a lack of understanding of normal anatomy and physiology of the pelvic floor. Since MRI has evolved as an optimal method for evaluation of PFD, static MR imaging has delineated each component of the pelvic organ support system, including the anal sphincter complex, while dynamic (cine) MR imaging has been performed for functional evaluation to assess pelvic floor relaxation and pelvic organ descent. In this lecture, the MR imaging features of normal and abnormal pelvic organ support system will be reviewed. Based on detailed combined static and dynamic information and their correlation in the same patient, MRI can help to understand normal and abnormal pelvic floor function-structure relationship.
body_text.section: C. Complications of pancreatitis C. Triantopoulou; Athens/GR (chatri@mycosmos.gr)

body_text.text: Learning Objectives: 1. To become familiar with normal anatomy of the pelvic floor supporting systems on MRI. 2. To identify the types of defects in each supporting system and how to classify them. 3. To understand how anatomical defects detected at static images can affect the type of functional abnormality of the pelvic floor supporting elements at dynamic images. 4. To discuss how the MR findings at static and dynamic images can be reported in an easy, systematic and comprehensive way.
body_text.section: C. Complications of pancreatitis C. Triantopoulou; Athens/GR (chatri@mycosmos.gr)

body_text.text: Pelvic floor dysfunction with genital descensus, incontinence or stool outlet obstruction are common problems, especially among elderly women. Main risk factors are vaginal delivery, age, obesity and constipation. Functional cine MRI allows an excellent imaging of all structures of the pelvic floor and their interaction during straining and evacuation. An enourmous advantage over conventional defecography or colpocystorectography is the excellent soft tissue contrast, which allows a direct visualization of all pelvic organs and structures. Moreover, as no iv contrast medium and no radiation exposure is needed, the examination can be repeated if necessary. This lecture reviews the correct indications for cine MRI of the pelvis and provides detailed instructions on how to perform the examination. We give explanations on how to interpret the images and how to evaluate the position and range of movement of the pelvic organs using reference lines (pubococcygeal reference line). Subsequently, we show examples of normal anatomical findings as well as of pathological findings. We will present typical diagnoses of pelvic floor dysfunction for all three pelvic compartments, e.g., cystocele, bladder neck fixation after surgery, uterine descent, enterocele, anterior and lateral rectoceles, rectal intussusception, signs of insufficiency of the levator ani muscle and paradox contraction. In summary, the lecture illustrates the usefulness and superiority of functional MRI of the pelvic floor to conventional X-ray procedures and gives clear instructions on when and how to perform it and how to interpret the images. Functional cine MRI should be the modality of choice in patients with pelvic floor dysfunction. Ultrasound offers major advantages over X-rays or MRI for imaging pelvic floor diseases. It provides good soft-tissue morphologic analysis of the urethrovesical junction and anal canal, in addition to a dynamic bladder neck imaging with quantified movements. Examinations are easy, relatively quick (10-15 min) and inexpensive. Evaluation is limited, however, to the lowest pelvic compartments and requires operators to have experience and knowledge of urodynamics. Three different approaches to ultrasound are available, namely external ultrasound (transabdominal, perineal, and introital); endosonography (transvaginal and transrectal); and endoluminal (intraurethral). Perineal and introital ultrasound seem to be the easiest techniques and use a common endoluminal probe. Evaluation is first performed at rest in the lateral decubitus with knee flexion and in the standing position. Dynamic studies are then carried out during pelvic floor contraction and maximum straining in each position. Posterior canal anal defects are well evaluated easily, especially all types of internal sphincter pattern and collections. An ultrasound assessment of bladder neck descent has good reproducibility using the perineal approach. ECR 2008 is an important date in the history of European-German radiology. With Prof. Maximilian Reiser as the President of Congress, Germany is one of the hosted countries in the "ESR meets-programme". It is an honour and privilege to present four German speakers in this session addressing the use of CAD in mammography, the lungs, the colon, and the liver. German academic radiology has always had its place at the forefront of European radiology. It is our aim to share with the audience the use of CAD as another field where German radiology contributes to the considerable advances in European radiology. In mammography, computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) can help to improve breast cancer detection by pointing out potential lesions to the radiologist, which otherwise would have been missed. Current commercial CAD systems achieve a sensitivity of more than 98% for microcalcifications and 80-90% for masses. The sensitivity of CAD schemes for the detection of microcalcifications is so high, that some groups have proposed the use of CAD as a preprocessing tool for microcalcifications in soft-copy reading, showing only those areas of the digital mammogram in full resolution, where potential microcalcifications were found by the computer. Several clinical studies have demonstrated that by using CAD more, and smaller, cancers can be detected, usually at the expense of a slightly higher recall rate. The usefulness of CAD will vary with the mammography experience of the reader, and thorough training in the use of the CAD system will improve results. One major problem of CAD is the still relatively high number of false-positive computer marks, on average between one and two per case, which means that in a screening situation often less than 1 in 100 computer prompts will actually represent cancer. Future applications of CAD include prescreening, where a radiologist would no longer need to look at all at a mammogram with no computer-detected abnormalities, and double reading with CAD, where one of the human readers in the double reading process would be replaced by the computer. Comprehensive imaging of smoking-associated diseases represents a major challenge to radiology. CT can be used as the workhorse in this field, potentially complemented by MRI. Smoking causes or at least substantially increases the risk for multiple diseases. Most of them are located within the chest, such as pulmonary nodules and lung cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and emphysema as well as arteriosclerosis affecting the coronaries, aorta and supraaortic vessels. Quantification of the extent and severity of these manifestations is crucial for management, decisions on further work-up and treatment as well as longitudinal monitoring. CAD tools for detection and volumetry of pulmonary nodules as well as calculation of doubling times during follow-up are well established.
body_text.section: B. Functional MRI: When and how? T. Fischer; Munich/DE

body_text.text: Although the range of error of these measurements is still broad and multiple effectors have been investigated, most tools are robust enough to support changes in management. However, CAD for pulmonary nodules has not yet been combined with CAD tools to assess COPD measuring airway disease (bronchial diameter, wall thickness, skeletonization) as well as parenchymal destruction (mean lung density, emphysema index). More sophisticated CAD tools even provide cluster analysis or texture classification. CAD analysis of air trapping as a sign of small airway disease and often encountered in smokers is still work in progress. Since vascular disease is another hallmark of smoking, CAD-based assessment of calcifications is required for a comprehensive work-up. Coronary calcifications are assessed by the Agatston score, whereas no score is available for calcifications of the aorta and supra-aortic vessels. Learning Objectives:
body_text.section: B. Functional MRI: When and how? T. Fischer; Munich/DE

body_text.text: 1. To consolidate knowledge of the benefit of software assistance to detect lung nodules. 2. To understand the rationale for CAD in airway disease and emphysema. 3 . To learn about the advantages of quantification of lung disease severity for staging and monitoring. 4. To become familiar with multi dimensional imaging for the analysis of perfusion and respiratory motion.
body_text.section: B. Functional MRI: When and how? T. Fischer; Munich/DE

body_text.text: Virtual colonography was first introduced in 1994 using CT data and advanced post processing after colon distensions to simulate an endoscopic fly through of the colon. Both CT and MRI have been shown to have potential for the detection of colon polyps and masses and are best referred to as CT or MR colonography (CTC, MRC). Although studies were able to show that CTC (and to a lesser extent MRC) is capable of detecting relevant polyps, open issues include the wide variability in reported sensitivities of different groups, the time-consuming evaluation combining 2D and 3D approaches and training issues including a known learning curve. Computer-aided detection (CAD) of polyps is intended to help reach constantly high sensitivities by reducing observational oversights and to flatten or shorten the learning curve for interpreting CTC or MRC cases. The principal method of CAD in colonography is the identification of polyp candidates according to characteristic features after colon extraction from the 3D data set followed by the differentiation of polyps or false positives. CAD can be used either in a "first reader" or "second reader" manner. CAD as first reader marks potential findings, and the radiologist evaluates these findings only, ignoring the rest of the data set. CAD used as second reader marks potential findings after the initial read and the radiologist re-evaluates each finding. Although this seems to be the way to go, some doubt whether it is realistic that readers will be able to resist turning on to CAD before their own evaluation. Learning Objectives: 1. To provide an overview over potential benefits of CAD in CT colonography and to understand how CAD may be used to improve diagnostic performance in the detection of polyps and masses. 2. To understand different CAD approaches in CTC and to learn about current detection performance for colorectal polyps. 3. To understand potential pitfalls in CAD.

Computational medical imaging improves diagnostic accuracy as well as planning, monitoring, and assessment of liver tumor therapy. The lecture explores three different aspects of computer aided diagnosis and therapy: response evaluation in chemo therapy, surgery planning, and radio frequency ablation. Computer aided volumetry can cut the errors in evaluating the response to treatment of solid tumors. Automatic segmentation of liver metastases and volumetric measurement of tumor growth can improve the diagnostic accuracy and decrease the number of misclassifications dramatically in staging tumor response to chemo therapy. The lecture also covers the assessment of the remnant function in complex liver surgery based on computer aided risk evaluation and surgery planning. Computer aided analysis of preoperative CT o MR data, including the analysis of the vessel systems and the calculation of the tissue volumes supplied from different vessel branches, is crucial for the choice of resection strategies in liver tumor surgery. Computer aided methods have enormous potential in optimizing the results of CT/MR-guided radio frequency ablation of liver lesions. The precise planning of applicator positioning and a numerical, patient individual estimation of the coagulation area combined with image guided navigation leads to a more reliable destruction of tumor tissue. Trauma is the leading cause of death in young people in the Western world. National statistics, where available, suggest that many more people under 40 die from trauma than from common cancers at the same age. The cost to health-care systems is in billions of Euros and thousands are left disabled. Early and late deaths are almost always the result of haemorrhage. It has been estimated that 1:3 trauma deaths are avoidable. The ATLS manual is the "bible" of the trauma doctor. Like all bibles it has much that is good, but it can be dangerous in the hands of those that interpret it rigidly. It makes very little mention of radiology and even the latest version is sadly out of date. Much has happened in imaging and endovascular intervention over the last 10-30 years, which many trauma doctors are unwilling or too prejudiced to take advantage of. Radiologists have played their part in this by building radiology departments for themselves and not putting patients first. This lecture will focus on these issues and ask why radiologists are not leading the field and shouting loudly about innovations that could save many young lives.

To understand the importance of an accurate diagnosis since patients die from even the most innocuous vascular injuries because the principles of damage control are often ignored. 3. To be familiar with embolic agents in trauma and their methods of deployment which may depend on many factors including the patients clinical status, the amount of blood transfused and the collateral supply of the end organ that is bleeding.

body_text.text: Vertebral compression fracture is an important cause of severe debilitating back pain, adversely affecting quality of life, physical function, psychosocial performance, mental health and survival. Its diverse etiology encompasses osteoporosis, neoplastic vertebral involvement (myeloma, metastasis, lymphoma, hemangioma) and osteonecrosis. Percutaneous vertebroplasty (PVP) is a therapeutic, image-guided procedure that involves injection of radio-opaque cement into a collapsed vertebral body, in an effort to relieve pain and provide stability. The ideal candidate for PVP is one who presents within 4 months. Ideally, patients should have at least 3 weeks of conservative treatment. Intervention within days of a painful VCF is considered in patients at high risk for decubitus complications. An experienced operator who has been adequately trained in the procedure should perform PVP. The procedure can be performed under local anesthesia and sedo-analgesia or general anesthesia. The classical transpedicular route is preferred in the thoracic and lumbar vertebrae. This can be performed either by a unipedicular or bipedicular approach. An intercostovertebral route is useful in the thoracic spine when the pedicle is too small or destroyed. In the cervical vertebrae, the anterolateral approach is used. High-quality fluoroscopy should be available for adequate visualization of the cement during injection in the early detection of leaks. The complications of PVP are rare, but could be life threatening. How major complications could be to reduced or avoided will be described. The most critical elements for a successful vertebroplasty are proper patient selection, correct needle placement, good timing with injection of pasty cement, appropriate monitoring and operator training. A current trend in MRI is a move to higher magnetic field strengths to take advantage of the superior signal sensitivity. The purpose of this talk is to present some of the transient physiologic effects that have been associated with exposure to the various electromagnetic fields of MR imagers and to illustrate their practical impact on performing patient examinations at very high field (7 T). Current regulations regarding the operation of high field and very high field MRI scanners will be reviewed. Emphasis will be put on the differing regulations regarding patient exposure and occupational exposure of health care works and service personnel. Currently, magnetic field strengths above 4 T are not considered to be suitable for patient examinations except within the purview of the ethics committee approval. New legislation at the EU level might restrict worker activity in and around MR scanners even at fields below the 4 T level. Finally, the ethical implications of performing human studies at 7 T will be discussed. Learning Objectives:

1. To learn about the physiologic effects associated with the electromagnetic fields of MR imagers. 2. To review the current standards and regulations governing the exposure of patients and workers to these electromagnetic fields. 3. To become familiar with the ethical prerequisites for performing studies in humans at very high field (7 Tesla).

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the human body has been widely introduced some 25 years ago and is still one of the fastest developing fields in clinical diagnostic, clinical research, and neuroscientific studies. While 1.5 T has been accepted as the best compromise for clinical imaging for many years, the introduction of 3-T clinical MRI over the past few years has shown to clearly improve image quality. Currently, 7-T whole-body MRI systems are being installed in a number of research laboratories. The main driving argument behind the quest for higher and higher field strength is the increased signal-to-noise ratio obtainable. In neuroscientific applications, the increased BOLD (blood oxygen level dependent) effect that allows the detection of brain activity is another driving force. However, a number of methodological obstacles have to be overcome to make ultra-high field MRI as a valuable tool for a wide range of applications. The main limitations are the RF-energy deposited in the subject and the RF-homogeneity across the object. To cope with these challenges, modifications to existing acquisition methods A 43 B C D E F G are necessary to exploit the potential of the ultra-high magnetic field. In addition, many practical points have to be taken into consideration for the installation of a human whole-body 7-T system. Among these are the size, weight and magnetic fringe field of the magnet. With current systems siting in a clinical environment is challenging and costs are significant. Learning Objectives:
body_text.section: Physical implications of a 7 Tesla MRI installation

body_text.text: 1. To comprehend the physical implications of higher magnetic field strength and thus reduced RF wave length with regard to imaging of human subjects. 2. To understand method to compensate for high RF-power absorption (SAR) and inhomogeneous radio frequency excitation and reception. 3. To become familiar with the possibilities and limitations of very high field imaging.

body_text.text: Future impact of the 7 Tesla MRI in the clinical applications R.W. Bowtell; Nottingham/UK (richard.bowtell@nottingham.ac.uk)

The availability of magnetic resonance (MR) scanners operating at fields of 7 T and above has already been proved to be highly beneficial for MR imaging and spectroscopy of the human brain and promises similar benefits in the human body. These advantages result from the increases with the magnetic field of the intrinsic signal-to-noise ratio, blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast, which forms the basis of the vast majority of functional MR imaging (fMRI) experiments, and chemical shift dispersion. These gains can be exploited in improving the spatial and/or temporal resolution of anatomical and functional MRI experiments and in increasing the spectral resolution in volume selective spectroscopy or chemical shift imaging. Operation at the increased magnetic field also offers easier access to T 2 * -contrast and improved implementation of susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI), in which the phase of gradient echo images provides information about local variation of magnetic susceptibility. In the brain, such variation appears to be dominated by heterogeneity of iron concentration so that high-field SWI may provide useful information about the progression of neurodegenerative disease. Current and potential future applications of high-field MRI in clinical and pre-clinical studies in a number of areas will be discussed in this presentation. Imaging speed in magnetic resonance (MR) is a compromise among spatial resolution, signal-to-noise ratio, volume coverage, image quality and image contrast.

Pushing the speed limit is thus tightly linked to improvements in signal-to-noise ratio by more and better coils and/or higher fields and/or other means like hyperpolarization. Parallel imaging is already well established in 2D-imaging. Dramatic increases in imaging speed in 3D-examinations and/or in repetitive scans like cine imaging are just beginning and will lead to further progress significantly with further sophistication of coil design and reconstruction algorithms. As an extreme case of parallelization techniques like MR-encephalography have already shown to allow examination of physiological changes at 100 fps and more. Increasing imaging speed by acceleration of gradient switching has reached limits set by neuronal stimulation. New concepts based on non-linear, non-Cartesian gradients carry the potential to allow significant increase in gradient performance within physiological limits. An extremely intense field of current research is the developmental techniques to encode images with a dramatically reduced number of acquired data. Approaches like compressed sensing and HYPR can increase imaging speed by several orders of magnitude without loss in significant information. MR as we know it is reaching a status of high sophistication, nevertheless it can be expected that ongoing developments based on fundamental different approaches will lead to dramatic changes. In the bigger picture of optimizing patient care, one needs to be aware that good and reliable diagnosis leading to correct and curative therapy is the first priority in speeding up good patient care. Some radiological aspects seen on upper abdominal imaging studies are quite specific and/or suggestive of certain pathologies and, if correctly integrated in the clinical context, may provide important clues to the correct diagnosis. The central dot sign relates to the presence of vascular components adjacent to a cystic-like structure and should recall the diagnosis of Caroli's disease. Transient hepatic attenuation differences (THAD) are well-defined areas of parenchymal enhancement recognized in the arterial phase of the dynamic liver imaging. THAD reflects a local vascular disturbance and may be due to portal venous inflow obstruction, hepatic vein obstruction, intrahepatic vascular shunts, etc. Capsular retraction is a non-specific finding generally associated with malignant focal lesions. Although more frequently observed with intra-hepatic cholangiocarcinoma, epithelioid haemangioendothelioma or metastases with a fibrotic component, it may also be associated with benign liver entities. Spontaneous T1-weighted hyperintensity of a liver tumour is a useful sign that allows to straighten the differential diagnosis. The main causes for this peculiar finding will be addressed. The penetrating duct sign is a subtle finding favoring the diagnosis of chronic focal pancreatitis instead of pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Although more easily depicted on MRCP images, this sign may also be observed in other cross-sectional techniques. Many diseases that affect the gastro-intestinal tract have, at first sight, similar signs in imaging: wall thickening, changes in perfusion, changes in the luminal diameter, and reactive changes of the neighbouring tissues. These signs may be present focally or in larger segments of the bowels, both the small and large intestines. In order to be able to differentiate the extent of disease, optimal distension of the intestinal lumen is important, together with tailored injection protocols for intravenous contrast administration. In search of the underlying reason for small bowel obstruction, detection of the transition zone and the faecal sign in the part of the small bowel proximal to the stenosis may give important clues for the differential diagnosis. Detection of ischaemic bowel disease can be the most difficult task in critically ill patients; thorough evaluation of the mesenteric vascular tree, identification of air bubbles attached or within the bowel wall, as well as the differentiation of venous or arterial disease based on the imaging signs can be essential. Finally, some neoplasms of the gastro-intestinal tract exhibit specific imaging features by which they can be identified and correctly staged. The imaging of a suspected musculoskeletal tumour requires a pragmatic approach commencing with detection and diagnosis. The majority of bone tumours are first identified on radiographs. Ultrasound may be used to detect and to some extent characterize soft tissue masses. The long recognized contrast resolution and multiplanar capability of MRI means that it is excellent in detecting both bony and soft tissue abnormalities.
