Radiographs remain pre-eminent in the diagnosis of bone tumours, but close attention to the MRI signal characteristics and morphological features will allow further characterization in some cases. MRI allows accurate diagnosis of approximately 50% of soft tissue masses. In the remaining cases, depending on the clinical picture, biopsy may be required. The main role of MRI in musculoskeletal tumours is in the surgical staging of the primary lesion. This should accurately identify the full extent of the tumour in bone and soft tissue, the relationship to the nearby joint and neurovascular bundle and confirm/exclude skip metastases. MRI may be used in the follow-up of these patients to detect local recurrence of the tumour and postoperative complications (seroma, etc. MR imaging is generally the most sensitive and specific imaging modality for inflammatory and infectious diseases of the musculoskeletal system, which makes it the modality of choice for these pathologies. Whole body MRI is of particular importance in the imaging of inflammatory diseases where frequently initially clinically silent areas of involvement are seen. The definition of the extent and distribution of lesions aids in narrowing the differential diagnosis. Especially in infection, imaging should normally be complemented by biopsy to establish a histological/microbiological diagnosis and to exclude other disease entities such as malignancies. The assessment of treatment response in inflammatory or infectious disease is often challenging. MR imaging plays an important role, but all other imaging modalities can contribute valuable information. Especially for the assessment of the response to disease-modifying drugs in inflammatory disorders, MRI is establishing itself as an important quantifiable imaging method. Contrast medium enhancement is often valuable, but not always necessary. Other parameters such as the extent of synovitis, size of bone erosions and bone marrow oedema are also important and often sufficient markers. Image detail is very important when focal and especially when diffuse lung disease is studied with CT. A high image detail is not only necessary to detect small pulmonary changes and to study their characteristics, but also for a good topographical visualisation of the lung anatomy. Diagnosis of lung diseases with CT is indeed not only based on the study of the characteristics of the abnormalities, but also on the study of their regional distribution and in determining their distribution in relation to the anatomical structures of the lung. Recognising the normal and abnormal elements of a secondary pulmonary lobule is for example very important in diagnosing diffuse lung disease. High-detail images can be made using the "classical" (discontinuous) HRCT acquisition technique, usually producing 1-1.5 mm thick sections every 1-2 cm. With modern 16-64 slice scanners, it is possible to acquire the whole chest in a high-resolution mode. Not only thin-HRCT sections can be reconstructed, but also thick 5 mm-and high-detail coronal sections can be made allowing, respectively, a better evaluation of nodular opacities and of the mediastinum and an additional, often better, view of the distribution of the disease within the chest and within the secondary pulmonary lobule. Both acquisition methods have advantages and limitations, but it can be expected that the MDCT volume acquisition method will become the major player even in the study of diffuse lung disease. Lung cancer screening utilizing low dose CT has been an active area of investigation for the past decade. Encouraging survival results have led proponents to the conclusion that CT screening is effective and should be used in patient care. However, others point out that there are no studies that show a mortality reduction with CT screening and, therefore, screening should be delayed until those benefits are proven. The pros and cons of CT screening for lung cancer will be reviewed. A side benefit of the data collected in the CT screening studies has been a better understanding of the management of small ( 5 mm) nodules. It has been shown that there is a very small ( 1%) risk that a nodule 5 mm will be a lung cancer. Utilization of this knowledge in the formation of new management algorithms will allow radiologists to better manage these small nodules and benefit patients by allowing longer intervals between scans and fewer overall scans. Another evolving area in the evaluation of solitary pulmonary nodules is volumetric scanning that can allow the determination of volume doubling time of a nodule on scans performed as little as 1 month apart. This data will be discussed along with additional imaging modalities and imaging findings that the radiologist can use to help differentiate benign from malignant pulmonary nodules. Pulmonary function tests do not reflect regional differences in disease severity nor pathological processes that tend to counteract each other (i.e. interstitial lung disease associated with small airway obstruction). Blood gases measure overall gas exchanges and oxygenation, but do not detect regional impairment of lung perfusion or ventilation that induces compensatory changes on oxymetric uptake. Forced expiratory volume per second (FEV1) is affected by size and elastic lung properties, bronchial calibre and collapsibility of airways. MDCT provides isotropic data sets that offer the advantage of allowing multiplanar reformations of high quality and accurate assessment of the airways and pulmonary vessels. New postprocessing techniques contribute to quantitative assessment of lung volumes, airway dimension and extent of lung disease. Dynamic MDCT during forced expiratory manoeuvre helps assess air trapping and tracheobronchomalacia. In COPD patients, CT helps separate patients having emphysema or airway remodelling as their predominant phenotype. Reliable and reproducible CT quantification of emphysema is currently available and easy to perform. Both extent and mapping of emphysema account in the assessment of functional severity. Bronchial wall thickening measured at CT may be used as a surrogate marker for the presence of remodelling in the small airways. In asthma, the ability to follow-up bronchial wall area, bronchial reactivity and lung attenuation at expiration over time in patients receiving different treatments can provide an independent tool to assess therapies. Bronchial wall area measured at CT is related to the duration and severity of the disease, and reflects the degree of airway wall remodelling.

Learning Objectives: 1. To comprehend that pulmonary function test results do not reflect regional differences in disease severity, and, pathologic processes that tend to counteract each other are not reflected. 2. To understand how MDCT, providing accurate high resolution assessment of airway and lung disease at a regional level, may be a more sensitive input on clinical trials, and ultimately in a clinical management of individual asthmatic or COPD patients. 3. To become familiar with new post processing techniques permitting quantitative assessment of lung volumes, airway dimensions (airway reactivity, remodelling and collapsibility), and extent of lung disease (emphysema and small airway disease). The roles and competences of general practitioners in the field of radiology within Europe vary tremendously. The differences are due to different health care systems and their characteristics (referral system vs. direct access to specialists), the economic realities of the country and the development of the discipline. The policy of Wonca Europe is to stimulate cooperation between specialities within the health care system to enable better use of resources and better patient care. In this session, two speakers will present their point of view for the potential of the improvement of assessment of coronary arterial disease from a perspective of a general practitioner in a Mediterranean country and a radiologist from the Netherlands. Peripheral arterial obstructive disease (PAOD) is also a field of common interest of general practitioners and radiologists. The immense socioeconomic burden of this disease requires joint efforts of both disciplines in order to achieve adequate diagnosis and treatment. A stepwise, evidence based approach in primary care and radiological diagnosis and treatment will be addressed in this session. Session Objectives: 1. To compare points of view of general practitioners and radiologists in the assessment of coronary disease. 2. To discuss the relevance of guidelines. 3. To look at the potential use of coronary angiography in primary care in the future.

Assessment of coronary artery disease (part I: General practitioner) C. Lionis; Iraklion/GR (lionis@galinos.med.uoc.gr) Coronary artery disease (CAD) is one of the most chronic disorders in the western world and a leading cause of morbidity and mortality. There is some evidence that general practitioners (GPs) could contribute substantially to the assessment of the risk for the development of cardiovascular disease and diagnosis of CAD. This presentation aims at reviewing the different approaches for the assessment of that risk and in particular the following: (a) The clinical individual-based traditional diagnostic approach that is based on the clinical recognition of risk factors, the usage of diagnostic tests of uncertain diagnostic quality, and the usual care. (b) The clinical individual-based modern approach that recognises the multifactorial nature of this disease and uses the SCORE model and risk charts. (c) The epidemiological approach at the GP's office that uses pretest and posterior probabilities based on estimations given by the office EPR system based on episode of care (ICPC-2R). (d) The population-based approach, which uses medical records or community-oriented health prevention programmes to assess the population risk using different multifactorial risk models. Diagnostic probabilities of symptoms and signs recognised at the GP's office that indicate CAD will be discussed. Guidelines to all GPs will be presented. These target (i) patients without CAD whose symptoms suggest chronic stable angina, (ii) patients with known stable angina, and (iii) asymptomatic patients with evidence from previous testing. Procedural skills and diagnostic algorithms for evaluating patients suspected for CAD, including a standard treadmill exercise test (ETT), an ETT imaging, and a coronary angiography, will be provided. Learning Objectives:

1. To be familiar with the approaches and methods used to asses the risk for development of cardiovascular disease. 2. To discuss procedural skills and diagnostic algorithms for evaluating patients at risk for coronary artery disease. 3. To discuss links on diagnostic approaches between general practitioners and radiologists. Computed tomography (CT) coronary angiography permits non-invasive evaluation of both the coronary lumen and the coronary vessel wall. Coronary plaques can be detected and classified into calcified, non-calcified, and mixed plaques, and their impact on the coronary lumen can be evaluated. Moreover, CT coronary angiography permits evaluation of the extent (e.g. number of disease coronary segments), size, and anatomical distribution of coronary plaques. Recent literature indicates that such comprehensive assessment may have prognostic value and may aid in the risk stratification of patients suspected of coronary artery disease. Current CT resolution does not allow detection of certain vulnerable plaque characteristics such as a thin fibrous cap, a large lipid pool, or inflammation. Several publications reported on the potential of CT to further classify non-calcified plaques into lipid-rich and fibrous plaques on the basis of CT density values. Scarce data are available on the accuracy of CT to detect remodeling of the coronary vessel wall. However, current literature indicates that CT is able to detect both negative (inward) and positive (outward) remodeling, of which the latter is considered to be a marker of plaque vulnerability. A recent study reported on the use of a nanoparticulate contrast agent in rabbits, which can be used to detect macrophages at the level of atherosclerotic plaques. Such contrast agent could be an important adjunct to the clinical evaluation of coronary arteries with CT.
Learning Objective: 1. To discuss the potential of CT coronary angiography in the detection and classification of coronary plaques.
Patients with peripheral arterial obstructive disease (PAOD) in primary care (part I: General practitioner)

Patients with peripheral arterial occlusive disease (PAOD) are common in primary care, with an estimated prevalence of 4.5-7% among those aged 55-74. For their long-term care, the full spectrum of competencies of the general practitioner (GP), such as recognition of early symptoms, counselling for changes in life style, identification of acute potentially dangerous conditions, selection of appropriate additional investigations, informing about non-invasive and invasive forms of treatment, planning and provision of long-term care and follow-up management, selection of appropriate rehabilitative measures and motivation of the patient to comply with recommendations, is required. Of particular, relevance for the GP is the respect of the autonomy of the patient and his/her priorities. The skills to perform the physical examination and to identify individual risk factors are of prime importance in early diagnosis. Selection of the medically appropriate diagnostic procedure is required and consideration of costs and cost efficiency are mandatory in the public health sector for referral. Relevant co-morbidities have to be taken into account before non-invasive therapeutic options or invasive procedures are discussed with the patient. During follow-up and rehabilitation, the compliance of the patient and his/her functioning in daily life have to be addressed. Medical practice in a city or in a rural area causes different challenges to both the managing physician and the patient. Despite the technical developments of recent years, diagnostic workup of patients with PAOD at the primary care level follows a stepwise approach based on medical needs and consideration of cost efficiency. Long ago, vascular diseases have become the diagnostic challenge of the millennium since they are more prevalent and more deadly than many leading diseases. Their systemic character with a potential coincidence of peripheral, coronary, and cerebro-vascular manifestations causes the demand for an interdisciplinary diagnostic and therapeutic concept. The general practitioner plays a critical role within this concept since he will be regularly the first being confronted with typical symptoms, and furthermore will act as an interface between the different vascular specialists involved. Therefore, he inevitably needs to have detailed knowledge about state-of-the-art imaging modalities and endovascular and surgical treatment options. In the past decade, diagnostic imaging has evolved enormously and to date radiology can offer non-invasive highly sophisticated whole-body vessel imaging algorithms, either by computed tomography or by magnetic resonance imaging, and less capacious but more detailed invasive imaging by digital subtraction angiography with an option for immediate treatment. During the past decade diagnostic imaging and endovascular techniques both enormously have evolved. For that reason the endovascular approach meanwhile is considered as an important alternative to vascular surgery at least in some states of the disease and clinical conditions. This lecture gives an overview on state-of-the-art imaging modalities and endovascular treatment options for peripheral arterial disease, discusses their potentials and limitations, and tries to aid the general practitioner in the process of developing individual diagnostic and therapeutic concepts. Questions from the radiologist to the general practitioner as well as premises for the discussed imaging modalities and endovascular techniques as well as aftercare will be addressed. Osteoporosis is a healthcare-social problem of increasing relevance in developed countries, especially because of the rapid increase in the incidence of fragility fractures. The diagnosis of osteoporosis has been defined by WHO, on the basis of the assessment of bone mineral density (BMD), as a BMD -2.5 SD or more below the average value for premenopausal women. Severe osteoporosis denotes osteoporosis in the presence of one or more fragility fractures. Even if in the first years all measurable sites were equally considered valid for diagnosis, recently it was recognised that the most effective site for diagnosis is the proximal femur with dual energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA). Other skeletal sites (axial and appendicular) could also be evaluated by other validated densitometric techniques (QCT, QUS) for fracture prediction. Other clinical risk factors contribute to fracture risk independently of densitometric techniques. These include age, previous fragility fracture, premature menopause, a family history of hip fracture and the use of oral corticosteroids. Because of the many techniques for fracture risk assessment, the T-score approach to determine the risk of fracture appears to be lacking because of discrepancies among sites and techniques. The 10-year probability of fracture is the most effective approach to determine intervention thresholds. Many treatments can be provided cost-effectively to women on the basis of 10 years' probability of fracture.

Up to now, the values of 10 years' probability of fracture have been published for DXA and for phalangeal QUS techniques in the European population. Insufficiency fractures are defined as stress fractures that occur due to normal biomechanical loading in abnormally weak bone. They are commonly observed in patients with osteoporosis, but may also be found after radiation therapy or chemotherapy. Typical locations are the pelvis, sacrum and the spine. At the spine, MRI is very sensitive to differentiate acute and old vertebral insufficiency fractures, also these fractures have typical morphologic features that frequently allows their differentiation from neoplastic fractures. At the pelvis, insufficiency fractures are often located in more than one location, which affects imaging protocols, and coverage of the whole pelvis is generally recommended. Given frequent concurrent osteopenia in the patients, fractures are very difficult to diagnose on radiographs, and more than 40% of pelvic insufficiency fractures, in particular sacral fractures, are negative on radiographs. It should also be noted that CT detects only approximately 70% of the insufficiency fractures diagnosed with MRI. Typical combinations of insufficiency fractures are found, for example, pubic insufficiency fractures are in approximately 90% associated with fractures in another location, in particular the sacrum. At the knee, it has been now generally accepted that lesions previously described as spontaneous osteonecrosis of the knee are actually insufficiency fractures occurring typically in elderly patients ( 60 years). In summary, insufficiency fractures are a frequent pathology that need to be correctly diagnosed, and MRI currently is the most accurate imaging test to arrive at this diagnosis. However, radiologists have to be familiar with the typical features of these fractures. In the day-to-day practice of radiology, we use radiological signs in order to describe some crucial imaging findings in a summarized and didactic way. Regarding retroperitoneal imaging, the following signs will be analyzed: 1. The bear paw sign represents the CT appearance of a kidney with xantogranolumatous pyelonephritis. Complications, related conditions and differential diagnosis will also be discussed. 2. The psoas sign is a well-known radiological finding depicting loss of visualization of the psoas border in an abdominal plain film, thus indicating a perirrenal process. Some cases evaluated with plain film with CT correlation will be shown in order to understand its significance. 3. The term horseshoe kidney refers to the appearance of fused kidneys, which results from fusion at the lower pole. The embryologic explanation and the potential complications will be discussed. Examples of tumor, lithiasis and trauma will be shown. 4. The string of pearls sign is an angiographic sign that is virtually pathognomonic of fibromuscular dysplasia of the renal arteries. The differential diagnosis of abnormalities of the renal arteries will be briefly discussed. 5. The beak sign, when present, is useful in determining the tumor's origin from the retroperitoneal organs. 6. The embedded organ sign is complementary to the beak sign, and allows differentiating a mass compressing a specific organ or if this mass actually arose from the organ itself. The genitourinary organs in the pelvis include the ureters, the bladder, the urethra, the prostate and the seminal vesicles in males, the uterus and the ovaries in females. Different pathologies, inflammatory, traumatic and neoplastic, may affect these organs. The pelvic genitourinary organs may be examined by means of different imaging modalities, including conventional plain X-ray film of the abdomen, intravenous urography, ultrasonography, computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI; with CT and MR urography). In spite of the introduction of US, CT and MRI, intravenous urography still has a role in the evaluation of the ureters, the bladder and the urethra. Nevertheless, CT-urography and MR-urography reproduce the same findings of intravenous urography in most instances, therefore most of the considerations made about intravenous urography can be applied also to CT-and MR-urography. This presentation will review the features that can be seen with the different imaging modalities, which may be helpful to characterise a disease or to make a differential diagnosis. A greater emphasis will be given to the more common diseases such as urinary tract stones and different causes of urinary obstruction, with an overview of the most common signs on plain X-ray film, intravenous urography, US and CT. A review of the useful signs in the differential diagnosis of the pathologies that may affect the bladder, the prostate, the uterus and the ovaries with special emphasis on neoplastic conditions will also be made. Percutaneous biopsy can be used to confirm the diagnosis of suspected malignancy, and infections, and there is increasing evidence to suggest that biopsy can be used to sub-type and grade many primary renal cancers. Just as important, biopsy is being used also to diagnose benign renal tumors that are being detected with greater frequency with the burgeoning use of cross-sectional imaging for abdominal disorders. Incidental renal masses are common and need to be managed appropriately. With advances in imaging technology (largely with use of thin-section images), many incidental, small renal masses are being diagnosed confidently as enhancing and, therefore, solid. Because a considerable fraction of small, solid renal masses are benign, it is important to diagnose them to prevent them from being treated unnecessarily. Performing a biopsy after a full imaging work-up can prevent unnecessary and potentially morbid surgical and ablation procedures in a substantial number of patients. Although more data are needed to understand the overall accuracy of percutaneous biopsy in diagnosing benign renal masses, biopsy is capable of diagnosing many of them. In our experience, biopsy has been shown to be particularly helpful in diagnosing causes of renal masses that are small, hyperdense, and homogeneously enhancing. Masses with these features may be renal cancers, but are found commonly to be benign angiomyolipomas with minimal fat. This lecture reviews the literature and our experience with percutaneous renal mass biopsy, and details eight specific clinical settings in which biopsy results affect patient care. to increase the accuracy of this method. This paper reviews the basic and new techniques for breast MR imaging. The required MR pulse sequences will be described.

In addition, the technical elements to perform high-resolution, dynamic breast MRI as well as image post-processing and interpretation of time-enhancement curves will be described. The use of MR spectroscopy as well as diffusion and perfusion imaging will be introduced. Future directions for breast MR imaging at 3 Tesla, and the potential role of "functional imaging" will be discussed. In the field of oncologic surgery, an accurate local staging, i.e. the delineation of local disease extent, is considered to be of key importance in patients with operable cancers. Imaging studies are used to provide an accurate road map for the surgeon to help him or her obtain clear margins. It is well established that breast MRI is by far superior to mammography, with or without concomitant ultrasound, for the local staging of breast cancer. MRI allows the most accurate delineation of the size and the local extent of cancer, including the depiction of multifocal, multicentric or contralateral disease. MRI offers the highest sensitivity for demonstrating intraductal extensions around invasive cancers. For all these reasons, MRI should be considered an integral part of the workup of patients who undergo breast conserving treatment. And yet, the technique is only slowly adopted in clinical practice. Arguments against the use of breast MRI include costs, frequency of false positive diagnoses, lack of availability of minimally invasive biopsy capabilities, lack of evidence by randomized controlled clinical trials, and, last, fear of overtreatment. In this lecture, these concerns are explained, discussed and weighted against the advantages of MRI for breast cancer staging. The point is made that breast MRI is indeed essential for surgical planning, but that unnecessary mastectomy may result if old guidelines (established for mammographic staging) are used to guide management decisions regarding MR-detected lesions. Guidelines that require mastectomy for multicentric breast cancer were established before the advent of MRI. Using the same guidelines to manage MR-detected multicentric foci may be inappropriate because some of the small MRI-detected multicentric foci may be sufficiently treated by additional lumpectomy or even by radiation therapy alone. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NC) has become the standard treatment for patients with advanced breast cancers and is now a potential treatment for patients with earlier-stage operable disease. Pathological response of tumours to NC appears to correlate with the outcome. The advantage of NC is that it not only increases breast-conserving surgery, but also enables direct in vivo assessment of response. Breast imaging is used to evaluate the shrinkage of tumour under treatment and to try determine responders. Physical examination associated with mammography and ultrasound is a valuable noninvasive combination for assessing tumour response. At this time, this morphologic evaluation is the only one recognised by the international criteria. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the most accurate imaging modality for the assessment of response in terms of tumour size and detection of residual tumour after treatment. Flattening of the contrast uptake time-intensity curve after the first chemotherapy cycle and complete absence of contrast uptake after the fourth cycle are observed in responders. Conversely, the detection of a persistent wash-out phenomenon in residual tumour allows prediction of nonresponders. Like other functional imaging modalities proposed for the assessment of response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy, MRI is also restricted in the imaging of very small residual tumour foci. Studying the effect of NC will demonstrate the accuracy of these complementary functional imaging techniques. The signal intensities of normal structures and pathological findings on conventional T1-and T2-weighted MR images depend on many factors. The amount of water, proton density, chemical structure and or/binding, presence or absence of flow (of blood or CSF), calcification, fat, blood degradation products, melanin, mucine and even air are all factors that influence the signal characteristics. T1-and T2-lenghtening is the rule in most tumoral, vascular and infectious lesions and therefore is rather unspecific. T1-and T2-shortening can be due to the presence of fat (lipoma), melanin (melanoma and metastasis of melanoma), mucine (metastasis of sigmoid carcinoma), colloid material (colloid cyst, Rathke cleft cyst) and even calcification (falx!). T1-shortening with T2-lenghtening can be due to cholesterine (cholesterol granuloma, craniopharyngioma), high protein content (tumoral cysts) and methemoglobin (late hemorrhage, thrombus). T1-lenghtening and T2-shortening is almost exclusively due to deoxyhemoglobin. Acute hemorrhage and meningioma can be iso-intense on T1-weighted images, while some meningiomas and micrometastases can be iso-intense on T2-weighted images. Absence of signal can be due to high-velocity flowing blood (aneurysm, AVM, hypervascular tumours), high velocity flowing CSF (normal pressure hydrocephalus, cortical bone or extensive calcification, air and a large amount of iron (coils, clips). It is concluded that the simple use of a combination of T1-and T2-signal intensities on conventional MR images can be used to arrive at the diagnosis and differential diagnosis of brain lesions. The cortical anatomy is often perceived as a complicated, irregular arrangement of variable structures, which are difficult to differentiate and to identify. We will first review the overall subdivision of the brain into lobes and describe the boundaries of these lobes and their major gyri and sulci. We will then describe the location of specific functions such as the primary areas of sensorimotor function, speech, audition and vision. 1. Primary sensorimotor cortex: Motor is located in the precentral gyrus, sensory in the postcentral gyrus around the central sulcus (CS), hence the importance of always correctly identifying the CS. We will present four interlocked methods to identify the CS in the axial plane: a) knob, b) lateral axial, c) medial axial, d) gyral/cortical thickness and three to identify it in the sagittal plane: a) lateral sagittal, b) hook, c) medial sagittal. 2. Speech: Motor speech is located in the frontal operculum/anterior insula, whereas sensory is found around the sylvian fissure. 3. Primary auditory cortex (A1): Centered at the postero-medial part of Heschl's gyrus (HG), we will present simple landmarks to reliably identify the gyrus in each of the three planes: a) adhaesio interthalamica in the axial plane, b) the omega/heart shape of HG in the sagittal plane, c) the omega shape of HG in the coronal plane defined by the tent shape of the fornices. 4. Primary visual cortex (V1): Centered on the calcarine sulcus, we will discuss the characteristic shape that allows the identification of this structure in all three planes. The normal and variant anatomy will be briefly reviewed. Major physiological principles will also be discussed: venous resistance and peripheral venous pressure; the effect of changes in right atrial, intraabdominal and gravitational pressure on lower limb venous pressure; venous valves, calve muscle pump and respiratory pump (changes in thoracic and abdominal pressures during the respiratory cycle). Direct venous pressure measurements in standing position show approximately 80 mmHg ankle pressure; tiptoe dorsiflexion in normal subjects, operating the calf muscle pump, lowers the ankle pressure to 20-30 mmHg. In deep vein incompetence, the muscle compartment never fully empties and rapidly refills with refluxing blood. Ambulatory venous pressure measurements or pletysmography is an important indicator for considering operative or endovascular therapy in case of venous valve incompetence causing varicose veins. Recent studies using noninvasive assessment of human large vein diameter, distensibility and ellipticity in situ showed that femoral veins are highly distensible in the reclined position, but are rigid tubes in the standing position. Aging decreases the distensibility of the femoral vein in the reclined position. In situ distensibility of femoral veins on the side of previous thrombosis as well as the disease-free side is reduced in the young DVT patients, compared to veins of the age-matched, healthy controls. The pathophysiological mechanism of generalized venous wall changes in these young DVT patients remains unknown. Sonography of the venous system in the diagnosis of venous diseases is now considered as a reference method. Its main application is based on dynamic Bmode evaluation of the venous permeability to rule out venous thrombosis. The Doppler mode may help for examination of distal veins and to separate acute and chronic thrombosis. The examination must be bilateral and cover the deep venous axes, the superficial saphenous veins and some important intramuscular trunks such as circonflex, medial gastrocnemius and soleus veins. Considering that its performance is inadequate at the calf level, some prefer a limited examination from the groin to the knee, repeated a week later if negative. Others perform a complete examination from the groin to the ankle, with more recent results being reported as equivalent at both levels. Sonography is indicated when clinical suspicion of venous thrombosis is sufficiently high. It is also mandatory in pulmonary embolism to avoid false negatives of angio-CT and to obtain a venous status for prognosis. D-dimers (DD) can be measured, before sonography, to rule out thromboembolic disease in the absence of co-morbid factors. The second main indication of venous sonography is venous insufficiency, most often located on the saphenous veins, but sometimes on the perforator veins or on the main deep trunks. It is characterized by a venous reflux during dynamic manoeuvres lasting more than 1 s. Deep venous thrombosis (DVT) and venous insufficiency are primarily investigated with ultrasound. However, there may be some indications for indirect CT venography (CTV) or MR venography (MRV). DVT and pulmonary embolism are the two aspects of venous thrombo-embolism. Therefore, combined CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA) and CTV (or MRPA and MRV) are single useful tests that accurately depict both PE and DVT and therefore avoid delayed diagnosis and limit cost. The incremental value of adding CTV to CTPA is in the range of 5-27%. The optimal use of sequential vs spiral acquisition for CTV remains debated. In opposition to ultrasound, CTV and MRV are not limited by leg cast or painful compression, dressing, edema, open wounds, severe burns, trophic changes of the lower limbs or obesity. They provide adequate visualization of veins that are difficult to image with other techniques, such as iliac veins and IVC, which is advantageous to guide further interventions, such as catheter placement for thrombolysis or IVC filter introduction. Combined CTPA-CTV (or MRPA-MRV) results in a complete evaluation of potential sources of clots by screening the veins of the lower limbs, IVC, SVC and the heart chambers. MRI may be preferred particularly at the level of abdomen and pelvis, as it is noninvasive, does not require contrast agent and carries no exposure to ionizing radiation. In venous insufficiency, MR demonstrates the gross and objective morphology of venous structures, but without dependence on the operator's technique, limited field of view and subjective interpretation that may be associated with other techniques. Looking at challenges and opportunities in general, we still see an increase in vascular interventions in Europe. Although some of these vascular interventions are now sometimes performed by other medical specialties like vascular surgery and cardiology, in general interventional radiologists are still the largest group in this field. Our biggest challenge for the near future is to keep interventional radiology in the house of radiology as a subspecialty of radiology. The first step to achieve this is to assure that IR gets a seat within the UEMS radiology section and because of this more profile and recognition. Creating an IR curriculum and finally an IR diploma and staying as the leading force in IR in Europe are challenges. There are good opportunities to achieve this. CIRSE as the European house for interventional radiology has almost 2,500 members and is still growing fast. CIRSE has the knowledge, vision and manpower to do this. Looking in more detail we see a growth in almost all types of vascular interventions. However, one of the most important clinical problems for the future is diabetes. There is a worldwide uncontrolled increase in diabetic patients and peripheral vascular disease. Vascular interventions are going to play a major role. Interventional radiologists should turn their focus in this direction. Finally, the last big challenge for interventional radiologists is to become a "real" doctor, a clinician with clinical responsibility not only to technically treat local disease but also to treat patients as a whole at our own ward in IR run beds. This talk will focus mainly on spinal trauma and will highlight some of the potential pitfalls and misunderstandings which may occur. The emphasis will be on plain radiographs although CT will be used to clarify some of the findings seen on the plain film. The teardrop fracture is a specific entity which is often misunderstood. This and other similar fractures will be shown and their nature and significance clarified. Thoracic fractures are often overlooked on chest radiographs in poly-traumatised patients and several examples will be shown. It is important that these signs are recognised. In the lumbar region, the Chance fracture is another fracture which can be misinterpreted and this will also be considered and existing knowledge consolidated. Obesity is a rapidly growing problem that is affecting most developed and many developing countries. It is estimated that obesity will continue to grow over the next decade, resulting in an increasing impact on the health of the general population. Many radiologists are already aware of some of the problems in trying to image the obese patient. In many cases, imaging is sub-optimal or impossible in such patients. It is however important that radiologists recognise the need to adapt their imaging for their obese patients. Imaging modality selection as well as optimising imaging parameters may enable a significant improvement in visualisation of the imaged obese patient. In addition, vendors have recognised the need to cater for such patients with wider CT and MRI gantries now available in the market. In this session, three expert speakers will discuss different aspects of imaging the obese patient. The panel will then discuss whether we are doing enough to optimise imaging for the obese patient. It is estimated that at least 20% of the population in Europe are obese. The implications of this for the health of the nation are huge, with obesity causing more deaths each year than road traffic accidents as a result of heart disease, peripheral vascular disease, diabetes, and cancer. The cost of obesity on the health budget of most countries is increasing exponentially with the indirect costs on the employer and the taxpayer remaining unquantified. The causes of obesity are multifactorial but in 99% of the cases environmental factors are responsible. The increasing consumption of high calorie, energy-rich food and a reduction in physical activity result in an individual becoming overweight. Primary causes of obesity include genetic causes, metabolic disorders and secondary to medications. Regardless of the aetiology, the impact of obesity on radiology and radiologic interventions is huge. Radiology can play a role in the evaluation of patients with obesity both in determining a primary cause and also in evaluating complications of obesity. Obesity can also hinder the radiologic evaluation or treatment of an affected patient. Radiologists are increasingly facing challenges in producing diagnostic quality studies in the growing obese patient population. This cohort stretches the current imaging technology to its limits; assuming that a patient is transferable to the department and onto the appropriate modality's table, there remains a lot of work to be done to optimise that patient's imaging. Thus, producing diagnostic quality images on obese patients with current technologies will be the basic thrust of this lecture. I will address these challenges from basic physics and practical management approaches and will suggest technique modifications and workarounds to obtain diagnostic quality studies with conventional radiography, computed tomography, ultrasound and magnetic resonance imaging. These patients present particular challenges to the inerventionalist who depends on adequate on-the-fly image acquisition to guide procedures and I will discuss the ways of optimising the quality and safety of these cases. I will address the impact of invariably present co-morbidities on contrast usage and the prescription of sedo-analgesia in the intervention suite. I will also discuss the developments in machine design specifically introduced to overcome the limitations of current machines, namely, increasing the power of all the above, increasing the strength of the supporting tables and increasing the space available to fit the patient into the machine. I will briefly discuss the techniques used in the quantitative and qualitative analysis of obesity and the relevance of this research to clinical practice. Surgery for morbid obesity is rapidly growing with 13,000 procedures performed in 1998 and 200,000 in 2006. The demand for imaging primarily fluoroscopic studies and CT is, therefore, also growing. Since the jejunoileal bypass, first performed in the 1950s at the University of Minnesota, other less dangerous morbid obesity procedures have developed including the vertical-banded gastroplasty, Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch and adjustable laparoscopic gastric band. The normal and abnormal imaging of these procedures will be discussed. Emphasis will be placed on the Roux-en-y gastric bypass, which is the most common procedure in the United States and the adjustable laparoscopic gastric band, the most common procedure in Europe.

Learning Objectives: 1. To understand the surgical procedures used to treat morbid obesity which includes: vertical banded gastroplasty, gastric bypass, adjustable gastric band and duodenal switch. 2. To understand the fluoroscopic and CT techniques used to study patients after the above procedures. 3. To understand the normal and pathological post-operative appearance of these procedures. The imaging of patients treated for a neck malignancy is still challenging because besides postsurgical changes and distortion of anatomic landmarks, the signal intensities in MRI and densities in CT will change, and contrast uptake is frequently present and mostly unspecific. This part of the course will allude to the expected changes, such as changes of anatomical landmarks following surgical removal of neck masses and neck dissection, and changes of MRI and CT appearance following radiation, surgery and other forms of treatment. Typical follow-up patterns will be displayed and discussed and the role of new imaging modalities will also be discussed. Motor cranial nerve lesions are often accompanied by symptoms and signs of denervation. Patterns of denervation are used to locate a lesion along the course of a given cranial nerve(s). To recognize these patterns it is mandatory to know the course of the cranial nerves and the muscles they supply. Motor and mixed cranial nerves include all oculomotor nerves and cranial nerves V, VII, IX, X, XI and XII. In the acute stage, denervation manifests on imaging as oedema and enlargement of the affected muscle(s). These changes are best appreciated on MR through an increase in signal intensity on T2W images and abnormally intense enhancement after gadolinium administration. At this stage, changes should be interpreted with caution as they usually mimic a mass lesion on the affected side. In the chronic stage of denervation, there is loss of muscle fibres and fatty replacement of the muscle(s), depicted well both on CT and MR. A potential pitfall at this stage is to mistake the normal side for a mass lesion, a common occurrence when imaging patients with chronic denervation of the tongue. Whenever denervation is depicted, a thorough evaluation of the complete course of the cranial nerve(s) in question to its brainstem nuclei is mandatory to identify the offending lesion. Causes of denervation can be intrinsic or extrinsic to the affected cranial nerve. In patients with head and neck cancer, particular attention should be given to differentiate between iatrogenic denervation and that secondary to perineural spread of the primary tumour. Comprehensive cardiovascular assessment of the thorax is a reality since the introduction of 64-slice CT technology. The newest development concerns the evaluation of the heart and coronary arteries. CT seems to be already a reliable diagnostic modality for the assessment and especially for the exclusion of significant coronary artery disease. Previous literature extensively provided validation of this technique against conventional coronary angiography. Above all, most of the studies reported a high negative predictive value as a major strength of this technique. Contemporary literature is exploring many aspects regarding the clinical role of this modality. Several fields of application are emerging in the assessment of suspected or known coronary artery disease such as atypical chest pain, nondiagnostic provocative tests, acute coronary syndrome, plaque imaging and so forth.

In addition, the multi-phasic nature of cardiac CT scan allows the assessment of left ventricular volumes and motion. These parameters are "part of the deal" while scanning the heart for the assessment of coronary arteries and are very profitable when associated with the clinical background and with the extent of coronary artery disease. A recent field of implementation is the so-called "triple rule-out", in which cardiovascular CT can play a major role by excluding/diagnosing coronary artery disease vs. pulmonary embolism vs. aortic dissection. Preliminary data are promising in this field. Radiologists are used to reporting on most body parts; however, the heart remains a territory that is not usually assessed. Therefore, an overview of cardiac language and parameters should be part of the knowledge of cardiovascular radiologists. The heart is no longer a difficult organ to study with magnetic resonance (MR). Instead, for a lot of cardiac diseases this technique has become the preferred imaging modality, offering substantially more accurate information than other techniques, such as echocardiography, nuclear medicine and cardiac catheterization. In this presentation, an overview will be given of how to approach the heart with MR, discussing the practical aspects (patient installation, monitoring issues) and specific sequence design, and a brief description of current applications. The follow-up with CT of children treated for heart disease is performed mainly to evaluate the post-operative status of the great arteries and extracardiac shunts. MRI of the heart is a very useful modality in children, as it demonstrates chamber morphology, cardiac connections, and relationships of great arteries without using ionizing radiation. However, it is somewhat limited by the frequent need of sedation and lack of cooperation in breath holding. Cine sequences provide important functional and flow information. MR angiography is replacing conventional angiography for many indications, as it exquisitely depicts the anatomy and abnormalities of the aorta, pulmonary arteries, and veins. The development of high temporal resolution acquisitions with an acquisition time of a few seconds is also a major advance. The quantification of stenosis and shunts is easily performed with phase-contrast techniques. It is very important for the radiologist performing these examinations to be familiar with the anatomy, surgical procedures performed, and relative strengths of each modality in order to suggest to the clinician the most appropriate modality to each particular clinical question. In most emergency centers, the diagnostic imaging work-up of patients admitted with acute abdominal pain is based on abdominal plain film (APF), sonography and MDCT. Because these are easily available, APF and, to a lesser extent, sonography, are often considered by the clinicians as the first line imaging tools to be systematically performed for the screening of these patients, while waiting for MDCT. In some limited situations, for example in patients admitted with acute pancreatitis, bowel occlusion or for detection of intra-abdominal foreign bodies, APF or sonography may add further information with regard to MDCT. However, in many other situations, the systematic use of APF and sonography, performed before MDCT, just constitutes a waste of medical and financial resources and can lead to inappropriate delays in patient care. For a rational use of radiological means, the decision of performing APF and/or US in patients with acute abdominal pain should be tailored to well-defined clinical situations, and based on pre-established appropriateness criteria. CT is more and more often used in the diagnosis and management of acute abdomen. It is now performed as the first-line examination in a patient with acute abdomen and not with argues given by abdominal plain film, ultrasound or laboratory investigations. The advantages and limitations of such an attitude will be discussed by illustrating important diagnoses that have been given quickly by CT and also by showing some CT pitfalls and the key to avoid these mistakes. The goals of radiological imaging procedures in the assessment of acute abdomen are: (1) to identify the cause of acute abdominal pain, (2) to aid in the optimal management of pain by designating the patient either for medical treatment or surgery and (3) to plan percutaneously image-guided aspiration and catheter-based drainage. In the assessment of acute abdominal pain, computed tomography (CT) has gained the status of the gold standard in the last years. In contrast to CT, the use of MR imaging to investigate abdominal emergencies has not been widespread despite technical advances. The main reason for the limited use of abdominal MR imaging is the long study time with the disadvantage of poor image quality due to motion artifacts and the limited monitoring options of severely ill patients. Because recent spiral CT-MR imaging comparisons on state-of-the-art systems have shown that MR imaging is superior to CT for the demonstration of many routine (non-emergency) abdominal diseases due to excellent tissue contrast, it is self-evident that MRI may be used for abdominal emergencies also. For an optimal assessment of the bowel wall and its pathologies as well as for an unambiguous delineation of para-enteral processes against the gastrointestinal tract, a bowel opacification is necessary. If possible, in our patients an oral bowel opacification using 1.000 ml of a 2.0 % sorbitol solution is performed achieving a so-called hydro-MRI. In this course, the possibilities of hydro-MRI in the acute abdomen will be demonstrated. Vertebral compression fractures (VCFs) occur frequently in elderly patients. These fragility fractures frequently result in both acute and chronic pain, being a source of increased morbidity and possibly mortality. Vertebral fractures may result in pain about the fracture site, loss of height caused by vertebral collapse, spinal instability and kyphotic deformity. Regardless of their etiology, the mainstay of management of VCFs is medical therapy, which includes analgesics, bed rest and external fixation. However, medical treatment is frequently only partially effective, and about one-third of patients present persistent pain and functional limitation. Vertebroplasty and balloon kyphoplasty are two minimally invasive procedures developed for the management of symptoms of vertebral compression fractures. Nowadays, both techniques have gained substantial popularity for the treatment of pain and in order to stabilize the spine, not only in those vertebral fractures related to osteoporosis, but also those caused by malignant involvement of the spine or in benign tumours such as hemangiomas. Vertebroplasty involves a percutaneous injection of polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) into the fractured vertebral body, usually through a transpedicular approach. In balloon kyphoplasty, injection of PMMA is done once a cavity has been created in the vertebral body by inflation of a percutaneously inserted balloon. The anatomic considerations, patient selection, technique, possible complications and post-procedure management of both procedures will be described and illustrated. Percutaneous vertebroplasty and kyphoplasty constitute an effective therapy in the management of patients with symptomatic osteoporotic vertebral fractures refractory to conventional medical therapy. The dilemma on how to treat acute herniated discs remains unresolved. This painful disease has a favorable spontaneous outcome requiring in most cases a conservative approach. However, for many patients intense pain makes conservative management difficult to accept. This may be the reason why operative discectomy is still highly popular, since the major advantage of discectomy is the possibility of achieving early pain reduction 1. Nevertheless, the major drawback of surgical discectomy is the risk for recurrent radicular pain known as "failed back surgery syndrome" which is a disabling condition, very difficult to manage 2. New minimally invasive percutaneous intradiscal techniques like nucleoplasty could play an important role in the management of herniated discs. The use of low temperature disc nucleus decompression with Coblation® technology 3. has some characteristics in common with chemonucleolysis, an effective but abandoned treatment. It is not clear whether pain relief is achieved by mechanical decrease in disc size or by an anti-inflammatory effect; however, nucleoplasty seems to be effective in the early stages of disc disease and might even induce disc regeneration 4. Pre-clinical and clinical studies focusing on the safety of the technique and its effects on disc biochemistry have been published, the majority with favorable outcome 5-7. However, no randomized controlled trials are available yet. We shall review the indications, limitations and complications of this technique as known to date in the present data and compare it to the well-established treatment of facet joint disease. The purpose of this course is to demonstrate the techniques used in bone biopsy and RFA. We will address patient selection, indication and possible approaches. Imaging techniques, including fluoroscopy, ultrasound, computed tomography and magnetic resonance, will be shown. Analgesia will be discussed, as well as mobilization and drugs. Anatomic and positional landmarks will be presented. Concerning bone biopsy techniques, the designs and use of needles will be addressed. Size, type and fixation of samples will be discussed; complications will be analyzed. Although radiofrequency ablation (RFA) has been widely used, it is yet to find its place among bone interventional techniques and conventional therapies, such as external beam radiation and narcotic analgesics. We will review the differences between lytic and blastic lesions and the characteristics of various ablation devices, as well as the role in size and number of lesions to be ablated. The attending physician will have an overview of the materials and methods available, such as monopolar, bipolar, and single and multitined electrodes. Complications are analyzed, as well as techniques to minimize potential permanent neurological damage. In conclusion, this presentation for bone biopsy and RFA will hopefully allow the interventional radiologist to perform these techniques in a safe and efficient way, minimizing the risk for his patient, while yielding all possible potential advantages. Knowing the limitations of the material at hand seems to be important for avoiding technical complications. This is the first time at ECR that a special focus session is linked to the IMAGINE exhibition. The IMAGINE, a high-tech specialty exhibition, which this year features 10 research institutes, university groups, and research departments of industrial companies. It presents novel and exciting technological developments in the field of diagnostic and interventional radiology. The IMAGINE exhibition is unique in that it provides a platform to discuss the potential of these techniques in radiology in the near future with the people who are creating them. This IMAGINE special focus session will be dedicated to recent technological developments in imaging biomarkers, image analysis, modelling, and image-guided interventions, which have great potential for improving both the diagnosis and therapy for cancer. The speakers of this session will, among others, discuss the possibilities of these technologies created for early diagnosis, individualized treatment planning and monitoring, and improved image-guided treatment. After introducing the audience to these new developments, the main aim of the session is to address the question whether these technologies will indeed advance cancer therapy, and reduce errors in cancer diagnosis and treatment. As functional imaging becomes increasingly important to modern drug development and for the personalized assessment of therapy response, it has become important to be aware of the practical steps that are needed for the qualification of imaging as a predictive biomarker. The process begins by a precise definition of the clinical issues with reference to the clinical question, followed by biomarker choice, making sure that there is a biological link to the underlying pathophysiological processes that are moderated by therapy (this requires preclinical validation also). Feasibility clinical studies demonstrate in principle the link with therapy response in humans. Prior to full evaluations, the biomarker optimization/adaptation for clinical environments are undertaken. Definitive studies documenting test performance and for estimating group predictive values follow to see whether the biomarker meets its objectives. Determining the level of change that predicts response to therapy on an individual basis via measurement error determinations is undertaken at the same time. Provided that these initial steps are successful, full qualification is performed by undertaking well-designed, randomized control studies with efficacy endpoints. This framework will be illustrated using dynamic MRI as an angiogenesis biomarker in the context of breast cancer response to chemotherapy. Assessment of therapy response on the basis of morphologic parameters is a well-established procedure. Despite the growing interest and great hopes based on advances in molecular and functional imaging, CT-based evaluation of tumor size provides the fundamental information to assess therapy response for the vast majority of patients and clinical studies. Attempts made by the WHO and the RE-CIST consortium to standardize tumor response classifications have led to partly incompatible procedures. These are based on manual diameter measurements in which multiple studies are shown to suffer from very poor reproducibility. Some studies found that as many as one-third of all pairs of measurements performed by different observers on identical images yielded nonstable RECIST classifications. Another study reported that in more than 5% of diameter measurements, difference of more than 3 mm was found with high-contrast lung lesions with a median size of 7 mm. By contrast volumetric morphological assessment using suitably designed software provides three to seven times better reproducible quantification. Volumetry is no longer restricted to the use on small lesions in lung cancer screening. Prototypical software systems are capable of segmenting metastases at all frequent sites of cancer spread (liver, lung, lymph nodes and brain) with high success rates. Recent results also show the superiority of volumetry even for high anisotropic and low-dose data. In conclusion, automatic segmentation of tumors and volumetric measurement of tumor growth can improve the diagnostic accuracy and decrease the number of misclassifications dramatically in staging tumor response to chemotherapy. Colorectal cancer affects approximately 11% of men and 11% women, and approximately 10% of cancer deaths. Liver and colorectal cancers are intrinsically related, since a majority of liver cancers metastasise from the colorectum. This lecture presents recent work on MRI image analysis: Estimation of the circumferential resection margin (CRM), a key parameter in determining resectability of a tumour; segmentation of the mesorectum; analysis of lymph nodes within the mesorectum; relation of pre-operative representations of a rectal tumour to post-resection histology; and in the liver, integration of information from multiple breath holds, and the use of MRI to assess HIFU ablation of a tumour. We also report recent work on fusing dynamic PET with DCE-MRI for assessing complete responders to neoadjuvant chemotherapy for colorectal cancer. Images have long been used to guide interventions and direct therapy. In interventional radiology, catheters or needles (the effector) can be guided using real-time imaging in which the target, access route and effector are all visible. In image directed radiotherapy planning scans are used to simulate treatment, specify target radiation dose and minimize dose to organs at risk. In image guided surgery preoperative images are used to plan a procedure and this plan is registered to the patient coordinates in the treatment room while a pointer tracked in 3D is used to provide surgical navigation. We are now seeing a convergence of the underpinning technologies in these three areas. The latter two methods are limited to situations in which the rigid body transformation is a good approximation to the motion of the patient's anatomy before and during the procedure, i.e. where there is minimal deformation of tissue. Recently there has been progress in using models of motion and the biomechanics of soft tissue to predict such deformation. These advances are, in turn, creating opportunities for more accurate pre-procedure planning in interventional radiology. This talk will summarise this progress with reference to lung radiotherapy and interventions in the liver, breast, prostate and colon. Degeneration of intervertebral disc is characterized by dehydration, fissures, bulging, and herniations. In the bulging disc, the contour of the outer annulus extends in the axial plane beyond the edges of the disc space over more than 50%. Disc herniation may take the form of protrusion or extrusion. Regression or reduction of symptoms occurs after 1 year in at least 71% of patients affected by disc pathology. MRI is useful in presuming spontaneous regression of disc herniations. After 6 months, free fragments involve in 100% of cases and T2-weighted hyperintense extrusions in 83, while protrusions are more stable and bulging disc usually does not undergo anatomic regression. Many symptomatic patients have normal or minimally abnormal findings on standard supine exams. It is known from dynamic myelography that thecal sac and nerve compression are often unmasked only in the erect position. Weight-bearing or upright MR imaging of the spine can help the diagnosis in all these cases. Moreover, dynamic scans, and mostly 3D reformatted myelograms performed in dynamic conditions, are useful to have correct definition of spinal stenosis. Finally, minimally invasive interventional procedures offer today a valid alternative to surgery, because at follow-up the success rate ranges from 70 to 80%. MRI is a valid instrument to select patients, who are candidate to these procedures. The acute onset of spinal cord symptoms, imaging and CSF abnormalities lead to a broad spectrum of diagnoses. Besides myelin-specific disorders like multiple sclerosis, Devic disease and acute disseminated encephalomyelitis, other inflammatory (transverse myelitis), infectious, granulomatous, metabolic or toxic disorders should be recognized. MRI is the method of choice and must be performed within few hours in order to eliminate acute compression. From isolated location in the spinal cord to widespread involvement of the CNS, MRI of the spinal cord and/or the brain will help in making diagnosis and prognosis. The distribution of the lesion in the white and/or grey matter of the spinal cord and the size of the lesion may help in the differential diagnosis. Contribution of new techniques such as diffusion imaging with tractography or magnetization transfer is increasing especially to better characterize the degree of tissue involvement. The advent of multidectector CT (MDCT) marks a qualitative as well as quantitative advance in spine imaging. As compared with single-slice helical CT, visualization of bony abnormalities is strikingly improved on MDCT. CT of the cervical spine is now the standard of care at many trauma centers for evaluation of spinal fractures. For thoracic and lumbar fractures, post-processing of the chest and abdominal CT data is sufficient for detection and classification of these spinal fractures. In patients with spinal fractures, MR imaging is an adjunct to CT for evaluation of discoligamentous injuries. Although MR imaging is still the preferred imaging modality for evaluation of degenerative diseases of the spine, MDCT with a soft tissue algorithm has become an alternative in patients in whom MR is technically not possible. CT excels in the depiction of bony abnormality when compared with MRI. This can be useful in the evaluation of cervical neural foraminal stenosis. For tumor imaging, MDCT permits exquisite depiction of trabecular anatomy in the bone marrow. This capability of MDCT is particularly useful in evaluation of patients with multiple myeloma. However, in most cases the information provided by MR is more important to make the diagnosis in tumor patients. In the postoperative patient, MR with gadolinium enhancement remains standard for evaluation of disc abnormalities and postoperative scarring. However, CT is superior to radiographs and MRI in the depiction of body fusion. Finally, CT may be superior in patients with indwelling hardware. Imaging examinations in polytraumatized patients should be fast and highly accurate, require minimum patient cooperation, enable careful patient monitoring and observation, provide a maximum of information in a single examination, use techniques that minimize radiation exposure, be cost-effective and use imaging technologies that can be located conveniently in emergency departments. All are possible with MDCT. With newer 16 and 64-slice scanners, trauma patients benefit

A 61 B C D E F G from greater anatomical coverage per rotation, faster speed to decrease motion artifact, rapid total body single-acquisition trauma scans and total body CTAs, a decrease in the required IV contrast material, high-resolution images, rapid multiplanar reformations and cardiac gating to decrease aortic and cardiac motion. In polytraumatized patients, routine coronal reformations are obtained on head CT scans and both routine coronal and sagittal reformations on face, cervical spine, chest, abdomen, pelvis and extremity CT scans. Curved plane, MIP, 3D and CTA reformations are obtained when indicated by clinical presentation or findings on axial slices. Multiplanar reformations of the chest and abdomen have eliminated the need for thoraco-lumbar spine clearance films after CT and have been useful in providing better display of sternal and pelvic fractures, as well as soft tissue injuries of the parenchymal organs, diaphragm, bowel, mesentery and urinary bladder. CTAs have provided superb displays of injuries of the aorta, brachiocephalic arteries and other vascular structures. By diagnosing injuries quickly and accurately, MDCT can decrease patient morbidity and mortality, decrease non-therapeutic surgery, prevent unnecessary hospital admissions and decrease the costs of trauma evaluation. Learning Objectives:

1. To learn the optimum MDCT protocols for imaging the polytraumatised patient, including protocols for single acquisition "total body" trauma MDCT scans. Computed tomography (CT) has historically played a central role in musculoskeletal (MSK) imaging, by its ability to accurately evaluate bony pathology. In more recent years, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with its ability to produce multi-planar imaging and its characterisation of soft tissues has played an increasingly central role. However, CT has an important place in imaging peripheral bones and joints and in particular in the imaging of complex bony trauma. This role has increased further with the advent of multi-detector CT (MDCT) and the ability to produce near isotropic voxels allowing for multi-planar reformats and faster scan times. This presentation explores the current role of MDCT in the imaging of peripheral bones and joints with particular emphasis on imaging complex bony trauma, the evaluation of post-operative complications relating to joint prostheses and evaluating the knee following meniscal surgery utilizing arthrographic techniques. The current role of MDCT in guiding MSK intervention (biopsy and radiofrequency ablation) will also be discussed together with its role in problem solving where unexplained abnormalities have been found with MRI. A seven Tesla MR scanner is an expensive piece of equipment, but is it worth it? Will 7 T be the final frontier, a stepping stone to something greater or an expensive white elephant? In this session, we will attempt to answer these questions with the help of three distinguished speakers. Jürgen Hennig will take us through the technical challenges and pitfalls associated with the step up to 7 T. Dorothee Auer will give a neuroradiologist's perspective on 7 T imaging and finally Mark Ladd will report on imaging in the extremities and abdomen with 7 T. The session will conclude with a panel discussion in which you, the audience, will have your chance to question the speakers and chair. Some issues that I hope we can touch on are: 1. Safety: What are the extra safety precautions with 7 T. How can you move to sensible SAR limits? How does the RF power deposition really increase with field strength? 2. Sensitivity: Can we really attain the theoretical SNR gain? 3. Clinical practice: Will we ever be able to move to a high throughput situation, or will 7 T remain a niche application for some special diagnoses? 4. Are there real applications with nuclei other than protons that could be used clinically? These are just a few of my thoughts, but please raise any issue that you consider relevant. I look forward to a dynamic and informative session. Current development of ultrahigh field (UHF) human scanners with field strengths of 7 T and beyond is driven by the higher spin polarization, which promises to increase signal-to-noise that translates into better images and/or improved resolution and/or faster acquisition. Realization of UHF-MR needs, however, to overcome a number of challenges that affect all the parts of the system. Higher field leads to stronger mechanical forces of the magnetic field gradients and therefore to increased acoustic noise. Due to the increased resonance frequency, the wavelength approaches the dimensions of typical organs. This leads to severe image inhomogeneities and spatially variable image contrast. Higher frequency leads to increased specific absorption rate (SAR), which especially affects pulse sequences with many densely spaced pulses like TSE and trueFISP. Most physical parameters relevant to image contrast are field dependent, therefore image contrast will be different. Currently the problems related to the RF fields constitute the most severe challenges to UHF-MR. For SAR reduction, considerable progress has been made using specially designed flip angle-modulated sequences like HyperTSE. Different strategies to compensate for B1-inhomogeneities by spatially modulated transmission (B1shimming, transmit SENSE) are under intense research. Better understanding of the spatiotemporal distribution of the RF field has, however, also led to the insight that patient heating is strongly dependent on the individual anatomy with local ‚hot spots', which are difficult to predict. Therefore, considerable additional effort will be necessary before UHF-MR will become a reliable and safe tool for application studies or even clinical routine. Feasibility of human ultrahigh-field MRI has raised enthusiasm and scepticism regarding its potential clinical usefulness. Neuroimaging applications to date fulfil the expectations of image quality improvement, showing unprecedented delineation of intracerebral structures, such as intracortical lamination. There remain technical challenges and limitations especially for MRA. T1 contrast in the brain is however less impaired than expected. The biggest gain is seen for susceptibility-based applications with improved temporal and spatial resolution for fMRI studies and venography. The latter provides new ways to classify arterio-venous malformations and white matter lesions, and to delineate tumour neovascularisation. In MS lesions, this technique demonstrated small central veins within some plaques as in vivo confirmation of perivenous plaque evolution. High-resolution relaxometry can be performed in clinically acceptable acquisition times. This enables the systematic investigation of the putative pathogenetic role of iron in neurodegenerative diseases. First results in Parkinson's disease revealed that there is no increase of paramagnetic iron in the substantia nigra compared with age-matched controls, making it unlikely to be involved in the pathogenesis of the disease, but not excluding a potential modulatory role. Lastly, the specific gain in spectroscopic resolution will enable truly novel clinical applications by probing regional neurotransmitter profiles in diseases previously not amenable to MR diagnosis as well as assessing their pharmacological modulation. In summary, despite the vast technical challenges to 7 T, the progress achieved over the past few years highlights the potential diagnostic advance in clinical neurosciences that may ultimately translate into improved patient care. MRI at 7 Tesla has already been shown to hold great promise for applications in the head, including enhanced sensitivity for fMRI experiments and exquisite sensitivity to iron content. The general increase in SNR, the non-linear sensitivity increase to susceptibility effects, and the enhanced spectral separation suggest that 7 T would also be of great value in the remainder of the body; however, translating these benefits outside the brain has proven to be extremely challenging due in particular to inhomogeneity of the radiofrequency excitation field and SAR restrictions. Solutions to these issues are being pursued, including the introduction of transmit coils with multiple independent RF channels, which allow the RF field to be shaped to account for the anatomy of interest. First examples in the prostate, extremities, breast and heart will be shown, demonstrating the current technical hurdles and potential of 7 T outside the brain for both fundamental research and clinical diagnostics. The learning objectives are to give some background into clinical and surgical aspects of the main subtypes of femoroacetabular impingement, to illustrate the classic radiographic and MRI imaging appearances of femoroacetabular impingement, to discuss some imaging pitfalls and solutions and to present future scientific areas of research. Femoroacetabular impingement (FAI) is a major cause of early osteoarthritis of the hip, especially in the young and active patient population. There is early pathological contact during hip joint motion between bony prominences of the acetabulum and/or the femur, limiting the physiological hip range of motion, typically flexion and internal rotation. Two main types of impingement are distinguished: Pincer impingement is the acetabular cause of FAI and is characterized by focal or general overcoverage of the femoral head. Cam impingement is the femoral cause of FAI and is due to an aspherical portion of the femoral head-neck junction. Bone marrow edema is a generic term used to describe a common finding on MR imaging of the bone marrow. We will first define and illustrate the MR features that are characteristic of this syndrome as seen in the femoral head. We will also emphasize additional imaging findings on MR imaging or on conventional radiographs that can help to make a more specific diagnosis, because femoral head edema can be observed in a spectrum of diagnoses including hip osteoarthritis, femoral head osteonecrosis, transient osteoporosis, femoral head fracture (post-traumatic, insufficiency or stress related), and in the idiopathic bone marrow edema syndrome. We will stress on the value of features, helpful in clinical practice, which offer the patients and the referring physicians prognostic information. Learning Objectives:

1. To define the generic term of bone marrow edema of the femoral head as seen on MR imaging. 2. To remind the audience that bone marrow edema should be regarded as a sign of an ongoing abnormal process. 3. To emphasise the role of the radiologists in making a specific diagnosis, by focussing on ancillary MR findings. 4. To illustrate the importance of other imaging modalities.

The hip joint is designed for stability, supports the body weight and shifts mechanical loads during ambulation and activity to the lower extremities. The surrounding structures can be classified into static and dynamic stabilizers. The hip capsule and ligaments, primarily the iliofemoral ligament, act as a static stabilizer. The surrounding muscles and tendinous attachments are the dynamic stabilizers. Sport injuries to the hip and pelvis generally account for 5-6% of athletic injuries in adults. Soccer players, runners and ballet dancers are particularly prone to such injuries. Hip or groin pain in athletes can originate from the femoral head, labrum, muscles or pubis. A systematic approach with different imaging modalities, especially MRI, provides a valuable tool and permits an accurate diagnosis. The most common hip injuries in athletes are: 1. Bone: a) stress fractures; b) avulsion fractures. 2. Labrum: a) labral tear; b) FAI, type CAM; c) cartilage-associated injuries. 3. Muscular and myotendinous junction (clockwise approach): a) anterior quadrant (rectus femoris, iliopsoas, adductor muscles and pubis); b) lateral (gluteus, abductor muscles and bursae); c) posterior (Hamstrings). 4.
