Others including hernias, vascular and nerve compression syndromes. BI-RADS classification is now universally recognized as a standard language for breast lesions. One of the advantages is the ability to classify lesions according to the diagnostic strategy, treatment options and follow-up. BI-RADS includes a standardized description of the imaging characteristics of the lesion: mass, calcifications and architectural distortion on mammography; internal structure, shape and limits on sonography; focal/non focal, shape, distribution and enhancement parameters on MRI. Considering all these criteria, the patient can be classified as BI-RADS 1 to 6. BI-RADS improves the average quality of patient workup. Therefore, the radiologist should be aware of the BI-RADS criteria in order to avoid interobserver variability. Nevertheless, not all patients can be classified easily. For instance, BI-RADS 4 proved to be a heterogeneous group and was split into 4 A, 4B and 4C according to the different probability for malignancy. In order to become familiar with BI-RADS, cases will be presented for interactive expertise; the audience will be presented with mammography, sonography and MRI images. Attendees will have the opportunity to better identify simple or tougher cases. At the end of the lecture, attendees will become familiar with the headlines of BI-RADS classification and be able to identify the traps of BI-RADS 3 and 4 categories. Crohn's disease is expressed with a multiplicity of features that reflect the chronic, segmental, transmural and interchangeable disease processes. The role of the radiologist, even in the era of detailed and capsule endoscopy, remains crucial and challenging. Identifying the disease subtypes and assessing the disease activity are new roles recently added to radiology, much more so as new pharmaceuticals are coming into use. Such tasks may now be accomplished due to the introduction of techniques such as enteroclysis, small bowel multislice CT, CT enteroclysis, MRI, MR enteroclysis, high resolution ultrasound (HRUS) and contrast enhanced ultrasound (CEUS). Conventional enteroclysis is ideal in effectively demonstrating endoluminal superficial disease. In addition, rapid technological improvements on cross-sectional imaging have offered outstanding resolution capabilities, thus making it possible to detect the full range of transmural, mesenteric and distant extent of inflammation and its complications. Multislice CT is the fastest growing technique with the best spatial resolution, capable of providing not only multiplanar reconstructions, but also volumetric (VRT), projectional (MIP) and virtual endoscopic images. MRI, a modality with no radiation exposure, offers multiple contrast mechanisms, direct multiplanar projectional and cross-sectional imaging capabilities and at the same time morphologic and dynamic/functional information. HRUS and CEUS are bedside techniques with the minimum harm and discomfort to the patient and a possibility of almost unlimited repetition of scans to assess the disease course, focused at the involved bowel loops. In this interactive teaching session, the attendees will have the opportunity of actively discussing, through selected clinical cases, the distinctive role, the advantages and the limitations of each of the above modalities in assessing the pathological and clinical manifestations of Crohn's disease. The complementary use of these modalities and the clinical criteria that affect modality selection decisions will be emphasized. The possibility of creating imaging based activity indices will be also addressed. Before the advent of the fast-scanning multidetector-row CT (MDCT) technology, thoracic CT studies were exclusively used for the morphological assessment of thoracic organs, but concurrent examination of the heart has traditionally been hampered by image degradation from cardiac motion artefact. The introduction of fast rotation speed and dedicated cardiac reconstruction algorithms exploiting the multislice acquisition scheme of the data has opened new possibilities for chest imaging, starting with the possibility of integrating cardiac functional information into a diagnostic CT scan of the chest. Initiated with 16-slice MDCT, this concept of integrating morphology and function has been further simplified with 64-slice and dual-source CT scanners, thus allowing the radiologists to provide vital information in the management of patients with a wide variety of acute or chronic respiratory disorders. Because this CT technology offers the possibility of generating highresolution and motion-free images of the coronary arteries, evaluation of the coronary arteries during CT examinations of the chest should further widen the clinical applications of CT for respiratory patients, keeping in mind that cigarette smoking is a shared risk factor for both impaired lung function and cardiovascular events. The purpose of this session is to review practical aspects of this new concept in thoracic imaging. Because of the combination of fast rotation time and multi-slice acquisition with a high spatial resolution, multislice-CT with 64 slices or even with two tubes (dualsource CT) is now able to provide detailed information on the complete cardiothoracic morphology. Recent technical developments open up a wide variety of possibilities in imaging the heart and the thoracic vasculature. For cardiac imaging, protocols include non-contrast-enhanced CT of the heart (i.e., calcium scoring) and CT angiography of the heart and coronary arteries. Using a larger cranio-caudal scan range, an ECG-gated CT angiography of the whole thorax is feasible, e.g., for bypass imaging or detailed imaging of the thoracic aorta. Recently, even more comprehensive CT angiography protocols offering a simultaneous evaluation of pulmonary embolism, coronary stenoses and aortic disease have been described, often referred to as 'triple rule out' protocols. Such protocols are used in the differential diagnosis of chest pain increasingly often, aiming to opacify pulmonary and coronary arteries as well as the aorta simultaneously and without motion artefacts.

body_text.text: A B C D E F G Using ECG gating, the acquired images of the coronary arteries applying such a protocol have a similar diagnostic accuracy as a dedicated coronary CT angiography protocol. However, a number of issues have to be addressed, including minimization of radiation exposure, and limitation of the contrast volume applied to the patient. Therefore, in this talk, an overview of the various protocols for cardiothoracic CT imaging will be given, including technical considerations and detailed protocol parameters as well as clinical indications and correct patient selection. Multi-detector row computed tomography (MDCT) permits to include an evaluation of the heart in the course of chest CT examination. This makes sense for the investigation of disorders that may have an important underlying cardiac cause or association that is not clinically obvious. Idiopathic and acquired cardiomyopathies, ischemic heart disease and valvular dysfunction may present with respiratory symptoms such as dyspnea on exertion, chest pain or hemoptysis, leading to the request of thoracic CT. The detection of interstitial edema can lead to the discovery of previously unsuspected cardiomyopathies, affecting the left ventricle. In patients with thoracic malignancy, invasion of the pericardium, pulmonary veins of left atrium must be precisely described to influencing the surgical decision between extra-and intra-pericardial resection. Patient undergoing thoracic surgery may have unsuspected coronary artery disease that can be detected in the course of preoperative evaluation by CT. EGC-gated MDCT is superior to echocardiography in the assessment of cardiac structures in patients with extensive parenchymal lung abnormalities and can estimate right ventricle (RV) function and pulmonary artery pressure. In acute pulmonary embolism, the detection of RV dysfunction is an important prognostic factor. In chronic thromboembolic disease or in non-embolic pulmonary hypertension, changes in RV function can reflect the efficacy of medical treatment and influence surgical decision. In patients with severe COPD, emphysema may induce pulmonary tamponade effect that causes left ventricle dysfunction affecting diastole volume, and which may be cured by lung reduction surgery. On the other hand, lung reduction surgery is contraindicated in the case of pulmonary hypertension. Since the introduction of in-line PET-CT and later SPECT-CT systems, multimodality imaging has become the standard of management under various clinical conditions. To address the increasing expectations of clinicians in detecting more and more subtle changes and in characterising an always broader list of molecular features, more powerful imaging devices need to be developed. Today's hybrid imaging instruments are still juxtapositions of two different devices within one "wrapping".

body_text.text: To make substantial improvements new concepts need to be created. Combining PET and MRI is one of those concepts where it will ultimately be possible not only to provide combined information about anatomy and radioactive tracer distribution/ kinetics but also to image various functional aspects (on the basis of radiotracer and magnetic resonance techniques) on the exquisite anatomic support of MRI. In the same spirit, it is important to favour intense research and development of new radionuclide and paramagnetic compounds for the study of a broad spectrum of molecular processes to better understand physiology and to characterise disease. This session is intended to present the current state of the art of hybrid imaging and open the discussion on future developments. The use of PET/CT for oncology is growing markedly due to the convincing diagnostic power. In oncology, the use of PET/CT is increasing for diagnosis, staging, relapse, treatment evaluation and radiation therapy planning. With the tracer FDG and new tracers as 18 F-choline for prostate cancer, the diagnostic universe of PET/CT for oncology is developing markedly. PET/CT with FDG is used as routine in our hospital for, e.g., staging in patients with cervical and ovarian cancer. For ovarian cancer staging the sensitivity and specificity of PET/CT is 95 and 91% (Loft et al. 2007). The 2007 JCO international guideline recommends use of PET as standardized response criteria for Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Multitracer principles with PET/CT and FDG combined with hypoxia scanning with, e.g. 64-Cu-ATSM can identify tumor areas with hypoxia for 3D radiation therapy planning with increased radiation to hypoxic tumor areas. Micro-PET/CT is "the tool" for translational research, with models for hypoxia, apoptosis and angiogenesis, evaluating new cancer drugs. PET/CT for dementia with FDG or PIB is under evaluation and if PET/CT can predict which patients will benefit from treatment with vaccine and anti-Alzheimer drugs, a marked rise in use of PET/CT is expected. A 64-slice CT for non-invasive coronary angiography combined with functional imaging with PET showing myocardial function and perfusion is also expected as future routine investigation. PET/CT hybrid imaging has developed into a powerful tool in oncology -and will probably develop further also for neurology and cardiology. Molecular imaging with radioactive tracers has the potential to deepen our knowledge on the chain of molecular events that accompany or even cause disease. Single-photon emission computerized tomography (SPECT) is the most frequently used nuclear medical computerized tomography. However, SPECT suffers from low anatomical resolution, thereby reducing its diagnostic accuracy. This shortcoming is overcome by registering SPECT images with those from X-ray computerized tomography (CT). The anatomically most accurate method of image registration is offered by hybrid cameras integrating detector systems from CT, on the one hand, and SPECT, on the other. This offers the potential to exactly relate foci of regionally disturbed metabolism to an anatomical region. Furthermore, CT may be used for attenuation correction of the SPECT images, thus improving their quality. Evidence suggests that SPECT/CT offers a gain in diagnostic accuracy of approximately 30% compared to stand-alone SPECT, in particular in orthopedics and oncology. Therefore, SPECT/CT hybrid imaging may substitute for conventional SPECT in the near future. Molecular imaging promises access to new functional parameters on a molecular level. This will help scientific discovery and medicine likewise. Both modalities are pursuing similar applications such as neurodegenerative disease, imaging of angiogenesis, apoptosis and cell proliferation, etc. Magnetic resonance (MR) benefits mostly from the huge variety of different functional parameters such as perfusion, diffusion, and susceptibility weighting that express tumour therapy response still on a macroscopic level. In addition, there is a potential to track disease-specific agents for inflammatory processes, tumour or hallmarks of Alzheimer. The lower sensitivity of MR compared to positron emission tomography (PET), however, increases the challenge significantly to detect smallest concentrations of biomarkers. Radiotracers also offer easier synthesis with the targeting ligands and smallest change to their pharmacokinetics. Thus, the integration of both modalities provides the most versatile tool for comprehensive diagnose. PET-CT is a well-established modality for many of today's clinical questions and it is unlikely that an MR-PET will fully take over. However, the future developments of technology, tracers and agents will allow new applications. The integration of MR and PET has just begun, and only a few demonstrators for rodents and human brain are available. More results from these systems are expected in the near future. It can be expected that the added functional and molecular information that MRI will provide allows unprecedented, comprehensive examinations. Especially for neurological applications, this will be a major step beyond the PET-CT capabilities. The need for more advanced and accurate methods for guiding and controlling minimally invasive procedures continues to grow as these procedures become increasingly important in medicine. MR imaging has many advantages that make it an exciting tool for guiding endoluminal and endovascular procedures. The rationale for using MRI as a guidance tool is not primarily to avoid radiation exposure, but to add therapeutically relevant information to an interventional procedure. MRI can provide functional and morphologic information in tumor-bearing bile ducts as well as in atherosclerotic arteries. It has the potential to visualize not only the vessel lumen, as does conventional angiography, but also the vessel wall, different plaque components and the surrounding tissues. In the past, MRI-guided catheter-based endoluminal and endovascular interventions were performed in animal models to test device visibility and procedure feasibility. More recently, complex procedures, such as endovascular repair of aortic aneurysm, arterial recanalization and stenting, embolization, transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt creation and septal occluder placements have been performed in pre-clinical settings. There are only a limited number of reports on patient applications. Most of these clinical applications are feasibility studies copying X-ray fluoroscopy-guided procedures that have not yet demonstrated the clear additional benefit of MRI guidance. Few studies showed that MRI is able to replace the combined utilization of other imaging modalities to guide devices during a procedure. Although MRI does not involve ionizing radiation exposure, there are some hazards that must be known before utilizing interventional MRI in a clinical setting. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) enables excellent visualization of the heart and the surrounding structures. It is not only possible to image the mechanical function of the heart, but also to accurately determine the size and location of the infarct using MRI. MRI can be used in cardiac intervention and therefore complex interventional procedures can utilize the high imaging power of MRI. Stem cell injection, electrophysiological measurements, cardiac ablation and valve placement are some of the many applications of MRI-guided procedures. The most common problems in these procedures are the accurate visualization of the devices and RF safety of the corresponding devices. In this presentation, after a brief overview of the devices used in the procedures, some applications will be demonstrated. Fetal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has evolved to a valuable adjunct to ultrasonography in prenatal diagnostics. In complex fetal pathologies, fetal MRI can help to confirm, correct, or complete ultrasonographic findings. This extra information may guide intrauterine treatment, determine route of delivery, the immediate postnatal care, predict functional outcome postnatally and may be used to counsell parents for future pregnancies. With the ongoing hardware and software development, multiple new sequences became available which give a wealth of anatomical and functional information. Initially, fetal central nervous system pathologies were the main indications. In the meanwhile, fetal MRI is progressively applied for thoracic, abdominal and muskuloskeletal pathologies. The radiologist should be familiar with the different sequences that can be applied, with the normal fetal anatomy during the different phases of development and with the different pathologies that can be encountered intrauterine. Part of these pathologies may be unfamiliar to the general radiologist because many pathologies are lethal intrauterine or the fetus dies within the first hours after delivery. In addition, the spatial resolution is still reduced compared to postnatal imaging because the fetus is small, the fetus may be moving within the uterus, the distance between imaging coil and fetus is large, and not all routinely used sequences of postnatal MRI are available intrauterine.

body_text.text: Finally, no contrast media should be injected. The objective of our session is to present a comprehensive summary of the different MRI-sequences, normal fetal anatomy and an overview of indications of fetal MRI covering the fetus from the top to the bottom. The preparation of a pregnant woman includes exclusion of contraindications for magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). In the case of claustrophobia, sedation can be provided. MRI procedure, indication, and possible consequences of the results have to be explained. The woman should be positioned in the magnet comfortably and be accompanied by a psychological parent. For optimal image quality, the coil elements should lie as close to the region(s) of interest as possible. Repositioning of the coil during the examinations may become necessary. T2-weighted (w) contrast is still the mainstay of fetal MRI. Other sequences provide additional information about tissue-composition and/or function of organs.T1-w contrast is necessary to follow normal development of glands, bowels, body fat, cerebral cell-density and myelination, and to detect hemorrhages and calcifications. FLAIR-images are mainly used to further differentiate cystic structures. Steady-state-free-precession (SSFP) sequences may visualize vessels. Dynamic SSFP-sequences are the basis to study gross fetal movement and intrinsic movements. Diffusion-weighted sequences allow to study brain development, and to diagnose acute lesions, to identify kidneys, and to study placental impairment. On the basis of diffusion-weighted anisotropy, white matter trajectories in the fetal brain may be identified, giving a clue to early connectivity. Fetal MRI is always whole-body imaging, even if the clinical question is related to a certain anatomical region. As a consequence, correct interpretation requires a broad knowledge of early organ development, deviations thereof, and patterns of acquired pathology. Fetal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is exquisitely well suited to examine the normal and abnormal development of the fetal central nervous system. Fetal MRI allows to directly study multiple programmed and interacting processes of brain development. Compared to ultrasonography, fetal MRI directly visualizes (a) the migration of neurons from the germinal matrix to the cortical ribbon, (b) the infolding of the cerebral cortex (sulcation) and (c) the progressing myelination of the cerebral white matter. The general radiologist should be familiar with the normal brain development to identify and differentiate errors of development from acquired intrauterine brain injuries. He should also understand that an "insult" during an early phase of development may induce a cascade of errors in development and result in an erroneous continuation of brain development. In addition, the radiologist should always correlate pathologies of the fetal central nervous system with possible additional pathologies of the thorax, abdomen or musculoskeletal system. Frequently, malformations of the central nervous system are part of a multilevel, multiorgan syndrome. Finally, follow-up examinations may be necessary to identify or confirm a developing fetal malformation or pathology. Initial imaging may show only discrete findings while on follow-up the malformation or pathology may be much more extensive or obvious. An exact and complete identification of the total extent of central nervous system pathology is essential to predict neurofunctional outcome. This information will be essential in counselling the parents and in optimizing pre-and postnatal care. The rapid development of fetal magnetic resonance (MR) imaging techniques has led to improved assessment of all organ systems of the fetus. By applying organ-specific examination techniques, the imaging of the normal and pathologic fetal lung has become more sophisticated and progressed from research into daily clinical practice for privileged tertiary centres. With the currently available image resolution, detailed evaluation of even mediastinal structures of the fetus, such as the trachea, oesophagus, and the heart, are feasible. Especially in compromised and extremely premature fetuses (24-30 weeks of gestation), survival is strongly dependent on lung maturity, which is assessed by volumetric measurements and characteristics of signal intensities of the lungs. This information is important in predicting the survival of newborns with congenital diaphragmatic hernia. When planning neonatal ventilation management of premature newborns increasing emphasis is laid on the determination of the expected lung maturity by fetal MR imaging. The most commonly used sequences for the evaluation of the lungs are T2-and fast-T2-weighted images, diffusion-weighted images and T1-weighted images adapted to the MR-unit and coils used. Dynamic sequences have to be obtained to enable the assessment of oesophageal function and heart movements. This talk gives an overview of the normal fetal lung development and a summary of the most relevant congenital lung lesions. Special focus will be made on the embryology and nosology of pulmonary parenchymal lesions as described by the new histological classification. The potential of MR imaging of the mediastinum and the heart will also be explored. During this presentation, we will illustrate the applications of fetal magnetic resonance (MR) imaging in the field of the abdomen that started later than its use for the fetal CNS or chest. Among the potential abdominal applications, some appear obvious such as the characterisation and evaluation of large and complex masses. The technique also proved useful in the case of bilateral uro-nephropathies to precise the type of uropathy or the degree of renal parenchyma anomalies. In both indications, compared to obstetrical ultrasound, fetal MR imaging provides additional information and helps to optimize the pregnancy management and parental counselling. A third interesting indication is the evaluation of the fetal digestive tract and particularly intestinal obstruction. This can be based on the differences in signal between the small and large bowel on T1 and T2 sequences. Some diagnoses have become easier, i.e. esophageal atresia. For others, more experience is needed to fully understand the changes in signal during intestinal obstruction. Further directions of the technique will also be described. Magnetic resonance imaging has proven to be especially valuable for the diagnosis of disorders of the central nervous system and of the brain in particular. The continuous improvement of the technical capabilities of the scanners has allowed not only the improvement of the standard imaging sequences, but also the successful implementation of more sophisticated techniques such as magnetic resonance spectroscopy, functional MRI and diffusion tensor imaging. MRS is a method, which takes advantage of the difference in the resonance frequency of the hydrogen nuclei that are bound in various macromolecules. Its implementation in vivo allows detection and evaluation of the changes in the chemical composition of the brain that may occur in various diseases. fMRI is based on the detection of the BOLD effect that indicates increased perfusion of the areas of the brain that are activated during specific stimulations. In this way, it detects the exact location of the activation areas of the brain. DTI uses the diffusion-weighted images acquired with appropriate gradients applied in many directions to calculate the direction of the water diffusion through the white matter of the brain and enables the estimation of the pathways of the white matter fibers. All these methods can give important information both for diagnosis and for accurate planning of the treatment, and their role alongside with the standard techniques is already established but also constantly expanding. Their successful implementation, however, demands appropriate planning, technically correct acquisition and careful postprocessing and analysis of the acquired data.

body_text.text: Learning Objectives: 1. To understand the physical and physiological principles applied in functional magnetic resonance imaging, magnetic resonance spectroscopy and diffusion tensor imaging. 2. To become familiar with the implementation methods, the responsibilities of the technologist and the possible pitfalls. 3. To understand the areas of application and the additional clinical information that these techniques can provide for the detection and assessment of disorders of the central nervous system.

body_text.text: Magnetic resonance imaging is now the modality of choice in the evaluation of an increasing number of pathology in the brain, spine, chest, abdomen and musculoskeletal pathology. Despite the recent association with gadolinium and nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (NSF), the requests for noninvasive vascular imaging is still on the rise. Faster sequences combined with high-tech coil design have reduced imaging time, but have also shown that MR imaging is still perhaps the most susceptible to a variety of artifacts than other modalities. In addition, the shortage of radiologists resulted in the opportunity for radiographer-led MR units, as is the case in Malta. As a result, radiographers must be knowledgeable in every aspect of MRI including artifacts. These artifacts can potentially affect the quality of MR images and may simulate pathologic conditions or produce pitfalls in interpretation. Recognition and, if possible, minimizing their effect is an important role of MR radiographers. My goal is to display in an interactive way some of these common artifacts that occur in MRI. These have been classified into 1) human and 2) machine artifacts. The artifacts in the human category include those caused by improper patient positioning, ferromagnetic objects in the patient and motion by the patient or within the patient. The machine artifacts are inherent to the process of MR image acquisition, including aliasing, truncation, chemical shift, RF interference and crosstalk. A major application of molecular MR imaging to neurological disease studies is cell tracking. We will discuss the fundamentally different strategies of cell labeling with various MR contrast agents: i) systemic or ii) localized (stereotactic) contrast agent application, and iii) in vitro labeling followed by stereotactic implantation of the prelabeled cells. The influence of this label incorporation on the native function and viability of the treated cells must be assessed before such cells can safely be applied. Basic protocols necessary to validate the usefulness of the chosen procedure will be presented. Major applications of in vivo cell tracking will be presented and their potential and challenges will be discussed for the safe localization A B C D E F G of cells in the host organ over time. Here, the major focus will be on experimental stroke, which most of the investigations dealt with. Other applications will also be presented. New strategies to observe not only localization but also function of the cells in vivo using innovative approaches with smart contrast agents and/or molecular biological imaging reporters in transfected cells will be presented for potential future applications. Cellular therapies are being developed in humans with the goal of repairing damaged tissues (myocardial infarction, Parkinson disease, etc.), synthetising a deficient hormone or molecule (diabetes, liver congenital diseases) or for gene or anticancer therapy (dendritic cells). Cellular imaging, a technique aimed at visualising magnetically labelled cells by MRI, has several objectives when monitoring these innovative therapies: It should answer several questions: Do the therapeutic cells reach the organ? Are they functional? Can they proliferate? Can they differentiate? Can they move and relocate? The goals of this presentation are to highlight the technical requirements, imaging protocols and preliminary results of cellular imaging in animals and humans. Since the introduction of multislice CT in 1999 there has been a tremendous technical improvement that allows for a plaque imaging. Initially the main focus of cardiac CT was to rule out the presence of a significant stenosis in the coronary tree. The initially available scanners where challenged with heart related motion artifacts and non-assessable coronary segments due to severe calcifications. However the ability even of the early generation scanners to differentiate between different plaque compositions intrigued the medical community with the hope to either identify vulnerable plaque prone to rupture or at least to determine whether medical intervention such as lipid lowering drugs could be monitored. With the advent of currently clinically available scanner generation with up to 64 slices and dual source configuration provide for a temporal resolution up to 83 ms and thus allowing for minimized motion artifacts and improved images quality even at low heart rates. Early results indicate that monitoring lipid lowering therapy is feasible, but larger trails are missing to confirm these findings. To date no tools are available to quantify plaque mass in clinical routine, but technical development may provide these tools in the near future. Detection of the vulnerable plaque, however, will not be feasible in the near future. Spatial resolution and low contrast resolution will prevent direct visualization of the thin fibrous cap with the underlying fatty core. Novel developments in contrast media research may trigger the advent of specific contrast media such as targeting macrophages in plaques. Atherosclerosis is an inflammatory disease, where the degree of inflammation, not the plaque size, determines risk of rupture and therefore likelihood of a clinical event. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can image atherosclerotic plaque with high resolution, and several MRI parameters of disease extent in the carotid arteries and aorta have been shown to correlate with atherosclerotic risk factors. Dynamic-contrast-enhanced MRI (DCE-MRI) is a new technique for the study of plaque composition. In this study, the extent of plaque inflammation, determined by FDG uptake, was correlated with DCE-MRI. By providing a metabolic image of macrophage activity, F18-fluorodeoxuglucose (FDG) positron emission tomography (PET) can image atherosclerotic plaque inflammation in patients and in animal models of disease, with a strong correlation between FDG uptake and plaque macrophage content. In addition, autoradiography has confirmed that the FDG signal originates from activated macrophages within the lipid core and fibrous cap of the plaque. This has led to the suggestion that FDG-PET might have a role in identifying 'high risk' plaques and monitoring their response to therapy. Computed tomography (CT) can be used in conjunction with PET to help co-register the PET images and for attenuation corrections. Moreover, CT with its exquisite coronary imaging has the potential to address atherosclerosis in the vessel wall of the coronary arteries. We review in this talk the use of multimodality imaging (MR, PET and CT) for the study of inflammation of vessel wall, which may be useful in the assessment of plaque vulnerability. Coronary artery calcium (CAC) scoring by computed tomography (CT) is an effective tool for coronary risk stratification and prediction. Numerous prospective trials using electron-beam CT have shown that the severity of CAC is associated with the risk of suffering a heart attack and predicts plaque burden, which is potentially useful in patients at an "intermediate risk". Thus, the CAC score provides valuable information to the cardiologist on how to manage a patient with an intermediate likelihood of coronary artery disease. CT allows an accurate and quick quantification of coronary calcium based on the CT densities (HU). Three different CAC scores can be measured. Most well known is the "Agatston score" (AU; calculated based on HU + area of calcium), besides the mass and volume score, which show different reproducibilities. Several CAC "cut-off" points have been defined to determine the individual patient´s risk, which will be addressed in this course. For example, an AU 300 indicates an increased 10-year risk of a cardiac event. CAC is influenced by various factors such as gender, age, ethnicity (MESA-trial) or the amount of intima versus media calcification. These issues will be discussed, because of their importance for reporting and risk prediction. Besides, the possible role of aortic valve calcium scoring will be debated. Coronary CT angiography has emerged over the past few years revealing that non-calcifying plaques can be detected beyond calcifying. Non-calcifying plaques represent early stage of atherosclerosis and might be linked with plaque vulnerability, thus raising the question whether the calcium score has become redundant. To discuss the current evidence on the predictive value of coronary events when calcium scoring is added to risk factor assessment. 3. To discuss the possible role of calcium scoring in cardiovascular risk assessment, its limitations and its role before coronary CT angiography. 4. Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the sixth most frequent tumor, with a heterogeneous geographical incidence. According to epidemiological studies, HCC is increasing in developed counties, probably related to hepatitis C virus diffusion. HCC appears in liver cirrhosis (LC) of any etiology, more frequently in advanced disease, and is the main cause of death by LC. Curative therapies (resection, transplant, ablation) are mostly effective in small tumors. Surveillance programs are considered cost-effective as they increase the proportion of patients diagnosed at an early stage and this results in the possibility of treatment. Surveillance of patients known to have LC should be performed to detect tumors 2 cm. The cadence of performing the studies are not fixed, but according to the doubling time of HCC, a study every 6-month is recommended. Ultrasound is the most commonly used technique for this purpose, and the detection of any new focal lesion in the follow-up of LC should raise the suspicion of HCC. The probability of a small lesion to be an HCC increases with the size. HCC is infrequent in lesions 1 cm (close follow-up is recommended), one-third of lesions between 1 and 1.5 cm may be HCC and the proportion may reach 90% in focal lesions 1.5 cm. CT or MRI can also be used for screening, but produce an increase in cost and radiation, thus not fulfilling the criteria for a screening test. CEUS, CT or MRI are used for non-invasive diagnosis and for staging. In the setting of a patient with liver cirrhosis, a solid nodular lesion found during ultrasound (US) surveillance has a high likelihood of being a hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). However, it has been shown by pathologic studies that many small nodules detected by US in cirrhotic livers do not correspond to HCC. The differential diagnosis between small HCC and non-malignant hepatocellular lesions may be very challenging. Nodules detected during US surveillance are further investigated with dynamic imaging techniques, including contrast-enhanced US, contrast-enhanced multidetector computed tomography (MDCT) and contrastenhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). In fact, one of the key pathologic factors for differential diagnosis that is reflected in dynamic imaging studies is the vascular supply to the lesion. Through the progression from regenerative nodule to low-grade dysplastic nodule (DN) to high-grade DN to frank HCC, one sees loss of visualization of portal tracts and development of new arterial vessels, termed nontriadal arteries, which become the dominant blood supply in overt HCC lesions. It is this neovascularity that allows HCC to be diagnosed. However, two further parallel processes take place during the carcinogenetic pathway towards dysplasia and full malignancy: a) the progressive loss of biliary polarization of the hepatocyte and the derangement of the microscopic secretory structure; and b) the progressive nodular depletion of Kupffer cells. MRI performed with tissue-specific contrast media (hepatobiliary and reticulo-endothelial) gives an insight on this "grey area", in which significant hystological changes are already present without an evident arterial supply of the nodule. Ultrasonography is commonly regarded as the technique best suited to evaluate the acute scrotum, since modern transducers with high-definition imaging and high sensitivity to flow allow depiction of both fine anatomic details and intratesticular vessels in all cases. The diagnostic approach has to consider that causes of acute scrotum have different frequencies according to patient age. Torsion, of the testis or of its appendages, is more common in the pediatric age group; infections are more frequently encountered in adults. In suspected torsion, detection of intratesticular flow with color Doppler allows a diagnostic sensitivity of 86%. However, small flow signals can be seen in low-grade torsions; detection at spectral analysis of high-resistance flow within intratesticular arteries may help to avoid false negatives. Torsion of the testicular appendages may be recognized when a small nodule, adjacent to a normal-looking testis, with normal intratesticular flow, is encountered. Infection usually starts at the epidydimis and is diagnosed on clinical grounds; imaging is only rarely needed, but may be helpful in assessing involvement of the testis. In patients with trauma, imaging plays a key role in assessing testicular integrity, since surgical repair is needed when there is testicular rupture. Other, less common, causes of acute scrotum involve the scrotal skin, vessels and spermatic cord. Additionally, in rare cases, "non-scrotal" causes of acute scrotal symptoms may be encountered. In these patients, scrotal symptoms, or signs, are due to extension to the scrotum of intrabdominal inflammatory or traumatic pathologic changes due to patency of the processus vaginalis. Ultrasound is the key modality for the evaluation of the scrotal content, while MR is indicated in selected patients only. A histological diagnosis cannot be achieved and solid masses must be considered as malignant. Seminomas present as nodular hypoechoic masses, while non-seminomatous germ cell tumors are commonly heterogeneous and there is frequent association with testicular microlithiasis. Color Doppler is not beneficial for lesion characterization. A growing challenge is the incidental detection of very small hypoechoic lesions, which tend to be more frequent in subfertile men. They are often benign Leydig-cell nodules, but malignancy cannot be excluded. When solitary, ultrasound-assisted testis sparing surgery is an option. In men with retroperitoneal lymph node metastases, scrotal ultrasound is indicated. The testicular primary tumor may be shrunken, fibrotic and calcified (i.e., burned-out lesion). Benign testicular lesions may mimic malignancy. A rounded mass with concentric layering is typical of benign epidermoid cyst and testis sparing surgery is justified. Men with segmental testicular infarction and hematoma are symptomatic and a careful follow-up may be the appropriate strategy. Solid epididymal mass lesions are most likely to be benign tumors, i.e., adenomatoid tumors, sperm granulomas or chronic (granulomatous) epididymitis. Malignant extratesticular and extraepididymal tumors are extremely rare in adults and include lipomas, liposarcomas or inflammatory masses. Ultrasonography (US) and MR imaging are the first-line modalities in patients with penile disease. The penile anatomy is well defined after pharmacologically induced erection /tumescence using high-resolution gray-scale US or MR imaging. The morphologic alterations include changes in the size and structure of the corpora cavernosa and the thickness of the tunica albuginea that can be studied well with US and MRI. With the distension of the penis, the tunica albuginea stretches and thins, while the erectile tissue distends and becomes hypoechoic on US or hyperintense on T2WI. The vascular supply to the erectile tissue is well explored with color Doppler US or with angio RM imaging after contrast injection. The tunica albuginea, the corpora cavernosa and the cavernosal arteries display different signal intensity on T2-weighted images. The most frequent penile pathology observed in the clinical practice are Peyronie's disease, fibrosis of the penis, trauma, tumors and complications after penile prothesis implantation. Erectile dysfunction is the second main group of diseases that are well explored with Doppler sonography. The resulting velocity waveform is displayed and the peak systolic and end-diastolic velocities are measured. It is possible to find the differences between arterial and venous erectile dysfunction and the results influence the therapeutic opportunities. The Israel Radiological Association (ISRA) was founded in 1927, 21 years before the declaration of the State of Israel (1948) . During the period from 1933 to 1935, hundreds of doctors immigrated to Israel from Germany and Austria. These physicians had a profound influence on medical practice in Israel, which changed from GP-based practice to specialized medicine based on experts. The first major medical meeting in Israel, which took place in Tel Aviv in September 1934 and included 150 doctors, was a radiological meeting! Professor Ludwig Halberstater, Director of Radiology at 'Charite' Hospital in Berlin, who came to Jerusalem in 1933 and founded the first radiotherapy service in the Middle East, formed the backbone of local radiology at that time. The ISRA includes to date more than 500 members and has two roles. It runs a union professional activity and has also an academic role in defining and updating the syllabus and supervising the training programs. It also takes part in defining medical radiological policies, standard of procedures and guidelines as well as organizing national and international meetings. Regulations of public healthcare in Israel restrict the installation of CT and MRI units. Nevertheless, the rate of examination per unit is one of the highest in the world. The Israel radiological community is also actively involved in the high-tech industry, in the research and development of advanced imaging projects. Israeli radiology appears to face similar problems and challenges as the modern radiology elsewhere. Session Objective: 1. To become familiar with the history, training programmes and utilisation patterns of the radiological profession in Israel.
