body_text.text: The hi-tech environment in Israel: Contribution of the radiological community to projects in medical imaging Y. Inbar 1 , T. Gaspar 2 ; 1 Tel Hashomer/IL, 2 Haifa/IL (Yael.Inbar@sheba.health.gov.il)

Medical devices and pharmaceuticals are produced in Israel for more than a century. The first Israeli pharmaceutical company was established in 1901. With the advent of advanced technologies in the late 1990s, the face of Israel's life sciences industry has profoundly changed. The availability of capable partners in the fields of electronics, communications, computer science, electro-optics and medical sciences took the development of medical devices to a new level and introduced advanced innovations in digital imaging, electro-medical devices, telemedicine, surgical equipment, diagnostic kits and rehabilitation equipment. Today, there are over 750 active life sciences companies with approximately 50 new ones starting up each year. One of the important factors contributing to the success of this industry is the cooperation between academia and the entrepreneurial spirit. There are more than 100 companies or start-ups linked to various aspects of imaging such as health IT (image management, teleradiology and archiving), MRI, ultrasound and other imaging devices including minimally invasive therapy applications. This presentation includes examples of hardware and software projects, which were developed in cooperation with the radiological community in Israel. Among those are an intra-operative MR system, MR-guided focused ultrasound system, a new technique employing sound for cardiac and chest imaging, hardware and software related to MDCT and to coronary imaging and more. Computed tomography (CT) takes an integral part in the evaluation and management of the emergent patient. This presentation evaluates the trends in the utilization of CT, as used in the emergency room (ER), over more than a decade (1995) (1996) (1997) (1998) (1999) (2000) (2001) (2002) (2003) (2004) (2005) . It includes a volume of more than 2,400,000 ER visits and 300,000 in-patient CT examinations, 170,000 of which were performed on emergency bases at the request of the department of emergency medicine. While the number of ER visits increased by only 14-17% over this period, the volume of CT examinations on emergency bases increased by 3-6-fold. An overwhelming increase of CT exams was observed during the night shift with particular increase in body CT studies. National guidelines for minor head trauma imaging, the increased use of CT for acute abdomen, technical developments such as the introduction of spiral and MDCT, the installation of CT in the ER premises are all proposed explanations to the factors that may contribute to the observed changed trends. The role of CT as an emergency tool in multi-casualty events (MCE) of civil and military nature is also described and discussed. Logistical aspects related to hospital preparedness to mass disasters, in general, and the specific role of radiological departments and their multi-disciplinary integration are considered. Pulmonary radiology has been the cradle of many diagnostic signs, starting with the most famous of all, the silhouette sign. In this presentation, common pulmonary signs have been selected, with the criteria that they should be recognizable and useful in daily practice. Their recognition should help in suggesting a diagnosis or, more often, to narrow the differential diagnosis. A "sign" in radiologic imaging can be defined as a pattern of certain findings seen at on radiography, ultrasound, CT, or MR. Such a sign, once recognized, published, and taught, may aid the learned educated radiologist to diagnosein diagnosing specific entities and disorders. In the chest, signs play a major role, mainly because of the complex anatomy, and the associated difficulties in the interpretation of findings. For example, iIn the mediastinum aund pleura, many useful signs have been described, including "Naclerio's V sign,", the "3 sign,", the "ring-around-the-artery sign," and the "split pleura sign," -just to name a few. In this course, we will present the most important clinical signs in imaging of the mediastinum and pleura. Specifically, the anatomic and morphologic basis of these signs at radiography and cross-sectional imaging will be elucidated, and their clinical use in every day practice will be discussed. According In accordance withto the format of the session, interactive teaching will challenge every attendee to test his or her knowledge, and to learn about the most useful signs. The first 100 years of research in medical imaging was characterized largely by the development of new methods in the laboratory followed by translational research -often termed bench-to-bedside research -aimed at establishing the clinical role of the new methods. Few bio-scientists outside of radiology used medical imaging methods in their work. In the 1990s, three broad-based advances converged to change this dramatically and to create a new era for imaging in biomedical research:

(1) the development of practical digital methods for acquiring, storing and analyzing images, (2) the invention of new MRI-based functional imaging methods and (3) the explosion of new approaches to molecular imaging. Today, scientists from literally every biomedical discipline are adopting imaging methods to take advantage of their unique capabilities as probes of biological systems and structures. The perceived power of "bench-to-bench"-translation of imaging methods is bringing imaging scientists and bio-scientists together in interdisciplinary teams aimed at tackling many of the most interesting and important questions facing science today. Imaging methods are now transforming entire disciplines such as the cognitive neurosciences and are contributing building blocks of knowledge in many others such as systems biology and genomics. Imaging has come of age and occupies an important position in the pantheon of research methods. Atherosclerosis is a major health problem associated with high morbidity, particularly in Western countries. Due to the good vessel contrast, the extended field of view coverage and the high spatial resolution, MR-angiography (MRA) is the modality of choice for the detection and grading of atherosclerotic lesions. Its three-dimensional character allows for an exact grading of stenoses. Complications of atherosclerosis such as focal dissections, aneurysms or vessel occlusions with collateral vessels can be exactly demonstrated. In combination with morphologic sequences, the evaluation of atherosclerotic plaque composition is also feasible. This lecture will give a comprehensive overview on imaging of atherosclerosis with a focus on MRA.

The specific advantages and drawbacks of MRA will be highlighted and MRA will be compared with other available imaging techniques such as CTA and Doppler ultrasound. Typical sites of atherosclerotic vessel involvement and typical imaging findings will be presented. Appropriate MRA-protocols will be presented in due consideration of parallel imaging techniques, dedicated contrast agents and of high-field imaging. The lecture will also present suitable means of post-processing for accurate detection and grading of stenoses. Contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance angiography (CE-MRA) has revolutionized vascular imaging in recent years and has become a widely accepted alternative to intra-arterial digital subtraction angiography (IA-DSA). The modality allows for routine, high-fidelity depiction of the neurovascular, thoracic, abdominal, upper-and lower extremity vascular trees. In addition, CE-MRA is a minimally invasive and truly three-dimensional (3D) imaging modality. After data acquisition has been completed the vascular tree can be viewed from any desired perspective; at the same time information about the relationship between vascular structures and surrounding tissues can be obtained. In this lecture we will discuss different non-atherosclerotic causes of arterial disease and how MRI can be used to differentiate the different causes. Although advanced atherosclerosis is the underlying cause of peripheral arterial occlusive disease in the vast majority of patients, in up to 20% of patients, diseases other than atherosclerosis may be responsible for the complaints. Patient demographics incongruent with the typical history and complaints of intermittent claudication or chronic critical ischemia, or lesions found in atypical locations may provide clues to an alternative etiology such thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease), different forms of vasculitis, cystic adventitial disease, connective tissue diseases or vascular compression syndromes.

Learning Objectives: 1. To become familiar with the major differential diagnoses of nonatherosclerotic disease including vasculitis, congenital disease and dysplastic changes. It has long been recognized that the inherent tissue contrast between liver parenchyma and liver tumors is greater for magnetic resonance (MR) than computed tomography (CT). This is especially true when comparing unenhanced CT and unenhanced MR. However, this inherent advantage has not necessarily thrust MR ahead of CT in clinical practice. The comparison between CT and MR is complicated by the fact that neither CT nor MR is reliant solely upon unenhanced imaging and because the various imaging parameters are widely different. For example, CT tends to have a major advantage over MR in terms of in-plane spatial resolution, slice thickness, interslice gap and acquisition speed. MR, on the other hand, has the ability to acquire many more post-contrast enhancement phases, due to the lack of ionizing radiation. In general, post-contrast imaging with either iodine and CT or gadolinium and MR yields similar enhancement patterns since both are small molecular weight extracellular agents. In the past, MR and gadolinium-based agents were preferred over CT and iodine-based agents in patients with renal insufficiency. This advantage no longer exists, however, due to the recent elucidation of nephrogenic systemic fibrosis. MR-cholangiography does have an advantage over CT in the biliary tree and is particularly useful for depicting intrahepatic bile duct anatomy in patients being evaluated prior to living-related liver transplantation. Furthermore, some gadolinium-based contrast agents (i.e. Multihance) demonstrate delayed biliary excretion which can be helpful for characterizing certain tumors such as focal nodular hyperplasia. Multidetector helical CT (MDCT), with its faster rotation times, has led to new dimensions in spatial and temporal resolution in CT imaging. One-millimeter slice collimation or less can be applied that leads to isotropic voxels and allows very high quality multiplanar and 3-D image reconstructions. In the assessment of pancreatic disease, MDCT is mainly used to improve spatial resolution. MIP and minIP reformations allow for assessment of both pancreatic vessels and duct. The evaluation of resectability in patients with pancreatic cancer remains a diagnostic challenge, especially regarding the preoperative assessment of vascular invasion. Thin-slice multiplanar reconstructions obtained with MDCT provide an exact depiction of the spatial relation between the tumor and the potentially invaded vessels and thus have the capability to improve the assessment of local resectability. MDCT remains the standard of reference technique for the assessment of most pancreatic diseases, including pancreatic cancer, endocrine or cystic tumors, acute and chronic pancreatitis. MRI is a strong competitor in terms of evaluation of biliary and pancreatic ducts and is useful for the evaluation of associated liver disease. In the 1990s, CT questioned the role of intravenous urography (IVU) in a number of clinical conditions, i.e. renal colic, trauma, uroseptic fever, obstructive uropathy. More recently, the spread of MDCT units, which allow the capture of urographic images comparable to those obtained with IVU, offered the possibility of substituting IVU in clinical situations where imaging of the entire urinary system with detailed calyceal evaluation was required, i.e. asymptomatic haematuria, follow-up of transitional cell carcinomas, congenital anomalies, fistulas, TB, and planning of difficult endourological procedures. Nevertheless, a very limited number of comparative studies are available and above all the radiation issue scared the radiological community: the radiation exposure in MDCT exceeded the dose for IVU significantly. However, the radiation dose largely varies in the literature, depending on the CT urographic protocols, and more specifically on scanning parameters and number of phases. The efforts of the manufacturers and additional protocols refinements will probably allow further reduction of the X-ray dose, but the best way to lower it is the radiologists' awareness and their selection of different approaches. CTU technique, similar to IVU, has to be tailored to the clinical problem, high X-ray dose being justifiable in patients at high risk of neoplasms, not in patients with a very high probability of having benign disease. Such a tailored approach is highly likely to provide CTU the possibility of cancelling the residual role of IVU. Coronary CT angiography was the topic of numerous publications, presentations and extensive discussion over the last 5 years. As the technology starts to mature, the questions arise whether the new developments would further improve the results of the method, whether the excellent image quality and preliminary results would be sufficient to define the clinical role of the method and, last but not least, whether additional costs arising from the introduction of this technique would be balanced by the expected benefits. Expert speakers on technology development, clinical application and cost effectiveness of coronary CTA will ellaborate on these questions and, in a final panel discussion, we will try to identify those patients who cannot benefit from this technology. Since its introduction, coronary CTA has progressively advanced from an imaging modality applied for research purposes to that of a widely used diagnostic tool that has in the meantime fully entered the daily clinical practice. Even with 64-section CT scanners, limitations in cardiac imaging were perceptible that mainly included the high, but limited, temporal resolution. Thus, coronary CTA was of limited diagnostic value in patients with high heart rates and arrhythmia. In addition, obesity and severe calcifications hindered an accurate diagnosis and the results were unsatisfying in many cases. Using coronary CTA as a clinical tool, the entire coronary artery tree has to be depicted with diagnostic image quality. Otherwise, the patient will not benefit from this procedure as he would need to undergo subsequent invasive work-up in clinical practice. The novel dual-source technology solves many of the problems of previous scanner types and also introduces approaches to reduce radiation exposure to the patient. Image quality of dual-source CT is improved in patients with high and irregular heart rates, obviating the need to administer betablockers prior to the scan. Besides new scanner types, software improvements of existing CT technology such as cardiac sequence technique may be applicable in selected patients with low and stable heart rates. Future technical developments including 256-section CT and flat-panel CT will be explained, and promises and limitations in the application of these technologies will be discussed. Especially since the introduction of 64-slice CT, coronary CT angiography has become increasingly robust. Under certain conditions, the technique allows to reliably demontstrate and rule out coronary stenoses. However, relative to the small dimensions and rapid motion of the heart, the spatial and temporal resolution of CT are still somewhat limited. Also, CT angiography is a purely diagnostic technique, which does not allow immediate intervention. Selection of patients for CT angiography must therefore follow two important principles: Patient conditions must be favourable for high image quality and the information that can be gained by CT angiography must be clinically useful in the individual patient´s situation. Patient characteristics that will usually allow high and diagnostic image quality are a relatively slow and regular heart rate (preferably below 60/min), the ability to perform a breath hold of ~10 s and the absence of morbid obesity. Since a contrast agent is necessary, renal failure is a relative contraindication. Clinically, the benefit of CT angiography will be limited in the setting of high pre-test likelihood of disease, because CT, as opposed to cardiac catheterization, does not allow immediate intervention in case a stenosis is found. In many patients, however, the symptoms, the results of stress tests or other findings will mandate the rule out of coronary artery stenoses, while pre-test likelihood is not very high. In these situations, coronary CT angiography can be very beneficially applied. However, only if coronary CTA is expertly performed and interpreted, will it be clinically useful. The diagnostic accuracy of non-invasive (imaging) tests for coronary artery disease (CAD) has been extensively evaluated in literature. Inspite of the low sensitivity and specificity of stress ECGs (in men 72 and 77%, respectively; in women 61 and 70%, respectively), it is still being used as an initial test in most hospitals. In two recently published systematic reviews and meta-analyses of non-invasive imaging tests (Heijenbrok Am Heart J 2007; Vanhoenacker Radiology 2007), we found the following pooled sensitivity and specificity results and associated 95% confidence intervals: stress echocardiography (155 studies): sensitivity 79% (78-81%), specificity 87% (86-89%); stress SPECT (70 studies): sensitivity 88% (87-90%), specificity 73% (69-77%); CT calcium scoring (21 studies): sensitivity 93% (91-96%), specificity 55% (45-64%); 64-detector MD-CTA (6 studies): sensitivity 93% (88-97%), specificity 96% (96-97%). Optimizing the diagnostic imaging strategies for patients with chest pain could potentially result in major health benefits and cost savings. The estimated effects on health and cost will depend on the prior probability of CAD, the non-invasive tests performed and the consequences of missing the diagnosis of CAD on long-term outcomes. For example, replacing the conventional workup consisting of stress ECG plus stress SPECT plus coronary angiography if indicated (total mean diagnostic costs Euro 2000-3000) with a single non-invasive imaging test (e.g. MD-CTA, diagnostic costs Euro 500) can potentially increase the number of CAD cases identified annually in Europe by approximately 150,000 and reduce the diagnostic workup costs by roughly 2 billion Euro annually. The role of imaging in the accurate detection and diagnosis of tumours of the spine is dependent on the inherent sensitivity and specificity of the imaging modalities, the interpretative and processing skills of the reporting radiologist and a sound knowledge of the biological behaviour of the different tumoral pathological entities. This short talk will therefore focus on the strengths and weaknesses of the imaging modalities, the imaging signs used in the detection of spinal pathology and the differentiating imaging features related to the specific tumoral conditions. Tumour-like conditions will also be included in the differential diagnosis as well as coverage of the interventional radiological techniques used in the diagnosis and treatment of tumours of the spine. Infective spondylitis represents 2-4% of all cases of osteomyelitis and is increasing in prevalence. The most common causative pyogenic organisms are Gram-positive bacteria, mainly Staphylococcus aures. Rarely, spondylitis is the result of infection with Gram-negative bacteria or nonpyogenic micro-organisms (Mycobacterium tuberculosis). Typically, the lumbar spine is involved, followed in frequency by the thoracic, sacral and cervical spine infection. The hematogenous spread of infection via arterial or venous system is the most common route of contamination. It may be also the result of different spinal operations, the extension of infection per continutatem from a contiguous focus or direct implantation of micro-organisms following diagnostic or therapeutic disc punctures. Vertebral infections, pyogenic as well as granulomatous, represent serious disease entities, which if left unrecognised may cause neurological compromise and late spinal deformities. Therefore an early diagnosis with prompt treatment is of utmost clinical importance and mainly based on the use of different imaging modalities. In practice, bone scintigraphy, conventional radiography, CT and MRI are utilised. Due to its high sensitivity and specificity, MRI The increase in the number of surgical spinal procedures makes imaging of the postoperative spine ever more important. The rate of complications both acute, such as bleeding, infection or dural tears, or late onset, such as recurrent herniation, spinal stenosis, pseudoarthrosis, accelerated degeneration or instability, has been multiplying. There is a variety of imaging techniques available for the diagnostic evaluation of the postsurgical spine, including conventional X-rays, computed tomography and MR imaging. Imaging findings depend on the pathology for which the surgery was performed, the patient's individual anatomy, the segmental level and the kind of surgical procedure as well as the time after operative treatment. Since several complications of the surgical procedure as well as superimposition of the original disease process and surgery-related alterations may complicate the interpretation of imaging findings, one or the combination of different imaging techniques may be required. Both the instrumented and non-instrumented postsurgical spine will be discussed in this presentation including procedures such as simple herniectomies, fusion surgery using cages and/or instrumentation. Signs represent an easy way of mnemonics, characterized by the imagination of the radiologists who first described them. Signs either represent a pathognomonic finding of a disease or a radiological finding suggesting a list of various disorders. The most commonly found signs in disorders of the axial skeleton will be explored interactively, including the following: posterior vertebral scalloping, ivory and pancake vertebra, fluid-fluid level, hair-on-end, salt-and-pepper calvarium, reverse hamburger bun, naked facet and fluid-sign/vacuum intervertebral cleft. Many of the above signs are depicted with a certain imaging modality. Others are depicted with more than one imaging modality. The explanation of the signs will be highlighted in detail. Multiple signs are described in musculoskeletal radiology and have been designed for educational reasons. Indeed, many of these signs are easy to remember and are particularly helpful for effective communication with the referring clinician, because they refer to ordinary things from daily life. The nomenclature is very variable. Some signs are specific for a certain location (e.g. double PCL sign, anterior drawer sign, boutonniere deformity, heel pad sign), whereas others are not (e.g. onion peel appearance, button sequestrum). Many signs are named after food (e.g. cookie bite sign, sausage digit, broccoli sign), others resemble animals (e.g. anteater nose sign, sea gull's wing, swan neck deformity), or refer to specific tools or objects (e.g. absent bow tie, spade hand, Erlenmeyer flask deformity). Still others are named after famous persons (e.g. Terry Thomas sign). In this lecture, examples will be given of classic signs of the peripheral musculoskeletal system, which will be particularly helpful in making a confident diagnosis or differential diagnosis. The initial investigation of a pelvic mass is invariably with ultrasound. Analysis is based on the following criteria: size; calcifications; septa; wall thickness; papillarities; mixed cystic and solid state; blood flow; contrast enhancement; and abnormalities outside the presenting lesion. Certain benign lesions such as haemorrhagic cysts and dermoid tumours can present characteristic features. Clot retraction and the change of blood with time can accurately define a haemorrhagic cyst. Likewise, a fat/fluid level, echogenic plug or dermoid mesh indicate a dermoid tumour. Appropriate clinical features help too; for instance, fever points towards an abscess and pregnancy and pain in someone known to have a fibroid suggests fibroid degeneration. Papillarities, a mixed cystic and solid pattern and evidence of disease outside the presenting lesion are strong pointers to a malignant lesion. When an adnexal mass is found, the operator must take into account the age, menstrual status, prior and presenting history as well as the ultrasound appearances in deciding the nature of the lesion. Possible decisions are: a) benign, no follow-up needed; b) benign, but needs removal or other treatment; c) most likely benign, follow-up with ultrasound after an interval; d) possibly benign, but level of uncertainty high, proceed to MR to characterise the lesion; e) malignant, proceed to CT scan for staging. Finally, in patients unfit or unsuitable for surgery, biopsy may be needed to confirm the nature of a tumour. Transabdominal omental biopsy or transvaginal biopsy of a pelvic mass are well tolerated and provide reliable results. Ultrasound is the first line imaging modality to assess a suspected adnexal mass. However, overall approximately 20% of masses on US are considered as indeterminate. MRI has been established as a powerful modality to further investigate these lesions. The latter include benign complex masses, such as dermoids, endometrioma or other benign hemorrhagic lesions, leiomyomas, fibrothecomas, hydropyosalpinx and ovarian cancer. The purpose of further imaging these lesions includes a) identification of the origin, b) differentiation of benign from malignant tumors and c) differentiation of benign lesions that warrant intervention from those that do not. Characterisation of an adnexal mass by MRI is based upon morphologic features, signal characteristics and perfusion. In indeterminate masses, a diagnostic algorithm will be presented, which depends on the findings using standard MRI with T1 and T2WI. Such lesions are divided into the three following categories: a mass bright on T1, a mass dark on T2WI and a cystic solid mass. Depending on these features further characterisation is possible by using additional sequences including fat saturation, chemical shift imaging or contrast enhanced imaging. CT staging, especially multislice CT, is the modality of choice for staging ovarian cancer. The prognosis of patients with ovarian cancer is still related to the tumor stage at laparoscopy and residual tumor after cytoreductive surgery. Nevertheless, tumor debulking is not always possible because of the tumor extent and planning surgery might be difficult. Thus, the three roles of imaging are to select the candidates for primary chemotherapy if the lesions are nonresectable, to determine the best sites for biopsies in case of peritoneal carcinomatosis, and to help to define the therapeutic strategies in a multidisciplinary approach. Resectability on imaging depends on two major factors, lesion size and location. The imaging criteria for predicting nonresectable disease must be known and include abdominal wall invasion, retroperitoneal presacral disease, lymph node involvement above the renal hilum, peritoneal implants 2 cm (porta hepatis, intersegmental fissure, gastrosplenic and gastrohepatic ligaments, diaphragm) and invasion of small bowel mesentery. CT staging must include chest, abdominal and pelvic images to detect also distant metastasis. In case of nonrespectable lesion, the treatment must begin with primary chemotherapy in order to allow debulking surgery. Nevertheless, sensitivity of CT is still low in detecting small peritoneal implants ( 2 cm). Whole body MR imaging, as for all potential screening methodologies, has to diagnose curable problems with minimal false negative findings. Only recently has it become possible to examine the whole body in an acceptable time frame.

To begin with, it is likely to be used for just one system, such as examining the musculoskeletal system for bone and soft tissue metastases. Later, it may be used for a wider search. The panellists will discuss progress and some of the associated controversies. Screening is a rather new application of MRI. Single organ MRI can be performed for tumor screening, for coronary heart disease or stroke. Whole-body (wb) MRA for the first time allowed "whole body" imaging. Wb-MRA can be extended to a rather "complete" imaging work-up of atherosclerosis, if the brain and heart are included. This concept of "disease-specific" screening can also be transferred to malignancies. Imaging often consists of either fluid-sensitive or 3D gradient-echo sequences, which cover the whole body. After adequate preparation, also MR colonography can be added. Within an acceptable examination time of 90 min, these two strategies (atherosclerosis and tumor screening) can be combined into a "total" screening protocol. One of the limitations of wb-MR screening is that unexpected abnormalities will be discovered, and that many structures, though included in the field of view, might not be evaluable (joints, small bowel, prostate, breast). The amount of image data may have its part in the rate of false negative findings. The few existing studies on screening usually deal with novel MR techniques. Screening studies in non-selected groups of asymptomatic individuals show low prevalences of malignancies or atherosclerosis; prospective studies are still lacking. Extended table movement range and simultaneous multi-channel data acquisition allow for wb coverage and parallel imaging. Data acquisition with a moving table promises faster imaging, thus potentially reducing examination costs. Despite all technical advances, MRI will need to be subjected to prospective cohort studies to provide a detailed investigation of parameters determining cost effectiveness. Previously, authors have emphasised the role of whole body MRI (WBMRI) as an alternative to bone scan in the detection of skeletal metastases, in the assessment of total tumour volume in breast carcinoma, in unknown tumour detection, in the evaluation of multiple myeloma and lymphoma and in the assessment of muscle diseases. In most cases, WBMRI has replaced a multimodality approach facilitating diagnosis and staging as a single study. This talk describes the relative cost-effectiveness of WBMRI in clinical practice by comparing it to conventional strategies. A diagnostic test is said to be "cost-effective" when the additional benefits it provides are considered to be good value for the money spent, usually by comparison to an alternative conventional strategy. There are four types of full economic evaluation (cost minimization analysis, cost-benefit analysis, cost-effectiveness analysis and cost-utility analysis) [Unsupported Character -⁹]. This talk focuses on the use of cost-effectiveness analysis to calculate cost per additional unit benefit of WBMRI as an alternative to conventional strategies in day-to-day clinical practice employing reimbursable costs of major European health-care insurers. The presentation focuses on the ethical dimension of the value of whole body MR imaging (WBMRI). What can 'ethics' contribute to the evaluation of WBMRI? Ethical orientation regarding complex practical questions needs to be based on reasoning, but it should take empirical data into account as well. Ethical core concepts and approaches will be identified that may be useful for this purpose. Ethical evaluation relies on principles of medial ethics such as respecting patient autonomy, especially through obtaining informed consent. Procedural ethics goes beyond the individual patient-related approach; it includes discourse and consensus building at the level of professional teams, institutions, academic societies or other relevant groups. Combining ethical principles and procedural approaches allows for the development of guidelines or other "tools" that may help to make ethically justified judgments. Studies have raised concern that informed consent and autonomous patient decision-making do not always lead to convincing results. Offering expensive services with potentially complex consequences for the patient may increase these difficulties. There is evidence of a lack of transparency and unfairness in the use of limited resources, especially in costly diagnostics. Spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage is a common cause of an acute focal neurologic deficit and represents up to 15-20% of all strokes. The purpose of this presentation is to review imaging findings in various types of spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhages and to summarize their characteristic appearance on different imaging modalities. Patients with intracranial hemorrhage can present a formidable diagnostic challenge to the clinician. Moreover, neuro-imaging findings of intracerebral hemorrhage are highly variable and depend on many factors such as imaging technique (US, CT, MRI), location of the hemorrhage (basal ganglia, brainstem, hemispheres, etc.), age of the bleed (hyperacute, acute, subacute, chronic), underlying lesion (cavernous malformation, amyloid angiopathy), etc. The role of the radiologist is threefold: 1) to consult with the clinician and recommend the optimal imaging strategy; 2) to establish the correct diagnosis and determine the cause of the hemorrhage; 3) to participate in the treatment planning of the patient. Ultrasonography plays an important role in the detection of perinatal hemorrhage (premature infants). In the adult population, CT is the method of choice in the hyperacute and acute stages of intracerebral hemorrhage, whereas MR is the preferred technique in chronic hemorrhage. To illustrate the degradation of blood products, we shall discuss the CT and MR characteristics of hyperacute, acute, subacute, early and late chronic hemorrhages. MR is particularly useful in detecting sequelae of diffuse axonal injury due to shearing stresses. In conclusion, a comprehensive understanding of the pathophysiology and evolution of an intracerebral hemorrhage is essential to adequately interpret the imaging findings. Stroke is a well-known clinical syndrome that is caused by an acute event leading to ischemia of the brain or an intracranial hemorrhage. Apart from such acute presentations, cerebrovascular diseases can also develop more gradually. Various conditions can be responsible for such a protracted course. Such conditions can affect the carotid arteries, the large intracranial vessels or the small vessels of the brain. The underlying diseases affecting these vessels are heterogeneous and comprise conditions such as atherosclerosis, fibrohyalinosis, amyloid angiopathy and vasculitis. These conditions often remain undetected during life, whereas the evidence is growing that they are major contributors to conditions such as agerelated cognitive decline and intracranial hemorrhages. Learning Objectives: 1. To learn the clinical presentation of chronic cerebral vascular disease. 2. To understand the advantages and drawbacks of the various radiological techniques for imaging the brain parenchyma and the intracranial and neck vessels. 3. To be able to establish a cost-effective diagnostic strategy for patients with suspected vascular brain disease. 4. To learn the differential diagnosis of chronic cerebral vascular diseases. CVT is a rare disease compared with arterial stroke; however, in recent years more frequent cases have been diagnosed due to improved imaging techniques. The annual incidence of CVT is 3-4/1 million population. Most of the adult are women of childbearing age. A wide spectrum of symptoms can be found with acute (37.2%), subacute (55.3%) or chronic (7.2%) onset. The most frequent symptom is headache, but seizures, focal neurologic deficits and even coma can be detected. MR with venography is considered, at the present time, to be the most sensitive non-invasive technique. T1 and T2 sequences show thrombus and depending on the signal, the age of the clot can be evaluated. Abnormal signal in a sinus plus corresponding absence of flow void in venography confirms the diagnosis. MR is also very sensitive to parenchymal changes. Disadvantages of MR compared to CT are that it is time consuming, the patient needs to collaborate, it is not widely available and requires experienced professionals to avoid pitfalls. CT is almost always the fisrt choice exam because of accessibility, speed and simplicity. Direct and indirect signs can be visualized, but an entirely normal exam can also be found. Spiral CT and more recently multidetector-row CT has increased tremendously the sensivity in the diagnosis of CVT. Disadvantages include the need of contrast injection and radiation. CT and MR are competitive and complementary techniques, the choice between which depends on experience and accessibility to the equipments. Future prospects seem to indicate that CT/angio will probably be the elective procedure in the acute phase and MR with major applications in the follow-up of patients with CVT. The major advantage of PET/CT is that in a single instrument it adds anatomical detail (CT images) to molecular PET images. Three potential applications of PET/CT can be distinguished: 1. Diagnostic studies, where accurate localization of metabolic abnormalities is vital for clinical decision making (e.g. staging), requiring a PET study in combination with a full clinical CT scan. 2. Quantitative PET studies, where anatomical precision is less vital. In this case a low-dose CT scan for attenuation correction purposes may suffice. 3. Treatment planning studies for radiotherapy, where addition of a PET scan allows in adding molecular information (e.g. metabolic activity or degree of hypoxia) to the conventional anatomical approach. PET and CT scans are not acquired simultaneously. In practice, the patient's bed moves from the CT to the adjacent PET gantry. As the patient remains in the same position, however, there is no need for fusing the images. For many PET studies, quantification is required. A PET/CT scanner can therefore only be used optimally if it still allows such quantitative studies. In this respect, the main difference between PET/CT and stand alone PET is the way in which attenuation correction is performed. Therefore, attention should especially be given to the issue of mismatch between CT and PET data, leading to attenuation of correction artefacts. This could be due to patient movement (between scans) or inappropriate bed design (bending between gantries). Attention should also be given to the accuracy of attenuation correction, especially when using contrast material for CT or with metal implants. Recently, imaging devices integrating a CT scanner with a dual-headed SPECT camera have been developed. Furthermore, considerable progress has been made also in the field of software-based image registration, since data compatibility between different modalities has been much improved. However, evidence on the anatomical accuracy of software-based registration between SPECT and CT is still scarce; most authors report the anatomical inaccuracy of that technique to be in the order of 1 cm. With SPECT/CT hybrid imaging, the accuracy of image fusion is expected to be much better. The first known data show that the anatomical mismatch between SPECT and CT is approximately 1 mm in regions of the body not moved by respiration and in the order of 4 mm for thoracic and abdominal lesions. In SPECT/CT data sets, CT may be used for attenuation correction of the SPECT images. Applying this technique to skeletal scintigrams, the deeper structures of the body will gain in counts compared to the more superficially located parts of the skeleton. However, misalignments between SPECT and CT will lead to considerable artefacts when attenuation correction is used. Therefore, for the clinical application of that technology, an exact data match is mandatory and it should be employed cautiously. The high anatomical accuracy of image registration by SPECT/CT offers the potential to exactly relate SPECT abnormalities to an anatomical region and elucidate unclear SPECT findings by obtaining a CT in the same imaging session. This potential greatly enhances diagnostic accuracy, which will also be demonstrated in this lecture. The combination of MR and PET poses severe challenges due to the fact that the photo multiplier tubes (PMT) used in today's PET scanners cannot be operated in high-magnetic fields. Therefore various groups pursued different concepts to overcome these problems: 1. Use of a heavy magnetic shielding between the MR magnet and the PET camera. 2. Use of light guides to place the PMTs further out of the magnetic field. 3. Use of avalanche photodiodes (APD) instead of PMT to construct an MR-compatible PET camera. A second challenge to MR-PET is the attenuation correction of -Quants. It is actually one of the merits of PET-CT that this information is gained out of the CT image at no cost, via the Hounsfield units. On the contrary, MR images provide no equivalent. Therefore, alternative approaches can be based on 1. image segmentation and classification; 2. machine-based learning from PET-CT -MR reference data; 3. atlas-based approaches. Several groups have published MR-PET images based on the different approaches and thus provided the proof of principle for each approach. In addition, rodent images with functional studies have been achieved with the light guide/PMT as well as with the APD approach. Lately, also human brain images have been acquired. Many academic groups as well as industry are solving the technical challenges of MR-PET integration. The availability of fully functional demonstrators for rodent and human imaging will pave the road map for clinical MR-PET applications. In this lecture, attention will be focused on gas distribution in abdominal emergencies and on acute mechanical problems like malrotation and intussusception. Abdominal trauma is not included. Plain abdominal films are frequently obtained in abdominal emergencies. The importance of gas distribution is discussed with special attention on free intraperitoneal air. The most important abdominal emergency is a malrotation complicated by volvulus. Absent or incomplete rotation of the primitive bowel results in a small mesenteric root, which predisposes the bowel to a volvulus with possibly bowel necrosis. Ladds bands, which run from the liver across the abdomen may accompany a malrotation and can cause obstruction, mostly of the distal duodenum. The radiological diagnosis is by contrast swallow and can be difficult. The transition from completely normal rotation to non-rotation is gradual and the position of the duodenal-jejunal junction is not always obvious. Meticulous technique is required to limit the "grey zone" between normal and abnormal. Ultrasound can demonstrate an inverted relationship of the superior mesenteric artery and vein as a sign of malrotation. A "whirlpool sign" means that a volvulus is present. Patients with intussusception can be dangerously weakened wih hypovolaemia and electrolyte disturbances. Proper surveillance is mandatory. The initial diagnosis of intussusception is by ultrasound. Reduction is attempted with air or liquid contrast. The results for air reduction are generally better. IBD, including Crohn Disease (CD) and Ulcerative Colitis (UC) often affect children and adolescents. Their are clinical, biological, endoscopic and histological data to approach the diagnosis and the follow-up of IBD. Imaging data play a major place in the initial detection and the localzation of the small bowel and/or colonic intestinal lesions, to provide orientation between CD and UC, and to exclude other abdominal diseases. Ultrasonography with color Doppler is the essential first step in this direction and is adapted to appreciate the disease activity. As a complement CT or MRI are more relevant for delineation of gut extension and to assert complications as abscess or fistulae.Our objectives are to point the current place of US, MRI and sometimes CT in the diagnosis and follow-up of IBD specifically in children. 1. To provide a general overview of the common inflammatory bowel diseases in children. There are a wide variety of imaging modalities of value in evaluation of biliary tract disorders in children: High-resolution real-time ultrasonography is the imaging modality of choice for screening. MR cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) plays an increasing role; but in young children sedation is needed. MRCP uses the signal from the bile within the ducts to allow visualisation of the biliary system. MDCT is indicated in selected cases. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography is invasive and requires general anaesthesia.Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography is very useful in treatment of complications of liver transplantation, lithiasis and malignant obstructive jaundice. Hepatobiliary scintigraphy uses a tracer (HIDA) that is taken up by the liver and excreted into the billiary tract. It can be used to diagnose bile leakage. There are numerous causes of jaundice in children. The aetiology depends on the age of the child. Obstructive and nonobstructive causes should be differentiated. Biliary atresia is defined by the atresia of the extrahepatic bile duct. It is very important to obtain an early diagnosis to afford the patient a successful outcome, but the role of imaging is limited because of the absence of dilatation of the bile ducts. Choledochal cyst is a localised dilatation of the biliary ductal system. Five types have been described. The frequency of bile plug syndrome, cholelitiasis and choledocholitiasis has been increasing. Neoplasms are very rare. Biliary problems after liver transplantation are the most common complications. They are more frequent in reduced-size transplantation. We will review biliary obstruction, bile leakage, mucocele and stones. The role of the radiographer is changing very rapidly in the 21 st century, as the education and professional development of radiographers continues to improve, and as cash limited health care economies seek ways to deliver high quality health care more efficiently. The current practice of radiography in the United Kingdom provides a case study of the enormity of change taking place in radiographers' roles. Specifically, reporting is a role that is becoming integrated into the role of the radiographer, and it is now possible for a radiographer in the UK to reach consultant level status (23 consultant radiographers in the UK at April 2007, with the number continuing to grow). Research is vital to support the enhanced roles of radiographers, and excellent professional leadership and management is essential to ensuring that radiographers can continue to increase their contributions to high quality, cost effective health care delivery. Hopefully, all radiographers with a higher education and also those pursuing a master's degree will join the communication platform and be active participants in the group. Some of the strategy document issues are to identify research needs and priority areas. The main objective is to establish radiography as a unique research discipline and thereby ensuring an evidence-based radiography practice in the future. RadForum aspires to cooperate with the other Nordic countries and to establish a new board of directors at The Nordic Congress in Copenhagen 2009. The possibility to share a common open web site with an internet-based peer-reviewed journal will be a progression which will encourage the collaboration between radiographers in the Nordic countries.

1. To learn about The Norwegian Radiography Research Group.

2. To learn about the research activity among Norwegian radiographers. 3. To understand the potential to radiography research. 4. To become familiar with the term "science of radiography". 5. To appreciate radiography as a unique discipline with its own knowledge base.

Technology is made to be used (Dahlbom 1997). Radiology Informatics is a discipline focusing on the use of information and communication technology (ICT) within radiology. The CLINTEC Department at Karolinska Institute has a new research group with its discipline within Radiology Informatics. The aim of the group is to analyse and present how work changes as medical staff and new information technology become intertwined and how we can design the information technology of the future. The group of researchers applied both ethnographic qualitative and quantitative research methods. The studies were conducted at the Swedish radiology departments. Our interest lies firstly on how radiology becomes distributed and thereafter how distributed work changes the healthcare organisation. Distributed work includes the sharing and transferral of data within and across health organisations. It requires more than new technology, good ideas, strong leaders, positive framework and extensive resources; it also requires a deep competence in what may be labeled "the virtual organisation". Realising the virtual organisation will have effects on individual's work i.e. how they perform work, their understanding of work and the way they think of work. What these effects will be cannot be foreseen. Increased competence of radiology informatics can improve the design and use of ICT, just as it can improve our understanding of the effect on work and professional roles of digitalisation.

Hence, quantification of contrast enhancement provides information about tumour behaviour supplementary to that obtained from tumour morphology, aiding tumour diagnosis and evaluation of therapeutic response. Simple measures of enhancement are affected by factors other than angiogenesis, e.g. patient weight and amount of contrast medium, and more advanced quantification can reduce such variability. Methods for assessing heterogeneity of tumour enhancement are emerging. Analysis of contrast enhancement is simpler and more widely available than many other methods for imaging angiogenesis. Furthermore, angiogenesis does not always parallel other aspects of tumour physiology such as glucose metabolism. Uncoupling of tumour vascularity and glucose metabolism is more common in aggressive tumours and may develop in response to therapy. Multi-modality imaging of vascular-metabolic relationships can therefore provide further insights into tumour behaviour and sub-classify response. There are a number of commonly available MRI techniques that are able to evaluate vascular functionality in clinical practice. The most commonly known technique is dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI (DCE-MRI) exploiting susceptibility and relaxivity MRI mechanisms. This lecture will outline the biological basis of the observations seen and show that imaging data can be analysed quantitatively or qualitatively for the purposes of lesion characterisation and for assessing response to therapy (to conventional and novel therapeutic methods). The strengths and weaknesses of these two analysis techniques will be compared given the emergence of sophisticated analysis techniques now being launched by software/hardware companies. Attendees will also be guided on emerging techniques that are likely to impact on the field in the intermediate future.

A-283 17:00 C. Information you can get J.O. Barentsz; Nijmegen/NL (J. Barentsz@rad.umcn.nl) In this course, the available postprocessing methods for evaluating dynamic MRI results will be shown. Simple methods evaluate the level at the start of enhancement, at peak enhancement, and at wash-out; more sophisticated methods show semiquantitative parameters, such as time of start, time to peak, and slope of wash-in and wash-out; finally, there is true quantitative evaluation using pharmacokinetic models, providing parameters like K trans , K ep , and extracellular volume. These methods will be illustrated by showing cases of breast and prostate cancer. Also, the clinical value of dynamic MRI will be illustrated. Dynamic MRI, in general, provides important additional information on anatomic imaging, the location and extent of tumor and early response to therapy. Finally, the combined value of dynamic MRI with other functional techniques will be discussed, e.g., the combined use of dynamic MRI and MRS of prostate and breast cancers. Pulmonary nodules are commonly detected on radiography and particularly CT of the chest. In more than 50% of asymptomatic adult smokers, at least one non-calcified pulmonary nodule is detected on examining the chest with MSCT. Almost all of of these nodules are small (maximum diameter of 10 mm or less) and also more than 95% are benign. Therefore, non-invasive techniques are required to diagnose the very few malignant nodules among the many benign lesions. Different modalities are available: 1. Follow-up with unenhanced low-dose thin-section CT to detect or exclude growth, ideally utilizing computer-assisted volumetry for early detection of growth. The aim of radiological staging of a bronchogenic carcinoma is to determine its clinical stage to solve the problem "What is the adequate treatment?" The first question concerns T, the tumour. CT is the best and its aspects may have prognostic consequences. The second question is "What is the node dissemination, N?" CT has an advantage, which is its good spatial resolution, especially in the hila, and the functional drawbacks are completed by PET/CT. The last question is "Does metastasis exist, M? CT and PET/CT are completed by MRI of the brain. Anywhere, sometimes guided by clinical signs but often silent, it is mandatory to search for metastases since they contraindicate surgery, modify the general treatment and, sometimes, require local treatment, including radiofrequency. Finally, depending on the clinical stage (I-IV) and the WHO clinical status, the patient can be included in a standard protocol, even with a pathologic stage, or benefit from a new therapeutic approach. Staging a patient with bronchogenic carcinoma implies an accurate determination of the size of the tumour, the potential infiltration of the tumour into the adjacent structures, the involvement of hilar and mediastinal lymph nodes and the detection of distant metastases. Recently, combined PET/CT scanners have been introduced in clinical practice. These systems permit the acquisition of PET and CT images coregistered by means of the hardware in the same imaging session. The major benefit of PET/CT lies in the direct link between the information on metabolic changes of structures and the highly detailed anatomic CT information of these structures. The additional information of integrated PET/CT can be the following: 1. Detection of lesions initially not seen on CT or PET. 2. A more precise localisation of lesions, a better delineation of the surrounding structures and a better distinction between tumour and distal atelectasis. 3. A better characterisation of the lesion as benign or malignant. The benefit of PET/CT compared with PET in nodal staging appears to lie in an increase in specificity. According to the literature, an important contribution of FDG/PET is its ability to exclude malignancy in most distant lesions with equivocal CT. Integrated PET/CT can be valuable since exact correlation of the FDG accumulation becomes possible. The general conclusion can be that integrated PET/CT will be the oncological staging "one-stop-shop" examination of the future for staging bronchogenic carcinoma. Information derived from cancer imaging provides a fundamental framework to direct subsequent approaches. However, this information is becoming increasingly complex with the development of new and more sophisticated technologies. Breast anatomy is extremely variable depending on age, personal constitution, hormonal status, and physiological changes with pregnancy, lactation and menopause. Appropriate knowledge of this normal variability is fundamental to the identification and characterization of artefacts as well as pathological findings. Stavros has extensively described several sonographic features that should be considered in the differential diagnosis of breast lesions, including mass shape, orientation, margin characteristics, lesion boundary, echo pattern, posterior acoustic beam behaviour, surrounding tissue changes, and vascularity. A synthesis of such heterogeneous sonographic signs has been developed by the American College of Radiology and described in The Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) for US. This system provides a standardised language for inter-professional and inter-institutional communication in order to improve the overall management of the lesions. MRI of the breast identifies glandular tissue regardless of the amount of underlying fat tissue and demonstrates skin, nipple and chest wall components adequately. Motion artifacts are minimized in prone patient positioning in a breast coil, hands against legs and head positioned on a front holder allowing breathing with a relaxed neck. Because the detection of breast lesions relies on visualization of abnormal contrast enhancement during T1-weighted imaging, the suppression of white fatty signal intensity is mandatory. Subtraction of precontrast images from post-contrast images is a technique used in both 2D and 3D sequences; spectral fat suppression and water excitation are other fat suppression techniques. Abnormal enhancement is close to vessel enhancement but exhibits unusual morphology (spiculated borders, rim enhancement, segmental enhancement, irregular linear enhancement, etc.) and may display washout kinetics. The description of both morphological and kinetic enhancement characteristics follows the BI-RADS lexicon to allow standardization and clinical acceptance of results. The interpretation of enhancing elements within a breast into a risk category of malignancy takes into account the patient's age, phase of the menstrual cycle, personal risk of breast cancer and history of or current medical, surgical and radiation therapy. According to the clinical situation an abnormal finding may be read differently. Knowledge of tumor histology in patients with known breast cancer is also important as invasive lobular cancer, medullary breast cancer or ductal carcinoma in situ often not exhibit washout kinetics. A comparison with prior mammography and ultrasound is crucial for integrating the findings of MRI in the final diagnosis. Teleradiology is probably the most extensively developed area of telemedicine.

There are no doubts about its added value to healthcare, particularly in reference to imaging services. When used appropriately, teleradiology can significantly improve access to quality radiological services. In this environment, new opportunities arise, making it possible to share specialised care and optimise the use of technological and human resources. This new scenario requires novel organisational approaches to define and coordinate relations among radiologists, between radiologists and clinicians, and ultimately between patients and radiologists. First and foremost, teleradiology is a means of providing the radiological image interpretation and consultation by professionals located some distance from the site where the images are acquired, due either to a lack of human resources or specialised knowledge at the institution requiring the services. Although much emphasis was formerly placed on the technological aspects involved in establishing reliable and secure connections between the different sites, a teleradiology project involves much more than overcoming physical distance. The real challenge in teleradiology today is in integrating a variety of information (not just images) into the workflow of different professionals working at least in two different institutions. Although the technical difficulties related to transferring information have been overcome, these aspects are nonetheless important today. However, it has become clear that it is even more challenging and important to establish guidelines to ensure smooth and efficient workflow and to reach a consensus regarding the criteria to determine the roles of the different professionals involved. Session Objectives: 1. To become familiar with best practice in teleradiology.

2. To learn about the different practical applications. 3. To appreciate the influence of teleradiology on future trends in organising diagnostic imaging services. 4. To emphasise the benefits, potentials and risks of teleradiology.

Quality standards J. Reponen; Raahe/FI Teleradiology is the electronic transmission of radiographic images from one geographical location to another for the purposes of interpretation and consultation. Today, the development of communication networks makes it possible to exchange images, which are of original quality and obey the DICOM standard. A successful technical framework follows the published ACR teleradiology standards and ESR guidelines. Special attention should be given to the quality of the reading workstation, but the speed and reliability of network connections and security measures are equally important. The quality of teleradiology reports is related to the contents of the requests. Often the connection to the RIS and HIS of the sending site is inadequate and not all the necessary comparison images and patient record texts are available. Thus a better integration to the electronic patient record is needed. Also, additional manual workload to the personnel should be avoided. The basis of teleradiology service is a written contract between the customer and the provider. It specifies for example the requested services, response time and the professional qualification of the reporting radiologists. A key factor is a clinical audit of the reports. In cases of cross-border services, there are additional questions related to responsibility, legal and language issues. For the buyer of services, the principal question is trust. The local hospital bears the full responsibility towards its patients. Thus, the head MR imaging of the liver is a diagnostic technique that can evaluate not only the morphological abnormalities with an impressive signal and contrast resolution, but also the functional and biochemical properties of liver diseases. MR performs better than contrast enhanced MDCT and US in the detection and characterization of liver tumors. The impact of both conventional and specific contrast agents in the clinical settings will be commented upon. However, the main topics of this lecture will be related to the ability to perform, evaluate and quantify fat and iron deposits in the liver, the degree of edema and fibrosis in the liver parenchyma, the diffusion related changes of the liver disease, the approach to quantify tissue oxygenation, and the chemical spectroscopic composition of the liver and its inflammatory disorders. Additionally, the perfusion evaluation of angiogenesis, permeability and extracellular extravasculare space through the analysis of the pharmacokinetic properties of the liver and its lesions will be shown. There is a large group of patients who can be diagnosed, treated and followed up with these new MR techniques in a proper and tailored way. New and accurate liver MR imaging parameters can detect chemical, vascular, structural and molecular changes relevant to the patients' healthcare status. With these new MR tools, which can accurately quantitate abnormalities in a reproducible way, we will be able to establish the presence and severity of a disease and its prognosis. The ability to move from technical development to clinical research, thereby impacting the workflow, is in the hands of radiologists. MDCT is considered to be the best performer in diagnosing the full range of pancreatic inflammatory and neoplastic conditions. In this setting, MRI is generally used to obtain additional information that may be useful for differential diagnosis or for planning therapy. Hardware improvements, advances in fast MRI techniques and the use of gadolinium-chelates and/or hormonal stimulation with secretin expanded the indications and improved the performance of MRI in investigating the pancreas. Using these ingredients we can assess the morphology (signal of the parenchyma and detailed imaging of the pancreatic ducts) and the exocrine function (quantification of flow in the ducts and of duodenal filling) in a single session. This approach is indicated in diagnosing the early stages of pancreatitis, in defining the cause of recurrent attacks of pancreatic pain (sphincter dysfunction, main duct strictures, and intraductal cystic neoplasms) and in detecting more subtle complications of pancreatitis that may necessitate specific endoscopic approaches such as main pancreatic duct (mpd) disruption and fistulous tracts. MRI has been reported to be as sensitive as ERCP in detecting pancreatic adenocarcinoma limited to the mpd and it may challenge MDCT in its detection abilities. However, the prediction of tumor non-resectability is poor and related to the unreliable detection of small metastatic lymph nodes and mesentery invasion. The differentiation of a focal inflammatory mass from pancreatic cancer remains a challenge. The recent advent of high-b-value diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) with acceptable SNR has brought a new "marker" in identifying pancreatic disease. Although non-specific, this approach may help in the differential diagnosis of pancreatic cancer and pancreatitis. Multi-detector row CT (MDCT) scans are changing the imaging strategies in (acute) cerebral ischemia and are proving to be an excellent way to assess the functional status of brain tissue. Non-contrast CT remains valuable in ruling out hemorrhagic stroke. Contrast-enhanced perfusion MDCT is performed during intravenous bolus injection of a high-concentration iodinated contrast agent, followed by a fast series of images. Density values change over time and reflect iodine concentration. Sequential images are combined to generate time-density plots. Software is used to calculate parametric maps which reflect blood flow (i.e. perfusion, expressed in mL/min/100 g tissue), blood volume, and mean transit time of the contrast bolus.

With advanced data processing techniques it is also possible to assess blood-vessel permeability and size of the extracellular compartment. In acute stroke, areas of reversible ischemia demonstrate reduced perfusion, but preserved blood volume. This suggests that the auto-regulation of cerebral microcirculation is intact, and that therefore the brain tissue remains viable. Patients with reversible ischemia are potential candidates for thrombolysis, to prevent progression of the ischemic region to a completed stroke. Conversely, when a reduction of both perfusion and blood volume is observed, this indicates irreversible infarction. Disadvantages of MDCT perfusion imaging include substantially higher radiation dose, markedly increased data load and the need for time-consuming data analysis. An advantage of MDCT is that, thanks to the high temporal resolution, the total quantity of contrast medium can be reduced. In conclusion, MDCT provides a better understanding of the pathophysiology of cerebral ischemia and may contribute toward improving patient outcome.

Learning Objectives: 1. To understand the impact of multidetector CT on imaging strategy in acute and chronic cerebral ischemia. 2. To discuss the optimal techniques for MDCT of the brain, with emphasis on CT perfusion and CT angiography. Multidetector computerized tomography (MDCT) has put CT back on the map of modern radiology. It is easy and quick to perform and has very few contraindications. The possibility of obtaining images in all three planes and even making oblique reconstructions is a valuable tool not only for the radiologist but also for the surgeon and the radiotherapist. MDCT of the neck should practically always be performed during intravenous contrast infusion, provided the patient does not have a renal disease. Skeletal, vascular and soft tissue lesions in the neck are revealed with high resolution. In patients with a lump in the neck as the first symptom, MDCT often shows not only the metastasis but also the primary tumor. In this oncologic population, CT of the neck should always be followed by CT of the chest and upper abdomen in the same setting, which gives the referring clinician a "one-stop shopping". At the Lund University Hospital and its referring area of 1.5 million people, fine needle cytology is the first diagnostic step taken in assessing patients with suspected tumours. MDCT is the primary radiological modality in patients with cytology-proven head-and-neck cancer. MRI is used as complementary tool in selected cases to further identify the exact tumor extension and not as a primary modality. Ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration can be used for detection of lymph node metastases. PET-CT is the latest modality introduced in this field, and preliminary results indicate that this could be used as the first modality in patients with recurrent cancer in the neck, since both CT and MR are very difficult to interpret due to post-therapeutic changes. While open surgical exploration still represents the most commonly applied surgical technique, minimally invasive surgery (MIS) is becoming widely accepted in the light of the reduction of access trauma for the patient. In addition, the surgical scenario is evolving under the influences of a number of emerging technologies. Image-guided surgery, augmented reality, intelligent surgical instruments, robotics and bioengineering are contributing to evolve the surgical procedures from a "traditional" model, based only on the surgeons' skill, to the "computer-assisted" model, where surgeons and machines work together with diagnostic imaging modalities as their guide. Full integration of advanced imaging and robotics/mechatronics into interventional radiology and minimally invasive surgical methods will result in fundamental changes in therapeutic strategies and approaches. The computer-assisted model improves the quality of surgical intervention, providing tools and methods that assist (never substitute) the surgeon in making the best use of his/her skills. Advances in technology have already resulted in sweeping changes in diagnostic radiology, and more widespread use of modern therapeutic devices, computers and advanced imaging technologies will have a far-reaching effect on surgery as well. Session Objectives: 1. To discuss the integration of advanced imaging techniques for the assessment of intra-operative anatomy. 2. To emphasise the need for a close collaboration between radiologist and surgeon in order to prevent turf battle. 3. To present the advantages of the novel approach for planning and simulating the interventional procedures.
Intraoperative navigation using radiological data and software support N. Navab; Munich/DE

The growing number of imaging modalities and the increase in their resolution have provided physicians with a large amount of heterogeneous data. However, each modality comes with its own user interface and requires considerable interaction for providing appropriate viewing during interventions. The traditional monitor-based solutions for diagnostic imaging do not satisfy interventional requirements. In order to design new medical procedures taking full advantage of the available functional and anatomical imaging, engineers and physicians have started to work closely in different labs around the world. In this presentation, we present several examples of new end-to-end solutions developed by such multidisciplinary teams. These solutions often take advantage of multimodal preoperative imaging for the creation of patient-specific anatomical and/or physiological model, allowing advanced surgical planning. Our focus in this talk is on taking full advantage of multimodal imaging intraoperatively. In order to do so, one wishes to register the preoperative data to the patient. However, due to large deformations for most abdominal applications, the preoperative data could only serve for planning and as a basic reference. For guidance during interventions, one needs to use intraoperative imaging. We present new methods for acquiring co-registered intraoperative functional and anatomical images without need for registering them to the patient. These so-called 'registrationfree' methods allow us to provide physicians with automatically fused multimodal image data as well as advanced surgical navigation. We present different examples, in which such solutions have been not only integrated within the medical workflow, but also evaluated by surgeons and interventionalists. Surgical navigators provide a visual guidance to the surgeon during the surgical procedure. In particular, passive navigation systems give a 3D representation of the surgical scenario, updated in real-time and detected by means of computer graphics techniques, and show dangerous conditions, thereby providing an alert message to the surgeon. The surgical navigator integrates the virtual scenario created preoperatively with the different information provided intraoperatively by the surgical tools (e.g. video or ultrasonography images, or sensor data of mechatronic/robotic tools). The manipulation of volumetric imaging data in an augmented reality environment ("virtual patient") is becoming commonplace, thus dramatically increasing the need for a better integration of radiological and surgical competences. Therefore, educational changes are required for both radiologists and surgeons, who will have to learn how to master the technology that empowers them to bridge between the panoramic imaging allowed by diagnostic modalities and the key-hole imaging, which is typical of minimally invasive surgery. They will have to learn to work as a team, where the radiologist (a "new type of radiologist", as the title of the discussion states) will have to support (and even to train) the surgeon by carefully tailoring dedicated processing of multimodality data sets acquired on each individual patient. This is the only way to achieve a truly personalized treatment planning and to minimize the risks of surgery. Lesions of the superior labrum and the long head of biceps tendon have recently been recognized as important sources of chronic shoulder pain and instability. Frequent sites of damage include the superior labrum and biceps anchor (superior labral anteroposterior = SLAP lesions), the proximal portion of the biceps tendon and the reflection pulley system, which is formed by the corocohumeral (CHL) and superior glenohumeral (SGHL) ligaments. Lesions of these structures can either occur in isolation or represent associated findings in patients with glenohumeral instability or rotator cuff tears. Arthrographic imaging techniques (MR and CT arthrography) appear particularly useful in depicting morphologic changes in this anatomically complex area. Recent advances in breast interventional procedures have allowed not only a significant improvement in diagnostic accuracy, but the possibility of stepping forward "minimally invasive" therapeutic indications under image guidance of benign and malignant lesions. Lobular neoplasia is a spectrum of lesions including atypical lobular neoplasia (ALH) to lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS).
