Neuroimaging plays a crucial role in the timely diagnosis of prenatal and postnatal central nervous system (CNS) infections and for therapeutic decision making. Although pyogenic infections of the central nervous system are not a frequent group of diseases in the pediatric population, their morbidity and mortally are very high. Therefore, CNS infections require prompt diagnosis and treatment for avoiding severe complications that can lead to an undesired outcome. It should be noted that the imaging findings are sufficiently specific to suggest the underlying cause in some pediatric patients. For example in uncomplicated cases of meningitis cranial computer tomography might be sufficient for clinical management. However, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is considered superior to other imaging methods in depicting subtle and early abnormalities and is therefore considered to be the method of choice in the work-up in most cases of suspected CNS infections in the pediatric population. Not only the primary CNS infection but also the sequela of CNS infection, including hydrocephalus, subdural collections, ischemia/infarction, cerebral abscess, demyelization, and vascular thrombosis, can be correctly depicted and any interval change over time can be followed with current imaging techniques. Newer MRI techniques such as diffusion-weighted imaging and magnetic resonance spectroscopy add additional information and are considered to be helpful for the final diagnosis of CNS infections. The objective of this lecture is to describe the most common pediatric prenatal and postnatal CNS infections, emphasizing key pathological and neuroimaging features, and to outline the strengths, weaknesses, and applications of the current neuroimaging technology. Intracranial tumors in early infancy are often thought to be congenital even though some cases fail to show any clinical signs and symptoms until some time after birth. Congenital brain tumors (CBT) are often arbitrarily divided into "definitely congenital" (present at birth), "probably congenital" (producing symptoms within the first week of life) and "possibly congenital" (producing symptoms within the first 6 months of life). CBT represent fewer than 2% of all childhood brain tumors. The clinical features include enlarged head circumference, associated hydrocephalus, and asymmetric skull growth. At birth, large head or tense fontanel is the presenting sign in up to 85% of patients. Initially, neurologic symptoms are comparatively rare. The prenatal diagnosis of CBT has significantly benefited from the introduction of prenatal MRI studies. Postnatal imaging involves a combination of MRI and CT for the detection of calcifications. Teratomas constitute about one-third to one-half of these tumors and are the most common neonatal brain tumors. They are often immature because of primitive neural elements and, rarely, a component of mixed malignant germ cell tumors. Other CBT include choroid plexus papilloma, primitive neuroectodermal tumors, and atypical teratoid rhabdoid tumors. There is a strong predilection of CBT for supratentorial locations. Differential diagnosis includes spontaneous intracranial hemorrhage and congenital brain malformations, especially giant heterotopia. Prognosis for patients with brain tumors at birth is generally poor, usually because of the massive size of the tumor. The most favorable outcomes are with choroid plexus tumors where aggressive treatment leads to disease-free survival. The past few years has seen the rapid assimilation of digital X-ray systems within the field of diagnostic radiology. Clinical applications of these systems span the entire range of imaging from small, dedicated dental X-ray intra-oral systems to high-resolution digital mammography, high frame rate cardiac acquisition and even 3D rotational angiography. Three distinct detector technologies dominate current, commercially available digital X-ray detectors, namely computed radiography based around photostimulable phosphor plates, electro-direct flat panel and opto-direct flat panel detectors. This talk will start by describing the basic technology that underpins these detectors, giving examples of their current clinical application and the relative merits of each technology type. We will then follow the signal conversion and noise transfer stages through the detector. For the photostimulable plates, this involves generation of the latent X-ray image, subsequent production of optical photons via laser stimulation and final light collection using a photomultiplier tube. For flat panel systems, the detection process involves conversion of X-rays to secondary quanta (either light photons or electron-hole pairs), followed by sampling of this signal by the thin-film transistor pixel matrix. Design compromises that affect the resolution and the noise properties of these detectors are then discussed. Finally, both objective and subjective image quality results are used to demonstrate the image quality that can be achieved using the current generation of these detectors. The International Commission on Radiological Protection (ICRP) published in 2004, a document entitled "Managing patient dose in digital radiology". Diagnostic information provided by modern digital detectors can be equal or superior to conventional film-screen systems, with comparable patient doses, but with digital systems, an overexposure can occur without an adverse impact on image quality. Overexposure may not be recognised by the radiologist or radiographer. A tendency to increase doses can occur. The document includes eight formal recommendations dealing with: 1) training aspects; 2) review of diagnostic reference levels; 3) patient dose audits; 4) availability of the original image data to the user; 5) optimisation when new digital systems or new post-processing softwares are introduced; 6) procedures for quality control; 7) justification criteria; 8) role of the industry promoting tools to know and control the exposure parameters. It is expected that the ICRP report would help to profit from the benefits of this important technological advance in medical imaging with the best management of radiation doses to the patients. It is also expected to promote training actions before the digital techniques are introduced in radiology departments and to foster the industry to offer enough technical and dosimetric information to radiologists, radiographers and medical physicists to help in the optimisation of the imaging. Some ongoing efforts to standardise patient dose data from digital technology, carried out by the International Electrotechnical Commission, will be presented together with some results of the European SENTINEL Consortium. The aim of all imaging methods is to answer the diagnostic question with sufficient quality and certainty. Decoupling of image acquisition, image processing and image documentation lead to new possibilities and risks for digital radiography. For the digital imaging methods, a suitable choice of parameters could lead to advantages in diagnostic information. An unsuitable choice could lead to harmful effect and result in wrong diagnosis. The aim of image quality optimisation should be to reach the necessary quality with the lowest possible dose. The following concept shows the strategy for optimisation and quality assurance in digital radiography. 1. Optimisation: Optimal post-processing is not independent of the dose range (acquisition parameters). Therefore, the necessity exists to optimise the quality depending on clinical criteria (like organ field, clinical problem, demand image quality). 2. Objectivation: Performing each kind of examination (organ program) in different reference centres could be a strategy for quality management. Afterwards the result would be objectivated by phantom exposures. 3. Standardisation: (defined bandwidth of image quality). The range of results, which correspond to a sufficient image quality, will be defined by these reference centres. For an unknown equipment, image quality can be determined by evaluation of similar phantom exposures. Dose and quality management means that in a broad range, the dose and image quality can be optimised and adapted to the clinical questions. For the future optimisation, objectivation and standardisation will be necessary in the framework of European quality assurance program. Foreign body aspiration and ingestion is a common problem encountered by a radiologist dealing with children. The spectrum of foreign bodies aspirated or swallowed is very wide. In this presentation, only solid foreign bodies are discussed. Foreign body aspiration involves the lodging of foreign material in the respiratory tract. Complete obstruction in the upper respiratory tract is an emergency, where diagnostic imaging does not play a major role. Those foreign bodies that reach the bronchi or get beyond can result in partial or intermittent obstruction. Furthermore, they may have a "ball valve" effect leading to hyperinfilation or complete collapse. The primary diagnostic imaging modality is chest X-ray and particularly one in exspiratory phase in order to mark out the hyperlucency of the lung. Bilateral decubitus chest radiographs can provide additional information. Fluoroscopic evaluation of the lungs and diaphragm during breathing are helpful. In foreign body ingestion, the gastrointestinal tract is the site of involvement. Esophageal foreign bodies and, depending on the type of foreign body, those in the stomach may require emergency endoscopy. Radioopaque objects can be detected on a radiograph that covers the whole gastrointestinal tract, lateral neck, AP chest and abdomen radiographs. In the case of non-radioopaque foreign bodies, oral administration of contrast media under fluoroscopy is helpful to depict the object in the esophagus. There are foreign bodies like batteries and magnets that deserve special attention. A negative radiograph or fluoroscopy does not exclude the diagnosis of foreign body aspiration and ingestion. This talk will focus on the experience of a district general hospital housing the major trauma centre for the area. However, quality assurance, maintenance and knowledge of potential pitfalls are important factors in enabling users to get the best out of the unit. Clinical feedback has been positive and with increasing use by the radiography staff, the imaging service to patients has significantly improved. The last decade has seen the profile of the radiographer in the emergency department raised to new levels. Clinical assessment, image acquisition, image reporting, decision making and discharge are all tasks, which may now lie within the scope of the emergency department radiographer. New technological applications are revolutionising the way diagnostics are used at an earlier stage in a patient's assessment. This presentation will discuss the UK and international perspectives in relation to role development and provide examples of historical, current and future opportunities as well as explore some of the implications for education, professional practice and autonomy for the future. In today's medical -and specifically, -radiologic -environment, competition is not only a buzz-word, but a dominant factor directing that directs streams of patients, influencing influences the flow of capital, and building builds the intellectual capacity of institutions. Building a radiology practice is a two-step process, starting with market research to determine who your customers are and what they need or want. The wide range of sophisticated technologies available today has brought radiology into a new era in which imaging is central to diagnosis and management of disease. This increasing focus on imaging has changed the role of the radiologist and the radiology department from simply providing the results of a test to becoming clinical leaders, often directing treatment decisions. To achieve success in this expanding role, the radiology service requires a robust system of quality assurance and a framework for a continuous improvement. Key issues to be addressed in setting and developing quality standards include clinical outcomes, patient safety, patient experience, work force and resource efficiency. Such quality standards must be underpinned by good governance, strong leadership and team work. These principles will be discussed, drawing on experience gained to date in developing an accreditation programme of radiological services by the Royal College of Radiologists in partnership with the Society and College of Radiographers in the UK. This programme has been supported by the Department of Health in the UK and by other major healthcare bodies and provides a flagship for the development of accreditation in other specialties. The results of the pilot phase currently underway will be briefly reviewed. For every organisation interested in quality improvements, the introduction of quality management (QM) and certification is a logical step. This is particularly true for radiology departments, which serve as central hub and therapeutic directional point for patient management in every hospital. The decision to establish a quality management and certification program is necessarily made by the leadership. Nevertheless, a factor that is critical to the success of such a venture is to enlist all co-workers and employees into the team approach. In QM, several processes, such as patient services, performing and reporting diagnostic procedures, and error and risk management, must be designed, optimized, and made known to every co-worker involved. Documentation is an integral part of QM, as is information for all stakeholders. Examples of detailed tasks include structuring and standardizing imaging protocols, creating key performance indicators for the major processes, detailing job descriptions for every employee, building a patient safety and risk management program, in addition to many others. In this presentation, the major success factors for establishing a quality management, risk management, and patient safety program will be discussed. In addition, practical tips, which may be potentially helpful for the novice, will be provided. And, finally, the personal experiences of a radiology leader who successfully established a QM program will round off this session. The concept behind the assessment of myocardial viability is that even patients with severely dysfunctional myocardium may have significant improvement in function following revascularization. Since any process of revascularization carries both risk and high costs, particularly in patients with poor ventricular function, it is important to make an accurate diagnosis and assessment of these patients. The main imaging modalities used are stress echo, nuclear imaging and cardiac MRI. During the past years, the major problem of non-invasive cardiac imaging has been to obtain the optimal temporal and spatial image resolution of a moving organ with small-calibre vessels. The technique of CT colonography has steadily evolved and improved since it was first described over a decade ago. CT colonography (CTC) is an accurate technique for the detection and classification of colonic lesions. Data interpretation is performed on a computer workstation, equipped with dedicated CT colonography software. CTC data sets can be evaluated by a primary 2D or a primary 3D approach. In either case, the alternative viewing technique must be available for rapid correlation and characterization of any suspicious findings. Primary 2D evaluation is based on "lumen tracking," by interactively scrolling through the axial slices and multiplanar reformatted images, focusing only on the air-distended colonic lumen from one end to the other. Primary 2D evaluation provides information about the attenuation of findings during the search process and is more time-efficient. Primary 3D evaluation is based on 3D virtual endoscopy in an antegrade and retrograde fashion. Primary 3D evaluation was shown to be sensitive for polyp detection because both, the conspicuity, especially of small and medium-sized polyps, and the duration of visualization, are increased. Colonic findings are characterized by their morphology, attenuation characteristics, and mobility. Knowledge of the CTC imaging features of common colonic lesions and artifacts is necessary for characterization of findings and to differentiate between definite colonic lesions and pseudo-lesions. Computer-aided detection (CAD) may have the potential to reduce the number of perceptual errors by providing the radiologist with a second opinion, pointing out possible abnormalities that might otherwise be missed. However, dedicated reader training and further technical improvements are important to increase the accuracy and ease of interpretation of CTC. Liver transplantation is the accepted treatment in patients with irreversible liver cell failure, some metabolic disorders and a selected group with hepatocellular carcinomas. Over the last decade, the major transplant centres have reported improving survival rates, even though they have developed more complex surgical techniques and treated more marginally higher-risk patients. This successful outcome has been dependent on appropriate patient selection, robust surgical technique, improvement in immunosuppression, and the recognition and treatment of complications. Interventional radiology has been a core speciality in achieving these goals. Interventional radiology is important to the potential recipient where techniques such as TIPSS, chemoembolisation and local therapy may obviate the need for or defer the timing of transplantation. This is an important consideration, because, though split liver, live-related and non-heart beating donors have increased the donor pool, there is an increasing number of potential candidates with a rise in the prevalence of viral liver disease. Improvement in surgical techniques have reduced the incidence of the more common vascular and biliary complications, although the quest for normal graft function and histology has increased the demand for non-invasive diagnosis and the reversal of any structural vascular or biliary abnormality detected on USS, MR and MDCT. Vascular techniques of angioplasty and stent placement are proven techniques in reversing the sequels of graft ischaemia and portal hypertension. MRC allows diagnosis of biliary strictures that may be treated by stent placement or dilatation. This presentation will review the European experience of these techniques. The portal vein (PV) is a vessel that collects the venous blood of the entire digestive tract, spleen, pancreas, and gallbladder. It ramifies within the liver, defining the segmental anatomy of the organ. Portal hypertension (PH) is a syndrome that naturally develops in diseases and conditions that impede the normal drainage of the PV. Its anatomic location, deep in the abdomen, makes access to it for any investigation relatively difficult. The PV can be percutaneously catheterized through the transhepatic and transjugular approach. Transumbilical and transmesenteric catheterization techniques are alternative approaches requiring a cut-down performed in the epigastrium or minilaparotomy. The selective catheters cannot be safely inserted through the spleen. The transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) is a percutaneous method of creating a portosystemic shunt for decompression of symptomatic PH. Prehepatic PH, which is related to the stenoses of the PV or its tributaries is suitable for angioplasty and stenting. An adjuctive embolotherapy of gastroesophageal varices most frequently prolongs the interval between possible recurrent PH due to TIPS stenosis and rebleeding. Transhepatic catheterization is also utilized in islet cell transplantation in which islets can be perfused into the liver via the PV. In patients prior to hepatectomy and insufficient future liver remnant (FLR), the embolization of PV branches must be as complete as possible to avoid the development of intrahepatic portoportal collaterals that may limit regeneration. In patients who have diffuse liver disease in addition to liver tumors, the FLR has to be 40% to permit a safe resection. Stroke diagnosis, prognosis, and risk of recurrence, as well as clinical evaluation and treatment decisions are influenced by the stroke subtype, ischemic or hemorrhagic, topography and extension, and likely causative mechanism. Identifying this subtype can be better achieved in the early phase of acute ischemia with the use of various neuroradiological techniques, such as CT, CTA, CT perfusion, multimodal MRI, and DSA. Knowledge and understanding of the advantages and drawbacks of these techniques for proper assessment of acute stroke is essential to establish the most cost-effective diagnostic strategy, which should be based on evidence-based published data and on personal experience and equipment availability. Thrombolytic therapy in acute ischemic stroke patients requires an adequate selection strategy, which can be based on unenhanced brain CT or on more advanced neuroradiological techniques, such as multimodal CT or MRI. These advanced techniques can provide an estimate of the presence or absence of potentially salvageable ischemic brain tissue (ischemic penumbra), and accurately identify the location of the arterial occlusion. A critical overview of the use of these techniques for this purpose will be presented. Criteria for thrombolytic therapy based on the findings obtained with advanced neuroradiological techniques will also be presented interactively with clinical cases. Endovascular techniques for both ischemic and hemorrhagic (intraparenchymal and subarachnoidal) strokes, such as superselective intra-arterial thrombolysis, mechanical clot retraction, and various occlusive procedures will be described, critically reviewed and discussed. The entire field of medicine is moving towards more individualized or "personalized" approaches. This holds true not only for therapeutic strategies -where more refined, stage-adapted procedures are in use to meet the individual needs of a given patient -but also for the field of early diagnosis and prevention. Adequate risk stratification and risk-adapted, individualized screening policies are advocated.

Regarding the early diagnosis of breast cancer, population-based mammographic screening has been shown to help reduce breast cancer mortality. Mammographic screening, reduced post-menopausal hormone intake and the development of new, targeted therapies all contributed to the reduction of breast cancer mortality that has been observed in the last couple of years. Still, breast cancer is one of the most frequent cancers overall, and it continues to be the leading cause of cancer death in women, indicating that there is room -and need! -for improvement. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the breast has been introduced a decade ago. Over recent years, it has become increasingly evident that breast MRI by far the most powerful breast imaging technique that is currently available. Across all different clinical and screening scenarios, MRI has been shown to be superior to mammography -be it for diagnosing primary or recurrent, invasive or intraductal, familial or sporadic breast cancer, irrespective of a woman's breast density -and yet it is the technique only slowly being adopted in clinical practice. Arguments against the use of breast MRI include costs, frequency of false-positive diagnoses, lack of trained radiologists, lack of minimally invasive biopsy capabilities, lack of evidence by randomized, controlled clinical trials, and, last, fear of overtreatment. In this lecture, these concerns are reviewed, discussed and weighted against the advantages of screening and diagnostic applications of breast MRI. as "TB anywhere is TB everywhere", reflecting a message of urgency and shared responsibility. We, in India, have made renewed efforts and a "Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme (RNTCP)" has been developed almost a decade ago. This is the largest TB control programme in the world, which detects and puts on DOTS (directly observed treatment short course) more than 100,000 patients every month. Since the inception of the programme, about 6.7 million patients have been initiated on treatment, thereby saving more than 1.2 million additional lives. With 100% geographical coverage in March 2006 and treatment success rate of over 85%, RNTCP has been recognised internationally for the fastest expansion in the history of DOTS. Cure rates have more than doubled, and deaths reduced sevenfold. This symposium is a tribute to the renewed spirit to fight the dreaded disease and I hope the Indian speakers will also be able to enlighten the gathering from the rest of the world about the sporadic encounters of the disease in their settings. Combating TB is a long-term, but a winnable battle. To identify the unusual appearances of intracranial tuberculous infection and to discuss the role of newer imaging modalities like spectroscopy, which aid in the diagnosis of the same. Giant tuberculomas present as mass lesions, which commonly pose a diagnostic dilemma. Sometimes it is difficult to differentiate them from glioma, metastases and pyogenic abcesses. We present few cases of intracranial tuberculous infections with unusual location and morphology: 1. Tuberculosis of the pituitary gland is extremely uncommon and may masquerade as non-functional pituitary neoplasm. We describe imaging findings in three patients and review the pattern of involvement. 2. A case of an unusual mass like "giant" extra-axial tuberculoma during pregnancy whose morphology and imaging made meningioma a close differential diagnosis. MR spectroscopy served to complement MR imaging and provided diagnostic information. Two other cases with smaller extra-axial lesions were also evaluated. 3. Giant tuberculomas present as mass lesions, which commonly pose a diagnostic dilemma.

Sometimes it can be difficult to differentiate them from glioma, metastases and pyogenic abcesses. We studied 30 cases and found that elevated lipid peak with Cho/Cr ratio less than 1.5 ppm in lesions measuring more than 2.5 cm suggested the diagnosis of giant tuberculoma in 77% of the cases. Modern imaging has made diagnosis of CNS tuberculosis easier. However, the appearance of these tuberculous lesions is varied, diverse and sometimes difficult to diagnose. Newer MRI imaging techniques like MR spectroscopy and perfusion add to the information and help in arriving at the final diagnosis. Spinal TB is the commonest cause of non-traumatic compressive myelopathy. Early diagnosis, made possible by MRI, and prompt institution of treatment are essential to prevent permanent neurologic deficit or spinal deformity. MRI can most efficiently delineate common patterns of involvement of spinal and paravertebral structures in TB and is also very useful in follow-up. Contiguous osteomyelitis of two or more vertebral segments is the common presentation, with varying degree of accompanying soft tissue component and abscess loculations. Progressive bone destruction causes collapse of the affected vertebrae, which is more anterior in the dorsal spine because of weight transmission, leading to characteristic gibbus deformity. There may be diffuse involvement of cord as myelitis or rarely tuberculomas may be seen as focal mass-like lesions. Follow-up scans on patients during successful treatment of the disease shall serve to illustrate changes that suggest healing. There are conditions that mimic common tubercular patterns, such as non-Hodgkins lymphoma and osteoporotic vertebral end-plate compression, which need consideration in the differential diagnosis. Abdominal tuberculosis is one of the commonest diseases in our part of the world. Ultrasound (US) is often the first modality to screen vague abdominal symptoms and fever of unknown origin, which form the common clinical presentation of abdominal tuberculosis. It is important to pick up the changes and suggest the diagnosis so as to avoid delay and multiple investigations. Advances in US resolution have opened new vistas in the evaluation of GIT disorders. US demonstration of thickening of the bowel wall, peritoneal involvement, fluid with septa and necrotic nodes enables the diagnosis of abdominal tuberculosis in the appropriate clinical settings. US-guided aspiration of ascitic fluid and nodes is simple and can further authenticate the diagnosis. US is also simple, safe and economical compared to other imaging modalities and can be used to monitor the response to ATT in these patients. Our experience has made us to experiment and improvise the technique of US, which will be highlighted by the use of case material from a busy private establishment where we use all modalities and deal with abdominal tuberculosis in everyday practice. Pulmonary tuberculosis is one of the commenest disease entities in tropical countries with an estimated 12-14 million cases of tuberculosis in India, the chest being the most common area involved. The recent emergence of drug-resistant organisms and increase in the incidence of AIDS and diabetes have led to tuberculosis being seen with protean manifestations. We observed various atypical clinical and radiological presentations in day-to-day practice. Patients with tuberculosis may present as ARDS, clinically as well as radiologically with pulmonary edema. Some patients may present with acute symptoms such as sudden onset of dyspnoea, haemoptysis and radiologically show pneumonic consolidation proving to be tuberculosis. Mediastinitis with collections in the posterior mediastinum may be due to tuberculus oesophagitis. Immunocompromised patients, e.g. HIV positive or post renal transplant, show tuberculosis associated with other opportunistic organisms. Patients with tuberculosis may be asymptomatic, as detected in few of our cases during the preoperative workup for coronary artery bypass graft (CABG), and most of them were diabetics. Since the introduction of multidetector-row CT (MDCT), the evaluation of pulmonary circulation has dramatically improved, enabling the radiologists to use CT as a precise diagnostic tool in many categories of patients, including dyspneic patients. This improvement in image quality is directly linked to the increased spatial and temporal resolution of CT acquisitions recently reinforced by the introduction of ECG-gated acquisitions of the entire thorax. The latter technology allows complete suppression of cardiac motion artifacts at the level of central and peripheral vessels, which is the sine-qua non condition for the development of accurate computedaided-diagnostic tools. However, its use is associated with increased radiation exposure and this lecture will review the clinical situations in which ECG-gated benefits outweigh their current limitations. The second field of development concerns the evaluation of peripheral pulmonary vessels, currently poorly investigated on transverse CT scans. The second objective of this lecture will be to summarize our needs in clinical practice and to illustrate the potential solutions to improve the evaluation of pulmonary vessels beyond the subsegmental level and to integrate lung perfusion imaging in daily practice. Lastly, this lecture will review the current status of functional imaging of the pulmonary circulation, emphasizing the areas in which it provides more information than morphological imaging. The arterial system is a critical network delivering the fuels of metabolism to the body's tissue. As the super highway for the arterial system, the aorta is a critical structure in supplying oxygenated blood to all the tissues of the body. MDCT an-giography has become the dominant modality for diagnosing and characterizing abnormalities of the aorta and its branches. Abnormalities such as dissection or atherosclerotic occlusion can slow the flow of traffic within the aorta and in extreme cases block flow resulting in end-organ ischemia. If these obstructions develop over a sufficiently long period of time, then collateral vessels form to bypass the obstruction, preventing end-organ ischemia. In the case of aneurismal disease or other diseases affecting the strength and integrity of the aortic wall, the primary concern is for aortic rupture and exsanguination. MDCT is effective in characterizing aortic abnormalities both for primary diagnosis and for managing treatment options. Following repair of the aorta, MDCT is equally beneficial in assessing the robustness of the repair. This presentation will focus on the optimal techniques for using MDCT to study the aorta as well as on the key imaging findings in the identification and characterization of aortic abnormalities. MDCT angiography has become a powerful tool in the evaluation of vascular diseases. The high spatial resolution and speed of acquisition of up to date scanners allow excellent results to be obtained, not only in the assessment of large calibre arteries but also in the evaluation of smaller branches. The clinical results are strictly dependent on the quality of the examination; therefore much attention must be paid to the scanning technique, the administration of the contrast agent and the synchronization between the two. The differences in acquisition among the different generation of scanners will be shown. Extremely important are also the methods of post-processing used; in this respect the possibilities with different reconstruction algorithms will be shown in terms of clinical results and time needed. Clinical applications and results in abdominal vessel disease and peripheral arteries disease will be shown, also in comparison with other imaging modalities. Emphasis will also be given to the importance of CT angiography in treatment planning. X-ray dose to the patients, suggestions to reduce exposure and optimization of scanning will also be discussed. The role of MR imaging is steadily increasing in the evaluation and management of small intestinal diseases. Its main advantages include the excellent soft-tissue contrast, based on multiple contrast mechanisms, and the absence of radiation exposure, as opposed to CT. MR enteroclysis is based on duodenal intubation and administration of a maximum of 2 l of a biphasic intraluminal contrast agent with the patient lying in a prone position. An iso-osmotic water solution with PEG may be used. MRE is as accurate as CE in the detection and localization of the affected SB segments, estimation of wall thickening and length of involvement in patients with IBD. Wall thickening, significant enhancement of the mucosa and relatively hypointense submucosal edema have been reported as common findings on postgadolinium T1-weighted images in active Crohn disease. Significant enhancement of mesenteric lymph nodes in post-gadolinium T1-weighted images and presence of deep ulcers are consistently demonstrated in patients with active disease. Perfusion imaging based on T1-weighted sequences may be used to quantify local blood flow, whereas T2-weighted images are utilized to discriminate edema from fibrosis. In patient with IBD, a tailored MRE examination protocol, providing optimal image quality, can demonstrate the transmural nature and extent of inflammation, depict lesions beyond severe luminal stenosis, characterize further stenotic lesions, identify intraperitoneal extension or extraintestinal complications and allow accurate disease subtype classification. Patients who present with acute symptoms, indicating intestinal obstruction or abscess formation, or patients requiring investigation for obscure GI bleeding should be directed first to CT, due to the issues of availability limitations and cost effectiveness. Because ultrasonography (US) is often the first imaging modality used in patients with abdominal symptoms, the radiologists who perform abdominal imaging should be familiar with normal and abnormal small bowel US appearance. This lecture will detail the technical conditions for US examination of the small bowel, stressing on high resolution and advanced US techniques. Elementary images and criteria of both normal and abnormal small bowel will be described including identification of a small bowel loop, use of patent peridigestive changes to focus the US examination on an abnormal intestinal loop, and evaluation of an intestinal wall thickening for an appropriate diagnosis of the main intestinal diseases. The potential role of US in patients with suspected acute or chronic small bowel diseases will be discussed, with a special dedication to the impact of US examination on the management of patients with inflammatory lesions (as Crohn disease) to know how and when US could be used as the first-step examination in these patients.On the contrary, endoscopy refinements such as capsule endoscopy (CE) and double balloon endoscopy (DBE), which are the only means to extend preoperatively the frontiers of endoscopic examination beyond the proximal jejunal or the distal ileum loops, should be considered only as last step examinations in precisely defined conditions. The technical conditions of small bowel examination with CE and DBE will be presented and the indications and contra indications, advantages and limits of these techniques discussed, with a special dedication to obscure intestinal bleeding. New developments in CT-and MR-imaging allow efficient acquisition of highresolution images of the liver. Especially, in patients with known primary cancer, accurate detection and differentiation of liver tumors are essential for optimal-treatment planning. To reach these objectives, new techniques and contrast agents may be used according to certain protocols. During this session, we will elucidate frontiers in liver imaging and discuss the advantages and limitations of both CTand MR-imaging of the liver.
Optimising MDCT for the detection and characterisation of liver tumors F. Caseiro-Alves; Coimbra/PT (fca@netvisao.pt)

The major advances of MDCT for liver imaging derive from the combination of growing acquisition speed and reduced slice thickness, resulting in increased temporal and spatial resolution, routinely allowing high-quality multiplanar reconstructions and 3D rendering. From 4 row to 64 row scanners, the acquisition time needed to encompass the whole liver has been further reduced from 15" to not more than 5" per liver phase as seen on contrast-enhanced dynamic studies. This creates the opportunity to evaluate distinct liver phases and to separate them into pure arterial, late arterial and parenchymal phases of enhancement when using multiphasic imaging. Although beneficial, increased acquisition speed may increase a new problem since the optimal phase to depict a particular tumor may be completely missed when using such ultra-short acquisition times. To rationally choose the best MDCT protocol for liver tumor detection and characterization, the radiologist should be familiar with the normal distribution, and pharmacokinetics of iodinated-contrast agents especially related to total iodine load, concentration and injection rate, which should be tailored to address the specific clinical demand. Protocols are also strongly dependent on the nature of the tumor under evaluation (hyper or hypovascular) which should govern several parameters such as type of multiphase imaging, nominal slice thickness, and retrospective reconstruction. Pros and cons of different MDCT protocols will be addressed and some practical tips will be provided to optimize liver studies going from the 4 row to the most recent 64 row scanners. Learning Objectives: 1. To describe CT protocols to optimize the detection and characterization of liver lesions and explain advantages and disadvantages of different MDCT techniques (4-row to 64-row). 2. To provide protocols for optimal delivery of i.v. contrast media. 3. To explain the value of multiplanar reconstructions in the preoperative setting.
Maximising the accuracy of MRI for the detection and characterisation of liver tumors J. Gaa; Munich/DE (gaa@roe.med.tum.de)

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has become the most important diagnostic tool for the detection and characterization of primary and secondary liver tumors. Improvements in gradient hardware and phased-array technology allowed implementation of high-quality breath-hold T1-and T2-weighted pulse sequences. Application of respiratory triggering can provide T2-weighted images of the liver with high spatial resolution. In addition, diffusion-weighted imaging shows excellent tissue contrast and has the potential for detecting small tumors. Quantitative measurement of ADC-values may be valuable in distinguishing malignant from benign hepatic lesions. This course describes recent advances in MRI of the liver such as fast imaging techniques and diffusion-weighted MRI. Optimized protocols for lesion detection and characterization will be provided. Learning Objectives:
1. To describe recent advances in MR imaging of the liver, such as fast imaging and diffusion weighted MRI. 2. To provide protocols for optimal lesion detection and characterisation.
The role of contrast agents in liver MRI P.J.A. Robinson; Leeds/UK (106030.3217@compuserve.com)

Because of the wide range of pathologies in the liver, and the number of contrast agents available, it is inappropriate to use a single protocol for all liver cases. An optimum approach requires a review of unenhanced images, along with all available clinical data, to determine the best choice of a contrast agent. Extra-cellular gadolinium agents which produce transitory T1 enhancement analogous to iodinated contrast in CT provide a powerful method for the detection of liver lesions, and can characterise most lesions which are distinctly hyper-or hypo-intense to liver on unenhanced images. The liver-specific contrast agents are more effective in characterising lesions which appear close to iso-intense on unenhanced images; this includes most benign hepatocellular lesions, and some well-differentiated malignancies. Liver-specific agents -both T1 enhancing (positive) and T2* enhancing (negative) -also offer a small additional improvement in sensitivity when compared to ECF gadolinium, for the detection of small tumours when optimum technique is used. MR cholangiography with gadoxetic acid or mangafodipir can be helpful in patients with non-dilated ducts in whom MRCP may be difficult (e.g. potential live transplant donors). The combination of ECF gadolinium with an iron oxide agent to produce a double-contrast effect offers the most effective approach for the characterisation of suspicious nodules in the cirrhotic liver. The double-contrast technique is also valuable in problem cases in which the initial single contrast examination is equivocal. Learning Objectives:

1. To understand the basic pharmacodynamics and the enhancement characteristics of the contrast agents used in liver MRI. 2. To become familiar with the appropriate selection of acquisition parameters for each type of contrast agent. 3. To appreciate the advantages and limitations of each agent in specific clinical applications.
Why liver tumors appear as they do? Imaging-pathologic correlation P.R. Ros; Barcelona/ES (pros@hsp.santpau.es)

As demonstrated in this special focus session, the study by MDCT and MRI of liver neoplasms can be challenging. However, achieving a preoperative, non-invasive imaging diagnosis is not only of paramount importance for proper patient management but also possible in many occasions. The state-of-the-art MDCT and MRI appearance of benign and malignant neoplasms is based on their pathologic features. Knowing the underlying histologic and gross pathology of liver neoplasms allows us to understand, and therefore remember, their characteristic imaging features and offer a likely diagnosis. We correlate the pathologic features with the imaging findings in the main primary liver neoplasms. We discuss as well a few uncommon neoplasms with characteristic imaging findings. The presentation is organized along the different cellular lines in the liver (hepatocytes, biliary epithelium, and mesenchymal cells) since each of them is capable of giving rise to benign and malignant neoplasms. We review focal nodular hyperplasia, hepatocellular adenoma, biliary hamartoma, hemangioma, hepatocellular carcinoma, intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma and angiosarcoma. We prove why and how imaging-pathologic correlation enables us to state why liver tumors appear as they do.

Learning Objectives: 1. To compare CT-and MR imaging with histopathological findings in primary and secondary liver tumors. 2. To explain the appearance of uncommon liver lesions. The role of imaging and the radiologist in the management of back pain is pivotal to ensure the optimum balance between cost effectiveness and clinical effectiveness. The attending radiologist needs to be familiar and conversant with the spectrum of spinal signs and symptoms and their importance in generating a request for the most appropriate mode of imaging in back pain sufferers. In addition, it is invaluable for the radiologist to be familiar with the natural history of degenerative spinal disorders and the therapeutic options available for their management. Of the vast spectrum of spinal disorders, it is essential that the detection of disease and the correct imaging interpretation is of the highest order. This requires appropriate use of imaging modalities with particular reference to MR imaging and a thorough knowledge of the imaging appearances of inflammatory, infective and neoplastic pathological processes. The strengths of the imaging department are measured by the available resource and expertise not only in the provision of non-invasive imaging, but also in the interventional imaging procedures used in both diagnosis and therapeutic management of back pain. The interactive session is specifically designed to show, using well-chosen case material, how best to apply imaging for the optimum and accurate management of back pain. Since the introduction of extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) and percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) in the 1980s as well as the more recent advances in endoscopic treatments for ureteric stones, the choice of the most suitable method of treatment for a given patient with a stone in the kidney or ureter has evolved as a result of regular audits. Several factors affect stone management, these include stone size, stone site, calyceal anatomy, evidence of obstruction, renal function and stone radiolucency. PCNL is mostly indicated with large stone sizes (burden) of 2.5-3 cm, failed ESWL (this includes stones in the lower calyx), cystine and radiolucent stones, abnormal or anomalous renal anatomy (making ESWL difficult, if not impossible), including horseshoe and ectopic kidneys, calyceal diverticula, infundibular stenosis, body habitus and spinal/pelvic skeletal deformities, etc. Careful patient selection and preparation before PCNL is essential for the successful outcome, including appropriate imaging, particularly with CTKUB and CT urography with or without 3D reconstruction, which has become essential for the planning of difficult punctures. The techinque for percutaneous renal access will be discussed with emphasis on instruments such as needles, guidewires, dilators as well as anatomical landmarks, choice of puncture site, difficult punctures, post procedure drainage and complications. The successful outcome in PCNL depends on a team effort involving imaging, endourology, anesthesia, nursing staff and the entire team of a busy stone unit. Many stones in the collecting system have a complex 3D structure, e.g. staghorn calculus. When planning a percutaneous stone extraction of such a stone from an IVP or a standard CT, it is often impossible to decide the optimal track. Often, these patients end up with multiple tracks, but with remaining stones. Our goal has been to make the patient stone-free using one track. The question is how to minimize the risk, but optimize the result? The goal has been reached by extended radiological planning with 3D-CT, creating the track under CT guidance and with a radiologist assisting the endourologist during surgery. The CT examination is performed with thin slices ( 1 mm) in two phases, native and excretory phase. 3D-images of the stone and the collecting system are produced in a workstation. On these 3D images, it is then possible to choose an optimal and safe track. In the most complicated cases, a biomodel of the collecting system with the stone is produced. When a high puncture, above the 12 th rib is chosen, the puncture is performed under CT guidance. Using CT guidance will minimize the risk. Finally, we have found that a radiologist attending in OR, supplying the endourologist with 3-D information from the two-dimensional fluoroscopic image, is of great help. Besides watchful waiting, there are four major techniques for the treatment of stones in the urinary tract, namely ureteroscopic stone extraction, extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL), laser lithotripsy through a flexible pyeloscop and percutaneous stone extraction. It is up to the endourologist to chose the best technique for each individual stone. In this decision, it is not only the effectiveness in stone removal, which has to be considered, but also patient safety and discomfort. Indications for percutaneous stone extraction are large stones ( 20 mm), ESWL-resistant stones and patients with anatomical difficulties. The majority of renal stones, which are treated with percutaneous technique are large and with a complex 3-dimensional structure. To avoid complications, when performing percutaneous stone extraction, the ideal is to create a track to a lower or middle calyx and with a puncture below the 12 th rib. However, the problem is that in some cases the whole stone cannot be reached by a lower calyx puncture and in other cases the stone cannot be reached at all by a lower calyx puncture. Often these patients end up with multiple tracks, but with the stones remaining. In these cases, a high puncture could solve the problem. But a high puncture means an increased risk, as the track may pass the pleura, lung, liver or spleen. Mammography is still the pillar of breast imaging. It gives a comprehensive view of both glands. It allows a direct view of some components, but anatomic definition may be limited by the reduced number of views and the need for compression. Sonography has the greatest potential in the definition of normal anatomy, but has a restricted field of view. The resolution may be very high, but requires an appropriate scanning technique. Sonography provides dynamic views of the ductal system, both normal and abnormal vascularity. It is even possible to differentiate the elasticity of normal parenchyma and stiff tumors. Its value is higher within the anterior compartment such as the skin, subcutaneous fat, superficial fascia and Cooper's ligaments. The integrity of these elements is important to exclude pathology or its diffusion. The presence of abnormal vessels in a doubtful glandular area usually suggests the need for a biopsy to confirm a tumor. Anatomical definition is reduced in large and/or fatty breasts and in the deepest area due to the reduced resolution. With magnetic resonance, anatomical resolution is not at its best, but changes of normal tissues are still clear. This exam better visualizes the deeper structures that are usually poorly defined both by mammography and ultrasound. Sonography is also the best method to evaluate the lymph nodes; alterations in normal morphology, cortical thickness and vascularity offer valuable information that may be enhanced by the use of specific contrast agents. This overview of different 3D-4D breast ultrasound (US) imaging modalities should bring a better understanding of its technical use and diagnostic information. The following 3D-4D imaging techniques are based on automatically acquired US volumes (Voluson®-technique): The multiplanar display view is the typical mode of 3D US data presentation. Surface mode rendering represents the data within a volume of interest. Glass body rendering is a transparency mode, which makes the gray-scale data transparent and shows the colour flow data in a surface-rendered mode. The inversion mode offers a 3D surface presentation of echo-poor lesions. Volume contrast imaging (VCI) works with static 3D and with dynamic 4D breast scanning. Volume calculation and virtual computer-assisted organ analysis of a lesion is performed with VoCal software. Tomographic ultrasound imaging (TUI) is a tool to document static 3D US volumes. 3D-4D US of the breast offers diagnostic information of the coronal plane. In this plane, benign lesions show the compression pattern sign, and malignant lesions the retraction pattern or star pattern sign. The indeterminate pattern combines signs of compression and retraction or star pattern. Glass body rendering in combination with power-Doppler, colour-Doppler or high definition-flow imaging presents the intra-and peritumoral 3D vascular architecture. 3D-Targeting proves correct or incorrect needle placement in all three planes. 3D-4D US is technically advanced and suitable for the daily diagnostic and interventional breast work. Compared with routinely used 2D US, 3D-4D breast US provides additional information in diagnosis and intervention.
Should thermal ablation replace partial nephrectomy? P.R. Mueller; Boston, MA/US (pmueller@partners.org)

The argument as to whether percutaneous ablation of renal cell carcinoma is better or worse than laparoscopic partial nephrectomy may never be resolved as a comparison study is almost impossible to perform. Suffice to say that results in the literature suggest that any exophytic tumor from the kidney that is 4 cm or less can be completely ablated via a percutaneous approach. Clearly, there are legitimate questions with percutaneous ablation on whether treatment of larger tumors or tumors that are more centrally placed will be successful. However, several technical innovations have been developed in recent years to allow treatment of central tumors and those close to the ureter can be treated, and initial results are encouraging. Laparoscopic surgery though has become even more "minimally invasive" recently, and some patients may actually go home on the same day of surgery. On the other hand, laparoscopic partial nephrectomy does require general anesthesia. This is certainly not a requirement for percutaneous ablation. In fact, in our experience, over 90% of the cases can be performed under local anesthesia and conscious sedation. A 7-year experience from the Massachusetts General Hospital comparing partial nephrectomy and RFA shows comparable short-term cancer control. Patients who are over 60 years with three or more significant medical co-morbidities are better served by percutaneous RFA. This talk will present both pros and cons of percutaneous ablation and will include the audience in a discussion on what makes ablation good and/or difficult. Learning Objectives: 1. To learn the differences between nephron sparing surgery and percutaneous RF ablation. 2. To understand the advantages and disadvantages of both techniques.

Percutaneous cryotherapy: When should it be preferred to radiofrequency? X. Buy, A. Gangi; Strasbourg/FR (xavier.buy@chru-strasbourg.fr) Cryotherapy achieves tumor ablation with lethal freezing temperatures ranging from -20 to -40 °C. This technique has been successfully used in liver, kidney, lung and bone. Miniaturization of the cryo-probes allows their percutaneous use in computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance (MR) tunnel. Compared to the other thermal ablation techniques, the ice ball created during the cryotherapy procedures can be clearly visualized under CT or MR guidance. This allows a precise tumoral coverage. Multiple electrodes (up to 30) can be activated simultaneously to treat large lesions (thermal synergy) or several non-adjacent lesions at the same time. Pain induced by cold temperatures is reduced, so majority of the procedures can be performed under local anaesthesia or light conscious sedation. Conjunctive tissues and vessels offer resistance better to cold than to heat; this can be beneficial in some cases where adjacent structure requires protection, but can also potentially increase the risks of post-procedural haemorrhage and tumor seeding. The duration of the cryotherapy procedure is similar to radiofrequency, but the cost is slightly B C D E F G Mammography, particularly when combined with US and MR-imaging, is an effective imaging modality for detection of non-palpable breast lesions. Some of these lesions require further characterization. Percutaneous biopsy is faster, less invasive, and less expensive than surgical biopsy, and is therefore becoming the preferred alternative. Percutaneous needle breast biopsy is recommended for lesions categorized as BI-RADS 4 and 5. Guidance for percutaneous biopsy is provided by stereotaxis, ultrasound, and MR. Stereotactic guidance is used for lesions seen only by mammograms and not by ultrasound, particularly microcalcification clusters, small opacities in fatty breasts and architectural distortion. Stereotactic equipment is designed to calculate the position of a designated site by localizing its position in the x, y, and z axes from the breast surface. Stereotactic guidance units are divided into two basic types: add-on units and dedicated prone tables. Imaging on these units is available as conventional or digital spot mammographic imaging. An increasing number of needle and biopsy probes are available, including small-gauge needles, cutting needles in combination with guns, and directional vacuum-assisted-devices. The last type is more often used under stereotactic-guidance. Directional vacuumassisted biopsy devices are attached to a vacuum. The vacuum draws tissue into a side-hole in probe and a rotating cutter advances over the tissue, cuts a core from the breast, and withdraws the specimen. Directional vacuum-assisted biopsy devices are available in 14-, 11-, and 8-G. Because of the ability to remove smaller lesions completely, it is necessary to place a localization clip to mark the biopsy site to identify the area for surgical removal or follow-up. Learning Objectives: 1. To become familiar with presurgical localisation procedures. 2. To understand basic principles and technical apects of stereotactic technique. 3. To learn when and how to perform stereotactic vacuum-assisted biopsies.

Radiologists will be attracted to those jobs that offer flexibility in an environment where they can have an interesting career. Departments that promote family-friendly workplaces have an edge when it comes to recruitment and retention of skilled employees. Family-friendly policies are a way to support and recognize the changing needs of employees at different points in their lives and careers. Learning Objectives: 1. To explain how radiological work patterns will change over the next 10 years with an increasing proportion of female radiologists. 2.
