Serious diagnostic mistakes are followed either by absent, delayed or erroneous patient management and may be lethal or carry significant complications, increased cost and patient's suffering and misery. In emergency medicine, a correct and complete diagnosis must be formulated at once. A considerable number of factors may exist at the origin of serious diagnostic mistakes. They may be related to hospital organisation of emergency medicine, communication, equipment, choice of investigation modalities, technique and medical and paramedical expertise. Other factors are the type of lesion or injury and pathophysiology. These general and specific factors will be discussed in the following conferences. Session Objective: 1. To understand the numerous factors generating serious mistakes in emergency radiology applied to the central nervous system, chest, abdomen and the musculoskeletal system.
Central nervous system D. Balériaux; Brussels/BE (dbaleri@ulb.ac.be)

More than ever, mistakes will be avoided by the radiologist if time is taken for talking to the patient and/or his family as well as to the referring clinician. Mastering the new upcoming techniques in the field of neuroimaging is mandatory to provide the right diagnosis at the right moment! Learning Objectives: 1. To comprehend clinical situations for which proper management and adequate choice of optimal imaging modalities is of utmost importance. This includes not only traumatic but also infectious, vascular and tumoral pathologies. 2. To understand how and why serious mistakes are sometimes made and how to avoid them by being more aware of the absolute necessity for a radiologist to be informed by the referring physician about the patient's clinical history, clinical examination and suspected pathology. 3. To become familiar with the latest technical performances of spiral CT and MRI enabling fast and accurate diagnosis of pathologies requiring rapid therapeutic actions.

Chest C. Beigelman-Aubry; Paris/FR Computed tomography (CT) has always been a modality of choice for the exploration of non-traumatic and traumatic chest emergencies. With new generations of multidetector-row CT, fast volumetric acquisitions are obtained with high-spatial resolution allowing 2D and 3D reformats of excellent quality. These post-processings may have a great added value under some conditions. However, potential pitfalls may be encountered due to inadequacy of technical factors including dose, effective slice thickness, reconstruction interval or kernel chosen according to the researched pathology. Most often, these examinations require contrast media administration.

In some situations, the site of injection may preclude correct analysis of structures, especially ascending aorta and supra-aortic vessels in the case of jugular or subclavian catheter injection. Moreover, pitfalls may be created by inadequate quality or timing of vascular opacification. Window settings have also to be adapted to the diagnosis suspected. Dedicated post-processing protocols must be applied to each anatomical compartment to avoid certain lesions, especially with polytrauma patients. Systematic matching of created images with native images will avoid potential mistakes of interpretation. Last, knowledge of artefacts created by external devices, respiration or vascular motions has always to be integrated for a correct final diagnosis.

Learning Objectives: 1. To be familiar with technical factors including acquisition and reconstruction parameters potentially generating pitfalls in CT analysis in chest emergencies. 2. To be aware of potential pitfalls due to contrast media administration, including the site of injection, the quality and timing of vascular opacification or the window settings used. 3. To know when and how to use post-processing tools in specific conditions especially in polytrauma patients according to the underlying pathology researched. 4. To recognise the artefacts created by external devices or respiratory motion for final interpretation.

A-399 16 To understand how mistakes in abdominal imaging may occur, it is necessary to consider both generic and specific causes. In the former, these may arise from failure of observation or deduction by the individual radiologist, but also include errors as a result of failed communication or misleading clinical information. Technical issues may also contribute but these are a relatively small cause of erroneous reports. Specific causes related to abdominal imaging include modality choices, contrast errors, as well as in many circumstances a failure to appreciate the pathophysiology of the acute abdomen. They can thus be summarised as follows: Errors related to modality choice are typified by the inadequacies of the plain abdominal film and a failure to realise the limitations of this examination. Likewise, ultrasound although extremely useful in specific clinical situations has limitations in the whole abdomen. The use of contrast agents is often essential, but it is just as imperative that the radiologist is aware of the dangers of administering barium sulphate to a patient as is knowledge of the correct protocol for administering intravascular contrast agents during CT examinations. Again indications of their use will depend on the potential diagnosis. Finally any radiologist reporting examinations in the acute abdominal situation must be aware of the numerous causes and the protean nature of their manifestations. Failure to do so may have catastrophic consequences for the patient. Liver cirrhosis is an extremely common condition. Diagnosis relies on pathological findings. Nevertheless, imaging data (US, CT, MRI) are highly accurate in detecting cirrhosis. Changes of liver contour, anatomy and contrast enhancement should be identitied, as well as the varions appearance of regeneration, from the "coarse pattern" to discrete liver nodules. Identification of fibrosis mimicking tumours will be detailed. Cirrhosis is commonly associated with portal hypertension (PH); identification of collaterals is the major sign of PH. The attendees will be trained to learn the classification of PH, based on physiopathology and aetiology and to explain and identify on US, CT or MRI the major collaterals like paraumbilical vein, left gastric vein and splenorenal shunts. Physiological signlficance of each group of collaterals will be detailed, evaluating if possible the risk of variceal bleeding and/or encephalopathy. Special attention will be paid to the identification of partial obstruction of the portal system, either related to splenic vein or superior mesenteric vein obstruction. In that case, most of the collaterals are portoportal shunts. The importance of assessing the portal venous system for patency prior to liver/portal surgery will be explained, as well as the possibilities for percutaneous treatment as an alternative to surgery in the palliation and treatment options of PH, including intra-hepatic shunting and embolization of arterioportal fistulas. Indications and follow-up of TIPS are challenging issues and will be discussed. In order to illustrate these topics, several cases will be presented with audience interactive participation using an electronic voting system (keypads). Basic science has delivered new insights into the molecular background of human diseases, which may lead to novel diagnostic and therapeutic procedures.

To translate preclinical approaches into clinical application, functional methods are required. This symposium will focus on two aspects, namely, angiogenesis and stem-cell tracking. Angiogenesis is a complex process involving pro-and anti-angiogenic mediators, multiple cell types and growth factors. For initiation and progression of angiogenesis, angiogenic factors are essential. This led to the concept of anti-angiogenic therapy, which is designed to starve tumors by disturbing their blood supply. In this context, several anti-angiogenic agents or genes have been successfully used in preclinical models and clinical studies. These new treatment approaches need novel diagnostic tools for the assessment of vessel density and perfusion prior to and following therapy. Techniques to noninvasively quantitate tumor perfusion, vessel density or permeability are complemented by new strategies to visualize specific targets on vascular cells and cell recruitment to the sites of angiogenesis. Stem-cell therapy is an attractive new strategy in the management of patients with cardiological or neurological diseases. Whatever the mechanisms underlying the therapeutic efficacy are, either cell replacement or bystander immunomodulation, a key issue to address for translation into the clinic is the development of in vivo, noninvasive methods for tracking the transplanted cells. Imaging allows in the in vivo monitoring of cells and can provide a better understanding in the evaluation of the functional effects of cell-based therapies. Magnetic resonance imaging, nuclear medicine techniques and optical-based approaches utilizing different cell-labeling techniques have been shown to provide a valuable means for monitoring cell therapies in vivo. Session Objectives: 1. To introduce techniques for the non-invasive quantitation of tumor blood flow, vessel density and cellular/molecular markers of angiogenesis. This will be done for radio-isotope based methods and for magnetic resonance imaging. 2. To discuss the advantages and drawbacks of the methods presented with respect to their preclinical and clinical utility. 3. To present techniques for cell tracking for radio-isotope based methods and for magnetic resonance imaging. 4. To present preclinical and clinical evidence for the successful application of these methods in monitoring and optimising cellular therapies.
Imaging of angiogenesis with MRI M. Neeman; Rehovot/IL (michal.neeman@weizmann.ac.il)

Angiogenesis, the growth of new blood vessels, requires coordinated participation of numerous cell types and signaling pathways. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) facilitates anatomical, functional, cellular and molecular non-invasive visualization of the basic biological mechanisms that execute angiogenesis, in addition to its role in preclinical drug development and clinical imaging of response to pro-and anti-angiogenic therapy. Expansion of the vascular bed by angiogenesis is characterized by vascular hyperpermeability, reduced vasoreactivity, instability and high tortuosity. The plasticity of the vasculature during angiogenesis is accompanied by activation of signaling pathways in endothelial cells, and subsequent changes in cell surface markers corresponding to growth factor receptors, transporters and adhesion molecules. In addition, enzymes secreted to the interstitial space and plasma proteins extravasated from leaky blood vessels result in profound changes in the extracellular matrix. Angiogenesis is facilitated by the recruitment of endothelial and accessory mural cells, which can be followed by MRI. Functional imaging of blood volume, blood flow, perfusion and vasoreactivity shows the consequence of angiogenesis. Recent developments in molecular imaging of specific cell surface markers using targeted contrast agents, imaging markers for gene expression and enzymatic activity and tracking recruitment of vascular cells further expanded the repertoire for MRI of angiogenesis. Thus, MRI provides a comprehensive multiparametric view of the angiogenic process. Learning Objectives: 1. To outline the mechanisms and potential imaging targets in the angiogenic process that are accessible by MRI. 2. To review the functional MRI tools available for imaging angiogenesis. 3. To review the molecular and cellular MR methods for imaging angiogenesis.
Imaging of angiogenesis using radiolabelled peptides R. Haubner; Innsbruck/AT (Roland. Haubner@i-med.ac

Angiogenesis is a complex multistep process involved in a variety of pathological processes including rheumatoid arthritis, diabetic retinopathy, psoriasis, restenosis and tumor growth. The interest in basic angiogenesis research is sparked by the translational therapeutic potential aimed at developing anti-angiogenesis drugs as novel therapeutics for tumors and a number of non-oncological diseases. Thus, imaging techniques allowing non-invasive monitoring of corresponding molecular processes will be of great interest for basic research as well as for planning and controlling corresponding anti-angiogenic therapies. One target structure involved in the angiogenic process is the integrin v 3, which mediates the migration of activated endothelial cells during vessel formation. It was found that peptides containing the amino acid sequence Arg-Gly-Asp (single letter code: RGD) bind with high affinity to this receptor. Meanwhile, a variety of radiolabeled RGD-peptides have been introduced for monitoring v 3 expression using nuclear medicine tracer techniques. Here some aspects of tracer development are highlighted and some preclinical and clinical data as well as the potential of this class of tracer to characterize angiogenesis are discussed.

C. Interventional procedures L. Steyaert; Bruges/BE (luc.steyaert@pandora.be) Fine needle aspiration (FNA): Cytological sampling with 20-23 G needles is the least invasive technique. Ultrasound-guided FNA is adequate to establish diagnosis of malignancy, but gives no information on invasiveness and requires an experienced cytopathologist. Mainly used for (symptomatic) cysts and to sample lymph nodes, it thus helps to select patients for sentinel node procedure. Core needle biopsy (CNB): 16 or 18 G needles are adequate for nodular lesions; 14 G is not necessary. Two or three samples per lesion are sufficient. The procedure is usually done immediately following a diagnostic mammography and/or ultrasound exam. It is the standard first choice procedure. Better histological material gives a more confident diagnosis and less false results than FNA. It is less reliable for microcalcifications. Freehanded ultrasound guidance is the most used method. Vacuum-assisted biopsy (VAB): This uses larger (11-7G) needles and is performed under local anaesthesia. Vacuum aspiration gives optimal sampling and enables retrieval of the sample while leaving the needle in place. Main indications are foci of microcalcifications (stereotactic guidance), suspicious enhancing lesions not visible on mammography or ultrasound (MRI guidance), indeterminate nodular lesions, or very small suspicious lesions in difficult areas close to the skin, chest wall or axillary region (ultrasound guidance). Quality assurance: Visual inspection of the cores is a simple method to judge the quality of the sample. Changes in the white substance seen on the MRI are normally non-specific and appear due to inflammation of the brain parenchyma, degenerative diseases, autoimmune diseases, tumours and vascular diseases. The correct diagnosis may be supported by the clinical history data, findings and labour data. During the evaluation of the changes of the white substance, an exact topical analysis of the lesions, space occupying effects and the enhancement after the gadolinium injection can be achieved. T1 and T2-weighted sequences are generally enough to conduct an approximate diagnosis. Detailed statements are possible with MTI, diffusion-weighted imaging and MR spectroscopy, but they contribute little to the specification of the changes and will be used in the future mainly for the evaluation of the development of a disease. Analyzing morphological changes on the scan, the following approach should be used: symmetry of the changes; laminar or focal lesions; round, oval, slotted forms; localisation and number of lesions in sub-cortical, corpus callosum, periventricular, supra-and infratentrorial; localisation of the changes, only in white matter or changes in white and grey matter; signal intensity in T1-and T2-weighted sequences; focal or generalized space occupying effect; and presentation of contrast agent enhancement. T2-weighted sequences are the preferred sequences over proton density sequences. FLAIR sequences show high-contrast changes, enhance the significance of lesions in the grey matter, however, show less infratrentorial lesions. Changes of the U-fibres in the subcortical area are important references for the differential diagnosis. In the presentation, special attention will be paid to changes in multiple sclerosis, systemic immune mediate diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus, Behcet disease, sarcoidosis, noninflammatory vascular syndromes, acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM), neuromyelitis optica, central pontine meyelinolysis, infectious diseases and metabolic diseases. A printed summary of characteristic images and typical pathological findings will be distributed to the participants. Neuroradiology plays a significant role in the field of dementia. Early diagnosis of neurodegenerative diseases causing cognitive decline is crucial to start treatment strategies aiming at neuroprotection. This implies precise characterization of the preclinical and early clinical stages, such as mild cognitive impairment and prodromal Alzheimer's disease (AD). Different neuroimaging techniques have shown the ability to provide characteristic findings in these early stages, which may be useful as biomarkers. This applies to both structural and more functional techniques, including MRI, MRS, fMRI, SPECT and PET. Differential diagnosis of patients with dementia has also improved with the use of neuroradiology. MRI is useful in characterizing vascular lesions in patients with dementia. Patterns of involvement have been described in fronto-temporal lobar degeneration, which are useful in the distinction from AD. Characteristic imaging findings have been described in Creutzfeld-Jakob disease and in dementia in Parkinson's disease, using both structural and functional imaging techniques. In genetically conditioned diseases causing cognitive impairment, such as Huntington's disease (HD), MR techniques, both structural and functional, have demonstrated its usefulness. MRS and MRI have shown changes in the brain in preclinical carriers of HD, which correlate to neuropsychological performance, and may therefore serve as early biomarkers.

The use of these biomarkers as indicators of treatment response in clinical trials is currently being investigated. To date, no such biomarker has been accepted as a surrogate marker. However, potential biomarkers, such as progressive brain atrophy, are being applied to research in dementia. CNS infection is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality and has an increasing prevalence in the general population. The incidences of these are largely dependent on the involved compartment and immunological status of the patient. Most of the CNS infections can be treated successfully as long as they are detected early. It has been shown that delays in diagnosis can lead to increased morbidity and mortality. Radiological evaluations play an important role in the diagnosis, subsequent treatment and treatment monitoring. The most useful classification of the CNS infections is according to the anatomic space involved. Each of these spaces has distinct clinical features and a variety of predisposing conditions. Infections of each compartment have distinct imaging findings and differentiation can be made using these characteristic imaging patterns. MRI has become the modality of choice with its higher sensitivity. Contrast administration is mandatory and increases the sensitivity. Imaging findings vary from obliteration of CSF space, thickening and enhancement of the meninges of meningitis to prominent ring enhancement with peripheral edema and central necrosis of brain abscess according to its location and stage. Neoplasms, nonbacterial granulamatous diseases and acute ischemic lesions should be considered in the differential diagnosis. MR imaging techniques undergo a steady process of ongoing developments and improvements, ensuring development towards a faster, more accurate, more patient friendly and more widely applicable noninvasive imaging modality. The most challenging, also most driving, development in recent years is the clinical implementation of parallel imaging (PI) techniques. As gradient strength comes to the limit of peripheral stimulation, these techniques allow for a further substantial speed-up of MR acquisitions. PI literally allows stepping from a single phase-encoding step technique to multiple phase-encodings at once. To elaborate, PI allows for a reduction of necessary phase encoding steps with the subsequent reconstruction of missing lines based on the additional consideration of the distribution and signal contribution of single elements in a multi-element array. Therefore, the application, speed and success of PI are directly linked to the existence of multi-channel MR receiver systems and to the use of dedicated multi-element coil arrays. While in the beginning of PI 2D techniques have been used with single direction acceleration, most recent 3D techniques further push PI with acceleration in two dimensions, allowing ~8-16 times faster imaging. Therefore, 3D techniques such as MRA substantially benefit from PI enabling the use of high temporal resolution in dynamic imaging or alternatively higher spatial resolution within the same acquisition period. Many vendor-provided protocols already incorporate PI techniques, but successful application is substantially dependent on individual optimization. This lecture reviews the basics and clinical implementation of PI in various applications and provides an overview on upcoming developments. Improvements in hardware and software have made it clinically feasible to obtain high-resolution whole-body MRI in a relatively short time; the technique represents a promising alternative to multi-modality diagnostic algorithms. Since the extended anatomy to be covered is much longer than the homogeneous region of the MR scanner, the available techniques can be divided into two main approaches. In the so-called "multistation" approach, dedicated MR sequences to different anatomical regions are applied at different table positions. With an aim towards decreasing the acquisition time of MR data, acquisition during either automated step-wise or continuous table motion has received significant interest recently. Examination protocols have been adjusted to specific clinical indications. For instance, healthy subjects have undergone a different protocol for screening than patients with malignancy for staging. A main part of the presented whole body MRI protocols has been based on coronal T1-weighted TSE-imaging which is used to obtain an overview and fat suppressed short tau inversion recovery (STIR) imaging with high image contrast as an overall search sequence. Whole-body MRI has mainly been applied in oncology for staging of malignant tumors or metastases detection, and promising results have been obtained in comparison to FDG-PET/CT or multi-slice CT. The technique has also been applied to assess the extent of muscle diseases and for whole-body cardiovascular and tumor screening. Although the clinical relevance of the technique in secondary prevention and surveillance of diseases is unclear, the potential acceptance for these indications, including research, is great. Diffusion weighted imaging (DWI) is based on the tissue-depending signal attenuation caused by incoherent thermal motion of water molecules (Brownian motions).

There are multiple ways of obtaining DWI: fast spin echo, single-shot and multi-shot echoplanar imaging (EPI), with water excitation or water suppression (STIR), and steady state free precession. We use a single-shot diffusion (DWI) EPI sequence. Inverse greyscale intensity scale is applied on 20 mm-coronal MIP, to obtain a "PET-like" image. This static coronal projection allows direct comparison with other modalities (bone scan) or sequence (coronal STIR in a whole-body MRI protocol).

The principal interest of this sequence lies in its contrast resolution. As there are no anatomical super positions, it decreases the time of reporting. It is of particular interest in the evaluation of bone marrow diseases, particularly multiple myeloma. In our experience, the use of DWI increases the sensitivity of a whole-body MRI protocol for the detection of lymph nodes, mostly in the mediastinohilar areas, and it is of great interest for initial staging of lymphoma and therapeutic follow-up. Single-shot diffusion EPI appears as the most sensitive sequence in staging, but its inherent sensitivity to susceptibility artifacts prevents its use as a standalone technique and obliges a confrontation with a more conventional sequence, like coronal STIR. DWI is a good complementary sequence in clinical routine and for many indications. It increases the sensitivity in the staging protocol and accelerates the examination reporting. For decades, imaging of the urinary tract has relied on intravenous urography (IVU) as the primary imaging modality. In more recent times, CT urography (CTU) and MR urography have taken over a lot of the imaging of the urinary tract. The process has been spurred on by fast technological advancements such as the use of multidetector-row CT and MRI using higher field strengths and powerful gradient systems. While some departments have completely abolished IVU, in others it still remains a frequently used examination technique, especially for non-malignant disease. As there is a paucity in the number of recent guidelines and comparative studies focusing on imaging management and outcome for common clinical scenarios, this abolition is often not based only on thorough scientific evidence. Other factors such as local preferences, technical improvements in CT and MRI, and the general trend of substituting projection by cross-sectional imaging techniques play an important role. This session will critically review comparative studies, radiation doses, economic factors, and the individual strengths and weaknesses of CTU and MRU in comparison to IVU for common clinical scenarios. Such an analysis should provide an improved understanding of: which patients and indications the use of CTU or MRU is justified, for which patients and indications IVU will remain a viable alternative, and how to optimize all existing urography techniques. Assessing PHT is mandatory for patient healthcare, comprising preoperative status, particularly for hepatocellular carcinoma resection. Portal hypertension is assessed by a portal gradient of 5 mm Hg or more. This measure is invasive. Portal hypertension is accurately explorated with Doppler ultrasound, including pulsed, color and power Doppler. Flow rates could be measured by Doppler ultrasound, as well as reversal flow or thrombosis. Portal vein thrombosis is related to clot, but tumorous thrombosis is frequent too. Concerning the hepatic veins and outflow, Doppler patterns are of interest. Indirect imaging features have a good specificity when viewing portal venous collaterals associated with liver morphological changes and parenchymal disorders. Collateral pathways are multiple, concerning various parts of the abdomen and pelvis, appearing in a random order. Some pathways are frequent and some are uncommon. Not only ultrasound, but also MDCT or MRI could assess these collaterals. Enlargement of the spleen and ascitis are less specific, but are part of the features of PHT. Searching of causes and diagnosis and treatment follow-up of the complication are performed with these techniques.

FIGREF6.text: Acute pancreatitis is classified into mild and severe acute pancreatitis in the light of clinical, laboratory findings and severity of pathologic changes. Morphological changes of the mild form are diffuse enlargement of the gland with or without peripancreatic fluid collections and thickening of the anterior pararenal facia. In the severe form of acute pancreatitis, extensive pancreatic necrosis and inflammation of the peripancreatic fat tissue is present that may evolve towards the formation of fluid collections. In this form, morphological changes can be described as Pancreatic tissue necrosis, Pancreatic or peripancreatic abscess and parenchymal hemorrhage. Imaging modalities are performed for confirmation of the diagnosis, identification of etiology and assessment of extent and complications of disease. US, CT, MRI and MRCP are accepted as imaging modalities for the diagnosis, management and follow-up of acute pancreatitis. The severity of CT findings correlates with the prognosis of acute pancreatitis. Balthazar et al. classified the severity of pancreatitis into five categories based on CT appearance. According to this classification, patients with grade A-C pancreatitis suffered a mild, uncomplicated clinical course, while grade D-E pancreatitis had prolonged morbidity with a higher incidence of abscess and mortality. Learning Objectives: 1. To discuss the value of clinical and radiological prognostic indexes. 2. To present the role of CT, MRI, and ERCP in the acute setting and for follow-up. 3. Hájek; Prague/CZ (miha@medicon.cz) Based on current clinical trials, transplantation of pancreatic islets (PI) is a promising method, which could help patients suffering from type 1 diabetes. In clinical practice, isolated human pancreatic islets from cadaveric donors are infused into the liver via the portal vein. They disperse in the liver and stop in arteries with smaller diameter than their own, and the production of insulin and other hormones commences. Unfortunately, many complications that decrease PI concentration and function occur. Visualization of pancreatic islets after transplantation can help to confirm the position of pancreatic islets in the target organ and also to describe their function. The best current in vivo visualization of pancreatic islets after transplantation is the application of MR-specific contrast agents (CA) based on superparamagnetic iron oxides (SPIO). When PI are labeled with a specific contrast agent, we can see their position via MR imaging and observe changes due to rejection when the MR signal disappears. The modification of the surface of SPIO nanoparticles by binding different compounds (polymers, peptides, etc.) improves the specificity of CA, which can be used for studying the status of pancreatic islets in pancreas. The advantage of molecular imaging techniques based on MRI is the possibility of repetitive measurements for the observation of the fate of PI. Thus, MR imaging can help to describe the clinical status of PI, and the position and fate of islets following transplantation. Thurnher; Vienna/AT (majda.thurnher@meduniwien.ac.at) The diagnosis and pre-operative evaluation of intracranial aneurysm is classically performed by catheter angiography using digital subtraction (DSA). Non-invasive techniques, such as color Doppler sonography (CDS), CT angiography (CTA) or MR angiography (MRA), are considered to be attractive alternatives to conventional angiography. Several studies have shown that aneurysms of the circle of Willis can be detected with high specificity and sensitivity using CTA, and most authors suggest the replacement of DSA with CTA in the evaluation of patients with SAH in order to detect aneurysms. CTA is also useful in the process of deciding whether to coil or clip an aneurysm. It appears that the main role of CTA is in the diagnosis and therapy planning of ruptured aneurysms; MRA has an increasingly important role in the screening for asymptomatic aneurysms. CT angiogram should answer the following questions: a) whether there is cerebral aneurysm, b) the location of the aneurysm, c) whether the shape and configuration of the aneurysm is suitable for embolisation or surgical clipping, and d) the status of the collateral circulations. Imaging evaluation of cerebral arteriovenous malformations (AVM) requires selective visualization of the different compartments of the malformation in order to select the therapeutic management. Studies comparing CTA and magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) in detecting AVM nidus and vessels have shown some advantages of CTA-reconstructed images where more veins but fewer arteries were depicted when compared to MRA. Learning Objectives: 1. To learn about the current role and diagnostic accuracy of CT and CT angiography (CTA) in evaluating intracranial aneurysms and AVMs. 2. To discuss possible fields in which CTA might replace invasive DSA and even compete with MRI techniques in detecting aneurysms and AVMs. 3. TABREF17.text: CT may either be used as a screening tool for atherosclerosis or as a diagnostic tool to triage patients for cardiac catheterisation. In asymptomatic persons we perform coronary calcium screening only. This protocol can be performed with any 4-detector-row or higher CT scanner. The calcium in the coronary arteries may be quantified with the Agatston scoring method and in mg calcium hydroxyapatite. Reference values are available to judge for accelerated atherosclerosis compared to a normal population. In any asymptomatic person with an elevated coronary calcium value above the 75 th percentile, risk factor modification and further work-up by noninvasive stress test should be considered. Cardiac CT angiography may play a complementary role in the noninvasive work-up of coronary artery disease in combination with ECG and nuclear stress testing. A well-balanced indication for cardiac CT may also be cost effective under these circumstances. Patients with intermediate pretest likelihood for coronary artery disease or equivocal stress test should undergo coronary calcium screening and CT angiography of the coronary arteries. CT is also requested in patients with atrial fibrillation prior to administration of anti-arrhythmic drugs and catheter ablation. A chest pain protocol is performed ideally with the dual source CT and reconstructed with full spatial resolution for the lung and high temporal resolution for the coronary arteries. It gives a complete overview of the different diagnostic aspects of chest pain in a single comprehensive CT scan.

Adams; Manchester/UK (judith.adams@man.ac.uk) Vertebral fractures are the most common type of osteoporotic fractures. Clinical symptoms (back pain, height loss, deformity, limited spinal mobility) may be present, but 30-75% are asymptomatic. Vertebral fractures are powerful predictors of future fractures (x5 vertebral fracture; x2 hip fracture), so accurate identification is vital in the diagnosis and management of patients with osteoporosis. Spinal radiographs are most widely used for confirming the presence and severity of vertebral fractures. A significant number (30-50%) of fractures present on radiographs are not reported. A collaborative initiative of International Osteoporosis Foundation (IOF) and European Society of Skeletal Radiology (ESSR Osteoporosis Group) to improve the accuracy and clarity of reporting by radiologists was established (www.osteofound.org). All fractures cause vertebral deformities, but not all deformed vertebrae are fractures; other pathologies must be differentiated from osteoporotic vertebral fracture, and other imaging methods are helpful. Learning Objectives: 1. To explain the necessity of reporting vertebral fractures. 2. To describe the radiological features that differentiate vertebral fracture from other causes of vertebral deformity. 3. To present methods of grading and quantitative morphometric assessment. Cieszanowski; Warsaw/PL (acieszan@amwaw.edu.pl)An improved diagnostic accuracy of the state-of-the-art imaging modalities (US, CT, MR) has resulted in an increased detection of small renal masses. First of all, the superb spatial resolution of MSCT contributes to higher detection rate of these lesions, although their confident characterization (benign vs. malignant) is often challenging. Ultrasound allows accurate discrimination of a majority of cystic lesions, including simple renal cysts; however, many of the other masses cannot be characterized with this modality. The other, not infrequent, problem encountered on US is pseudotumor, which is most often due to normal anatomical variants (i.e. column of Bertin, dromedary hump). The true nature of these lesions can be clarified by CT and MR imaging. According to Bosniak's classification, cystic lesions can be divided into four types, namely simple cysts (I), cysts with minimal risk of malignancy (II), possibly malignant cysts (III), and definite cystic neoplasms (IV). MR imaging, due to a very good contrast resolution, enables best characterization of fluid structures, allowing distinction of hyperdense cysts ( 40 HU on CT, due to hemorrhage or high protein content) from solid tumors. The diagnosis of angiomyolipoma is based on detection of fatty tissue and relies on CT and MR imaging. On the contrary, adenoma cannot be readily distinguished from RCC by either technique. Oncocytoma in many cases may also mimic RCC and only a small percentage of these lesions demonstrates characteristic appearance suggesting correct diagnosis. In the diagnosis of focal inflammatory lesions, clinical history along with imaging findings may be useful in lesion characterization.Learning Objectives: 1. Differential diagnosis of bright lesions on diffusion-weighted MR images M.M. Thurnher; Vienna/AT (majda.thurnher@meduniwien.ac.at) After the initial description of diffusion-weighted MR imaging (DWI) by Le Bihan et al. numerous studies have used DWI to evaluate cerebral diseases. The value of DWI in early detection of acute ischemia has been proven extensively. Differentiation between numerous cystic or ring-enhancing lesions is still a diagnostic problem. The contents of a cystic lesion frequently have the signal intensities of a generic homogeneous hyperproteinic fluid. DWI may give further information about the microscopic organization of these fluids. On DWI, untreated pyogenic abscesses are typically hyperintense, indicating restricted diffusion due to the high viscosity of pus within the cavity. A majority of fungal abscesses show restricted diffusion; however, the signal on DWI is usually more heterogeneous as seen in bacterial abscesses. Tuberculous abscesses have restricted diffusion and thus mimic pyogenic abscesses. Variable diffusion patterns have been described in cerebral toxoplasmosis, obviously dependent on the histological stage. ADC ratios have significant overlap with those of lymphoma and distinction remains a challenge. Primary CNS lymphoma seen in immunocompetent patients are highly cellular tumors and therefore often exhibit restricted diffusion. Usually metastatic neoplasms show low signal on DWI. However, adenocarcinoma metastases can have restricted diffusion simulating abscesses. Epidermoid cysts and cholesteatoma show restricted diffusion with high signal intensity on DWI. Intracerebral hemorrhage, trauma, metabolic diseases, epilepsy, and demyelinating disorders may have high signal intensity lesions on DWI. This lecture attempts to elucidate and discuss how to use DWI not only in stroke, but also in the differential diagnosis of non-infarct brain lesions. Learning Objectives: 1. To recapitulate the basic principles of diffusion-weighted MR imaging (DWI). 2. To discuss the importance of DWI and ADC measurements in the diagnosis and differential diagnosis of brain lesions. 3. TABREF125.text: A critical challenge for emergency physicians is to determine whether chest pain is cardiac or non-coronary in etiology and if cardiac, whether the patient has acute coronary syndrome (ACS = transmural MI, nontransmural MI, unstable angina). It is estimated that only 15% of patients present with chest pain have ACS but up to 50% are admitted, many with atypical chest pain and often after a lengthy work-up. Conventional non-invasive techniques such as myocardial perfusion imaging (MPI) and stress echocardiography have substantial limitations With the rapid development of MDCT and its increasing proximity to the ED, investigators have suggested its use to provide an accurate and expeditious evaluation of acute chest pain. Several studies suggest an excellent negative predictive value for ED cardiac CT with the potential for rapid triage. While challenges remain including how to manage the expected volume of ED cardiac CT and concerns about radiation dose, development of appropriate guidelines on the basis of large-scale studies may lead to a paradigm shift in the work-up of ED chest pain. Lefere; Roeselare/BE (radiologie@skynet.be)As a novel patient-friendly and minimally invasive imaging technique to detect colorectal polyps and cancer, CT colonography (CTC) rapidly seems appropriate for screening asymptomatic people for colorectal cancer (CRC). However this huge expectation was not immediately fulfilled because of an underestimation of the complexity of CTC technique and interpretation, resulting in a wide variability of results in the major multi-centre trials performed to date. Currently, CTC is an accepted indication after incomplete optical colonoscopy (OC) of obstructive carcinoma or technical failure, when OC is contraindicated or refused by the patient, and in the frail and elderly patient. Nevertheless, mass screening for CRC remains the main target. Agreement exists that CTC can be used for screening if there is validated local expertise. To overcome the issue of technical and interpretational shortcomings on a large scale, the concept of state-of-the-art technique and interpretation has been developed by the international CTC community. Focussing on the different aspects of CTC and underscoring the need for a structured education under supervision by experts, repeatability of good diagnostic performance should improve, enabling the reconsideration of CTC as a tool for mass CRC screening. Several large multi-centre studies are underway with some results being released soon. These studies should help to further refine and develop CTC as a widely accepted candidate for mass CRC screening. Once this is achieved, many problems need to be solved: How do we make CTC cost-effective, with efficient management of colonic and extra-colonic findings, improvement of patient compliance and reduction of the procedural costs? Learning Objectives:1. To define the indications for CT colonography in the symptomatic and asymptomatic patient. 2. To review the performance of CT colonography in clinical studies. 3. Glynos; Athens/GR (mglynos@gmail.com)When benign biliary strictures are inaccessible, percutaneous dilation is indicated. These strictures can be traumatic, postoperative, infectious, inflammatory and iatrogenic in origin. Contraindications include uncorrectable bleeding diathesis, marked ascites and uncooperative patients. Under broad spectrum antibiotics and mild conscious sedation and after puncturing a peripheral bile duct, crossing the lesion with a guidewire and establishing access to the bowel loop, an internal-external biliary drainage catheter is inserted temporarily if needed, otherwise dilatation is performed right away with an 8-10 mm angioplasty balloon. The procedure can be repeated every 3-4 months until an unobstructed flow is achieved. Patency after 3-5 years is around 70%. The use of cutting balloon appears, in skillful hands, to increase both primary and secondary patency. Major complications include sepsis, hemobilia, bile peritonitis, intraperitoneal hemorrhage, pneumothorax and subphrenic abscess. Minor complications include catheter dislodgement, peristomal bile leakage and cholangitis. Metallic stents should be held as the last option of percutaneous techniques as these patients normally have a long life expectancy. Bile duct trauma can be treated with long-lasting biliary drainage and/or insertion of one or more plastic stents. Bile duct stones could be cleared by pushing them to the duodenum with an angioplasty balloon and/or rinsing the biliary tree with normal saline. Mechanical lithotripsy could also be performed. Cholangioscopy is a useful tool in the decision-making for the management of patients with benign biliary disease, although not widely available as an everyday use method.Learning Objectives: 1. Menu; Le Kremlin-Bicêtre/FR (yves.menu@bct.aphp.fr)Small bowel imaging has always been a challenge. Barium studies have lost ground with US, CT and MRI, which made it possible to examine the intestinal wall and the surroundings. In the meantime, videocapsule has stepped in. The aim of this session is therefore to improve our technical knowledge and interpretation skills, and to learn the optimal strategy in patients with a suspected disease of the small bowel. In order to improve our technical and medical knowledge, three experts were asked to present different techniques, dealing with technical requirements, acquisition parameters and bowel preparation, with the idea that these techniques could be performed in most centers. They will also show the elementary images of normal and diseased small bowel. Consequently, a panel discussion will determine the adequate strategies and give recommendations for common clinical situations: Should we still perform barium studies? How far can we go with US? Are there situations where US is enough? What is the most adequate strategy in a patient with incomplete or transient small bowel obstruction, with -chronic or acute-intestinal bleeding, with bowel inflammatory disease? What are the good reasons to choose between MDCT and MRI? Is videopcasule a complement or a substitute for imaging? At the end of the session, the attendees will have a clear view of the optimal imaging technique and strategy, and will understand why the radiologist has an increasing role in the evaluation of these patients. Session Objective: 1. To describe how modern imaging impacts the work-up of patients with suspected or known small bowel disease, and the complementary role of imaging with clinical, endoscopic and biological data.Computed tomography: The heavy worker G.A. Rollandi, E. Biscaldi; Genoa/IT (gian.andrea.rollandi@galliera.it) The multislice-CT (MSCT) with transparent bowel distension is a validated method to investigate the small bowel. The difference between the density of the endoluminal contrast and the contrast medium (c.m). in the intestinal wall is essential to detect easily mucosal lesions, with a perilesional enhancement. To administer endoluminal contrast medium, the intestinal loops are distended, and a catheter is used to introduce the contrast overcoming the emptying of the stomach. The CT technique uses MSCT acquisition (16 rows); collimation 5 mm, reconstruction 1.25 mm, gap 1 mm, iodinated c.m.(370 mg I/100 ml; 2 cc/Kg body weight), at 3 cc/s, 40 s after the arterial peak. For post-processing, the MSCT data are reconstructed in multiplanar (MPVR) images from the PACS. For Crohn's disease, in the acute phase, the lesions are revealed as a pathologic mucosal enhancement with a thickened and multilayered aspect of the intestinal segments and the submucosal oedema. The late phase appears with luminal stenosis, creeping mesentery and fibrofatty proliferation. In this phase, fistulas and other complications are possible. The pathologic troubles of ileal vascularisation and the CT patterns are discussed. How do we recognize small bowel tumours? Bowel distension helps to detect the parietal lesions. The main elements of the diagnosis are stenosis, detection of extra or intraluminal masses and the presence of direct or indirect signs as dense mesenteric fibrotic strands in carcinoids. The X-ray dose in small bowel examination, the benchmarking of X-ray dose between the conventional barium studies vs the MSCT enteroclysis, is evaluated. Learning Objectives: 1. back_matter.text: As the principal route whereby most breast carcinomas spread to distant tissues is via the lymphatics, the determination of nodal invasion is of particular importance. The sentinel node hypothesis is based on the fact that sentinel nodes are the first nodes draining a tumor, and that their histological status predicts the status of the regional lymphatic basin. Using sentinel node biopsy, costs and morbidity of an axillary lymph node dissection can be avoided in nodal negative patients. Lymphoscintigraphy and blue dye injection represent the current gold standard. The technical parameters for sentinel node biopsy vary. Studies differ with respect to many parameters, including the labeling agent used for preoperative lymphatic mapping, the volume and site of injection, and the interval between injection and surgery. With the radioguided occult lesion localisation (ROLL) procedure, macroaggregates of technetium-99m-labeled human serum albumine are injected into the lesion, instead of the introduction of a wire hook or carbon injection. Ultrasound (US) is the study of choice for initial lymph node evaluation followed by power Doppler and contrast-enhanced US as the next step. Recently published studies show serious potentials for PET, PET-CT, MRI and even 3-dimensional multidetector-row CT lymphography. Contrast agents allow perfusional studies that increase the sensitivity for small nodal metastases and allow useful monitoring in locally advanced breast cancer. Molecular imaging with USPIO as specific lymph node contrast agent for MRI is already established in clinical practice; optical and near infrared probes will be used in the near future. Størmer; Tromsø/NO (jan.stormer@unn.no)Teleradiology has introduced a paradigm shift, from a "culture of isolation" to a "culture of sharing", in the radiology reading culture. For those not working in the radiology environment, it is fundamental to understand that there is a distinct difference between those radiological procedures that cannot be taken care of by anyone other than local radiologists (interventional procedures, ultrasound examinations or examinations requiring sophisticated intravascular contrast media). This is at least true for the time being. There are actually solutions for doing these kinds of operations also at a distance, but not in a high-volume manner. The scope of this presentation will be restricted to those imaging procedures in which the where and when of the images generated do not depend on the physical presence of the reading radiologist. Digital imaging and network communication (WWW) have dramatically opened the possibility of remodelling of logistics and workflow in imaging. The fact that all necessary information for reporting (images and clinical information) can be distributed wherever there is a network with acceptable bandwidth and an appropriate workstation has opened the possibility of many different models of remote reading, for primary reading, second opinion and robot reading. There are local, regional, national and international projects, where both public and private players participate. All experiences so far have demonstrated the tremendous potential in parallel with potential risks and hindrances related to new practices. All kinds of quality, legal, security and cultural challenges have been exposed and should be discussed by those intending to participate in this challenging future development. A teleradiology company has many stakeholders including patients, paying clients (with their radiologists and referring physicians), reporting radiologists, personnel, medical advisory board and shareholders. When providing teleradiology, one of the first questions is: Who is the client and who will pay for the service? There are many kinds of clients such as a radiology group, board of directors, healthcare company, diagnostic centre, other commercial companies for B2B, chiropractors, national departments and others. For each client, two aspects are of utmost importance, cost and quality. In the first phase of negotiation with a future client it has to be clarified what a client really expects and what is possible. Does the client have PACS, RIS, HL7, broadband infrastructure, etc., to meet his expectations? The contract itself is an extensive document and contains details of what kind of radiological procedures have to be reported, how many and when, what kind of protocol (e.g., which sequences of an MRI) will be used, how will the necessary clinical information be delivered, what about previous examinations, what about other clinical information, what is the turn-around time, what happens when this is not met, how should the report be delivered (e.g., direct in the RIS?), what kind of quality control will be performed, how frequently does the client receive data of quality controls, what is the commitment of both parties, etc. Along with all these aspects, also the legal, ethical, insurance and security issues have to be addressed. Learning Objectives:1. To get an insight how a commercial teleradiology environment works. 2. To get an idea of the types of services that are offered in a commercial teleradiology enterprise. 3. To get an overview of the quality issues that are involved and need to be managed.

Teleradiology is now widely used for delivering radiology services to rural communities, providing second specialist opinions, as local area networks between groups of hospitals and emergency 24/7 reporting services. It has recently been used by national purchasing authorities to provide a comprehensive internationally outsourced imaging service. The development alters the traditional way that radiology has functioned with marked reduction of contact with clinical colleagues and patients, increasing subspecialisation, potential language problems, variations in training, altered on-call arrangements and different remuneration rates. It may change radiology from a clinical service to a reporting service. In response to this development, international radiological organisations have drawn up guidelines to protect the patients and ensure an equitable quality of service among different service providers. These guidelines focus particularly on registration of radiologists in the country of the patient and the service provider, ensuring that equivalent training, appraisal, CME and re-registration requirements are observed as well as language proficiency. The EC radiation protection and working time directives must be satisfied, and proper communication between the reporting radiologists and the source clinicians is essential. This is best done by involvement of local radiologists or coordinated clinical links in local or wide-area networks. Radiologists should recognise that clinicoradiological and multidisciplinary team meetings are valuable for the coordination of patient investigations and care, providing feedback of outcome, auditing of interpretations and bringing radiologists into a central hospital role. This role can only be provided in teleradiology by teleconferencing. The knowledge of the normal anatomy of the shoulder joint and its variants is essential for a conclusive diagnosis in rotator cuff impingement. There are several forms of impingement. "Primary extrinsic impingement" (narrowing of the subacromial/subcoracoid space) may by caused by subacromial spurs, unstable os acromiale, variations of the acromial morphology, degeneration of the acromioclavicular joint or abnormalities of the coracoid process. Chronic or longstanding glenohumeral instability, mostly observed in athletes who participate in sports that require repetitive overhead or throwing motions, may lead to "secondary extrinsic impingement". In those cases, clinical symptoms may mask signs of underlying glenohumeral instability and point directly to rotator cuff lesions. "Internal impingement" may be caused by abnormalities due to friction between the posterosuperior labrum and glenoid. Sooner or later, impingement syndromes lead to lesions of the rotator cuff tendons (degeneration/fraying, partial tears, full-thickness tears). In this presentation, the different forms of impingement and MR imaging findings of rotator cuff pathology are demonstrated.Learning Objectives: 1. To become familiar with MR imaging of the normal rotator cuff. 2. To understand aetiology and MR findings of rotator cuff lesions caused by or leading to subacromial impingement. 3. To recognise tendinosis vs partial and full thickness rotator cuff tears. 4. To recognise internal impingement (posterosuperior glenoid impingement).A-305 09:00 B. Instability P. Hughes; Plymouth/UK The term shoulder instability embraces those patients with both subluxation and dislocation of the joint, and investigation is indicated predominantly for recurrent dislocation or for apprehension when the arm is held in certain positions. Accurate pre-operative assessment is essential and likely to become increasingly necessary with the increased use of arthroscopic repair. The primary diagnostic modality applied to the pre-operative investigation of instability is MR arthrography. Its sensitivity and specificity in identifying abnormalities related to instability will be discussed and contrasted with alternative imaging techniques. The injection technique, imaging protocols and optimal orientation of scans will be considered along with the potential benefits of ABER positioning. Common appearances of labral, glenoid and ligamentous abnormalities associated with instability will be demonstrated. The importance of identifying the less common posterior and multidirectional instability and rotator cuff tears will be emphasized. Common post-operative appearances and causes of recurrent instability will be discussed. Learning Objectives:1. To understand anatomy relevant to instabilty. 2. To recognise common labral and ligamentous normal variants. 3 . To identify lesions associated with dysfunction of the glenohumeral ligaments. 4. To select the appropriate imaging technique, tailored to surgical requirements. 5. To recognise the importance and signs of multidirectional instability.

back_matter.text: The final objective in women with breast pathology is a longer disease-free survival and better quality of life, a challenge that can be tackled by improving surgical, adjunctive therapies and technical imaging. In technical imaging, more detailed and novel information are available for the diagnostic process and new techniques should allow the diagnostic process to be as physically and psychologically invasive as possible for the patient. The complex ensemble of sonographic signs and color Doppler patterns (lesion shape, orientation, margin, boundary, echo pattern, posterior acoustic wave, surrounding tissue, vascularity) has found a synthetic standardized language in the Breast Imaging Report and Data System (BI-RADS) developed by the American College of Radiology. This system is gradually becoming the official language in breast lesion management. It solves efficiently lesions BI-RADS 2, 5 and 6. On the other hand, lesions BI-RADS 3 and 4 still require full agreement in their management. Advanced technologies for lesion assessment, like real-time sono-elastography and volumetric acquisition with multiplanar reconstruction, are being introduced to clinical practice and may be of greatest benefit (diagnostic power) for lesions BI-RADS 3 and 4. Nowadays, MRI should be the only technique to investigate the sellar region. Pituitary adenomas are, by far, the most frequent lesions observed in this area. They usually appear as well-delineated intra-or intra-suprasellar lesions, demonstrating T1 hypointensity and T2 hyperintensity, with slight variations according to their secreting types. Pituitary adenomas enhance moderately after gadolinium injection, usually less than the adjacent remaining normal adenohypophysis. Dynamic contrast-enhanced technique and delayed post-contrast T1-weighted sequence, sometimes better depict doubtful adenomas. Rathke cleft cysts (RCC) are also common sellar lesions and represent the main differential diagnosis of pituitary adenomas. Diagnosis is easy when they are on midline, exactly located between the anterior and posterior pituitary lobes, with homogeneous T1 hyperintensity and T2 hypointensity, due to their high protein content. However, RCC signal intensities vary and directly depend on their biochemical content. Thus, they can be more serous and present with more classical "cystic" signal intensities. In that case, visualisation of intracystic concretions, depicted as T2 hypointense intracystic nodules, is a clue to the diagnosis. Noteworthy, RCC do not enhance after gadolinium administration. On the contrary, craniopharyngiomas, often compared to RCCs, are rather different. They have calcifications, solid and cystic components and therefore mostly appear as heterogeneous and large suprasellar enhancing lesions, leading to stalk and optic chiasm compressions. In the sellar region, meningiomas often invade the cavernous sinus, resulting in internal carotid artery stenosis. Finally, intracranial aneurysms are often misdiagnosed and should systematically be evoked in case of T2 hypointense round lesion. Learning Objectives: 1. To learn the imaging protocol for the detection of pituitary lesions. 2. To discuss the clinical and imaging features of micro-adenoma of the hypophysis. 3. To discuss the clinical and imaging features of macro-adenoma of the hypophysis. 4. To discuss the differential diagnosis of micro-and macro-adenoma of the hypophysis.
