back_matter.text: B. Primary brain tumors S. Karampekios; Iraklion/GR (karampek@med.uoc.gr)Primary malignant brain tumors are associated with the third highest cancer-related mortality rate and a disproportional high level of disability and mortality. Therefore, early and accurate diagnosis is critical to determine prognosis and therapy. The primary goals of imaging in patients with primary brain tumors are: (1) detection of the lesion, (2) localization to a specific anatomic compartment, (3) determination of the extension and the resulting mass effect of the lesion. Radiology, by using traditional criteria, such as a) the age of the patient, b) the location of the lesion (intra-or extra-axial, supra-or infra-tentorial), and c) imaging characteristics (margins, edema, necrosis, hemorrhage, calcifications, cellularity, pattern of enhancement), in the majority of the patients is able to provide an adequate differential diagnosis, since different types of tumors occur in different age groups, in certain intracranial locations and with various imaging features. Although MRI is the imaging modality of choice for the evaluation of intracranial masses, it suffers from a number of limitations including difficulties in: (1) demarcating the exact margins of infiltrative tumors, (2) distinguishing high-grade from low-grade neoplasms, (3) differentiating a primary intra-axial tumor from a solitary metastasis, (4) discriminating between recurrent tumor and post-radiation necrosis, (5) distinguishing neoplastic from non-neoplastic intracranial lesions. Advanced MR techniques such as diffusion and diffusion tensor imaging (DWI-DTI), perfusion imaging (PWI), MR spectroscopy (MRS) and functional MRI (fMRI) can be used to improve the diagnostic accuracy and evolve brain imaging from a strictly morphologic diagnosis to one that combines anatomy, metabolism, physiology, biochemistry and function.Learning Objectives: 1. To learn the incidence and neuropathology of primary brain tumors. 2. To learn the typical imaging features of primary brain tumors. 3 . To report on the limitations of conventional contrast-enhanced MR imaging in the diagnosis and differential diagnosis of brain tumors.

C. Pseudo-tumoral lesions: Diagnosis and differential diagnosis C.F. Andreula; Bari/IT (candreula@gvm-ant.it)1. Pseudotumors and tumor-like lesions are non-neoplastic lesions, that simulate real tumors on imaging studies of the brain. 2. The location of the lesions mostly gives the best clue for the differential diagnosis. They generally occur in places where structures of different origin coexist. 3. The trick is to remember the anatomical components of the region. For example, in the cavernous sinus region there are cranial nerves (giving rise to schwannoma), meninges (giving rise to meningioma), vessels that can be be malformative (aneurysms and AVM), vessels that can be occluded (arterial and venous thrombosis), cells of the reticulo-endothelial system (hystiocytosis, sarcoidosis) and so on. 4. The most frequent tumor-like lesions are the inflammatory lesions such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and acute encephalomyelitis (ADEM). These lesions are intracerebral, rarely isolated in the same exam and/or in longitudinal studies, and they tend to decrease in size or disappear. 5. The most frequent tumor-like lesions in the ventricles and subarachnoid spaces are arachnoid cysts. In the cerebello-pontine angle, they should be differentiated from the epidermoids using MRI-dedicated sequences such as FLAIR and DWI. Learning Objectives: 1. To discuss the most frequent brain lesions that can simulate a brain tumor. 2. To learn possible differential diagnostic signs on conventional neuroradiological examinations. 3. To discuss the impact of advanced techniques in the differential diagnosis of pseudo-tumoral lesions. In diagnostic radiology, there has been a substantial increase in both the frequency and range of medical exposures. In addition, high-dose techniques such as CT scanning and interventional radiology/cardiology have become commonplace. Equipment design has led to higher patient throughput. All of these factors have contributed to a large increase in the frequency of procedures and the collective dose to the population. Worldwide, diagnostic radiology represents the largest manmade contribution to population dose. In this refresher course, patient dosimetry measurement methods for diagnostic radiology examinations will be described. This will include an introduction to various patient dose quantities and their relevance to patient dose surveys. The published literature on patient dose levels for various diagnostic procedures and their frequency will be reviewed. Proposed strategies for identifying and dealing with practices where doses are higher than the norm will be described. This will include a description of, as well as practical examples of, optimisation and justification. Case studies of practical approaches to patient dose reduction will be described. Specific examples drawn from paediatrics and radiology of pregnant women will be provided. Interventional radiology, and mainly fluoroscopy-guided procedures, is a growing activity in all developed countries and represents an important component of population dose. Several studies have evidenced a large variability of patient and staff exposures, equipment performance and level of justification of the practice in cardiology, neuroradiology and peripheral interventional areas. In some complex type of procedures, the skin dose can be, for a substantial number of patients, higher than the threshold for deterministic effects of radiation. The use of complex radiological equipment to perform potentially high dose procedures outside radiology departments by personnel nontrained in radiological imaging and radiation protection is another important factor explaining observed nonoptimised practice. The presentation will provides an overview of the level of exposures in different interventional areas. Examples of nonoptimised set-up of angiographic equipment, differences in technical protocols and differences in staff dosimetry and staff exposure will introduce the need of training and optimisation of procedures. The results of some studies on the adoption of reference levels (RL) in interventional practice, taking into account the complexity of procedures, the proposal of dose constraints for staff exposure and reference values for the entrance dose rates of equipment, will be presented for the available optimisation tools. Quality criteria of clinical images, together with the evaluation of test phantom images, is another important part of the optimisation process.The importance of training of interventional staff, the follow-up of some training events and the training material available will be finally presented and discussed. (2) of the directive, shall be kept as low as reasonably achievable consistent with obtaining the required diagnostic information taking into account economic and social factors. This clause implies that every establishment using ionising radiation for diagnostic procedures or therapeutic interventional techniques need to establish a patient dose management system in order to keep these doses as low as reasonably achievable. In nuclear medicine, due to the use of unsealed radioactive sources, there is a need to establish two distinct management systems, one for diagnostic procedures and the other for therapeutic procedures. The use of hybrid systems such as PET/CT and SPECT/CT for diagnostic purposes makes the management of patient doses even more difficult, since additional to the dose to the patient form the radiopharmaceuticals used, the dose from the CT in acquiring the anatomic images or from the image attenuation correction need to be taken into account. The aim of this presentation is to give a bird's eye view of the peculiarities of these management systems with the objectives of presenting a review of radiopharmaceutical administrative practices involved, presenting the challenges of optimisation and justification of the procedures and providing specific data for comparison with other diagnostic techniques that use ionising radiation. The type of traumatic head injuries depends not only on the mode of injury but also on the age of the child, as young children have anatomical and physiological particularities. Young infants have, for example, a relatively large head, weak neck muscles, thin compressible skull, large subarachnoid spaces, poor myelination, inadequate vasomotor reactivity and different regional metabolism activities. Primary injuries are direct consequences of the forces associated with the traumatic event.They include intra-axial lesions (cortical contusions, diffuse axonal injuries, brain hematomas) and extra-axial lesions (subarachnoid hemorrhage, subdural hematoma, epidural hematoma and intraventricular hemorrhage). Secondary injuries are considered as reactive brain processes. They include cytotoxic and vasogenic edema with possible malignant cerebral swelling, and cellular necrosis from hypoxia, possible associated seizures, arterial infarction and pressure necrosis. Diagnosis of infantile inflicted injury remains very challenging as most abused infants present with non-specific clinical findings. Craniocerebral involvement is not uncommon and has a worse outcome than in accidental injuries. Non-accidental injury is indeed the leading cause of traumatic death in infancy, of neurodevelopmental disabilities and permanent neurological deficits. Cranial lesions in non-accidental injury are produced by violent shaking without impact (shaken-baby syndrome) or with impact (shaking-impact syndrome) generating high translational, but also rotational, forces that accompany rapid acceleration-deceleration movements. MRI is required to detect non-hemorrhagic intraparenchymal involvement. Several studies have proved the sensitivity and the prognostic value of early diffusion-weighted (DW) imaging in non-accidental brain injury. The main objective of this presentation is to illustrate the factors affecting contrast media enhancement in rapid MDCT scanning and to interrelate the advantages presented with advanced CT technology and automated injectors in our daily routine. The advent of MDCT systems has made protocol design rather complex, particularly when contrast media is administered. High-speed scanning is a diagnostic tool only when its capabilities are exploited. However, pre-existing CT protocols have not been revised and thus produce images with insufficient contrast enhancement leading to misdiagnosis. Unless we become accustomed with the factors affecting contrast media enhancement and the associated scanning parameters, the diagnostic value of images will continue to decline as scanning speed increases. It is critical that these factors and parameters be synchronized in order to generate appropriate MDCT examination protocols. The presentation of examination protocols will be based upon recent bibliography considering the following key areas: I. Injection parameters: a. Contrast media (CM) volume and iodine concentration. b. CM flow rate. c. Saline flush. II. Acquisition parameters: a. Scan speed and rotation time. b. Section collimation and pitch. c. Scan delay. Concisely, the aim of this refresher course is to prove that (diagnostic) image quality must override examination speed by integrating recent bibliography to practice. For a clinical tool to be useful, it must fulfil a number of criteria, including ease of use, proven efficacy, acceptable time to achieve the desired effect, low cost and absence of significant adverse effects. High-intensity-focused ultrasound (HIFU) is a young technique, and its usefulness in the clinical setting has not yet proved. On paper, and in the laboratory, it fulfils many of the criteria set out above. The ability to focus a high-power ultrasound (US) beam onto a specified target volume with the aim of inducing instantaneous thermal ablation makes HIFU a very attractive non-invasive technique for tumour destruction. Laboratory studies have shown that cell killing is highly localised, with sparing of overlying and surrounding tissue structures. Clinical trials conducted to date on tumours of the prostate, liver, kidney, uterus, breast, pancreas and bone have shown promising results, with only minor side effects have been reported. Long-term follow-up has, however, not yet been possible for most applications. Treatment monitoring is either by US or by magnetic resonance imaging. Each has its own advantages and disadvantages. At present, HIFU treatments for abdominal tumours are still often too lengthy to allow the treatment to become more widespread. However, techniques are under development that will allow more rapid ablation of the required volumes. The principle of HIFU has been proved for many clinical applications. It is a new technique that seems possibly to find its niche as a useful clinical tool in the future. Focal opacities are a commonly seen abnormality on the CXR and CT. When providing a differential diagnosis of their causes, it is important to take into account the relevant clinical history and any previous imaging. Then by analysing their character and reviewing other abnormalities also present, it is often possible to determine their cause. This presentation will review the different types of focal opacities that are seen and provide a method for their analysis. It will review the commonest causes and place them in the clinical scenarios in which they are most likely to occur. It will also discuss the role of biopsy and bronchoscopy in providing a tissue diagnosis. This course will focus on diffuse, frequently bilateral processes characterized by "alveolar filling". The differential diagnosis of airspace shadows is long and includes a broad variety of diseases in terms of diagnosis, therapeutic management and prognosis. The radiographic and CT appearance depend on the intra-alveolar material, cellular or fluid, that resulted in the replacement of the air within the distal airways. Pieces of useful information, possibly representing the key towards the differential diagnosis, include: a) correlation with clinical symptoms such as hemoptysis, fever, history of cardiac insufficiency, immune status or a history of known or suspected malignancy; b) analysis of the features of the shadowing such as its density, distribution and borders; c) analysis of accessory findings such as signs of volume increase or decrease, vascularity, the presence of air bronchogram or the presence of overlying reticular or septal densities. The goal of the course is to review the common causes of alveolar shadowing, such as pneumonia, atelectasis, edema, hemorrhage, alveolar proteinosis or neoplastic diseases, and to describe the important morphological and clinical features that lead to the diagnosis, which provides the radiologist with helpful visual and clinical tools for differential diagnosis. Septal, reticular, nodular, reticulonodular and ground-glass patterns characterize interstitial lung disease. Each of these HRCT patterns characterizes some predominant entities, and in combination with clinical findings often helps to make a specific diagnosis. Occasionally, different entities may mimic each other tremendously on radiologic terms, either because they share identical HRCT findings or because of superimposition of HRCT patterns. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, fibrosis associated with connective tissue disease, asbestosis, chronic sarcoidosis, chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis and drug-induced fibrosis may present on HRCT with lower zone, subpleural reticular pattern associated with honeycombing. Cystic pattern also results in a reticular pattern. Occasionally, lymphangiomyomatosis may be indistinguishable from tuberous sclerosis or langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH), while end-stage LCH may mimic end-stage fibrosis or extensive emhysema. Both pulmonary edema and lymphangitic carcinomatosis may be characterized by a septal pattern resulting from thickened interlobular septa. Micronodular pattern with ill-defined centrilobular nodules may be identically present in hypersensitivity pneumonitis and respiratory bronchiolitis. Sarcoidosis may occasionally mimic miliary tuberculosis or hematogenous metastases presenting with a miliary nodular pattern, while bronchogenic spread of tuberculosis may be indistinguishble from panbronchiolitis, both presenting with a tree-in-bud pattern. Atypical infection presenting with ground-glass pattern may mimic hemorrhage. Ground-glass pattern associated with minimal reticulation may be seen in desquamative interstitial pneumonia, respiratory bronchilitis associated intestitial lung disease and nonspecific interstitial pneumonia. Various mimics in interstitial lung disease exist and differential diagnosis could be narrowed when possible, based on the integration of the correct HRCT pattern together with any additional imaging clues in the appropriate clinical context. Learning Objectives:1. To learn about the different HRCT patterns, which are related to interstitial lung diseases and to understand the underlying pathologic-radiologic correlations that cause each HRCT pattern. 2. To be familiar with the more "classical" entities presenting with each HRCT pattern and to discuss the possible overlap of different HRCT patterns and the more common diagnostic mimics in each case. 3. To familiarise with potential pitfalls in diagnosing interstitial opacities on HRCT and learn about some clues that help differentiate the various diagnostic mimics. Ultrasound guided interventional techniques play an increasingly significant role in the management of breast disease. Common indications are diverse and include biopsy of solid masses or microcalcifications, symptomatic cyst drainage, lymph node staging in patients with breast cancer, tumour mapping with preoperative radiotracer injection or hookwires and mapping with metallic markers in patients undergoing neoadjuvant chemotherapy, as well as breast abscess drainage. Less frequent indications are ablation of benign lesions with vacuum biopsy devices, cryoablation of fibroadenomas and radiofrequency ablation of small breast cancers. The technical aspects of US interventional procedures should take into account circumstances related to the patient (patient positioning an preparation), state-ofthe-art US hardware and software, all the different types of biopsy devices available and the insertion technique. The appropriate choice of the biopsy needle to be used (FNAB, automated core biopsy, vacuum-assisted biopsy) is one of the most important aspects of breast US interventional procedures because the needle conditions the correct sampling of the lesion to a great extent. Potential pitfalls to be considered are false negative results due to technical failure, or failure to choose the right type of needle, failure to recognize a radiological-pathological discordance and lack of imaging follow-up. Also to be taken into account are lesions that should not be biopsied and should undergo surgical biopsy (radial scar, complex cysts) and the management of complications (bleeding, pseudoanurysm formation). In summary, interventional US is a continuously expanding field that successfully avoids more invasive surgical procedures with a high level of accuracy. Contrast-enhanced MRI has proven to be more sensitive for the detection of breast lesions when compared with mammography and/or ultrasound. However, one of the continuing challenges of breast MRI is the differentiation between benign and malignant lesions. This combination of high sensitivity and only a moderate specificity results in lesions that are occult on other modalities and cannot be classified as benign based on morphology and enhancement dynamics. For these lesions, MRI-guided interventions are an option. The indication to perform an interventional procedure on MRI should be based on the aspect of the lesion, the primary MRI indication and the personal and family history of the patient. Any radiologist who performs breast MRI must be familiar with the possibilities and limitations of MRIguided breast interventions and be able to facilitate them in his own or a related radiology department. MRI-guided interventional procedures can be performed either by a free-hand technique or with the use of a stereotactic needle guidance system. Stereotactic needle guidance almost ensures an accurate needle placement. However, the biopsy system cannot correct for tissue movement during the procedure. This makes control scans during the procedure inevitable. Another limitation is that lesions near the chest wall or the axilla can be out of reach for some devices. Although MRI-guided interventional procedures are accurate it is important to discuss the results with the pathologist to check whether the findings are explanatory for the enhancement found on MRI. Many types of arterial hemorrhage in the digestive tract are amenable to transcatheter arterial embolization (TAE). The most common indications in the upper gastro-intestinal tract (UGT) include duodenal or gastric ulcer hemorrhage, refractory to endoscopic treatment or recurring following initially successful endoscopic treatment. The most common indication of TAE in the lower gastro-intestinal tract (LGT) is diverticular hemorrhage. UGT hemorrhage is often massive and more immediately life threatening than LGT hemorrhage.LGT hemorrhage can therefore be managed conservatively more often than UGT hemorrhage. In general, contrast extravasation can be observed angiographically when a patient has clinical signs of an active bleed, such as hypotension and tachycardia. When performing angiography, selective series of all visceral vessels should be obtained. Many anastomotic communications exist between the celiac axis and the superior mesenteric artery, as well as between different branches of the celiac axis itself. The UGT has much more collateral potential than the LGT and this should be taken into account when embolizing in these territories. As a consequence of these anatomic differences, rebleeds following TAE are more frequently observed in the UGT than in the LGT, whereas a higher risk for the development of bowel ischemia exists in the LGT. Success rates from the literature for UGT bleeds vary between 50 and 80%, whereas these figures are 70-90% for LGT bleeds. Recurrence following TAE is reported between 5 and 30%. In recent series, bowel ischemia as a result of TAE is reported in 5% of patients. Recent developments in multidetector computed tomography (MDCT) have had a major impact on trauma management. A CT protocol to image the thorax, abdomen and pelvis needs pre-and post-intravenous contrast injection. Multiplanar reconstructions should be performed and CT angiographic images have to be visualized. CT can show solid organ injury, hematoma and contrast extravasation in various anatomic spaces and organs, according to the mechanism of trauma. The identification and localization of an active bleeding source on multislice CT will help the angiographer to target his catheterization and subsequent embolization. Consideration of how and where trauma services are to be provided inevitably leads to the need of developing contemporary protocols for imaging and interventional management of trauma. The interventional radiology team must be involved at the time of imaging. The IR team needs to be large and experienced enough to ensure 24/24, 365/365 call coverage. The most frequently occurring injuries, amenable to angiographic embolization (AE), are retroperitoneal hemorrhage, pelvic fracture and intra-abdominal hemorrhage of the liver, spleen or kidney. Traumatic aortic injury (TAI) can be treated with stent-grafting. All source of bleeding will be treated in a consecutive manner by means of gelfoam or coils according to the target organ and the angiographic presentation. Temporary balloon occlusions in case of catastrophic bleeding can help to bypass a critical moment and open the door for embolization in a partly resuscitated patient. The endpoints of AE are cessation of contrast extravasation on angiography, improvement of the hemodynamic condition in hemodynamically unstable patients (reduction of heart rate and increase of diastolic blood pressure) and a successful non-operative management in hemodynamically stable patients. The goal of aortic stent-grafting is to overcome acute rupture. The current role of MRI in the evaluation of patients with ischemic heart disease will be reviewed. Coronary artery imaging provides information on stenoses and vessel wall thickness. Vessel wall imaging is an emerging application to assess atherosclerosis burden. Higher field MRI may help to improve coronary imaging owing to improved spatial resolution. Functional consequences can be assessed by MRI flow mapping, which provides additional information over luminography. The evaluation of cardiac function is well accepted as the gold standard for both left ventricular and right ventricular dimensions. In addition, the delayed enhancement technique is now an indispensable tool for assessing the extent of scar and viability. MRI first-pass perfusion is accurate in detecting microvascular obstruction in patients suffering from acute myocardial infarction. The combination of function, first-pass perfusion and delayed enhancement fully characterizes ischemic myocardium. In patients with extensive left ventricular scar, information on mitral valve competence is helpful for treatment planning, which is easily available by MRI.Patients who are scheduled for biventricular pacing may benefit from MRI, which show the extent and location of infarcts. Currently, MRI techniques are indispensable tools for characterizing multiple aspects of ischemic heart disease. Cardiac diseases from non-ischemic origin include a wide range of diseases, making appropriate diagnosis often difficult. Abnormalities may arise in the myocardium (cardiomyopathies, myocarditis, infiltrative diseases), pericardium (effusion, inflammatory/constrictive pericarditis), and cardiac valves. Moreover, differentiation between ischemic and non-ischemic origin is not always straightforward. Among current cardiac imaging modalities, MRI has emerged as the preferential one in assessing this heterogeneous group of cardiac abnormalities. Using a comprehensive approach, accurate information can be obtained on cardiac structure, myocardial, ventricular and valvular function, myocardial perfusion, and tissue characterization. The introduction of contrast-enhanced inversion-recovery MRI (so-called delayed enhancement imaging) has allowed the description of specific patterns of enhancement in several disease entities. Because abnormalities (e.g. myocarditis) frequently have a focal spreading pattern, abnormalities can be better depicted than endocardial biopsy, often lacking sensitivity. In this presentation, the strategies toward assessing non-ischemic diseases with MRI will be discussed, including the current shortcomings and limitations of the technique. Learning Objectives: 1. To describe the differential diagnoses for non-ischemic heart diseases including cardiomyopathies, inflammatory disease and storage diseases. Congenital heart disease requires repeated the imaging of morphology and function in children and young adults to plan and monitor therapy and to identify complications. Ultrasound (US) is most frequently used because it is easy to apply and inexpensive. It depends, however, on acoustic windows and is hampered by significant inter-observer variability. Magnetic resonance (MR), on the other hand, provides information on morphology, mass, function, ultrastructure, flow, and viability of the heart with unrestricted choice of imaging planes. Computed tomography (CT) plays only a minor role in congenital heart disease, as repeated radiation exposure is an important issue in young individuals. Indications for CT are quantification of calcification of conduits and grafts, assessment of variations of coronary anatomy, or emergencies. For MR imaging, planes are oriented similar to echocardiography; most important are four-chamber, two-chamber and short-axis views. Cine imaging allows for detection of wall motion abnormalities and calculation of ejection fraction, volumes, and cardiac mass. T1-weighted imaging provides the definition of anatomic details. Velocity-encoded cine imaging allows for the quantification of stenosis in grafts and conduits. Contrast material can enhance the diagnostic power of MR if inflammation or scar is present. Dobutamine stress imaging can disclose impaired ventricular functional reserve following the surgical repair of tetralogy of fallot or transposition. In conclusion, US and MR are strong and complementary tools for imaging congenital heart disease, whereas CT plays only a minor role. An increasing number of women enter medical school. Their choice of a subsequent career is huge. Thankfully, many choose radiology. The choice for women is no longer between parenthood and work. Most try to combine both aspects of life, for intellectual fulfillment and financial reasons. Many are the breadwinners of the family. In spite of political mantras of sex equality, belief persists that childcare is the woman's responsibility and she should reduce work commitments to care for the family. Part-time employment is the usual solution, but it is difficult to sustain full involvement in these circumstances. Women are thus often regarded as "secondclass citizens". Tensions arise and disturb departmental harmony. Many women would welcome the opportunity to remain fully involved in all aspects of work, but cannot because of the traditional daily work patterns. Life has changed and parenthood is not just for women. Many men would wish to spend more time with their family if the demands of work permitted it. Work/life balance is an increasing issue. This session, though entitled "Women in Radiology: How to maximise their input", raises issues that equally affect men. We will explore these issues, ranging widely and laterally, and consider how to maximise the input of all radiologists in maintaining and improving patient care, while providing stimulating and enjoyable working patterns and allowing precious quality time for the family, to each other and to themselves.

Life as a radiologist, before and after childrenThe number of working mothers of young children has risen rapidly in recent years. With changing gender roles, both employers and employees have to adjust to new realities. While men have traditionally been viewed as the breadwinner and women as the nurturers and caretakers of the family, these role models have been crumbling in the past decades. The birth of children is one of the major turning points in life. Even though this holds true for both men and women, women's careers generally tend to be affected more. While men are commonly in an upward phase of their career path around the time the children are born, women's careers rather tend to stagnate or to dwindle. Analyzing gender-specific patterns in career development and demographic figures of male and female positions within radiology may aid in identifying potential solutions to maximize the input of female radiologists. With an increasing percentage of women entering medical school, in many countries women actually exceed men in medical school, and an increasing proportion of female radiologists, radiology cannot afford to lose this highly trained and qualified workforce. In contrast to many other medical specialties, radiology offers unique chances to achieve flexible working patterns that may influence work-life articulation both for men and women, especially when parenting small children. Among these are the option to report from home, either as a provisional full-time solution or as a back-up option, e.g., when the children are ill or daycare solutions are unavailable or closed. Learning Objectives:1. To gain an understanding of the sociology of gender employment. 2. To see how the theory applies to radiology. 3. From theory to practice: A personal experience.

Eastern Europe: Are the issues the same?In eastern European countries, women regard education and professional career as important parts of their life. The number of women studying medicine systematically has increased and account for 60-70% of all medical students. Technical progress in radiology seems to attract them; in most of the eastern European countries about 60% of radiologists are women. Some of them are successful in interventional radiology, which was traditionally dominated by men. However, women traditionally take care of the family and children, which in fact means two full-time jobs, housewife and radiologist. Only about 30% of the chief positions in radiology departments in eastern European countries and 30% of professorships are held by women. The causes of this problem differ between the Western and Eastern countries. Although in theory, national law regulations support family, in practice pre-school children care facilities are insufficient due to a limited budget. In most of the eastern European countries, public health-care systems and young physicians do not benefit from the growing economy. The traditional hierarchic structure of hospital departments and the limitations in the number of positions available for training delay financial autonomy. This may sometimes result in their emigration to western Europe. Learning Objectives:To provide information about the number of women radiologist in Eastern Europe, their present status and achievements, changes during last 20 years and future perspectives. 2. To present the working environment: Organisation of national radiology services, structure of radiology departments, legislation, financial conditions. 3. To explore relationship between work and family life from radiology training to retirement. 4. To highlight the main differences between Eastern and Western Europe.

Diffusion magnetic resonance (MR) imaging techniques have attracted much attention in the past decade, providing information not available from conventional MR imaging sequences. They monitor, in vivo, random microscopic motion of water protons. Diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) is the simplest form of diffusion imaging. It allows tissue characterization at a sub-millimetric level. Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) is an evolution of this technique. It is a quantitative method based on diffusion anisotropy that allows further assessment of tissue microstructure. Microstructural parameters, such as fractional anisotropy (FA) and apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC), can be calculated with these techniques. MR tractography is a rendering method that allows 3-D visualization of anisotropic structures. These techniques have encountered a growing interest in the evaluation of musculoskeletal disorders. Promising applications are the evaluation of bone marrow cellularity, bone and soft tissue tumors, muscular disorders, cartilage imaging, and peripheral and spinal nerves lesions. Technical requirements are a limitation to the widespread use of these techniques, but recent advances in hardware and imaging techniques offer encouraging perspectives. Learning Objectives:1. To understand the basic principles of diffusion imaging. 2. To discuss the potential applications of these techniques in musculoskeletal diseases.

Ultrasound contrast media were introduced in mid-1990s. Based on cancellation and separation of linear ultrasound signals from tissue, they enabled better outlining of cavities, better contrast resolution between normal and abnormal tissues, enhancement of Doppler signals as well as tissue characterisation. Ultrasound contrast agents are microbubbles consisting of gas bubbles stabilised by a shell. Their diameter is smaller than 8 μm causing no embolisation of capillaries. The interface between the bubble and the aqueous medium acts as the reflector of US beam enhancing blood echogenicity and increasing contrast between the blood and surrounding tissues. The intensity of the reflected signal depends on the concentration of microbubbles and the frequency of the ultrasound beam. Different available contrast media present various resistance to acoustic pressure. Older agents having low resistance to acoustic pressure require high mechanical index technique (MI) giving short-lasting enhancement due to microbubble disruption. The agents of second generation, commercially available nowadays, have high resistance to acoustic pressure and high stability, enabling long-lasting enhancement of 3 to 8 min. These agents at very low sound pressures (low MI 0.3) present rhythmic changes of the diameter of the microbubbles (oscillation). Ultrasound contrast agents of second generation dissolve in the blood, being pure blood pool agents. They do not extravasate in the interstitial space. Microbubbles cross the pulmonary barrier and therefore are present in the arterial vascularisation. They are eliminated via the pulmonary route, and only negligible traces can be found in urine. The mean terminal half-life is 12 min, 98% is exhaled within 2 min whereas 100% within 15 min. Digital breast tomosynthesis (DBT) addresses the mammographic problems of dense fibroglandular tissue and superposition. The X-ray tube of the modified digital mammography system moves in a 40° arc above the stationary detector. While the breast is held in compression in the mediolateral oblique view, the system obtains 15 low dose projection images at slightly different angles in about 15 seconds. The total radiation dose is equal to or less than that of a two-view screen-film mammogram. A set of slice images for the entire thickness of the breast in the plane parallel to the detector is generated using a tomographic reconstruction algorithm. In the case of focal changes, differentiation from focal liver lesions, e.g. metastases or hepatocellular carcinomas, is required, and in the case of diffuse changes the level of vascular obstruction (pre-or post-sinusoidal, gross hepatic veins) has to be evaluated. They usually present as wedge-shaped areas with fatty changes of the liver parenchyma and with signs of hyperperfusion. Other causes of THAD include changes in hepatic perfusion caused by extrinsic compression (e.g. by ribs), arterio-portal shunting due to liver cirrhosis or as a complication of invasive procedures (e.g. liver biopsy). Changes in hepatic perfusion and venous outflow can be related to typical parenchymal pattern, which differentiates depending on whether there is pre-sinusoidal blood flow impairment (e.g. nodular regenerative hyperplasia, NRH), sinusoidal dilatation or peliosis, post-sinusoidal obstruction (veno-occlusive disease) or acute or chronic obstruction of the hepatic veins (Budd-Chiari syndrome). As a result of vascular disorders, lobar or segmental hyperplasia or atrophy can be found, e.g. segmental hyperplasia of the caudated lobe in case of Budd-Chiari syndrome resulting from aberrant venous drainage. Lobar or segmental atrophy can be related to either vascular causes, e.g. liver infarction after arterial occlusion, or non-vascular causes, e.g. atrophy due to segmental bile duct obstruction. In this session, basic extraspinal interventional procedures are defined as rapid procedures that use a needle for aspiration, injection of fluids or biopsy. The procedures are commonly guided with the use of different imaging modalities. Both fluoroscopy and ultrasound are cheap and the needle can be visualized in real-time. CT-guidance is more expensive and might be more time consuming than fluoroscopy, but gives more information of the trajectory and the nature of the target. Today, CT-guidance could be facilitated with use of needle tandem technique, plastic grids, external and internal needle holders and CT-fluoroscopy. US-and MR-guidance will not be covered in this presentation. The most common basic procedures are injections of corticosteroids or contrast agents (arthrograms) into joints. Different techniques and approaches will be described. Less common are treatment of calcifying tendinitis, tenographies and therapeutic nerve injections to the pelvic and suprascapular region. Indications and approaches for musculoskeletal biopsy, different biopsy needles and techniques will be shown. A biopsy obtained from the soft part or the area with the most aggressive appearances is often favourable. Important for a successful biopsy is the specimen handling. The understanding of the clinician's request and knowledge of what the pathologist has to do with the specimen facilitate the decision whether the specimen should be sent fresh, in formalin or frozen. Most diagnostics can today be performed on formalin-fixed material, however, the increased demand for banking of specimens and some specific analyses favour fresh and/or frozen material. Ultrasound (US) is an excellent modality for guiding interventional procedures in the musculoskeletal system. This lecture will discuss the indications, the rationale and the techniques used to carry out the most commonly performed interventional procedures guided by US in the musculoskeletal system. Among the technical points, we will focus on target identification, puncture point location and tricks of the trade for aspiration and injection. Then, common US-guided procedures including arthrocentesis and drainage of soft-tissue collections, steroid injection in joint cavities, paraarticular bursae and tendon sheaths, tumor biopsies, removal of foreign bodies, dry needling and autologous blood injection in tendinopathies, regional anesthesia and percutaneous treatment of calcifying tendinitis and painful neuromas will be discussed with regard to individual sites of the upper and the lower extremity. With appropriate preparation and attention to sterility, US-guided procedures have a relatively low complication profile. lung disease secondary to exposure to certain drugs or those occurring in the context of a collagen vascular disease). Secondly, there is the large and important group of idiopathic interstitial pneumonias. Thirdly, there are the granulomatous diseases and finally a group of miscellaneous, but nonetheless interesting, DILDs, which include histiocytosis of the Langerhans cell and lymphangioleiomyomatosis.In patients with established diffuse lung disease, HRCT not only improves the detection and characterisation of parenchymal abnormalities, but also increases the accuracy of diagnosis. Ground-glass opacification, reticulation, traction bronchiectasis/bronchiolectasis and the irregular interfaces along pleural surfaces and bronchovascular structures are all better appreciated on HRCT. An important caveat is that in patients with nodular infiltrates, HRCT appearances may mislead; on thin section images, the dimensions of nodules and pulmonary vessels may be comparable making the distinction difficult. Thankfully, the spectrum of CT features, which denote interstitial lung disease is relatively limited and manageable. The typical signs of interstitial pathology include a reticular pattern (with or without traction bronchiectasis), thickening of interlobular septa, honeycombing, nodules and ground-glass opacification. This presentation will dicuss the HRCT features of the commonly occurring and important DILDs. The common most surgical procedures of the ear are mastoidectomy, tympanoplasty and ossiculoplasty. Landmarks for mastoid surgery are the sigmoid sinus, the dura of the middle and posterior cranial fossa, the posterior wall of the outer ear canal, the antrum mastoideum and the short process of the incus. The following mastoid air cells should be identified: Periantral cells, tegmental cells, sinodural cells, perisinusal cells, central mastoid cells, apical cells, perifacial cells and zygomatic cells. For all the mastoidectomy and tympanoplasty procedures the course of the facial nerve as well the position of the ossicular chain has to be identified. For cochlea implantation the following nerves should be identified within the internal audidory meatus: Cochlear nerve, inferior and superior vestibular nerve and facial nerve. Furthermore location of the promontorial bone and of the round window should be known preoperatively. Fibrosis and/or ossification of the scala tympani and scala vestibuli should be identified before electrode insertion procedures. Today, state-of-the-art imaging of the inner ear should include (sub)millimetric Gd-enhanced T1-weighted images and at least 0.5 x 0.5 x 0.5 mm T2-weighted 3D-GE or 3D-TSE images. On these images, the four nerves inside the internal auditory canal (IAC) can be distinguished and very small anatomic structures inside the labyrinth can be seen. This high resolution is mandatory to detect subtle pathology in patients with congenital sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL). In these patients, one looks for small malformations inside the membranous labyrinth or for aplasia-dysplasia of the nerves in the cerebellopontine angle (CPA) or IAC. Nevertheless, imaging will remain normal in many patients with congenital SNHL, as the intracochlear malformations are often too small to be detected by MR. The most frequent non-neoplastic causes of SNHL is "labyrinthitis". There are, however, many causes of labyrinthitis and they can also be acute, sub-acute or chronic. Many other non-neoplastic causes of SNHL exist and most often cause enhancement of the IAC and/or labyrinth. The list is long and an overview of this pathology will be given. Many benign and malignant tumors can involve the inner ear and cause SNHL. Schwannomas are by far the most frequent tumors and these will be discussed in more detail. Meningiomas, metastases, lymphomas, etc. can also involve the inner ear and are often difficult to differentiate. Finally, the auditory pathways must be imaged in patients with SNHL, as the cause of deafness can also be located along these structures. Diagnostic X-ray radiation can cause modifications in single cells such as genetic changes leading to malignancy. These effects are termed as stochastic effects. It is assumed that stochastic effects do not exhibit a dose threshold. Carcinogenesis and hereditary effects are considered to be stochastic. To determine radiation detriment, national and international radiation protection organizations and committees have published risk coefficients. Strategies for dose optimisation are needed for X-ray modalities such as multi-slice CT. At high doses of ionizing radiation such as in fluoroscopically guided interventional procedures with very long screening time, there is also a possibility of cell killing sufficient to result in detectable consequences in certain tissues of patients, for example, skin erythema. These effects are known as deterministic effects. Dose responses for deterministic effects are judged to have dose threshold. Recent studies have shown that the eye lens may be more sensitive to radiation than previously considered. There are several ethical issues associated with exposure to diagnostic X-rays and radiation protection. These issues are mainly associated with the level of medical personnel's knowledge about patients' exposure doses from X-ray examinations. Reported experience has shown that nontrivial proportions of physicians fail to answer questions related to radiation dose levels from various radiological investigations. Another concern is that medical doctors unaware of the doses involved in X-ray examinations are not in a position to explain the radiation risks to patients. Justification of medical exposures and optimisation of protection can only be achieved with higher dose awareness and training of medical personnel. Session Objectives: 1. To elucidate the concept of radiation risk for high and low doses. 2. To become familiar with risk coefficients for stochastic effects proposed by radiation protection organisations. 3. To discuss ethical issues associated with exposure to diagnostic X-rays and radiation protection.

back_matter.text: Does the ever increasing exposure of patients in diagnostic radiology really pose a problem? G. Brix; Neuherberg/DE (GBrix@bfs.de)Man-made radiation exposure to populations in industrialized countries predominantly results from diagnostic and interventional X-ray procedures. In Germany, for example, the average effective dose per inhabitant and year has been increased from 1.6 to 1.8 mSv between 1996 and 2004. The increase is mainly caused by CT examinations, the number of which increases by 7% per year. In the year 2004, CT scans accounted for 7% of all X-ray examinations but for 54% of the resultant collective effective dose. Even higher numbers are reported for Japan and the USA. These facts imply, of course, the question whether the increasing radiation exposure of patients poses a problem. Risk-benefit analyses depend on a variety of factors, such as the exposed body region, the radiation dose, the age of the patient, the kind of disease, the life expectancy of the patient, and the benefit resulting from the imaging procedures performed. Due to this complexity, the question raised above has to be answered separately for different groups of persons undergoing X-ray examinations. To make this clear, two different situations will be discussed in the lecture: (i) X-ray examinations of cancer patients and (ii) CT screening scans of asymptomatic persons. In the case of severely ill cancer patients even relatively high exposure levels are most likely justified, whereas CT "manager check-ups" pose a serious problem from a radiation hygienic point of view; at present, there is no scientific evidence that the benefit of these examinations outweighs the radiation risks.Learning Objectives: 1. To consolidate knowledge of factors determining radiation risks of patients undergoing X-ray procedures. 2. To become familiar with radiation exposure of seriously ill patients, in particular cancer patients.3. To understand the necessity to focus risk assessment on the group of persons really exposed and not to use an average effective dose per inhabitant.

Appropriate use of a modality with high diagnostic accuracy and high radiation exposure: Multidetector CT J.R. Mayo; Vancouver, BC/CA (jmayo@vanhosp.bc.ca)Multiple studies have shown that CT accounted for greater than 60% of the medical radiation exposure early in this decade (2003) . CT radiation exposure has undoubtedly further increased with new high-dose applications (e.g. cardiac CT). Surveys have shown substantial variation in radiation dose between institutions due to differences in parameter specification by supervising radiologists. Wide variation in the indication for initial examinations and the technique and frequency of follow-up examinations has also been documented. We hypothesize that education will be a powerful tool to reduce CT radiation dose. In this talk, we will provide attendees with practice tools to monitor current levels of CT radiation dose, to compare administered dose to reference dose levels for specific examinations, to effectively utilize dose reduction techniques, and to educate referring clinicians about the most at risk populations for CT radiation dose effects. Finally, limitations in our current knowledge regarding the relationship between CT radiation dose and the outcome parameters of image quality, diagnostic accuracy, and diagnostic confidence will be discussed.Learning Objectives: 1. To give an overview of the diagnostic power of MDCT. 2. To become familiar with radiation dose reduction strategies in MDCT.3. To understand the relationship between diagnostic accuracy and radiation exposure in CT.

Radiation protection, ethics, law and public awareness: In harmony or out of tune?The ethical basis for many medical practices is being challenged. This is most evident in controversial areas, e.g., the scandals on infant organ retention or sourcing and use of blood products. This lecture examines new thinking on ethics in medicine and its consequences for how we practice radiation protection. Representative questions were examined as part a major European Project, SENTINEL. Within this, a series of studies on ethics and justification were undertaken. In addition, a multidisciplinary workshop, involving radiologists, physicists, philosophers, theologians, social scientists, journalists and parliamentarians, was organized. Significant deficits were identified in the ethical and legal framework for radiation protection. It appears out of tune with the views on the individual and society that generally prevail today. This will be illustrated by discussing the roles of paternalism and individual autonomy in the radiation protection system as it is now, and as it was in the 1950s and 1960s. Further, the impact of either approach on issues such as justification, the pregnant patient and patient consent is assessed. We need to become familiar with developments in philosophy and the social sciences and to examine their impact on the theoretical, legal and practical aspects of radiation protection in diagnostic radiology. Learning Objectives: 1. To become familiar with ethical and/or legal issues related to the use of diagnostic X-rays. The management of unruptured aneurysms remains challenging. Guidelines on the aneurysms that have to be treated and those that have to be observed do not exist. Similarily, the choice of treatment (i.e. endovascular versus surgical) is still a matter of debate. Although coils are less invasive, clips may procure more stable results over time. Since the materials used for endovascular procedures have improved (and are still improving), the time of follow-up observation naturally remains limited. Standards of practice during endovascular treatments (like anticoagulation and antiaggregation management) have not been agreed upon. This lecture will therefore raise more questions than it will provide answers, demonstrating the need for evidence-based data that may only be derived from large muti-center studies.Learning Objectives:1. To learn about the incidence, clinical manifestations and imaging findings in patients with non-ruptured intracranial aneurysms. 2. To discuss the risk for rupture of incidentally found intracranial aneurysms. 3 . To learn about reliable imaging predictors of aneurysm rupture. 4. To illustrate the most cost-effective decision strategy for the management of non-ruptured intracranial aneurysms.

B. Intracranial stenting I. Szikora; Budapest/HU (h13424szi@helka.iif.hu)With the newest developments in medical industry, stent technology has recently become available for the treatment of intracranial vascular disease. At present, stent implantation is applied in the endovascular treatment of aneurysms and angioplasty of atherosclerotic arterial stenosis. For aneurysms, self-expandable stents deployed across the aneurysm neck are used to: a) make intrasaccular packing feasible or support tighter packing by holding the packing material within the sac, b) improve long-term results by promoting endothelial growth over the aneurysm orifice and c) more recently, high mesh density stent-like embolization devices became available, that are capable of inducing aneurysm thrombosis without intrasaccular packing by significantly reducing flow across the orifice. Published results demonstrate that recanalization of originally completely occluded aneurysms can be reduced to 4.3% and progressive thrombosis in originally incompletely occluded lesions can be achieved in 14% of the cases. For intracranial atherosclerotic disease, both self and balloon expandable stents are used: a) to decrease the incidence of procedural complications by avoiding arterial dissection and b) to improve the long-term results by reducing the incidence of restenosis. Recent studies demonstrate that the complication rate associated with intracranial angioplasty has been reduced from 15 to 3%, and the significant restenosis rate from 18 to 14% by the application of stents. At present, intracranial stent implantation is an important adjunctive technique in the treatment of aneurysms and an inherent part of the treatment of intracranial atherosclerotic disease. Most patients with critical ischemia undergo imaging with a view to interventional treatment, either endovascular or surgical. Imaging studies should be used to influence the choice and nature of the intervention, minimise risks and inconvenience to the patient and make the best use of limited resources. Duplex is widely available and established in most vascular units. It is comparatively cheap, portable and, although operator-dependant, highly accurate in the vast majority of patients with sensitivities and specificity of 82-95% for stenosis 50, 90-95 and 96-97% for occlusions, particularly when using modern scanners with power Doppler and sono-CT. Confidence can be increased with the use of contrast agents. It seems sensible therefore to start investigation of these patient with duplex as the simplest and safest modality. In some cases, it will be the ideal choice where there is contrast allergy, renal dysfunction or claustrophobia. Although other imaging modalities may be more accurate and give more information, in many cases this has little effect on patient management and in only a small proportion additional imaging is required.No difference between duplex and intra-arterial angiography was found on direct comparison of patient outcomes. Having picked up significant disease, duplex can guide intervention in areas of localised disease. It can then also be used to assess the immediate outcome and also for postprocedure surveillance. Current vascular imaging techniques should be seen as complementary, with duplex as the starting point and other imaging used for problem solving. Magnetic resonance angiography has become a vital tool in the evaluation of critical limb ischaemia. Both non-contrast and contrast-enhanced techniques can be used, although CE-MRA is superior in most instances due to its higher spatial resolution, unrivalled SNR and freedom from artefacts. CE-MRA can be employed as a study targeted on a single field-of-view (e.g. the calf and pedal arteries), as a multi-station MRA (using a moving table approach) and can benefit from dynamic assessment of the arteries using either a 2D (MR-DSA) or 3D (TRICKS) approach.A B C D E F G Blood pool agent imaging allows exquisite sub-millimetre resolution without the need for bolus timing, but its role as yet remains unclear. The disadvantage of venous contamination can be overcome by sophisticated reformatting techniques, which are as yet not widely available. In order to optimize image quality, careful attention must be given to positioning of the feet, use and optimal placement of a surface coil, scan parameter selection, parallel imaging factors and contrast agent selection. If multi-station evaluation of the peripheral vasculature is desired, careful tailoring of acquisition time is essential to ensure absence of venous enhancement. Tourniquet compression of the thighs using inflation values between arterial and venous pressures (e.g. ~60 mmHg) eliminates venous enhancement in most patients. Extreme caution must be exercised in patients with renal impairment and a non-contrast technique may suffice in such instances. Traditional time-of-flight MRA using the head-coil is of proven efficacy in such instances, and newer noncontrast techniques such as fresh-blood-imaging and contrast-inflow-angiography may also be useful. Abdominal trauma is common in children and accounts for significant morbidity and mortality. Children may be injured during motor vehicle crashes, pedestrian accidents, falls while playing or because of physical abuse. The spleen is the most frequently injured intraabdominal organ, followed by the liver, intestine and pancreas. The management of abdominal trauma in children has changed over the past decade due to advances in imaging techniques and a more conservative treatment approach. Optimal evaluation of the injured child may require the use of multiple diagnostic modalities. Focused abdominal sonography for trauma (FAST) is indicated as a screening method for abdominal injuries in children, but FAST revealed limitations in identifying specific organ injuries, especially when free fluid was absent. Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen can depict abdominal injuries accurately, but requires patient transport, injection of contrast material and significant radiation exposure. Multidetector-row spiral computed tomography (MDCT) is excellent for imaging trauma patients, but should not be performed routinely in children. Appropriate low-dose MDCT protocols are available, which minimize radiation exposure and still allow reliable identification of typical injury patterns in pediatric abdominal trauma. Evaluating a child who sustained abdominal injury is daily practice in a department of pediatric radiology. Blunt abdominal trauma is much more frequent than a penetrating one. Various mechanisms may be involved, but discrepancy between deceleration and the grade of renal trauma can be encountered in children. Minor trauma can induce a severe renal fracture especially in cases of underlying kidney/urinary tract malformation or tumor. The most severe lesions are usually observed following motor vehicle accidents, pedestrian crashes or sport injuries. On the other hand, minor traumatisms represent the most frequent situation and include fall while playing in toddlers, and bathroom accidents in neonates and young children. The inflicted injury should be remembered as the potential cause. In this lecture, emphasis will be placed on the pediatric particularities of renal injuries and the different possible imaging strategies. Renal trauma cannot be individualized from associated lesions with regard to imaging strategy, which mainly depends on the local organization, available equipment and staff. In the majority of trauma patients, management is nonoperative, and noninterventional. This trend naturally impacts on imaging strategy. Initial MDCT coupled with follow-up sonographies is the imaging method of choice, but US can be sufficient in many cases, especially when a high standard examination is absolutely normal. IV urography should no longer be employed. Rarely, angiography can be used to take care of children with intractable bleeding e.g. in cases of traumatic arterio-venous fistulas. Evaluation of posttraumatic renal sequelae can be performed by DMSA scintigraphy or MR urography. Limping is a common presenting symptom in children and adolescents. Depending on the age group, the differential diagnosis includes various traumatic, inflammatory, infectious, developmental, congenital and neoplastic conditions involving the lower extremities, pelvis or spine. The diagnostic challenge is to differentiate trivial conditions, such as a foreign body in the child's shoe, from more severe causes requiring urgent medical attention. Based on a detailed history and thorough physical examination, appropriate laboratory testing and imaging evaluation may reveal the underlying cause and help to initiate proper treatment. Imaging studies attempt to define the pathology as well as exclude conditions with significant long-term sequelae. Radiography is usually the initial examination used as screening for fractures and other bone lesions. However, a normal radiograph does not exclude significant inflammatory, infectious or neoplastic disease. Ultrasound is useful for assessing joint effusion, subperiostal abscess and soft tissue pathology. Sonographic guidance facilitates diagnostic aspiration of an abscess or joint effusion. Bone scintigraphy or whole-body STIR magnetic resonance imaging is sensitive for localizing and detecting occult bone lesions, osteomyelitis, spondylodiscitis and neoplasm. Dedicated magnetic resonance imaging with different sequences and dynamic scanning following intravenous contrast administration allow comprehensive evaluation of the bones and marrow, joints, soft tissues and spinal canal. Computed tomography may be helpful to diagnose bone tumours and anomalies like tarsal coalition and can serve as guidance for percutaneous bone biopsy. The Western-European community faces a considerable challenge, as the increasing number of ageing people requires medical services. By 2020, persons over 65 years will make up more than 20% of the total population compared to 15% in the mid-1990s. A Norwegian health research centre has calculated that we need to expand the number of somatic hospital beds by 15-25% within 2025 if we continue our current practice of hospitalizing geriatric patients. We therefore need to organize a more flexible health care system, utilize new technologies and find new ways of servicing geriatric patients in their own environments to deal with increasing incidence of some diseases. In our nursing homes, patients have an average of 3.4 chronic diseases and 70% suffer dementia. The number of patient beds exceeded by three times in our nursing homes those compared with somatic hospitals, and these patients have the same requirements and rights to palliative treatments and functional improvements as the rest of the society. The increased number of elderly in society will also contribute to significantly more citizens with cancer, stroke, and dementia a.o. It is predicted that cancer alone may choke hospital capacity. The medical community may have to distribute their technologies and competence in new ways to cope with upcoming demands from society.

Mobile, digital X-ray services for nursing homes J.C. Hellund; Oslo/NO (JohanCastberg.Hellund@ulleval.no)The population of elderly in nursing homes (NH) is increasing. In autumn 2004, mobile X-ray service was implemented in Oslo, Norway, for diagnostic X-ray in NH. A simple X-ray unit equipped with a digital detector is transported to NH on demand, using a wheel-chair ramp equipped with a car. Examinations are performed in the residents' room. Images are brought by USB-disk to the radiology department for interpretation and reporting. Image quality, assessed by VAS scale, was not significantly different from controls taken with a fixed X-ray unit. A resolution of 3.2 lp/mm and exposure deviation from nominal of 0.12% was found. A survey revealed that tentative diagnosis verified in 58%, invalidated in 42%, with consequences to therapy in 85% and nursing in 71%. About 10% had no alternative to the service; 8% had to be hospitalised following the examination. Expensive and exhausting patient transportation with ambulance or taxi, or hospitalisation, were avoided in 90% of cases. Distribution of examinations includes chest 16%, extremities 32%, pelvis/hip 45% and spine 7%. Panorama of findings is found to be normal 18%, osteoarthritis 24%, prosthesis control/old fracture 28%, prosthesis failure 3%, pneumonia 3%, heart failure 8%, fracture 12% and others 4%. The use of the service is increasing, with 2,000 examinations in 1,700 examined patients since the outset. Digital technology can improve health services to the elderly population. A mobile radiological service gives less distress for the patients, reduces expenses to transport/staff and increases diagnostic accuracy in the NH. Image quality is found adequate. Ageing is a key risk factor for cancer, and the proportion of elderly in the population is increasing steadily. This clearly shows that there will be a greater incidence of cancer and increasing number of elderly cancer patients. The likelihood of developing cancer during one´s lifetime is approximately one in two for men and one in three for women. The impact of future cancer burden on the population is estimated on the basis of the growing and ageing population to more than double from the year 2000 to the year 2050. For a person of 45 years of age, the risk of developing cancer during the next 10 years is 1 in 24 (1 in 26 for men and 1 in 22 for women). One in six persons, aged 65, will be diagnosed with cancer by age 75 (one in five for men and one in eight for women). There is an increasing incidence of cancer in the geriatric population. In the year 2000, 55% of all cancers occurred in persons of 65 years and older. This will increase to 70% in the year 2050. This increase is mostly due to the change in incidence in those over 85 years of age. This group accounted for 8% of all cancers in the year 2000 and this is expected to increase to 17% in the year 2050. In both males and females, the incidence of cancer of the colon and rectum in 85+ will double during this period. In women, the incidence of breast cancer will increase 2.5 times, whereas in men the incidence of prostate cancer will triple. Different imaging tests play a pivotal role for the detection of these cancers. However, the frail elderly will often have complex care needs, unrelated to their cancer. The burden of stroke in developed countries is high and is possibly to increase in future decades as a result of the aging population. Acute stroke is a major cause of death and long-term disability worldwide. New approaches to stroke treatment or management, such as stroke unit care or treatment of ischaemic stroke with alteplase, improve the outcomes of stroke patients. However, these approaches are used most commonly at academic centres, although stroke care is often delivered at local community hospitals without specialised stroke care. Acute stroke care is time critical issue and needs supervision of experienced strokologists. However, especially in rural areas, economic requirements make it impossible to employ these specialists in every hospital. The establishment of telemedical networks for a close cooperation between stroke centres and community hospitals is a suggested way to improve effectiveness of acute stroke care at local community level. The Telemedic Pilot Project for Integrative Stroke Care (TEMPiS) network is a cooperation of two academic hospitals specialised in stroke care with 15 community hospitals in rural areas of Bavaria, Germany. The stroke centres provide a 24-h teleconsultation service via a high-speed videoconference system to examine patients and to transfer teleradiological data of CT and MRI examinations. Furthermore, the network hospitals formed stroke teams and a continuous medical training in acute stroke care. Research outcomes of the network revealed a significantly reduced proportion of stroke patients with poor outcomes (death, institutional care or disability) after 3 months and after 1 year. On the basis of standards of the World Federation for Medical Education (WFME) undergraduate curricula for medical students are currently subject to a reform process towards problem-based and integrated forms of learning. Digital radiological equipment and PACS have been widely installed and teaching in radiology needs to adapt and embrace these rapidly developing technical advances. The number of articles published in this field is exponentially increasing. Undergraduate education should be steered by defining three core competencies: in vivo visualisation of normal and abnormal morphology and function, diagnostic reasoning, and interventional treatment. With these objectives adequate teaching methods and e-learning should be implemented by focussing on case-based teaching. E-learning is emerging as an important tool to maintain the position of radiology against other disciplines in using image materials for teaching purposes. The radiologist as a teacher is changing his role from a traditional lecturer to a mentor who guides his students in making medical decisions. Along with these changes certain aspects of our discipline have to be prioritized: (1) The professional use of referral criteria and pretest probabilities of diagnostic tests, (2) a systematic film reading to teach "living anatomy and pathology" with multimodal techniques, and (3) radiation protection embedded in a broader concept of quality management. Synergies should be used to develop strategies for efficient training with limited resource allocation. Today, the radiology community is in an ideal position to maximize the potential benefits of technological advances to become the backbone within undergraduate curricula similar to its position in clinical medicine. Learning objectives are not only intended to motivate students but serve even more importantly as efficient steering instruments for coordinating all activities in teaching, learning and examining. The allocation of personnel, lecture rooms and other teaching resources are strongly related to the scope of the content and the competency level of a task to be accomplished. The definition of a learning objective needs some time with a step-by-step process to describe all relevant features. For matching and fine tuning of the various elements of a curriculum, learning objectives should be embedded in a broader concept of general and outcome-oriented aims and goals. A framework, or blueprint, that is generated in this way is a transparent system for both teachers and students to support them in tailoring their specific expectations and needs. For the imaging sciences, only a few catalogues of learning objectives in undergraduate student training have been published so far. Current developments include a shift away from basic physics and investigation techniques towards a clinically oriented "diagnostic reasoning" with the effect that diagnostic radiology and nuclear medicine will follow converging interests. Bridging the various aspects of these disciplines may be accomplished by using specific techniques of integrating basic knowledge into diagnostic skills training (transitional learning). Thus, the behaviorist access is put behind cognitive and constructivist learning theories. Resource planning models have to be developed, because case-based teaching in small groups is gradually replacing traditional plenary lectures and the importance of electronic teaching file collections and e-learning will be strengthened. Radiologists in a Medical School faculty have many responsibilities, of which mentoring of residents is one of the principal tasks. However, the future of radiology depends on the quality of the students who are attracted to the field, and on the general opinion of current medical students on radiologists as medical professional. The mentoring of students is therefore a very important responsibility. That is why involvement of Radiology faculty in the undergraduate curriculum is an opportunity that needs to be explored in great detail. Items that can be considered are the opportunity to provide students with the opportunity for clinical rotations on a one-to-one basis, research collaboration, and attending clinical-radiological conferences. Furthermore by close mentoring the A-level students are easily detected and can be guided into the field of radiology. The hidden curriculum of radiology, concerning communication, professionalism, ethics and multidisciplinary approach also cannot be learned from textbooks, but are easily illustrated with a close mentoring programme. Since Röntgen discovered the "X-rays", undergraduate radiology teaching to medical students was mainly performed by ex-cathedra lessons, projection of analogue radiographs in auditoria and occasionally direct radiologist-to-student teaching in the radiological department during reporting. Later on, plain film radiographs and CT-or MRI scan films have been used during many years in teaching files for undergraduate radiological education. Nowadays, computer, internet and PACS are new tools that can be used as new teaching instruments. Personal computers can be used for local or internet-based e-learning, by providing different types of self-teaching, usually with immediate positive or negative feedback on the given responses. On the web, many sites provide teaching files for radiological anatomy that can be used in undergraduate teaching. Other sites provide radiology of diseases, but often the level is too high for undergraduate students. Dedicated e-learning and e-testing systems can be used for improving the interpretation skills, learning what to order when, and creating interest of students for radiology. CD-roms of patient examinations, PACS and web-based pacs viewing of selected cases can be used for self-teaching by the students, also allowing them to learn how to work with these new tools. In this lecture, our 7-year experience with undergraduate radiological education to more than 5,000 students using these new techniques will be illustrated. Also the requirements for examining large groups of students will be discussed. Congenital heart diseases are structural or functional circulation system anomalies, which provide clinical symptoms at birth or in other life periods. The main categories of congenital heart diseases include diseases with left-to-right shunts, with prevailing right-to-left shunts, stenoses, hypoplasia of the valves or ventricles, anomalies of great vessels, position anomalies or other congenital syndromes. Another division includes cyanotic and non-cyanotic heart diseases. About 80% of all congenital heart diseases include ASD, VSD, PDA, AS, PS, CoA, ToF and TGA. While these diseases can be diagnosed with ultrasound, there is a need for confirmation of some, mainly complex heart diseases by imaging methods. Precise determination of the type and number of defects is a condition for proper surgical treatment and improves the prognosis considerably. Simple septum defects (ASD, VSD) do not require a confirmation. Other defects, including complex ones, require the choice of an adequate method. Indications for MSCT or MRI should be considered with respect to patient's age (neonate, child, adult), defect type and complexity. X-ray doses and quantity of contrast media are of significant values in MSCT, while contrast media nephrotoxicity, examination time (long anesthesia in neonates and children) and resolution are significant in MRI. Indications for both methods including the above-mentioned factors will be discussed. US is widely available and inexpensive, but depends on acoustic windows and has a substantial interobserver variability. MR, on the other hand, allows unrestricted imaging in any plane. Thus, US is not ideal because of interstudy variability and because it depends on assumptions and geometric models, which can be misleading in cardiomyopathies with distorted ventricular shape. Therefore, MR is the gold standard for volume and mass measurements. CT is also a precise tool for mass and volume measurements, but radiation exposure is unsatifactory, particularly when repeated measurements are required. Typically used MR sequences are T1-weighted turbo-spin-echo for assessment of morphology with high detail and to detect fatty infiltration of the right ventricular myocardium in ARVC.
