Ultrasound and MR are strong and complementary tools for the management of cardiomyopathies; CT plays only a minor role. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and computed tomography (CT) are useful noninvasive methods for evaluating pericardial disease. They are well-suited modalities offering excellent resolution and delineation of the pericardial anatomy and characterisation of various pericardial lesions including effusion, constrictive pericarditis, and pericardial masses. Imaging of the pericardium and pericardial disease with CT and MRI is dealing with advantages and disadvantages compared with each other and with echocardiography. However, CT and MRI are particularly sensitive for evaluating acute, chronic, and congenital disorders like partial or complete absence of the pericardium. MRI is particularly useful when ultrasound imaging does not provide adequate diagnostic information or requires further characterisation. For example, in ‚'non-echoic'' patients, thickening of the pericardial layers and pericardial tumors are usually better evaluated with MRI. CT has the advantage of detecting pericardial calcifications, a finding that is indicative of constrictive pericarditis in patients with adequate pathophysiologic features. Furthermore, CT allows with the same examination the assessment of the coronary arteries. Both modalities provide a large field of view compared with echocardiography. This allows examination of the entire chest and detection of associated pathologies in the mediastinum and lungs. Bearing in mind the wide variety of tumors and pericardial diseases evaluated with CT and MRI, radiologists should be familiar with the imaging features of these diseases and selection of the appropriate modality. PET is a major advance in molecular imaging. Coincidence imaging enhances its sensitivity, while the uptake of metabolic or receptor binding tracers characterize the aggressiveness of the tumors. FDG PET is indicated for the evaluation of advanced breast cancer, for the staging of patients with large or distant initial disease, for the restaging of patients with loco-regional recurrence or metastases and for monitoring therapy. The resolution of PET does not allow detection of small tumor or micrometastatic nodes, making it unsuitable for screening and for defining the axillary status. PET is specific in detecting metastatic disease early-on, in patients with numerous involved lymph nodes, loco-regional recurrence or increasing tumor markers and in characterizing the extent of the disease. PET is also useful in evaluating response to therapy and subsequent prognosis. It predicts lack of pathologic response but cannot assess the extent of residual disease in responding patients. Progress will result from increased resolution and sensitivity. The availability of specialized detectors for positron emission mammography (PEM) should allow resolutions down to 1.5 mm. This should allow screening of most tumors with high SUV, but well-differentiated and lobular tumors have lower uptake and could still be missed. PEM appears to be capable of detecting multicentric tumors and the extent of DCIS, leading to a potential reduction in reintervention. Newer tracers are needed to enhance detection and provide biologic information on the tumor. F-thymidine for proliferation, F-miso for hypoxia, F-RGD for angiogenesis and FES for estrogen receptors have the potential to increase the role of PET in the future. Optical imaging, particularly in the near-infrared (NIR) range, is a highly sensitive method that provides decent tissue penetration in the breast. Besides tomographic methods such as diffuse optical tomography (DOT), surface weighted reflection techniques (fluorescence reflectance imaging, FRI) can be applied, e.g. for intraoperative surgical guidance (e.g. sentinel lymph node imaging). While intrinsic absorbers such as hemoglobin, fat and water have been imaged by non-enhanced DOT, the sensitivity and specificity of this method is limited. The introduction of fluorescence-enhanced optical imaging has significantly expanded the capabilities of this imaging method. Different contrasting strategies are currently being pursued, ranging from non-specific, perfusion type-to targeted-and 'smart'-fluorochromes. The basic feasibility of resolving fluorescent signals by DOT in a clinical setting has been shown. Experimental data on targeted and smart optical probes strongly suggest that the sensitivity and specificity of fluorescence-enhanced optical imaging can be clearly improved. Moreover, combined imaging methodologies such as MR/optical or opto-accustics may further push the limits of the inherent technological limitations. This talk will provide an overview of the current developments in optical imaging technologies tailored for breast cancer imaging. The major goal for breast cancer imaging in the next decade is more accurate disease characterization through the synthesis of anatomic, functional, and molecular imaging information. No consensus exists regarding the use of imaging for evaluating primary breast cancers. Besides other imaging methods, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has emerged as one of the major modalities for noninvasive functional imaging. Functional MRI will thus play a key role in the detection and characterization of breast tumors and in the assessment of treatment response. MRI produces already high-resolution three-dimensional images delineating morphological features of the breast. Functional MR images of breast tissues depend on endogenous differences in water content, metabolites and/or diffusion characteristics of the tissue of interest. By applying different MR methods, these endogenous differences can be measured and can help to increase the specificity of MRI of the breast. Amongst others these methods include: (a) imaging of hemodynamic parameters, including blood perfusion and vascular permeability with MMCE-MRI; (b) imaging of metabolites to assess the relative concentrations of chemical compounds like cholin and citrate with MR-spectroscopy; and (c) imaging of thermally random molecular displacement with diffusion-MRI. Each technique is promising but is hampered by one ore more limitations. Thus the fusion of all functional MR methods to one image is a challenging but promising way [called the fifth dimension (5D) of imaging] to achieve the goal. Endovascular stent grafts are fast replacing conventional surgery in treating diseases of the thoracic aorta, including thoracic aortic aneurysms (TAA). In the 16 years since the technique was first described, many advances have been made not only in the stent grafts themselves, but in the delivery sheaths used to deploy them. They have evolved from simple home-made devices into sophisticated commercial products. Pre-procedural imaging, mainly with multidetector CT, is crucial both in assessing the suitability for endovascular repair and in selecting the appropriate device. The standard technique for stenting in TAA will be described as well as how to deal with problems and late complications. The stents are introduced through a small femoral arteriotomy and their main advantage is the low initial morbidity and mortality compared with open surgery. However, the long-term durability of these devices is not fully known and follow-up is essential. Future directions include further advances in graft design allowing lower profile systems and wholly percutaneous access. Methods to treat arch aneurysms such as hybrid techniques and branched grafts will be discussed and illustrated with examples. Learning Objectives:1. To review patient selection and preprocedural imaging for endovascular treatment. Aortic dissection is one of the most serious and dramatically acute pathologies with a frequency ranging annually from 10 to 20 cases per million people. Dissection is generally secondary to degeneration of the collagen and elastin matrix within the aortic medial layer. The formation of a tear in the aortic intima allows pulsatile blood to enter and propagate into the aortic media. The blood-filled space between the dissected layers becomes the false lumen. Diagnosis is based on modern non-invasive imaging modalities, such as multidetector-row CT angiography. Medical therapy is considered the treatment of choice in case of uncomplicated type B dissection, while in the case of lower or visceral ischemia or renal failure, an immediate operative treatment is necessary. However, in those patients treated with a medical therapy, mortality rate remains greater than 20%, with a high incidence (14-20%) of aneurysms in the first 5 years. A 30-day mortality rate of 10% is reported for uncomplicated type B dissection, while in the case of complicated dissection, mortality rate becomes higher, 20% at 2 days and 25% at 30 days. In the last few years, the endovascular stent-graft therapy has progressed from the placement of home-made devices to the routine use of commercially manufactured endoprostheses, which are deployed within the true lumen across the primary entry tear for its complete obliteration. The initial results of these feasibility studies suggest that stent-grafts offer an attractive alternative to open surgical repair, since this treatment can potentially reduce operative risks, hospitalization times and procedural costs. The subjective interpretation of breast lesions with mammography, ultrasound, and MR-imaging is difficult to evaluate and therefore difficult to improve. Medical audit is the only way to measure breast imaging performance in a manner that includes both technical and interpretive capabilities of the system. The 'Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System' (BI-RADS TM ) is a quality assurance tool, designed to standardise breast imaging reporting, reduce confusion in breast imaging interpretations, and facilitate outcome monitoring. Through a medical audit and outcome monitoring, the system provides important peer review and quality assurance data to improve the quality of patient care. The BI-RADS TM is the product of a cooperative effort between members of various committees of the American College of Radiology. The BI-RADS TM was first introduced in 1992 in the USA and has become a widely accepted tool all over the world. However, there is a need for continuous teaching of the BI-RADS TM classification because it is intended for use in everyday practice and should make the issue of meaningful, unambiguous breast imaging reports possible. This BI-RADS TM session has been organised to provide participants with an introduction to the most important sections of this system, the breast imaging lexicon for mammography, ultrasound, and MR imaging. Besides the theoretical background, the participants will be trained and tested on how to apply the BI-RADS TM . The material will be presented in an interactive way with audience participation and self-assessment by use of an electronic voting system (keypads). At the end of the session, the participant with the most accurate answers will be awarded a prize and will have to defend his/her title at the ECR 2009. The ECR 2009 registration fees will be waived for the winner.Learning Objectives: 1. To know more about BI-RADS TM , particular about the breast imaging lexicon, the reporting system, and follow-up and outcome monitoring. 2. To know how to apply BI-RADS TM for mammography, ultrasound, and MR imaging. 3. To use BI-RADS TM in everyday practice and issue meaningful, unambiguous breast imaging reports.
